description:
What a pleasant surprise. A perfect French restaurant with a Basque flair

Calamari and charcuterie appetizer was marvelous. 

I have the seafood cioppino. My wife had the Duck confit. Our friends had the hanger steak and lamb. All exquisitely prepared. 

The owner, Jean Marie, is an impeccable host while the front of house staff is efficient and attentive.

The atmosphere is perfect. 

The food is exquisite!!
author: Kevin C.

description: This place is awesome. Great food, reasonably priced and good service. I will define the back!
author: Dave S.

description:
We came here for a 3 course lunch. Kicked off with a very delicious beef carpaccio. My main course was a super tender onglet steak a la Parisienne.

Nevertheless, the ultimate highlight was the dessert: the Hazelnut & roasted almond mousse cake. I would visit this place just to have this mouthwatering dessert again! 

Last but not least, loved their Aperol Spritz!
author: Stefani K.

description: We believe! We spent my wife's birthday here and truly enjoyed ourselves. I strongly suggest wine with every dish as it really enhances all of the flavors. I appreciated the Acme bread served with butter. We went with the 3 course option. I got the calamari, steak with frites, and the flourless chocolate cake. All of which were delicious. I highly recommend ordering the calamari. Don't be afraid to go with what the waiters recommendations on wines because they're spot on. I do recommend having a reservation. We went on a slow holiday night and it quickly became full. I could easily frequent this restaurant as the service and food were perfection! Our waitress even noticed that we were splitting everything so she switched our plates for us when it was about that time to switch....nice touch! We'll be back!
author: Guisela L.

description:
WOW such a hidden gem!! 
Due to construction on 4th st, the restaurant is a bit hard to discern. BUT, go seek it out and you won't regret! 
Truly AUTHENTIC French bistro fare. No frills, just super well executed classic French dishes
Think - Foie gras
Duck confit w/ lentils
Cock au Vin

ANNNNND French speaking French servers! Service is on point and they know they wines too :)

Only tiny pet peeve is the decor- the place has so much potential being a corner unit in a charming older building. however, the decor doesn't speak bistro- in fact, with the recessed lighting and almost neon colored bar, it made me feel confused about what the venue tries to convey
author: Chloe Z.

description:
Craving fresh seafood after some black friday shopping.
This place had nice ambience, great food and very friendly servers. Also close to Coin-Op for arcade games & drinks afterwards.

My faves were the Sautéed Prawns and Calamari appetizers. The prawn sauce was creamy and so so yummy...perfect for dipping our bread. I wish I could have just bought a jar of that sauce to take home.
author: Linda W.

description:
We came here for a group outing at work and my whole team enjoyed the experience. Pretty much everyone order the 3 course lunch for $35.

I started with the Cab Franc, which I really enjoyed. 

I got the butter lettuce salad and really enjoyed the bleu cheese. I was able to taste the beef carpaccio as well and that was DELICIOUS. I'd probably order that instead if I come again. 

I had the steak for the main course, which was cooked perfectly. They didn't have green beans and served with salad instead, which was fine. The fries were nicely done as well.

I had the cheese plate for dessert, which was quite good as well.

Overall I'd come back. Nice ambiance, well executed food and a good wine selection.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Charming and authentic French restaurant with quality seafood entrees! This is a great place for more upscale and fine dining in SOMA not too far from the Caltrain. Fringale is pretty appropriate for fancier and more romantic dates, as the setting is pretty intimate and cozy. Make reservations on OpenTable if you're coming on a weekend.

I've taken my family here a few times now and Fringale has always been a pretty memorable spot for us near downtown SF. It's a bit easy to miss as it's surrounded by a lot of shabbier looking buildings and there's always construction around. Once you're inside, you're welcomed with furnishings and a setting that reminds me a lot like eating at nice seafood restaurants in New England. It has a very East Coast feel and ambiance to it that I haven't quite figured out exactly how to describe yet. Note that it can get quite crammed if it's a full house.

The menu is pretty pared down with some dishes that rotate or stay consistent. "Les entrees"/appetizer are $12, "les plats"/entree are $27, "jardin"/salad are $7 and desserts are $9. It seems like seafood is their forte here. There's also a nice deal to get a fixed price "entree"/appetizer + "plat"/entree + dessert for $47 I believe if you're looking to try a lot of things. We enjoyed the food so much we ended up just getting dessert as well so I would say if you're hesitant you should just go for it since it doesn't make a huge difference.

I would say the entrees are sized are pretty well portioned out and you'll definitely get stuffed. I recall most things being pretty solid besides the Organic Roasted Chicken Breast that my friend got one time. The Seafood Basquaise is a bit underwhelming and too salty for my likes as well.

LES ENTREES/APPETIZERS ($12)

Sautéed Prawns in Pastis -  Red & yellow cherry tomatoes, shallots & chives. This appetizer is what keeps me coming back! Highly recommend this if you're a fan of shrimp and dipping your complimentary bread into this amazing sauce. The sauce has a citrusy and savory taste to it that's really delightful in my opinion. You've missed out if you haven't ordered this!

JARDIN/SALADS ($7)

Heirloom Tomato Salad (Special) - Most of the salad specials are pretty good. Veggies were fresh!

Endive & Arugula Salad - My personal favorite salad here as it has nutty and crunchy components to it. 

LES PLATS/ENTREES ($27)

Steamed PEI Mussels & French Fries - Fried garlic, fresh herbs, shallots & sherry vinegar. Prepare for a huge bucket of mussels and what seems to be like hand cut french fries. 

Sauteed Petrale Sole -  Artichokes, asparagus, fennel, risotto, piquillo pepper sauce. Gorgeous presentation with the vivid orange sauce. You basically get two servings of the sole too, which makes the dish very filling. Very tender!

DESSERTS ($9)

Hazelnut & Roasted Almond Mousse Cake - Layers of hazelnut mousse and genoise topped with roasted almonds. Not too special, could skip out on.

Tarte Tatin Aux Pommes - Warm caramelized apple tarte with vanilla ice cream & creme fraiche. They did a pretty good job with this one.

I love Fringale and I'll always come back when my parents visit town. It's a special place for us to reunite and the servers are very friendly.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
I was invited to dinner at Fringale this evening. We were running late at a previous function and they were kind enough to extend the reservation time when called. Very understated location and upon entering we were quickly shown to our table for four. Like most major cities seating was tight as they make use of the small space. The service was excellent and our server Romain a solid 5. Very attentive and assisted my friend as she was looking for gluten free options though her choices are limited in the end. For drinks I wanted a Captain Morgan and Coke  but they had Sailor Jerry instead. No worries it was a good stiff drink just what I needed. 
My dining companions and I noticed a strange aroma in the air. Once my dinner of mussels arrived I figured out the mystery to jarred garlic. Which has a particular aroma and flavor profile. Neither enhanced the mussells for me in fact it probably was the worst I ever had. This was disappointing as I was looking forward to eating them. My companions had the cod and corvina and they all enjoyed their meals. But agreed it wasn't great food albeit excellent service.
author: Clarissa K.

description: Food was definitely four stars, a solid French restaurant of the area. Friendly and accommodating staff and easier to get a table than neighbouring marlowe. Decor is a bit dated.
author: Pavan D.

description:
My daughter went here for a birthday party and had a great meal. So we went to try after hiking at Mt. Tamalpais. 

The place was packed at 7 PM. The waiter was very nice and pleasant. 

My husband ordered Monterey Calamari for appetizer and rare hanger steak. 

The Monterey calamari was very tasty, but a little chewy. 4 Stars.

The steak was so tough with so much gristle. 1 star

My daughter's mussels was sour, we didn't like it. 2 Stars.

My duck was over done and tough. Lentil was not a great compliment to the duck. 2 Stars. I had terrible diarrhea.

Hazelnut and Almond mousse cake was great. 5 Stars 

The creme brûlée was good, but nothing special. 3 Stars 

The warm chocolate gourmand was good. 4 Stars.
author: R C.

description:
Came in for restaurant week and had a lovely and tasty dinner and a reasonable price. The portions were large and the flavors were great. The service was a bit slow, sadly, and my cocktail (the JM Negroni) was only OK.

For the meal I got the calamari entree which was a huge pile of calamari in a light, but spicy, dressing. I got the bacon-wrapped pork fillet for the main dish which was very tasty with a sweet and smoky glaze. And for dessert I had the almond and hazelnut cake which wasn't huge, but was more than enough since it was so rich and tasted very strongly of almond and hazelnut (and the little pool of chocolate it sat in was a great compliment to the cake's flavor).
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Went here for lunch and the food is just decent.  Got the hangar steak..not really tender.  Wife got the beef carpacio...not too much flavor and too many capers which made it salty.

Had the ravioli that was cooked well, just the goat cheese was overpowering.  Dessert was hazelnut cake.  Ok...sweet, but cake wasn't moist.  And it costs $90 for two, with no drinks so expensive for the quality of food.  

If you want good french, La Folie is the place to go.
author: Rich k.

description:
Cute little French bistro with probably just a little bit too much attitude and not good enough food for us to come back.

Called and made a reservation - nice that they had availability on a Friday night - and arrived and were seated promptly. Always weird when someone asks you "how many in your reservation?" As if to say "you better have a reservation" or "you don't clearly have a reservation". Maybe I'm due being too sensitive and it was more in the tone, but I got the sense that they didn't really care whether we were there or not.

Really enjoyed the foie gras appetizer. As well as they served some pretty amazing bread. However, the mussels and fries entrée had mussels bathed in vinegar and dry and almost inedible. The sole entree was weirdly covered in a not-French pepper sauce. Also the sole was a bit dry and the combination of risotto sole and pepper sauce just didn't really come together.

The chocolate cake dessert which was weirdly a little dry but mostly tasted good.

Nothing special, a bit pretentious and probably won't see these guys again.
author: Bob K.

description: Went here with my wife a few months ago so this is a late review.  Had the calamari, crab salad, and french onion soup as the apps, filet mignon and pork tenderloin as the main, and topped it off with the lava cake for dessert.  Calamari and crab salad were fresh and amazing, french onion soup had a good onion and beef broth, the filet mignon was tender and melted in your mouth/cooked to perfection, and the lava cake was a good sweet balance to finish the meal (good enough for 2 to share).  Only downside to a perfect dinner in this cozy intimate restaurant was that the pork tenderloin was a bit dry.  Overall though good for a small romantic dinner.
author: Raymond F.

description: Excellent restaurant with amazing service and great food.  Their spinach ravioli is great.  The sole fish dish is phenomenal and their shrimp entree is very good.
author: Thomas P. L.

description: We were looking for a place near CalTrain, for dinner after a matinee show, and had high expectations.  The waiter seemed annoyed when we didn't orders appetizers, the Petrale Sole was very bland, the Seafood Basquaise was quite good. Prices were about 25% higher than sample menus on both Open Table & Yelp, which isn't cool. Two entrees and two glasses of their cheapest wine cost $100 bucks. Will not return, too many other good options.
author: Ron C.

description:
After hearing raves about fringale from anyone and everyone we finally decided to go here for a date night. We walked into a warm, quaint place with a handful of tables. Our reservations were for 8 pm on a Saturday so the restaurant was a bit crowded. We were seated just after a few minutes. Obviously we had read and reread the menu at home we were ready to order the second we walked in. 

We started our meal with the soup of the day which happened to be butternut squash (my favorite!) and their endive and arugula salad (with just olive oil on top). My husband and I both got the Creekstone farm black angus ribeye steak for our entrees. The steak was served with green beans and fries. And we got their famous hazelnut and roasted almond mousse cake for dessert with coffee. Everything from their ambiance to their food was incredible. With the dim candle lighting and the romantic feel, I think it's the perfect date night spot. I will definitely be returning here. 

One thing I would want different it for the tables to not be so close to each other and the waiters to be a little more attentive (given it was super busy and I think they were a little short staffed)
author: Fatima A.

description: Came here for the $40 restaurant week dinner deal. Three courses and we had a few options for each of them! Started off with the calamari- SO good especially the small bits of chorizo they included. The lamb shank was my entree and also loved that. Super tender. Finally, ended off with the hazelnut cake. It was definitely very hazlenutty- i just wish it had more chocolate! Overall, awesome place and worth it.
author: Amanda F.

description: The food here was pretty good but the service was just ok. The waiter was always busy with talking to other customers and forgetting our request. We felt upset about the service so we tipped him just 15% - which pissed the Asian waiter off. He throwback the check to the table really hard after he checked the numbers on the receipt. Then wrapped the paper on the table super loud and stared at me (with angry/unhappy face and voice) while I am still there.
author: Rebecca H.

description: We had a lovely Xmas eve dinner here. Service is warm and efficient. It feels like a neighborhood Cafe but in a more upscale setting. The prix fixe menu is a fabulous value. We had the beef carpaccio and foie Gras starters, then petrale sole and duck confit entrees, and lastly the buche de Noel and creme brulee. Wow! Portions were very generous, everything was flavorful and satisfying. We'll be back!
author: Teri K.

description:
Lets say  4.5  stars . I have been to Fringale for lunch at least 8 times over the past 5- 10 years, and they have been consistently good. I really love this place.
It's not "as good as it gets" but it's awfully good.

A while back  I was with 2 vendors from St. Louis,and  they loved the meal so much -Quote: " I could eat 2 of those" ( the duck confit)

For lunch all mains are $ 20  very simple- 
Appetizers  are all $ 10 -  and about 5-6 choices for each

This is a Basque kitchen, which means they do meat exceptionally well from the duck confit to the grass fed beef. Appetizers are good, and with a salad that is usually enough for lunch.
Special soup of the day is usually a winner too.

They have mussles and the classic pommes frites now as well.

Their seafood is good, the salads are unique and fresh, especially the yellow beets with mint and goat cheese.
Desserts are always good , done with French tradition , not too sweet.
If you like your food fresh, rich in flavor, handmade along with good service in an intimate bistro atmosphere this is a place you will love.

It is a completely different experience though, from the also good but noisy and hectic  Marlowe ,two doors down 4th street.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
Restaurant week prix fixe meal is splendid. Loved everything! Perfection and the best creme brulee I've ever had... EVER. The staff is all French and know what their talking about. 

Appetizer spinach ravioli - slightly too al dente but clearly fresh and delicious.

Entree of risotto with petrale sole so spectacular.

Dessert - had the waitress surprise me and she brought the flourless chocolate cake. Between that and the creme brulee,  which she said was the best in the city, I'd definitely get the creme brulee if I have the chance to choose again. 

The prix fixe meal gives you 3 items so impossible to finish it all... but you'll want to it's so good.

Definitely will be bookmarked as a favorite to return. 5 star place all the way!!!
author: Tara C.

description:
Absolutely lovely restaurant!

We have lived here for nearly 20  years, and just made it to Fringale for the first time!

Atmosphere warm and cozy- wonderful authentic neighborhood vibe.

Cocktails were outstanding.
Food was amazing.
Waiter was terrific.

We will now make this a regular thing!

Highly recommended!
author: Dr. Octagon O.

description: Lovely French cuisine without all the pretension or hefty price tag of many other SF restaurants. It's a small restaurant but has a nice selection on the menu as well as delicious wines. Service was slow but this was only noticeable to us because we were in a hurry. If you're looking for a leisurely meal, lingering over courses, wine, and conversation, you'll be pleased with this experience.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Great Place! We very often there. The atmosphere is French authentic. The service is also great! Definitely recommend!
author: Stiliyan B.

description:
Absolutely terrible experience here last night. Food was great all up until I crunched down, hard, on A ROCK. I ordered the duck confit with lentils and there was a good sized white/light grey stone in my food that I crunched down on and CHIPPED MY TOOTH! 
I signaled to a waiter and told him what happened and a guy comes over and proceeds to tell me, "yeah it happens sometimes in lentils". No apology, no remorse, and didn't even ask me how they could make it right?! It was an absurd reaction. He then asks "Do you want me to take it away or what?" Of course I have them take it away and I get another order of foie gras because this is soft and easy to chew as I was already experiencing some nerve pain. I explained to our waiter, upon ordering the foie gras, that I expect to not have to pay for it. The waiter agreed. I had to say this because like I said, No one showed any concern or remorse and instead made me feel like it's my problem. No one ever asked me if I was ok. Of course when the check arrives it had the foie on there and I had to again tell them pretty pointedly that I will not be paying for it and have further discussion because the waiter said "I cannot just not charge for two dish"

I understand that lentils and beans can sometimes have stones in the packaging which is why you have to clean them extremely well and as a restaurant it is YOUR RISK that YOU TAKE, when you serve them. 

MY TOOTH IS CHIPPED and I'm experiencing quite a bit of pain from it and based off of the overall attitude of the staff and complete lack of concern I have a right mind to pursue this. Unacceptable behavior for a restaurant, truly.
author: Breana T.

description: This place is really hard to get into for some reason. We had a booking on a weekday, and had to wait about 15 minutes before being seated. Once we were seated the service was quite fst. I had a chicken dish, and had asked the waiter if it was good or he had another recommendation. He said if that's what you want, order it. Not very helpful. needless to say my dish was quite boring and bland. The restaurant was also 85 degrees which was not enjoyable, it was nice and cool outside. Not sure. Will not be back.
author: Jonah K.

description:
A little bit of Paris right on 4th Street!

I took a friend to this restaurant to celebrate the holidays and we both ordered the Onglet steak a la Parisienne. It was cooked to perfection!!! (My mouth is watering just thinking about that meal!) I'd go back in a hot minute to try one of their other special dishes. 

Jean Marie is a very gracious host and his staff were very accommodating. The restaurant itself is cozy and perfect for conversation.
author: Valerie C.

description:
Had very high expectations and had been meaning to stop by for a while so when the first day of Restaurant Week coincided with my monthly book club, we decided to try this place out. It was a rainy night when we arrived. There were a few tables available but we were asked to wait an additional 15 min or so to be seated (we were early for our reservation). 

Within minutes of being seated, the server stopped by but we told him we needed a few minutes, after which he didn't return for 20 min or so :( The complimentary bread was just ok. It was cold and a bit tough. 

We finally ordered - I started with the calamari a la plancha which was delicious and the highlight of the meal! Next was the sauteed sole. Unfortunately, this was a huge disappointment. It looked like it was breaded and fried to a crisp (menu listed it as sauteed). I also had a bite in which the fish tasted a bit spoiled. My friend got the same dish and made the exact same comment. Lastly, we moved onto dessert. The creme brulee was good, a bit on the sweet side (could've used more vanilla) but pretty good nonetheless. We also had 2 bottles of wine for dinner. Overall, the total came to almost $100 a person including tip. Overall meal (food + experience) was average but I definitely don't think it was worth the value.
author: Yin H.

description: So this review is a little late, my wife and I visited back in March on a daycation. We found this spot by chance for dinner one night and fell in love. We loved it so much we spent the two days we had and got dinner there twice. The atmosphere, the service and the food is top notch. They truly provide an excellent environment for their customers.
author: Mike D.

description: I wanted to like this place as we live nearby. Took my entire family here including 22 month old son. The food was meh, but the wait staff was beyond rude, muttering under their breath how obnoxious my son was.  No crying, lots of laughter, apparently too much fun for this arrogant staff. DO NOT GO HERE. Irate with the slow and demeaning staff, notably the management.
author: Brooke F.

description:
I went here with my boyfriend to celebrate his birthday. The ambiance of the restaurant was very romantic and the service and food were both wonderful. Our waiter was very charming and accommodating. To start, we both shared a salad and an Assiette de charcuterie. There were two different types of Pâté on the platter, as well as two different types of sausages. I love everything that was on that charcuterie board. For the entrees, I got the night special which was lamb shank with a red wine sauce and my boyfriend ordered the roasted rack of lamb. The Gruyere potato gratin that came with his rack of lamb was simply amazing, as were the brussels sprouts and mashed potatoes that came with my lamb shank. We had a long dinner and never felt rushed at all during our time there. 

As a side note, parking is pretty much all street parking. We decided to park by a bar two blocks down because the other areas around the restaurant did not look particularly safe to park a car late at night. Parking in this area is metered until 9 PM also, but the meters take credit card.
author: Lynn T.

description: Great neighborhood gem. Classic cooking, stellar service, warm and inviting ambiance.
author: K A.

description:
I came here for a business lunch, and was overall impressed. Kind of random, but mayor Ed Lee was dining at a table adjacent to ours. 

They have a $35 three course lunch menu, which is so reasonable. Or, you can order an entree for $20. Very classic menu, with nothing really innovating, but delicious nonetheless. 

I debated between the mussels and tuna Niçoise salad, and was pleasantly surprised by the mussels. It was a huge portion, and they delivered them with a giant container of fries. 

The restaurant is casual but elegant. The service was attentive, but not overbearing. Though they did make a huge deal when my colleague wanted to replace fries with green beans, saying it would be more expensive. 

Overall, it's a great little spot for a business meal, but not the best if you're in a rush.
author: Angela F.

description:
Rack of lamb with tender, juicy and well-seasoned. Gruyere potato gratin was very tasty.  

Prices were fairly reasonable for SOMA.  

Our server wasn't very friendly though. Went with my sister, got carded by waiter and then this conversation commenced:
My sister: "It's her 30th birthday!! Yay!"
Waiter: *grunts and averts his eyes without smiling*
My sister: *crestfallen* "umm never mind..sigh"

Ok, maybe he didn't hear her properly but service remained like that for the rest of our dinner. Too bad as the food was yummy and the restaurant is pretty cute.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
The first nice surprise about this place was that I was able to get a reservation at a place in the City on a weekend at the last minute! Granted it was right when they first opened for dinner service, but still...something is better than nothing!

We were here with a big group of family & family friends from Taiwan - it took awhile to order since the menu is slightly extensive but we managed to get a variety of food so we can try a little of everything:
- butter lettuce salad
- arugula salad
- beef carpaccio
- Monterey calamari
- roasted chicken breast
- duck confit
- braised veal short rib
- sauteed Corvina seabass
- sides: frites & aioli, brussel sprouts, haricots verts

Our waiter was friendly and very patient with us being a big party, so I really appreciated that. Everything was very delicious and we have no real complaints overall.
author: Cathy W.

description:
I've been to Fringale 2 times so far. First time was 2 years ago and we loved the food.

This week I went to Fringale again, this time for a company dinner that I organized. There were some things that happened that were not ideal, but overall I still stand with my 4 stars rating.

For those who don't know this place this is a French bistro. Place is cozy, not a lot of space between tables so come prepared for that. 

Drinks: full bar (no moscow mule or mojitos though). When I asked a Espresso Martini they said yes but once I got it, it tasted really strange. The waiter asked how was my drink and once I shared with him what I thought he immediately took it back and brought me another (they had forgotten to put one of the liquors in it). No harm done, ready to go for food!!

Starters and entrees were very good as last time. I had prawns au pastis for starter and it was great. My main dish was a perfectly cooked rack of lamb (do yourself a favor and do not get it medium well, it will be dry).

For dessert I had a chocolate kind of bread pudding and it tasted pretty bad. First thought was it could be just my taste but my colleague ordered the same dish and said the same thing. Once we mentioned it to the server, he immediately took them back and brought new ones that were much better. 

Server was also very friendly and apart from the dessert we had a great evening.
author: Nuno S.

description:
Vive La France. Celebrating Bastille Day in San Francisco as vacation vs. work, work wins this year, French country house has to wait. Took the family out. It's not fancy dinner but I've heard plenty of good things about it. It's right next to my favorite winter spot in SoMa: Cockscomb, so it's easy to find. Especially with the never ending construction, it's perfect for a meal when everyone else wants to avoid that street.

Bastille menu was a very decent deal. At $46 a head. I thought it was £46 per head as I just returned from UK and it was not. Whew! Pomme Frites were fabulous. I could eat that all night. Onion tart? I dissed it only to find out vert quickly this is filled with greens and protein, the tart was quite deliciously flaky. Charcuterie hit the spot. 

I paused. All those eating out in the Avenues had deprived me from my true passion for French food. It's always been my calling. Fringale reminded me how much I've missed my adopted home's food. I savored the charcuterie. It's all mine. 

Veal short ribs were on the fattier side this evening, and I did love it. Moules were filled with garlic and I did enjoy it more than some other places. It was more flavorful than some other places and it's perfect just the way it was. Salmon was a surprise hit. 

French does Apple tart well. Just like Germans does Apple Strudel well. Don't forget the apple tart.

Bread basket was filed with baguette which was always a nice welcome considering some places now ask you to pay for bread. 

Food was cooked very well. One could tell that given the longevity of this restaurant, preparing for really high quality food is not an issue here. All arrived relatively quickly, despite the filled restaurant. Service was very good, and polished, as you'd expect for a place like this.

One thing that is for sure: I have been suffering fro separation anxiety with good French food, for reasons as simple as I want to eat healthier and consume less caloric food. But on Bastille day, and for the love of French cuisine, one must indulge oneself once in a great while.

Last year I celebrated Bastille Day with a very dear friend of mine at the newly opened Monsieur Benjamin. The year before, I was in France with the family. I suppose I like to keep my tradition intact. If there is anything resembles the love affair of a lifetime, it's my love for French food. Fringale reminded me just how much so tonight. For that, I'm thankful.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Short Story:
A fairly awesome place!

Long Story:
I came here on a Thursday night at 7PM with two other friends and we were promptly seated.  The place slowly got packed as the evening went on.  I had the duck breast and my friend had the pork loin.  We also got a nice red wine...too bad I can't remember what it is now.

The view is alright, it's near a Wells Fargo so not too much of a sight.  The decor and ambiance are pretty nice.  There are large and tall windows.  The service is also really nice and attentive.

Verdict:
I'll go back!
author: Michael W.

description:
This place has been around for over 20 years but it's managed to stay fresh. The staff and management are friendly, accomodating and stay on top of things. Eric was most helpful and made recommendations that made our meal very memorable.
The lamb chops and potatoes were so tender, I wish I had ordered it, and the seabass was sweet perfection, firm to the bite and fresh.
Parking is street, which can be good or bad, depending on your point of view. 
Tres bien!
author: Eric T.

description: Fringale is a quaint neighborhood French bistro that delivers elevated French comfort food at a reasonable price. They are open for lunch on weekdays and offer a 3 course tasting menu for $35 for lunch and $48 for dinner.
author: Nelly M.

description:
Came here for restaurant week and was not disappointed! This is a cute little French bistro with delicious food and actual French waiters.

We got:
- calamari - a HUGE portion for an appetizer, definitely more than enough for 4 people to share. Calamari was grilled and tasted great with some lemon
- beef carpaccio - standard carpaccio, nothing special but nothing bad to say
- duck confit - the french fries here were the real star, but the duck was tender and juicy too
- slow cooked lamb shank - our favorite dish - meat literally falling off the bone with great tomatoey flavors
- creme brûlée - not the best I've ever had, the dish it comes in is quite deep so the ratio of crispy top to actual creme is a little off
- warm chocolate cake - decadent and chocolatey. A must try for chocolate lovers

All for $40 per person! I would definitely recommend coming here as everything we ate was really delicious and excellent portions.
author: Amy Y.

description:
This is one of those restaurants that you see on Yelp with great reviews, you go in thinking that you will have great dinner, and then you leave knowing that you will never come back there. 
Totally disappointed at this place. The second we came in, there was a red flag, most of the customers where  senior citizens. Waiter was fine, but in a crazy hurry, since it was Saturday and all tables where booked. Main courses where not good at all. I had sole on a bed of over cooked rice splashed in some kind of a red sauce, and my husband had probably the worst duck confit he ever tried in San Francisco. 
No idea how this place had such a great reviews here. 
Whatever it is, we are definitely not coming back here.
author: Bianca G.

description:
Wonderful restaurant!

I was very sad when I missed Fringale during the SF Restaurant week, and I really hoped that I would have the opportunity to return as soon as possible. So I waited a couple months, got a reservation, and came with three very good friends of mine.

So one thing I'd like to mention is- don't feel pressured to order from the prix fixe menu! I'm not sure what the purpose of the prix fixe menu was, but one of my friends ordered a la carte and she definitely seemed very happy with her choices. The dishes she ordered (I remember the beef carpaccio and the bacon wrapped pork) couldn't be found on the prix fixe menu, but they ended up being the same price!

In any case, a three course meal shouldn't cost much more than $50 before tax and tip, depending on what you order. Expect to walk out of this restaurant very happy!

For myself, I ordered the Prawn Pastis as my appetizer, the Black Angus for my entree, and the Creme Brulee for the dessert. All three were very delicious. However, if I had another opportunity to return, I would order differently.

Nevertheless, I think this restaurant deserves its five stars. Wonderful service, wonderful food, and the atmosphere is casually elegant. It's nice to come here, especially later in the evening.

I will be returning!
author: Anders Z.

description:
I was in the neighborhood and it was way past my dinner time, so I decided to pop in and try this place out. 

I ordered Sauteed Sole with Risotto. It was okay, a bit bland but okay. I would have loved if it had more flavor, such as leeks or cilantro.
author: Anelya S.

description: Nice place and quite authentic. Nothing really fancy, but we had a good time with my friends. I recommend this place.
author: Lydie A.

description:
SFRW #5

I'm an hour early for my reservation...that's right...EARLY!!! We sat at the bar and decided we might as well do our dinner right then and there.

We ordered:

- Clamari a la plancha = nicely season with delicious chorizo and a spicy kick of jalapenos. 

- Spinach Ravioli = toasted pine nuts with cheese sauce and basil will rub you the right.

- Sauteed petrale sole = had me at the risotto and the kobocha squash puree.

- Braised lamb shank = the deconstruction Brussels sprouts was the least favorite part of this dish. 

- Crème brûlée = creamy vanilla custard with lightly caramelized sugar crust. 

- Warm chocolate Gourmand = one scoop of vanilla ice cream beside a tasteful flourless chocolate cake drizzle with raspberry sauce was quite delectable. 


Fringale would be a place for a warm inviting dinner where one can enjoy a relaxing meal. No frills, just simple good eat. 

I hope you give this place a try. Cheers!
author: Owie N.

description:
One of my girlfriends wanted to do San Francisco Restaurant Week ($40). Since I was out of town when she asked, I told her to pick the restaurant. She ended up picking Fringale. I'd been here years ago (like at least 8 years?), and remember enjoying the steak and foie, so I was down to revisit.

Choice of appetizer:
*Butter lettuce salad: blue d'auvergne, herbs, piquillo pepper & boquerones vinaigrette
*Calamari a la plancha: jalapenos, chorizo, piment d'espelette & olives
*Roquefort & spinach ravioli: toasted pine nuts, basil & papillon cheese sauce

Choice of entree:
*Bacon wrapped pork tenderloin: braised napa cabbage, onion & apple marmalade
*Braised lamb shank: potato puree, brussel sprouts, mushroom fricassee & thyme sauce
*Sauteed petrale sole: risotto, artichokes, kobocha squash & piquillo pepper sauce

Choice of dessert:
*Creme brulee
*Warm chocolate gourmand
*Mme angele's gateau basque

*Charles krug, family reserve, generation, napa valley '11 ($60)

We were able to order the whole SFRW menu between the three of us. The appetizers were all pretty good. I enjoyed the ravioli. The cheese sauce was delicious! The entrees were okay. I think my favorite was the sole and I normally don't even like sole prepared that way. For the entrees, I was a little uninspired with the choices. In hindsight, I probably should have just ordered off the SFRW menu. But that would have defeated the purpose of going, right? The desserts were good and enjoyed by all.

For SFRW, Fringale offers a decent menu. But I really wish they offered a steak or something a little more enticing on their menu. The rest of the courses were good though. Not sure what happened to the restaurant I enjoyed so much so many years ago, but for SFRW, Fringale was just alright.
author: Elena N.

description: This place is pretty small and cozy with plenty of street parking around. I came here on New Year's Eve and they were able to accommodate for last minute reservations. Upon arriving, we were seated right away. Since the tables are so close to each other, the servers have to literally pull the table out so you can sit inside. You can easily hear the conversations from the table next to you so if you want a romantic dinner where people can't hear your conversations, this is not the place. The menu has a set price and you choose one from the appetizer, main course, and dessert. The menu was kind of limited as each section had about 3 choices to choose from. I had the shrimp, filet mignon, and chocolate dessert. Everything was good and I was too full to finish everything. At the end of dinner they also gave us chocolate, but again I was too stuffed to even try it.  Overall, my here experience here was pleasant. I would come back and try the other items.
author: Renee Y.

description:
My hunny and I had our 3 mos celebratory dinner here at Fringale last Sunday, and it was a pretty lovely experience. :)

Josh had made reservations for 7:45pm, and we found a spot for parking right next door to the restaurant. Despite us being there about 15mins early & the place being pretty petite and filled up, we got seated right away to a table next to a window.

We ordered the following: 

Butter Lettuce (okay--we're both not a fan of bleu cheese & bf didn't notice that it was part of it on the menu.)
Crab Napoleon (yummy! Refreshing & tasty. I remember seeing the movie Simply Irresistible & they had this dish in it. Such a good movie, everyone especially those who are into romantic movies should watch it!)
Steak (good)
Rack of Lamb (also delish)
Creme Brûlée (perfectly devine! This was hunny's dessert choice.)
Chocolate cake (pretty good, but I didn't like the raspberry sauce though.)

So overall it was a nice dinner at a little romantic French restaurant. Service took awhile after the appetizer, but I guess that's usually how it is with most nicer restaurants.
author: Amy C.

description: So the food here was decent but the service was really rude.  We made an open table reservation and when we arrived the waiter told us he would cancel our reservation because we were only planning to have dessert and not dinner.  Then he proceeded to clear the table loudly since we apparently did not need all the settings for my measly dessert.  The entire demeanor made my evening extremely uncomfortable.  We were not aware of what OpenTable charges you for a reservation nor responsible for the commitments you made to OpenTable.  It was extremely unprofessional to admonish the customer.  It's tough to be a small business but tougher when you treat a local Neighbourhood customer so poorly.  Never again.
author: Win L.

description:
Service wasn't good at all. Server kept pushing our little plates rudely out of the way so he could set our main dishes in front of us, and by setting, I mean tossing.

Some of us got the prefixe menu for SF Restaurant week, but they had also falsely advertised online that they had sea bass, and when we got there, they switched it to sole. We made a reservation based on that menu and wanted that seabass, and after several reluctant attempts from the waiter, we were finally able to switch it from sole to seabass under the prefixe. Sadly, the seabass was only mehhh. The only dish I enjoyed was the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin. The duck was overcooked and dry.

Maybe the quality of the food diminished because of restaurant week, but that and the service was enough to prevent me from coming back.
author: Stanley C.

description:
Came here for dinner with the team in SF. Food was good, but the decor and crowd is definitely older. The service was rough to start with but slowly got a bit better as the dinner progressed. We started with FOIE GRAS TERRINE which was lovely. There was a fruit spread that went very well with the foie gras pate. For the main course I had the PEI MUSSELS cooked with fried garlic, fresh herbs, shallots and a sherry vinegar. If you don't eat a lot this is definitely a good size dish to order. After our dinner, we made space for that CREME BRULEE. Very well made, good size, and delicious. ENJOY!

PS: Reservations are recommended. :)
author: Darlene Y.

description: We went after Cirque du Soleil, and arrived 45 miles minutes early and were seated promptly.  It is a small, sweet restaurant with a romantic aura. The vegetarian soup (a subtly delicious butternut squash), a fantastic salad, and an appetizer of gruyere and spinach ravioli (homemade pasta, a good amount of spinach with no ricotta, and a rich gruyere sauce to die for) was absolutely enough to serve as a full meal.  No vegetarian entrees, but I didn't miss it. And we had a simply incredible chocolate dessert (one of those cake/brownie things with a slightly hot-pudding-y middle).  The only downside was the neighborhood, which may be gentrifying in a few years, but is still sketchy and a bit scary.
author: Diana K.

description:
Still an excellent choice in SoMA. The Salad Nicoise comes with actual tuna steak slices seared to perfection, one of the best I've had at any French restaurant.

For dessert, opt for the warm chocolate gourmand. The vanilla ice cream that accompanies it is simply divine.
author: Kristen S.

description: Love this place! We went to lunch today and I had the tuna sandwich which I am addicted to - there is some kind of sweet carmelized relish on it that just takes it over the top. Today we also had the sauted calamari - so very good with the roasted peppers. Great food and a relaxed atmosphere with warm service. Enjoy it! I will have to take the Hubby here sometime soon!
author: J M.

description:
i was pleased to see that the construction outside their front door was not an interruption to our meal. we couldn't hear anything.

our server was not super attentive in spite of not being very busy at lunch. we were never asked how our food was - not even once. she kept taking bowls of mussel shells away from my colleagues when they were full but never took mine. i started using their bowls and she took them when their meal was completed. 

the mussels were not as good as i remembered. the sauce had a lot of vinegar. while it was nice in small portions, i felt like i'd had a salt lick for lunch about an hour after the meal. 

desserts were quite good. the hazelnut one was really good. the chocolate cake with berry compote was good but the vanilla bean ice cream on top made it better.

i wouldn't go back for the prices you pay to eat there.
author: Tera K.

description:
I was looking for a mid priced French Bistro and everything is listed under Best is $$$$. The prices here are much more reasonable and food is good, not great, but definitely good. 

My friend and I started with a Sancerre (Excellent) and an Alsacian Riesling (just okay), then bought a bottle of Cahors (Southern France Malbec) very nice and $45.00. Nice richness - needs 30 minutes to open. 

We split the fromage appetizer - it was presented with 6 cheeses, honey, apple slices, grapes and a basket of bread (2 kinds). All of the cheeses had great flavor - a nice way to start the meal. 

Then we both ended up ordering the Duck Breast - it was tender, beautifully presented lying on top a bed of lentils - overall good, it needed some seasoning, especially salt - a bit bland. We ended the meal with that - it's a nice place, I've eaten here more than a dozen times. This is more like a true Bistro than other places with the name Bistro.
author: Rew C.

description: We went to Fringale last night for our anniversary. I chose the place based on the description and other reviews. Everything we had was amazing. Most memorable meal in a long time. Well done Fringale, food, vibe, service - all top notch. This place will not disappoint people! I'll be going back and urge you to try it too.
author: Greg C.

description:
Wonderful little modern French restaurant with great service and food.

The bacon wrapped pork tenderloin and roasted rack of lamb were awesome.
author: David T.

description: Excellent! Took my husband here to celebrate his birthday. We had foie gras & calamari a la plancha for entrée, black angus steak and duck confit for main course & just shared hazelnut mousse cake which was to die for! We had a great time! I recommend making a reservation before going here. Staff are friendly and nice! Will definitely comeback!
author: Janie A.

description:
I first discovered my seat at Fringale a few months back while visiting the city and oh boy, it was love at first bite :) 

I find myself making the trek to the city just for Fringale more and MORE often. I tip my hat to the wonderful service and delicious food with my following review :) 

The first time I came here, I ordered the "mussels and  fries", the muscles were served in a light broth with garlic, sherry vinegar, shallots and fresh herbs (perfect for bread dipping, YUM).  The French fries are always hot, crunchy and served with a homemade (I asked) aioli. 

I asked my server to recommend a white wine for the meal and he brought me out a glass of 
Sancere which paired perfectly :) (thanks for the tip!)

When I want something a little lighter, I usually order the frisée salad served with warm bacon dressing, a poached egg, and pine nuts over the top. Hits the spot. 

I can't wait to visit again and try my new favorite meal from your kitchen. 

Thank you Fringale for the delicious food and great service this place is my new "go to" for French cuisine :)
author: Mackenzie G.

description:
One of our goals during restaurant week was to try a lot of the places that we walk by frequently but were just too expensive to try on a normal night out. Fringale is one such place.

This restaurant is a small french place on 4th in SoMa and has an interesting ambiance which felt like a cross between a cozy french spot and a dining area on a cruise ship. Sounds strange but I liked it (aside from what looked like a bullet hole through the window we were sat under). All of the staff that we encountered had very thick french accents as well.

The food was generally pretty good and off of the prix fixe menu I ordered the spinach ravioli, the lamb shank and the almond cake dessert. I also saw a poached egg bacon dressing salad which I gluttonously ordered on top of all the rest. At the start we were brought complimentary crostinis with various meats and cheeses which were excellent. The salad was good and I liked the egg/dressing/bacon combo, but the greens were just a bit too light and could have stood to be more leafy. The ravioli was decent but nothing that special. The lamb shank was delicious (as are most lamb shanks) and I thought it was delivered well with a tasty sauce. I expected a bit more out of the almond cake but I did enjoy it thoroughly and ate it all. 

Overall, this seems like an above average french place which may be just a bit too expensive to dine at regularly. Although I would normally say that 'I've experienced better' (a 2/5 rating) french food (which there certainly is in this city), because I really like their location I am going to bump it up to 3 and say that it is "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description: Dessert has been the best part of the meal.  First time I had the Duck Confit.  I wasn't particularly impressed and though it was underseasoned.  This time I had the Seafood Basquaise.  This dish was better but the fish didn't seem as fresh as it should be.
author: Patricia N.

description:
The dining area reminded me of a contemporary, cozy and intimate living room!  Besides the place being small and tightly knit to each other's table, their food and service was great!

I really liked their Calamari a la Pancha as an opening!

Their Roquefort and Spinach Ravioli with pine nuts added texture and their Papillon cheese sauce, added a distinct flavor to the dish entirely.

The tomato sauce to the Seafood Basquaise, tasted homely.  A good mix was given from the sea - shrimps, mussels, tuna and scallops.

Bacon Wrapped Pork Tenderloin -  it was nicely cooked and the apple marmalade gave it an extra specialty to this dish.

As for the desserts, one was the Mme Angele's Gateau Basque.  It reminded me of a strawberry shortcake, but in a cake, sliced up format.  It didn't quite enrapture me.

I loved the Warm Chocolate Gourmand!  The raspberry syrup was drizzled all over the warm fudge chocolate and topped with an ice cream scoop, that was melting and oozing all over the plate!  It was great!

They gave us complimentary cookies to take home.  A sincere gesture for moving our tables.

There's something about Fringale, that is missing sparks, to make it a sure 5 star dining experience!  I just can't pinpoint it!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I took my friend here for his birthday and we both enjoyed the meal. Service was friendly + attentive and the dining atmosphere is great for celebratory occasions. Overall 3.5 stars but I am rounding up.

Bread: Just okay. I read in previous reviews that the bread would be cold and taste like it came from a supermarket, so I didn't have high expectations. 

Sautéed Shrimp Appetizer: Delicious! The shrimp was well cooked and the sauce was flavorful.

Calamari Appetizer: I'm not a fan of calamari but my friend really liked this dish. I tried some and it was tasty. There was a spicy kick.

Sautéed Sole w/ Corn & Peas:  I picked this dish between 2 different entree choices for the prix fixe menu. It was a solid choice! The fish was tender and well cooked. The corn, peas, and red sauce also added tons of bright flavors. I usually am worried that fish dishes are overcooked and over salted, but this dish didn't have either of those problems. I would order it again.

Duck Confit: My friend ordered this dish and we both agreed it was a bit overrated on Yelp. The meat was ok - not super tender but not dry either. I don't think there was much meat either. I would not recommend it.

Chocolate Flourless Cake w/ Ice Cream: This was good and a nice way to end the meal. The chocolate was heavy and complimented the lighter ice cream on top well.

I think for how much we ordered above + two glasses of wine, the price was fair. I didn't walk away feeling overcharged, which is a pretty big plus, especially in San Francisco. I would be down to return. :)
author: Sophia H.

description:
Wonderful meal! We enjoyed the calamari & carpaccio entrées, followed by the rack of lamb and  special veal short ribs. Everything was delightful and cooked to perfection. We got a crème brûlée and hazelnut/roasted almond mousse cake for dessert, both excellent, particularly the mousse cake. 
Service was excellent, our waiter was nice, helpful and friendly.
author: T L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place--I love French and Basque food, and judging by their accents it seemed most of the Front of House staff were French, so I had high hopes when we sat down to order. Unfortunately, it failed to live up to my expectations.
 
We started with the calamari a la plancha, which looked good but tasted surprisingly bland. From the ingredients listed in the description--jalapenos, chorizo, piment d'espelette and olives--it sounded spicy and rich, but in actuality there was little trace of spice or even salt, and the calamari itself was rubbery and overcooked. For our mains, I had the duck confit and my girlfriend had the roasted rack of lamb. Both of the meats were fine, and the red wine sauce on the lamb was very good. The sides were more hit and miss. The lamb came with haricots verts, which again were a little overcooked, but went nicely with the aforementioned red wine sauce, and Gruyere potato gratin, which was great. The duck came with lentils and potato Landaises, the latter of which were basically thick, somewhat soft, unsalted potato chips topped with sautéed mushrooms.
 
Shockingly for a French restaurant, even the bread was boring--there were two kinds, and the darker of the two was OK, but the baguette tasted like supermarket "French bread."
 
We had initially planned to have dessert, but by the end of the meal we decided it was unlikely to be worthwhile.
 
Service was slow, but in fairness the place was pretty busy.
author: Nicholas D.

description:
-- Disclaimer: I am French, so I might be a bit picky with French places --

"Bib Gourmand" restaurants are always safe bets. Fringale is no exception. 

The prix fixe menu is very reasonably priced. 
The roquefort raviolis were full of flavor (if you like roquefort like me) and plentiful - especially for a starter. We also got a plateau de charcuterie which had a nice selection of sausages. 
Duck confit was delicious, I was not a huge fan of the presentation. 
The Hazelnut & roasted almond mousse cake was flavorful - but again, presentation could be better. 

Our waiter was French and provided a good wine recommendation. 

Overall a really great dinner and definitely a really good value. However I usually see Bib Gourmands as the antechamber of Michelin Stars, and Fringale is not even close for now. 

But again, solid experience.
author: Lionel F.

description:
This was my first time back for dinner after a couple of year absence.  We came on a Monday night which wasn't too busy.  As I remember from before service and food was excellent.  Additionally, the portion sizes are bigger than before which makes it a better value, though I always enjoyed the smaller portion sizes and not feeling totally stuffed -- but that is on me.

We had a party of five near the back and we could hear each other just fine.

Will go again.
author: Gunther J.

description:
Delicious!

I came here because I saw them on Great Cities Great Chefs.  Considering the quality of the food and the level of preparation involved in each item, the price us a bargain.  Our most expensive meal was only $34, yet I felt this place blew Fleming's out of the water.

I ordered the Duck Confit and it was simply amazing.  My sister in law ordered the ribeye, and it was the most tender and flavorful ribeye I have ever tasted.

I'll be coming been here before long.
author: Paul S.

description:
This place is so good when it comes to French cravings . I was up in San Francisco yesterday and with traffic I was so hungry so I got off the freeway to find the best food nearby and wanted to try this location.

I got the fettuccine pasta with cut up asparagus , mushroom , && Pesto!!!
But I was nervous to try it bc I am allergic to mushrooms but they took them out , which was amazing bc they were able to accommodate my needs && had no issues with doing so.

I also, had to try the prawns appetizer which was so yummy sautéed in butter the right way , which were very delicious , soft , didn't have the fishy taste to it , all you could taste is the butter && it was so good that I ended up just tossing them into my pasta which made my meal even Better!!! Had a side of French fries before my meal bc I was starving && they were so crunchy && had a lot of flavor !! 
I would defiantly say if you love French food this is the place to spend your money && it's reasonably cheap && the workers here are very attendant , respectful , nice && very courteous 


The owner of this location is very sweet , nice && very helpful, you can tell he takes pride in his restaurant && want to help you with food need you may have to make you happy , so Thank you very much for a wonderful mean && I promise you I will be back to try other food on your menu
author: Ariela K.

description: Order the pork tenderloin wrapped in bacon. The frisee salad with egg and bacon is fabulous. Service is spotty, but warm and friendly.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Saturday evening. 

Dinner was the bacon wrapped pork. Entree was cooked just right with nice flavors. For dessert we had the flourless chocolate cake. This was also good. I came here looking for a pineapple cocktail which I had read on Yelp but sadly it wasn't on the menu. Also, they have really good service.

Fringale overall is a very average SF restaurant. The big downside to this place is its size to customer ratio. We were cramped between two other couples with a little table. The place also gets very hot.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Stopped off for dinner whilst visiting SF for the day on vacation from the UK, in fact the venue is literally 5mins from the Cal Train Station so found it by chance on the way home...

Firstly we had a lovely warm greeting by the owner and the team, really nice start, inside the décor is wonderful and intimate ...the food itself was excellent in all ways, faultless, the waiter had extensive knowledge of the menu dishes and beverages, it isn't cheap but you do pay for quality...

The only negative was that they automatically added 15% tip to the bill, at all other venues in the US this was discretionary....however we had a lovely time and would visit again if in the area.
author: David B.

description:
I had my birthday dinner here.  Jean Marie was sooooo helpful in accommodating this event for me, table for 8 girls.  I've been here on a dinner date before, but totally forgot the name of the place.  But I was so glad I got to spend my bday dinner here again, since I did remember that I had a good experience.  Overall experience again was awesome!  The menu does not change, but the quality of food is yummy.  Thank you, for helping us capture the moments by taking lots of pics of us too! 

Les Entrees:
Frisée salad with warm bacon dressing, pine nuts, poached egg & toasted levain  12.
Spicy Monterey calamari "a la plancha", jalapenos, chorizo, piment d'espelette & olives  12.
Sautéed prawns in Pastis, red & yellow cherry tomatoes, shallots & chives  12.
Roquefort & spinach ravioli, toasted pine nuts, basil & Papillon cheese sauce  13.
Foie gras terrine, quince paste, fleur de sel, fresh black pepper, & toasted brioche  19.

Les Plats:
Traditional duck confit, lentils "Du Puy", potato Landaises, garlic, bacon & red wine sauce  25.
Seafood basquaise, sea scallops, seabass, prawns, tuna, mussels, red bell pepper & tomato coulis  27.
Braised veal short ribs, leeks, potato galette, carrots & mushroom fricassee, demi-glace sauce  29.
Sauteed Corvina seabass, potato puree piperade, artichokes & Nicoise olive tapenade  29.

Desserts: 
Hazelnut & roasted almond mousse cake 
Layers of hazelnut mousse and genoise topped with roasted almonds  
Warm chocolate Gourmand
Flourless chocolate cake served with a mint sorbet   
Apple tarte Tatin
Warm caramelized apple tarte with vanilla ice cream & creme fraiche
Les sorbets du jour
Assortment of house made sorbets
author: Mei B.

description:
Delish new American slash Italian in soma near att park.

Service is great. Started with a malbec, which was very nice and had great Aroma.

Ordered the charcuterrie appetizer with a large selection of cheese and all were unique and delish. Rabbit and duck pate plate were very unique too.

My coq au vin (chicken) was very good as well. Perfectly cooked.

And you can order for pickup on Eat24 which is awesome if you don't want the swankiness of dining out, but just want to get delish food and take it back to your spot in Mission Bay or nearby to watch the game / drink your own wine / hangout.
author: Chuck N.

description:
I am a big fan of this place. The food is always delicious. Service is good. The menu has plenty of fish options, which I am a fan of. I wish they would do specials more often. They once had coq au vin as a special and it was phenomenal, but I've not seen any other specials available since that visit. "Soup of the day" seems to always be potato leek. My favorite on the menu is the moules et frites.

Also, the waiters have charming French accents, but I kind of wonder about that, because I ordered my moules et frites in French once and the French-accented waiter could not understand. I had to tell him "mussels and fries," and it's just bizarre to me that any French speaker would not understand an order for moules et frites. So, I kind of wonder whether the French accent is affected, but I suppose that doesn't really matter. It's charming and the food is great. 

I would say the tables are crammed in pretty close and it can get pretty loud. God help you if you are seated at a table with a person whose voice carries, because you will be privy to their entire conversation. I wouldn't come here for a romantic candle-lit French dinner as it's not a very romantic atmosphere--more of a place for a small group, dinner with family, or catching up with old friends.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
This place was packed on a Sunday night and that could only mean two things, either the food here is delicious or DAT has arrived. 

We ordered the calamari, pork tenderlion wrapped in bacon, and almond mousse cake from the DAT menu and the Dungeness crab Napolean, duck confit from the regular menu.

The calamari and Dungeness crab Napolean appetizers were both superb. The calamari wasn't super chewy where you have to chomp away at it for like 20 bites until you feel like you've broken it down. The legs were the best part since it had retained most of the flavor. The Dungeness crab Napolean had so much crab! With all that Dungeness crab layered with avocado, I don't see why anyone wouldn't love this dish. I was surprised by how much flavor the crab had and the mango sauce was equally delicious.

Then came the entrees. The pork tenderloin wrapped in bacon was so juicy and tender yet it was still cooked all the way through. This was my favorite dish of the night and I really wish I could have ordered another one. The duck confit was a huge disappointment. Seeing how it was so highly rated by Yelpers, I decided to give it a shot. The beans, the thinly sliced potato, and the red wine sauce were all enjoyable, but the overcooked duck just killed the dish for me. 

The dessert was a hazelnut & roasted almond mousse cake. If you like the rich creamy taste of almond, then this is the perfect dessert. 

At first, the service was fast since we were the only table that had been seated for the second wave of reservations. Then as more groups were seated, the service slowed down to the point where we had to wait almost 15 minutes for our entree plate to be taken away and the dessert to be brought out. Very disappointing to the say the least.
author: Edward W.

description:
Oh Fringale...

While I've always remembered your food being pretty decent, I've also thought of you with a tinge of annoyance.  Maybe it's just the diligent (read: anal) Yelper in me, but it's always bothered me that I haven't been able to write a review about you.  Sadly, it had been too many years since that Dine About Town for me to recall all the details of what I had (steak frites?).

So, when it came time to pick a restaurant for our annual holiday, I knew exactly where to go (though my slightly drunk friend probably had no idea where he was during dinner...).  Fortunately, the food tasted just as good as before.  It's a good thing for you too Fringale, because otherwise I might have started thinking of you with a tinge of annoyance for an entirely different reason!

- CRAB NAPOLEON - Dungeness Crab, Avocado, Corn Salsa, Lemon Zest, Arugula, and Crème Fraîche (?)...$16
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fringale-san-francisco?select=ntiWk4eUFFCjZAPaF42W8g#S2XELHWEUJI5pUvcqeyxHw)
Hands down, the best thing I tried the whole night.  The crab was both incredibly fresh and delicious, the avocado added a great complimentary flavor, and the lemon zest gave it that hit of citrus the dish needed.  The other components will vary and change periodically, but it's an absolute must get.

- ROASTED RACK OF LAMB with Gruyere Potato Gratin, Harticots Verts, and a Rosemary Sauce...$28
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fringale-san-francisco?select=ntiWk4eUFFCjZAPaF42W8g#bXzfNBhmNK6NLBhQVd-SVA)
Decent for the most part.  The lamb was flavorful, tender, and mild in gaminess.  There could have been a little more herbs on the lamb and/or in the sauce, but fine otherwise.  However, I thought one of my pieces of lamb was more medium to medium well than medium rare, and the portion felt a little light for the money.  I wasn't expecting a beastly portion, but still more than what I had received.

- CRÈME BRÛLÉE...$8
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fringale-san-francisco?select=ntiWk4eUFFCjZAPaF42W8g#7D_Y41mo-ZNuDFxFE--lqA)
Much like my lamb, it was mostly hit...with some miss.  The flavor was spot on, and I liked the strawberries on top, but the sugary crust was disappointing!  Half of it had that nice, crunchy topping you'd expect, while the other half was borderline flimsy.  Disappointing in that respect, but not bad overall.

Much like my lamb and crème brûlée, service was mostly solid with one miss of note.  When the two filet mignons my friends had ordered were brought out, our server never ciphered which one was cooked medium and which one was cooked rare.  The orders ended up getting flipped, and my friends didn't realize the mistake until they were both halfway through (they both thought it was just cooked wrong).

Despite my somewhat minor quibbles with the service, price, and food though, Fringale did enough to earn four stars.  The intimate ambiance got them there, but the Crab Napoleon is what really sealed the deal.  A plate of it to share on a date with my future girlfriend?  Yeah, that works for me!
author: Mike L.

description: So expensive. Not so basque but really great confit de canard... the seafood appetizers were nice. The french bread was ok (not tartine legit and for the price I was expecting top notch) .. may be back
author: Natalia G.

description: We've been wanting to try Fringale for some time now and happy that we finally got around to it!  We started with the sauteed prawns in Pastis which was just divine - to the point that I looked up recipes for it and will try to recreate at home.  Fingers crossed :)  I had the seafood basquaise while hubby had the onglet steak a la Parisienne.  Both were good but I liked hubby's dish better and since he didn't mind exchanging dishes, we did :D
author: Kathy C.

description:
Weeknight date worthy Fringale is cozy, but inviting and conducive to easy converstations with your S.O.  Keep your voices low since the tables are close to one another. 

I asked for a cocktail list and was informed they don't really have one but they have a full bar.  My Campari soda woke up my palette but if you're looking for wine, the list has a handful of by the glass options and the bottles aren't overpriced (most bottles are around $36 - $80)

Classic dishes like duck confit and onion tarte are well prepared, as are unexpectedly un-French ones like the spicy Monterey calamari a la pancha with its jalapenos and chorizo. The bf's braised veal ribs are fall off the bone tender and a pretty generous serving at that! 

We finished off the meal with an airy hazelnut and roasted almond mousse. It got a bit too sweet for me after a couple of bites and I ended up leaving half on the plate.

Service isn't the most friendly because there was literally just ONE server and a busboy running the show, impressive since it was a bustling Tuesday night.
author: Janice C.

description: Relatively affordable restaurant with solid Italian dishes. Consistent throughout, nothing super spectacular but everything cooked well.
author: Sean G.

description:
Very cute dining room. Feels like at someone's home. The stuff was very nice. Our server Pierre was very pleasant and helpful. He made great recommendations on wine and food! 

The cheese plate was very pleasant. Sautéed calamari was delicious!  I had the braised short ribs. The meat fell off the bone. The seasoning was perfect. Generous pieces of meat, very solid plate. 

My boyfriend had the steak. It was very tasty!  

Definitely highly recommend place for the neighborhood!
author: Danielle W.

description:
Came here for restaurant week and had a pretty good meal. Of all the great food in this city, I'd consider this one just average. Don't get me wrong, it was a good meal, it just didn't go the extra mile for me as I've grown accustomed to here in San Francisco. We started with the butter lettuce salad with blue cheese and spinach ravioli. For entrees, we chose the bacon wrapped pork and leg of lamb. We finished with the chocolate ganache and hazelnut mousse cake. 

Unfortunately, the service really wasn't good or friendly. Our waiter never smiled and it took 16 minutes to get water on the table. Ultimately, we just ended up going to the bar (we were parched!). However, the guy bussing tables, refilling* water, and handing out bread was actually quite cheery and nice. Perhaps he should be promoted! 

It's a decent choice in San Francisco, but I've had better. Especially in this price range, I'll try somewhere else next time.
author: Kendra N.

description:
Definitely not the best French restaurant in the city. I'm French and I've had better, much better.
Our experience for Valentine's Day dinner was just ok. The food was ok (foie gras was not foie gras -- foie gras mousse maybe? And the chocolate pyramid dessert was very dry and bland), the service very slow (25min to get a plate of foie gras... what was going on?) and we could tell our waiter was not happy to be here that night (smiling never killed anyone). NOT honoring French food at all.
author: Morgan L.

description:
After having finished our meal, my husband and I were asked to move to another table if we wanted dessert. They wanted our table for a large party.  We told him politely that we didn't want to move since we were enjoying our table, we were still not accommodated. We paid the check and left. This is the most ridiculous thing I've heard after having already eaten $90 worth of food. Ever heard of planning better? Needless to say, we're not returning here. 
The explanation below by the owner/ manager is a lie since we had called ahead and they had told us that they're accepting walkins and that we don't need to make a reservation. Additionally, since clearly the large party had made prior reservations, then you should've planned better and seated us at a more appropriate table in the first place. Kicking us out for a large party is shameful.
author: S M.

description: Ive passed this place so many times i've lost count. My friend even lived across the street for a while and I never set foot in. Recently a group of us just wanted solid French fare and we came in pretty late. They almost didnt want to seat us but promising to be quick they let us in. Place was starting to quiet down but that wasnt our goal for ambiance., it was just get food in our belly. Split the charcuterie plate, lamb chops with potato gratin, prawns pastis and finally the gateau Basque and the cheese plate. Everything was solid. Our server was a very entertaining and friendly Frenchman as was the manager. They took really good care of us and got us fed and out of there in no time. Im so sad it took me so long to finally go in but im glad it happened. 4.3 stars
author: Kim N.

description: Service is terrible at this restaurant especially if you're non-white! We got seated as a party of two yet the wait staff was falling all over the 4 white couples who got seated much later than us. As a result we had to wait extra longer for service and our food. Not what I expect at an expensive San Francisco restaurant. It totally ruined our anniversary dinner celebration. I'll never go back to this restaurant even for a free meal.
author: Lee L.

description:
5 star food place.  
Went there for meeting.  We also have a meal for lunch.  I never eat there before.  It was delicious.  The server very nice. Professional polite.   And the food is the best.   A pricy place  yes.    But.  Worth it
author: Ford T.

description:
I've been to Fringale several times and it's always been a mixed reaction. 

This time, I left with an uncomfortable sense of being duped. For an entree I ordered the seabass. I am pretty sure the fish I got was not seabass. Or it was a liberal use of the word seabass applied to some other fish (I know seabass is a marketing name for some kind of toothfish).  Every time I've had seabass it's been light, flaky and delicious. This was a dense white fish, and very little flavor despite the lovely sauce it was in. I didn't eat much of it, and wasn't asked if there was a reason. 

The rest of the meal was fine.  The bread wasn't warm, which is always disappointing. The other dishes were very tasty. Nice wines by the glass. And a server with a delightful heavy French accent that makes everything seem better.
author: KJ A.

description: 5 Star Incredible Food, Service, and ambiance!!! I went with friends who were as impressed as I was.  The Frisée salad is one of my favorites, the freshest ingredients with delightful layers of flavor. The steak frites delicious and satisfying.  Hazelnut Mousse Devine decadence. Ravioli was rich and stupendous. Butter lettuce salad refreshingly delicious.  Chicken was succulent and the best my friend has ever had.  Creme brûlée was sublime.
author: Meghan J.

description:
OUI OUI OUI!!! OMG THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!!!

I can't wait to come back!

My buddy took me here for DINE ABOUT TOWN. It was the best choice ever! 

[ F O O D ]
[+] Calamari a la Pancha, it is one of the best calamari I have ever tasted! I will definitely order this again!
[+] Angele's Gateau Basque...I don't really like almond but this dessert was awesome!
[+] Braised Lamb shank...sooooo good, cooked to perfection! The meat falls right off, I didn't even need to use my knife.
[+] Bacon Wrapped Pork Tenderloin...omgah!! HEAVEN!
[+] Creme Brulee was good, not too sweet!

[ A M B I A N C E ]
[+] Very cute, romantic, petit restaurant
[+] Full Bar

[ S E R V I C E ]
[+] I forgot our server's name but he was very friendly. I love his accent. He is also very cute!

[ O V E R A L L ] 
[+] Great dining experience! I will definitely be back and try the duck confit and roasted rack of lamb! MERCI BEAUCOUP!!!
author: Tammy F.

description: I'm wrestling as to why I'm not giving this place 5 stars. I guess it's because it's next door to Cockscomb and that place always knocks my socks off. Fringale knocks my socks off 4 out of 5 times. It's actually really wonderful! It's in that perfect niche that's a dinner spot pre-Giants game and I love coming here several times each season. I'm particularly hooked on their bacon wrapped pork tenderloin...the best I've ever had! Fabulous! I also love the frisée salad with warm bacon dressing as well as the seafood basquaise and the petrale sole. The bread in this place is really memorable too! Fringale does it well and I've always found the service to be friendly and professional as well. One of the memorable things about this place to me is that there aren't many Giants fans in here. Usually my table is the only one...and they're full when I'm there. I take that to mean they have loyal clientele that comes frequently. They're not catering to my particular niche....as do many restaurants in this neighborhood that don't make it. Great job guys!
author: Jim M.

description:
Nice, small, intimate space.  Our group seemingly occupied half of the restaurant.  

A lot of good food to be had here, there were a few misses from some of the offerings that I tried, but I really enjoyed what I ordered:

Spicy Monterey calamari "a la plancha," with jalapenos, chorizo, piment d'espelette and olives.  This was extremely flavorful and one of the best calamari dishes I've had where the calamari wasn't deep fried.

Bacon wrapped pork tenderloin with braised Napa cabbage, onion, and apple marmalade.  It tasted even better than it sounds--very well presented to boot.  The pork tenderloin was seriously perfectly cooked!  Very tender and moist.  The whole dish was very flavorful, in fact, and all of the flavors married well together combining many savory flavors with some sweet as well.

I know I will find myself back here again soon revisiting these dishes.
author: Erich D.

description: The waitress spoke French which was a decent start. Turned out the food was excellent. Great service also. One disappointment, ordered a $40 bottle of wine and it was a miniature bottle. Didn't see that coming from the menu.
author: Espound ..

description:
On today's edition of Work lunch, we travel to France. Not real France, but rather Fringale - the France of SF.

And on the atmosphere and feeling it certainly executes, offering accents, great service, and I think even escargot (maybe it's seasonal?). Literally this small, cozy place was like being transported to France. The restaurant was surprisingly not crowded for lunch and it was easy to hold conversation. The service was a mix of attentive and patient, even throwing a joke in to amuse our party. The service is certainly where Fringale stands out. 

Anyway, no one in our party ordered snails. But, I'm certain everyone wants to know - the food:
I'll preface this my saying I'm a pretty picky vegetarian and usually nosh on salads for lunch so I can't speak to the meat here. 
-My eyes lit up when I saw the basket of baguette and varied breads. There is nothing like a good baguette, especially if it is warm. Someone else in our party said this, but I certainly mimic that sentiment. Unfortunately, I eagerly grabbed a piece of baguette and it was, dare I say it, stale. It was not warmed up and I actually left it on my plate. 
-I ended up ordering the heirloom tomato salad which tasted very fresh with the tomatoes and goat cheese. The cheese was creamy enough to add a great bite and creamy texture to every bite.
