-Our table got some fries (or whatever they're properly termed at fancy restaurants) to share. The fries were thin cut and not overly oily.
-Others in our party ordered meat, and as a vegetarian, I'm not one to describe it. They enjoyed their meals and actually the cut of meat was quite large.

Overall, come here for the atmosphere. A little piece of France in SF. 


P.S. (like dessert as a little extra) We were all stuffed, but I heard good things about the dessert.
author: Libby J.

description:
I've lived near Fringale for the past 6 years so have eaten here several times.  I'm always relatively disappointed with the experience.

I'll start positive - the food is quite good.  I love the braised veal short ribs with leaks, potato galette, carrots & mushroom fricassee.  The meat is so tender it falls right off the bone, and the demi-glace sauce is fabulous.  I also love their traditional sautéed prawns in Pastis appetizer - the sauce is so good you'll finish it up with all the bread.  I am not a big fan of the roasted rack of lamb with Gruyere potato gratin, haricots verts, and rosemary sauce - it has too much citris flavor.  The french fries ("frites") are very good, especially with a side of sea salt.  I was very disappointed with the sea scallops in potato purse - only 3 scallops for $14, and we didn't even eat the fried potato wraps, and I don't recall seeing any piquillo peppers.

Fringale loses its stars on service.  We had to wait 30 minutes past our reservation time to be seated, and then waited another 30 minutes to get any water.  I had to flag down a server to ask for bread and water.  I also ordered a double espresso, which never arrived (until I ordered it a second time).  Anytime we needed something, it was nearly impossible to catch a server as they were flying by.  And, at the end, they included a 20% gratuity.  This was particularly annoying since they added the 20% on the total bill, which included tax as well as a bottle of wine.  Very unacceptable and undeserved.
author: Greg B.

description: I usually don't write reviews, but was spurred to by some that I read here. This is perhaps the best restaurant in San Francisco that has been around for as long as it has that can still be called "underrated". It is a 5 star Bistro. I have eaten here a few times over years, and this is restaurant is French in all ways, including  service. If you are an oversensitive San Franciscan or a Bay Area helicopter mom you probably should just go elsewhere. If your a New Yorker or a Bourdain-ophile, and you miss Les Halles, then go here for a step up in food. The service, food and demeanor is authentic French. The service is professional, not cold, and if you talk to the staff about things that are not able to be answered from reading your menu they really do interact nicely and can tell you about things from the preparation to the history of the dish. The wine list is outstanding but limited, but they allow you to bring your own for a corkage fee (which they will waive if you buy another bottle from them). We shared 3 entrees and 3 plates, followed up by two desserts. All were top notch. If you love Bistro food, or miss your fantastic little restaurant in Paris, this is a place you should go.
author: Joseph S.

description:
Came here on a Friday evening for Father's Day dinner.  

Their Yelp page said not good for kids but they didn't say anything about well behaved toddlers!  We had a 16 mo boy with us and not only were they accommodating but they interacted with him too which was really nice to see.

Appetizers:
Calamari- Cooked perfectly and super flavorful
Watercress Salad- I'm not sure how I feel about eating salad where the main component is pears.  I would pass on this
Scallop- Small portion but the scallops were perfectly cooked and it went well with the potato crisp thingy
Prawns- Nice flavor

Mains:
Steak- The red wine butter sauce was fabulous!  It added great flavor to the steak.  The fries were nicely cooked and not too greasy.
Pork- TENDER.  The Napa cabbage salad was good too.

The food was good and the staff were friendly and attentive.
author: Linda N.

description: Best kept secret. Food is always perfection. Why there is no line, I think because new techies in the neighborhood only go to hype. This is a rock solid gem through and through.
author: Lily H.

description:
I will make this simple. Call somebody you love. Invite them to dinner. Take them to Fringale. This is an SF gem, almost too good to be true. Great atmosphere, small dining room, great service from very knowledgeable and kind staff. And the food is incredible. My favorite dish is the roquefort, spinach and pine nut ravioli. The cheese plates are delicious... last time I had a fourme d'ambert that I can still taste months later.

Considering the quality of cuisine and service, is
Basque restaurant is well-priced. My favorite restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Drew W.

description:
My friend and I went here for SF Restaurant Week. We were happy to get reservations here at a reasonable time. the restaurant is on the small side, but it creates a very intimate atmosphere. It would be perfect for a date. The service was also prompt and very friendly. 

Now for the food! The bread and appetizers that came first were fresh and enjoyable. Our calamari dish was exquisite. It is a must order. We didn't expect there to be so much, but we finished it. The sauce from the calamari also paired well with the bread. 

For the main course I ordered the petrale sole and my friend ordered the lamb. I was a little disappointed they weren't offering the sea bass anymore, but the fish was very moist and the risotto and artichoke sauce paired nicely. The crispy edges have the fish a nice touch. My friend's lamb shank was amazing. The meat fell off the bone and she was kind enough to share some. 

We were both extremely full before dessert came, but we couldn't resist! The creme brûlée with vanilla beans was very creamy and smooth, while the chocolate gourmand was still hot when served. The chocolate paired very well with the raspberry sauce and ice cream.

Overall the food and service was impeccable. My friend and I enjoyed our experience here and would love to come back!
author: Angela L.

description:
Wonderful time at Fringale! 

Great location with parking lot right across the street. 

Food is awesome! We ordered foie gras, salad of the day special, duck confit, seabass and with the cheese plate as dessert. Everything came out fastastic.  Love the French dining atmosphere, casual, relaxing, yet with high quality food and service. We will come back for sure! merci beaucoup!!
author: Shell J.

description: We had a very enjoyable evening here. The star of the evening was definitely the duck confit. So good. My calamari appetizer was a little under seasoned and I expected more chorizo flavor. Adding a little salt punched up the flavors. Desserts sounded so good that we actually had two, the hazelnut/almond mousse cake, and the tart tatin. Both were delicious. The place is really packed, but once we sat down, very pleasant. Service was very efficient if a little brusque, just as if you were really in Paris. All in all, a great little neighborhood bistro.
author: Judy D.

description:
Compared to other good restaurants in the city, it's easier to get reservations here at a reasonable time.  And the food is very good.
- Sea scallops en croute (5/5) - perfectly cooked scallops wrapped in a thin slice of potato.  Extremely good.
- Steamed mussels (4/5) - much more vinegary broth than other mussels we've had, but still really tasty.
- Fries (5/5) - these fries are really good, even better than McDonalds
- Coq au vin (4/5)
- Mousse cake (5/5)
author: Simon L.

description:
Fringale gets 5 stars and they deserve all of them, if not more. I moved to the neighborhood 9 months ago and have been at least once a month for lunches and tried a number of menu items. I typically eat at the bar where Jean-Marie himself attends to our hunger needs and he is great. Whether he's dealing with a full bar/restaurant or having a one on one on a slow day, he does not let a glass go empty or empty plate linger. The other waiters also do their part to help and are very nice and attentive as well.

Speaking of empty plates, that's the only kind of plate I've ever sent back. Thankfully they serve bread with every meal because it would be awkward seeing me lick the plate clean. The mixture of flavors, quality of ingredients, plate creativity and portion sizes for the price are spot on. 

Favorite appetizers: calamari "a la plancha", beef carpaccio and sea scallops
Favorite dinner/lunch plates: Basque tuna burger (so good), rack of lamb and seabass

Look forward to the next visit and keep up the good work!
author: German L.

description:
I didn't dislike Fringale, but unlikely to return again. Nothing quite stood out, so wasn't worth the price.

Cute decor, very bistro-like, very cozy.  French-basque cuisine and very authentically french staff. 

We ordered:

- roquefort cheese spinach ravioli with pine nuts - 4 stars
- traditional duck confit (something they are known for) - 3 stars
- seafood basquais - 3 stars
- pommes frites with aioli - 2 stars
- pinot noir
- bordeaux
- cabernet franc
- laurent pierrer champagne

I think our bill plus tip came out to $150+ for 2 people, which I would have rather spent at a dozen other restaurants. 

ravioli was good. a little too much spinach but I'm a huge fan of spinach and pine nuts so no major complaints here.

Duck confit was dry, not savory. lentils had no flavoring. 
basquais was also "ok"
fries were under seasoned. The aioli wasn't very dippable - more the texture of soft butter, so it was hard to get onto the fries.  Aioli did not add much in terms of flavor. We left 80% of fries untouched, which is pretty unusual for me b/c i love potato products =]

wines were ok. my bf did not like his pinot noir and that's usually his go-to for seafood. Can't go wrong with laurent pierrer but it's also a $18 glass of wine.
author: Alice Z.

description:
Pomme Frites weren't great. They're all fry and very little potato. 

But I got a meal sized portion of the Roquefort & spinach ravioli, toasted pine nuts, basil & Papillon cheese. It was very good. Very rich and creamy, but also well balanced. 

The service was pleasant, it's a small restaurant and very conducive to talking / business meeting. Overall, a good spot. Only reason I'm knocking it down to a 3 star is that for the price, Marlowe's is next door.
author: Dimple B.

description: came by for dinner while waiting or scuba class next door. friendly service, solid food, strong martini, great stuffed olive
author: Long C.

description:
I don't know if it's because my friend and I came here on a whim, but I was surprised by how fantastic everything was. The decor was simple yet elegant, and the service was unbelievably warm and friendly. Best of all, the food was amazing:

Heirloom Tomato Salad: Fresh fruit (yes, tomatoes are technically fruit) combined with a homemade dressing and just the right smattering of cheese. The colors and presentation alone make this dish worth ordering, but it's the explosion of flavors and textures in your mouth that will leave you gushing about it to your co-workers the next day.

Roasted Chicken with Pearl Couscous: What do you get when you perfectly roast a chicken so that the meat melts in your mouth, the skin crackles when you bite it and the flavorful jus seeps into the equally well-cooked couscous and vegetables? A comfort food dish with a dash of European sophistication that reminds you why this most common of meats is a perennial favorite.

Hazelnut Almond Mousse Cake: Hazelnuts and almonds are proof that nature knows best. A dessert that combines these two flavors? Proof that the pastry chef knows best. The cake was moist and creamy without being overwhelming rich. We polished this off within minutes.

Pear Martini: My treat to myself after a long day at work. Custom-made and perfectly mixed. Generously portioned too.

One of my clients is what you would call a "French blueblood" who's dined at pretty much every French restaurant worth knowing in the world. While discussing the best French spots in SF, I was delighted to find that we had the same opinion of Fringale: It's a great, casual bistro for authentic French home-cooking dressed up with just the right amount of flair to make it an impressive date spot too.
author: Josephine L.

description:
went in a group of 10 so I found the restaurant rather small and we were seated awkwardly together in kind of along the sofa seats with a long table that makes it impossible for people who sat on the sofa to get out ...

anyway, food-wise

- Crab Napoleon was awesome as well as the duck confit and  Seafood basquaise
- dessert :: MUST HAVE creme brulee - hands down the best in SF :D 

also the server was so nice ... so we got free creme brulee since one person in our group ordered something else for dessert but the server got him creme brulee instead ... which means that they only served freshly made creme brulee! which is good!
author: Sarah T.

description:
A. Food - meh
*4 stars - Beef carpaccio - fresh and delicious
*2 stars - Sauteed Corvina seabass - fish cooked nicely but the other flavors were too heavy handed.  No balance.

B. Service - 3 stars - pleasant but not really friendly nor welcoming. No one smiled and everyone seemed very rushed.

C. Ambiance - 4 stars - Cozy.  Sound level was good, not noisy. Able to have nice conversation with dining companions without having to shout.

Overall Guide
5 Stars - have already made next RSVP
4 Stars - definitely returning
3 stars - would return but not first choice
2 stars - would only return if friends insisted
1 star  -  nope
author: Lille L.

description: First time here.  Nice room. Somewhat crowded, and got noisy as it filled up. Very good service and food.  Would come back.
author: Ken A.

description:
I came here for a business dinner, and it was an impressive experience.

The service was outstanding, as all of them know their beer, wine, and what to pair.  They were also very accommodating with my lactose allergy, where they substituted sorbet for all of their creamy selections.

For the entrees, I tried their calamari (delicious), and sea bass (fantastic).  The atmosphere was cozy, appropriate for a date night or business.  The seatings can get crowded, so I'd definitely make reservation.
author: Sam L.

description:
I tried Fringale with a group of friends for SF Restaurant Week. I had the calamari, lamb shank, and crème brulee option. The food was fantastic. The calamari was perfectly battered, the lamb shank just fell off the bone and the crème brulee was creamy and light. My friends thoroughly enjoyed their dinners as well. The big hit for the night was the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin. There was a moment where I was afraid that my friends would lick their plates.

The only downside was getting to the restaurant. Currently most of 4th Street is torn up for construction so it's a definite challenge to get to the restaurant but worth it once you make it.
author: Makela C.

description:
Went on bastille day, and had the three course dinner offer for $42. It was a wonderful bargain for what you got, so don't let the prices get out. For the appetizer, I had the Onion Tart, which was on a very light, flakey crust. It was filling, but small enough to make me want for dinner. 

My main complaint about the duck that I had ordered, which had a lovely cherry port sauce, was that the duck was too under-done. So rare that it was chewy, instead of being just right. I almost wanted to send it back to be cooked some more, however, there were a few pieces that were cooked perfectly. It was served over mashed potatoes and string veggies, which were lovely with the meal. 

For dessert, a lovely almond gateau with a creme anglais. A very filling dinner, that I was happy to share. A nice dinner and ambiance.
author: Danielle L.

description: The service here is ok.  They were able to accommodate a larger party last minute.  We didn't get seated until later since the party before us was taking a long time.  The food is pretty good here.  The napoleon is the best appetizer and is better than the beet salad or scallops, which were not bad.  The pork tenderloin, sea bass and the braised beef were all excellent.  The chicken was ok.  The food was really solid here and I'd recommend it to anyone.  It's also close and convenient so I'd definitely come back.
author: Chris L.

description:
I'm very impressed with these place, one of the best lunches that I have had in years.
Started with this dish:  Monterey calamari "a la plancha", jalapenos, chorizo, piment d'Espelette & olives 
I love calamari, these dish was spectacular!
Had a great wine with this dish, Markus Cellars Chardonnay, it was the perfect pairing with the calamari.
It was a very well balanced Chardonnay, and the best one, I've had in a long time.
For my main course, I had: Onglet steak a la Parisienne, French fries, haricots verts, & red wine shallots sauce.
The meat was cooked perfectly, very flavorful and so tender, and the portion was very good.
Finished this great meal with an Underberg.
I believe for what you receive this place is great value.
author: Jimmy W.

description:
Based on the ratings, I had high hopes for this restaurant. My friends and I were extremely disappointed by our restaurant week experience here however. It began with the menu, when my friend and I were saddened by the fact that they swapped out the sea bass (listed online as the menu option) with sole. I decided that it wouldn't hurt to ask, so I checked with the waiter on whether the sea bass was still offered, or if there's only the sole. He responded grumpily that he would check with the chef. Probably ten minutes later, he comes back and in an annoyed voice asks what we would like to order. I tried to confirm whether the sea bass was offered, and he snapped back at me stating that they reserve the right to change the menu if they want, and said he would ask the chef (I guess he didn't ask the first time?). This time he returned, glared at me, and said yes the chef can accommodate our requests and make sea bass. It was a rather sour start to the meal, and my friends and I may have had a better experience just leaving and going somewhere else at that point. But to our own mistake, we stayed and ordered quite a few dishes.

Appetizers:
Ravioli: The ravioli was rather disappointing in taste. The somewhat pungent cheese of their choice overpowered the rest of the flavors, making for a bland ravioli with a strong tasting cheese.
Calamari: I didn't have any of the calamari, but I heard that it was pretty good.

Entrees:
Sea bass: Their sea bass portion was fair, but the flavoring of the overall dish was mediocre. While a decent dish, I found it overpriced for what they prepared.
Duck Confit: Their duck, considered it was duck confit, was surprisingly dry. I was also surprised that they didn't crisp the skin or anything either. The lentils with the dish were prepared well, but the duck unfortunately made the dish disappointing as well.
Pork tenderloin: This was easily the best dish of the three. The meat was tender and flavorful, and bacon on the dish of course made it all the better.

Dessert: The highlight of the meal! All in pretty good portion sizes as well (besides the creme brulee in a small bowl rather than a tradition ramekin)
Creme brulee: Their creme brulee was pretty good, especially since they used a bit of vanilla bean to accentuate the flavor.
Warm chocolate gourmand: As a pretty big chocolate eater, i loved this. Flavorful, and being flourless definitely did not make the cake any different from my expectations.
Gateau Basque: I love almonds, so this almond torte with custard cream was great as well.

Overall, the meal was an average meal (~3 stars) with -2 stars for service but +1 star for letting us still order sea bass. I think for the price though, SF offers many other options that I would likely have preferred. Perhaps I ordered the wrong dishes, or caught the waiter on a bad day, but the service was really appalling. I'll take my meal that I'm paying for WITHOUT the slamming down of plates please. Also, be prepared for rather tight seating arrangements at the restaurant, but street parking on the Friday night we went to was ample and cheap (~$2-3 for 3 hours somehow?)
author: Michael L.

description: This is a near perfect restaurant. Ideal size dining room where you can have a conversation. Excellent service and unpretentious yet delicious French food.
author: randy b.

description: Very strange experience. We got there right at 5:30. The front desk staff was super frosty. If we didn't have a gift certificate , I would have walked out. They looked at us like homeless people. We were appropriately dressed. He asked if we had a reservation. I gave my name. Once we were seated the waiter tried to chat us up to smooth things over a bit but no apologies. The decor was quite dated and we had a gorgeous view of construction. I ordered the rib eye which was more done than medium rare. It did not look like a rib eye cut of meat. More like flat iron steak. The rest of the meal was average. Nothing  extraordinary. With a plethora of great restaurants who needs the attitude
author: J J.

description:
Cute French place with great service and yummy food. I don't agree with the romantic/intimate atmosphere rating, though. I think it's more casual and homey. Lots of older couples and families when I went. Maybe the scene changes towards the end of the week. Nonetheless, a solid place for a nice sit-down dinner and wine in SOMA.

++ Crab napoleon was delicious!
+ Short ribs had good flavor, love the accompaniments, wish there was more polenta though
+ Hazelnut cake = soooo yummy!
o Calamari was good but not amazing
- Warm chocolate cake was underwhelming, but maybe my expectations were too high
author: Sherry L.

description:
Some friends and I came here for the Dine About Town menu last night which we all enjoyed.  The service provided was great, our server was very attentive and professional. I'll list the things we had w/ rating:

  Spinach & basil ravioli w/ roquefort sauce - 5 star - SO GOOD
  Seafood basquaise - 4 stars 
  Roasted beet salad - 4 stars
  Bacon wrapped pork tenderloin - 3.5 stars - was very tender but the combined flavors of the smoky bacon and balsamic created a bbq sauce like flavor.
  Warm chocolate Gourmand 4 stars
  Mme. Angèle's Gateau Basque 4 stars

The overall meal was very pleasant, I'd like to try a few other things from their regular menu.  Good recommendation for french cuisine, all the staff were french as well.
author: Spencer W.

description:
The restaurant is super busy but I will give them 2 stars because they accommodated 10 of us with a day notice. The downfall for that even though our reservation was at 8 pm..we finally sat at our table at 8.45 pm.. Most of us had to wait outside due to the small corridor and crowed bar from another group of 9 people waiting to sit like ourselves.
I am giving two stars not because of the food. The food was exceptional but unfortunately I will not be going back. The reason is that they failed to provide us with a receipt (see attached pic) they gave us a handwritten receipt! for a bill of $557! When I argued and asked for a receipt they just made this copy (turnign around our credit cards info..so that you will not be able to identify the restaurant as well.

IRS scam and I was sorry to participate in that. Such a good restaurant should be able to provide regular machine receipts.  Unbelievable in our times to support businesses like that so I am not going back. I pay my taxes they should pay theirs.

Shame..Fringale..Good luck.
author: Sissy P.

description: Went to this restaurant when it first opened, in the early 90's. Food was great back then, and it still is. Very glad this restaurant has lasted. Had some wonderful spinach ravioli as an appetizer, and steak frites for the main course. Both done professionally and both delicious. The only disappointment was the service. It was very hurried, very un-French. It seemed like their main concern was to close up shop and go home. This marred an otherwise good experience.
author: Partho G.

description:
We came here for a large birthday party. 

Some people from next table were eavesdropping and decided to pick a fight at the end of our dinner. I guess the type of clientele that visits here are more of a certain kind.... And dislike people who express their freedom of speech. 

We have of course been to many nice restaurants over the years but this one by far is not great for young professionals. 

Food was decent.

Stick to their wine. Some of us are whiskey drinkers and made the mistake of ordering whiskey cocktail.
author: Danika Z.

description:
Fringale used to be my go to place until this last visit.  Some of the dishes were really off, especially the mussel.
It only tasted strong vinegar and sands.
When my boyfriend and I told one of the waiters the dish tasted only vinegar, he simply told us they use the vinegar and left.  We're all aware of the dish has some vinegar, but it does not mean you could dump vinegar all over it to spoil the dish, and having customer eat sands inside mussel was not certainly something you would not do.  Alas, we lost one restaurant in the neighborhood.
author: Kahori M.

description: Classic menu and great service. Came on a Wednesday night and had the beef carpaccio, bacon wrapped pork tenderloin, and hazelnut & roasted almond mousse cake. Loved the onion and apple sauce with the napa lettuce in the main dish.
author: Em S.

description:
Where to begin, making reservations is a breeze either through open table or by phone (not sure if Yelp does it). Be mindful, the dress code is Business Casual and not Casual as it is disclose in the business information pane (otherwise you will feel out of place).

Parking is a pain if there is a Giants game going on (street parking), otherwise is rather easy to find an open spot. The place has a nice layout and decor, the restaurant was packed considering it was a Tuesday night (I took that as a good sign that the food was really good).

They showed us to our table and were immediately greeted by the server. I was concerned that there was only one server for the whole establishment on a busy night, there was another individual helping out (I think he was the bus boy). I would off knock points off for the lack of attention (he will check with us now and then, but we had to get his attention if we needed something), however, it would be unfair considering he was taking care of the whole dining area. Be aware that the drinks here are strong, we order a long island ice tea and a margarita, it makes you wonder if you can get some flavor or juice with your alcohol (I did not mind as much as my wife did, she end up getting a glass of red wine, while I enjoyed my alcohol).

We order two appetizers, the Heirloom Tomato salad and the calamari. Both were nicely done, salad was fresh and the acid provided by the tomato gave the dish a nice balance. I was impressed by how well the calamari was done, there was no rubbery feel to the squid and the seasoning was light, the black olives gave the dish a bold taste without overpowering the dish.

My wife order the sea bass, I had a bite and the crispiness of the outer layer of the fish was very good while maintaining the tenderness of the fish on the inside. It went well with the sauce and rest of the dish. I ordered the seafood combination and it was very well done, the sauce gave it a nice balance thou it could be less sweet. The deserts were very good, apple tart and hazelnut moose, we liked the hazelnut best out of the two deserts.

In closing, don't let the area where the restaurant is located fool you (lots of construction going on), the staff is friendly as long as they are not too busy (towards the end of the night, less patrons better service). Food is very good, drinks are too strong for people not a costumed to having more alcohol in their drinks than mixture. I will definitely go back, you feel like your money is well spent.
author: Daniel A.

description:
I am not a lover of French food. I would have starved on my recent trip to France if it weren't  for the abundance of croissants and coffee. So how did I end up at a very french restaurant? A friend of course dragged me there and because I love her I didn't instantly throw a tantrum when she sent me the reservation info.

The food at Fringale was delicious. I had the salmon served on a bed of sautéed veggies in a tomato cream sauce and my friend had the bacon wrapped pork loin with an added side of the most cheesy, buttery, heavenly potatoes. All served by our very French waiter, who gave us great service and a little flirting. 

I unfortunately am not eating bread at the moment. Yes, I'm insane. So I can't comment on the taste of the crusty bread and creamy butter that was placed on the table or the dessert menu that featured creme brulee and apple tartan and several other things I mustered all my will power not to order.

Overall I enjoyed Fringale and plan to return when me and bread are on speaking terms again.
author: Imoye F.

description: Hubby and I went to Fringale for New Year's Eve dinner.  We chose Fringale because the prix fixe price was fairly reasonable for New Year's Eve (Around $75.00 each w/o alcohol, compared to the $290.00 each w/o alcohol for the other restaurants we considered).  I truly do not expect very much from prix fixe holiday meals because of the other times I have dined out for such occasions; food is typically mediocre and overpriced.  Not the case at Fringale.  The food was great and the service was exceptional.  The only complaint I have was the overly quick service that made us feel a bit rushed.  However, because of the scheduled seatings for New Year's Eve - I get it.  So, I will definitely return and try the regular menu.
author: Theresa C.

description:
This is another gem thats tucked far away from the typical hustle bustle of SF.  Don't let the quaint outer appearances fool you.  Once you enter the door, you're greeted by the warmth of aromatic cuisine, dim lights, and mellow chatter.  While the space may seem tight, there was enough room to comfortably seat sixteen people for a business dinner.  The service was polite and unintrusive, and the atmosphere was very conducive to conversation.

I started with endive and watercress salad.  The lettuce was crisp and ice cold; a good sign of things to come.  The tartness from the vinagrette dressing was perfectly offset by the richness of the goatcheese and the sweetness of the candied walnuts.  The salad proved to be impressive, and was followed by my roasted rack of lamb.  This was cooked to a perfect medium rare and served with potatoes gratin.  The lamb had a nice smokey flavor, and was a succulent medium rare.  The pungentness from the lamb tasted great in combination with the rosemary crusted seasoning.  The potatoes were quite tasty as well.

Overall, my dining experience here was positive, so I will leave this as four stars.  It took a while to get our food, but we had an exceptionally large party (for the capacity of this place), so don't let that deter you.
author: David C.

description:
Everything was just okay; nothing really spectacular, but nothing really bad. The food was also okay, nothing really memorable. 

We were greeted very nicely at the door. Our server, however, was a bit...abrupt, toeing the line of rude.

So...meh.

Edit: I'm updating this to four stars because the owner contacted me regarding my concerns about the service at Fringale. I'm willing to go back and give this another try, as I do believe good service adds a lot to the dining experience. I will update again when I've gone back.
author: Evelyn C.

description: Portions were much larger than we anticipated. Food was all exceptional. We enjoyed the calamari which was not fried but fresh. The beet salad was the special and came with candied walnuts, goat cheese, and both red and golden beets. Lastly we had the duck which very tender.
author: Roz B.

description:
I hadn't been here in years, and now I'm regretting all the meals I should have eaten. Today I had a perfectly executed tomato salad, followed by a divine lamb shank. I also sampled my companion's shrimp pastis, the sauce from which I would gladly have licked off of the plate, or possibly the floor. The service was personal and warm.

Highly recommended.
author: Philip S.

description:
It's been a while since I visited Fringale so this review isn't as comprehensive as I'd like. All I remember is that the service was fantastic (polite and not overbearing) and the parking was a dream for SF. If you're looking for delicious French food and don't want to deal with the hassle of scarce parking spots and hills, it's reason enough to go to Fringale! Also makes an absolutely cute date night place.

(+) Chicken breast with couscous - the tender chicken breast lay on a generous bed of pearly couscous. It's hearty and satisfying, but not in a grease-filled, heavy kind of way. It's just really well-prepared and enjoyable. Pairs super well with a glass of white.
(+) Roasted rack of lamb - tender, the meat flaked right off the bone. After I attacked this all that was left was the clean bone. It's a simply prepared and presented dish but the lamb is very flavorful, the potatoes are creamy, and the haricots verts add a nice crunch. Pairs super well with a glass of red.

Their menu doesn't seem to change much, which is also a testament to their dishes being a hit with diners. It is a little pricey, so if you're curious about it and can wait, Fringale usually participates in Dine About Town. You can get a great taste of it then.
author: Brandy A.

description:
Everything I had off the dine about town menu was delicioius! The calamari was fresh and seasoned with jalepenos and red peppers. It was excellent!

I had the duck entrée which was crispy on the outside and fell off gve bone.  The lentils went well with the duck. 

Desert was really good, not overpowering. We tried the hazelnut cake and chocolate grom something.
author: Ken L.

description:
A simple and uncomplicated dining experience.....however really pleasant doing good food and with attention to detail and timing.

The menu is well balanced and it is hard to imagine many people's particular palette preferences are substantially missed .....and, yet the menu is not so expansive that one struggles with indecision. 

Four of us dined and 'taste tested' each others...on the starters or 'Les Entrees' the table was split on whether it was the Sea Scallops in Potato Puree or the Sautéed Prawns in Pas tis....and the other two dishes were also liked, the Spicy Monterey Calamari and the Assisette de Characuterie....so four out of four on the starters!

For mains or 'Les Plats' we enjoyed the Seafood Basquaise.....two of us had this dish and loved it....and we could recommend the Sea Bass and the Roasted Chicken Breast....and the side was simple, yet good too!

Wine, well the red was a reasonable quaffer however perhaps understated the food.

This was a good food and real dining experience, and all this, and it was still solid value for money.
author: Mick A.

description: Before going to have lunch at Fringale, I checked out the menu and had already decided I'd be ordering the Seafood Basquaise. I did, however, intend to order it without the tuna since I cannot remember a time when I've had fully cooked tuna that was not dry or overcooked. Thank goodness I forgot to order without the tuna because I would've done myself a terrible disservice had I done so. The Seafood Basquaise was cooked to perfection, including the tuna!!! Flaky, moist and delicious! How can that be so?? Every bite was full of flavor and perfectly tender! Take me back! And for dessert we had a lovely creme brûlée that was perfectly creamy and sweet. Seriously...ridiculously delicious. I'm ready to go back now. Thanks. Bye
author: Sarah C.

description: Fringale is my number one French restaurants in the city. I always enjoyed dinning there. The staff, the atmosphere, the food (of course), and the prices are FANTASTIC! I'll give three thumbs up, if I had a third thumb... :-) I have been going there for years or as far as I can remember it. I would give them 6 stars, not just 5...
author: Victor K.

description:
I wouldn't go so far as calling this a destination spot, but for what it is (a neighborhood Bistro), I think it does it's job incredibly.

The service is good and the food is prepared well. There isn't anything on the menu that's particularly innovative (or you couldn't find anywhere else), but what I tried was really good.

I had the rib-eye steak frites which was delicious. It was really tender and cooked to my requested medium rare perfectly. The shallot butter on top was really tasty as well, adding a nice richness and savory taste on top of the already flavorful steak. 

The frites were okay. While I would have preferred them to be a little more crispy, they tasted great with the aoili that I requested on the side. The aoili was really good, just a hint of garlic and a touch of tang. It was quite thick though (as if it were just straight up mayo), but I actually liked it that way.

The desert was pretty good. I tried the Pain Perdu (bread pudding with chocolate and bananas). It was moist and chocolatey, with the flavor of banana lingering throughout.  

Not sure if I'd go out of my way to come back, but if I were in the area, I would most certainly know where to go to have some really good French cuisine.
author: Jeffrey J.

description: Great food, wine, and service. The restaurant is small and not well ventilated. Go on a good weather day and you'll be fine. Prices are also very reasonable.
author: Lily Y.

description:
This place is fine, and perhaps this review is that my expectations were high and everything was fine. The service was pleasant and unobtrusive. The frisée salad was fine but I've had better in the city. My fish was cooked well but the sauce was not very good and the vegetables in it-peas, artichokes-all presumably fresh, had virtually no flavor as they were stewed in the sauce which was just not very good. And. French food-it's all about the sauce. 

My dining companion enjoyed her chicken more than I did my fish and, if she yelped she would probably give 4 stars.  The atmosphere is hard to describe-not romantic and not energetic. The whole experience-food and atmosphere-were disappointing.
author: S Blair P.

description:
Nice place to be calm and in relax and, of course , to eat some food. Service formal and medium level of professional skills. Medium level also for food quality.
If you are around it and you like eat at a table
You have find it.
author: Max G.

description:
Came here last year for dine about town and was pleased, especially with the seafood bas quakes. Came again list year cuz I thought it would be a repeat of last year's amazing ness, but to be honest, I was a bit disappointed.

Spinach Roquefort ravioli, spinach felt like it wasn't cooked enough! Or too cooked.

The entree that I had though was delicious, I think it was cod on a bed of creamy red pepper risotto? Flavors were perfect and fish was perfectly tender.

Creme brûlée was meh (& I usually love crème brûlée! It's my favorite dessert), but I think it was over cooked. The middle was good and gooey appropriate, but the sides were too firm. The chocolat gourmand though was perfection though. So warm and filling!
author: Christina C.

description:
I had my wedding dinner at Fringale in October and it was awesome! Being French, it was important for me to find a place with great French food and ambiance. My husband and I tried many French restaurants in the city and Fringale was really the one that stood out for us. And as a bonus, most of the staff is French speaking. Usually hard to get it all! 

Jean-Marie, the owner, was great throughout the whole planning process, from the flowers to the layout of the tables, to the menu/drink selection for cocktail and dinner, to the wedding cake, etc. He was very flexible and responsive to our requests and that was very much appreciated. 

The day of our wedding, the decor was perfect, food tasted amazing and service was impeccable! Hats off to the staff for being able to manage so well at max capacity! Everybody had a great time, loved how intimate it was, and kept raving about the rack of lamb so tender that it melted in their mouth, the tasty duck confit falling off the bone, or the seabass cooked and seasoned to perfection. 

Don't wait any longer; treat yourself for a wonderful dinner at Fringale!
author: Alex B.

description: San Francisco restaurant week is our favorite time of the year in the city! Excellent choices on the prix fixe menu. Service is always nice. It's more of casual French Bistro. Highly recommend.
author: Sridevi K.

description: The waiters here are authentic French people
author: Thomas C.

description: I have loved Fringale for many years.  My favorite dish is their duck confit with lentils.  It is exceptional. I also order the salad Lyonnaise with poached egg.  This is a wonderful way to begin your meal.  The slightly bitter frisee served with a tangy dressing, crispy bacon bits and a poached egg is delightful.  The restaurant is very small, tables are quite close to one another, but it doesn't distract from the delicious food and efficient service.
author: Lilikoikitchen M.

description: I had the pasta. It was ok. I asked if I could add a chicken breast and the waiter said no. I asked him to check and he came back telling me  the pasta dish that is $20 would be $35 with a chicken breast. Ridiculous, a whole chicken dinner is $23. The waiters are not friendly at all no chit chat. It was get get in and out quickly. Wouldn't go back.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday dinner on a Saturday night. Friend was able to make a reservation for 11 people at a relatively normal dinner time! The restaurant was on the small side though, I think a party any larger would have been really difficult. We were already squished trying to fit our group in, we ended up sitting at a long table but the tables on one end were right against the wall so it was very difficult to get in and out. Staff was pretty nice about it though and pulled tables out before and after our meal to make it slightly easier.

I ordered the duck confit. Potatoes and bacon were especially good, lentils were okay. The duck was really good and it definitely wasn't one of those times that you have to deal with all the tiny bones that ducks have. Portion size was not too bad, I was able to finish my food and was decently full afterwards.
author: Sophie Y.

description:
My friend and I came here Thursday, June 10 for Dine About Town.  We had a 6pm reservation (booked through opentable.com) but due to a parking attending locking keys in a car, we were unable to get our car out of the lot.  Knowing we would be late, I called the restaurant explaining the situation to the male who picked the phone and was then passed off to another male who said he we may or may not get seated at a table once we got there, either that or we'll have to sit at the bar.  As we arrived 20 minutes late, there were many tables available.

FOOD:
*Steamed PEI Mussels ($17) - Not bad.  The mussels were had a heavy amount of garlic, shallots, and a vinaigrette like sauce.  Although the mussels were flavorful, they were tiny!!

*Marinated Bay Scallops - *GAG* I hate wasting food so I forced myself to eat the scallops.  The scallops were cooked enough to be slightly cooked but still gave off that raw feeling and had a tangy taste to it.  Sadly, the best part of the appetizer was the small salad that came with it.

*Filet Mignon - I ordered the meat medium rare, but it came out medium to well.  I've had filet mignon on many occasions and even though I'm not a meat eater, I enjoy eating a piece of filet.  However, this didn't taste like a filet at all - the meat was not tender and chewy!  I enjoyed the string beans and fries that came as sides - that was the best part of my entrée.  

*Crème Brulee - The best part of my meal was the dessert.  The top was perfectly crisped while the content was sweet but not overwhelmingly sweet.

SERVICE:
Our waiter was not friendly and lacked social and customer service skills.  Not once did I see a smile on his face nor do I remember him checking to see if everything is okay with our table.  I would categorize Fringale as a nicer, somewhat classier restaurant and I'm sure that's how they perceive themselves.  However, good service should obviously come with that perception and they're really lacking in that department.

PARKING:
Metered street parking (free after 6pm)

Oh yeah, I called in mentioning that we would be late and we check and were seated once we arrived.  However, the next day I checked my OpenTable account and they put me down as a no show.  I had to go through the trouble of submitting an incident with OpenTable.

Thanks Fringale...Never again...
author: Nicole S.

description:
It's a Hit/Miss on the food. I opted for the 3 course dinner. My champaign vinaigrette salad tasted fresh but mediocre in taste leaving me with the feeling that I could have done better making it at home. The experience with the chocolate gourmand was the same. The saving grace was the real good lamb shank that could have hit all the high notes had the wine been better. I tried 3 different wines by the glass for the pairing and settled for the least undesirable which was a bordeaux. 

I must say that the service and staff was very accommodating. Overall, just didn't feel like anything more than a 3 star. The ambience is so-so. Nothing memorable to come back to.
author: Monish S.

description:
Went with a party of 13 and the service and food was still excellent! 

This restaurant is small so accommodating such a large party was difficult yet they managed to pull it off. The ambiance is intimate so I would recommend coming here with a smaller group. Ordered off the Dine About Town menu and here are my recommendations:
+ Lamb Shank - The shank was huge and so tender that it fell off the bone. So good and I don't even like lamb goddamnit! 
+ Spicy Calamari - Lots of calamari with spicy peppers made it super flavorful. I give it bonus points since it was not fried. 
+ Salmon Risotto - The top of the salmon was pan fried to give it a crunchiness and cooked to perfection with a vegetable risotto underneath to balance out the flavors. 

Overall everything was good. We also ordered the following:
= Roquefort & Spinach Ravioli - Ravioli was very good but it could have used a little more salt. 
= Creme Brulee - I'm biased because I've never really been a fan. 
= Warm Chocolat Gourmand (chocolate flour-less cake) - Nothing about this stood out. 

I would definitely go back!
author: Donna W.

description:
The service was excellent.  We found this place through yelp reviews at 7 and got a reservation and ate at 9.   Great location in the middle of all the great night spots and the ballpark.  The food was amazing.  We had the special corn soup, special salad with pear, oranges, cheese, balsamic, and champagne vinegarette.  We then had the calamari, special duck great dish and filet mignon dish, followed by creme brûlée, ice cream, and espresso.

It was pricey but amazing.  I will return.
author: Lyndsey C.

description: I came here for Dine About Town and it was amazing. The prefix menu was superb. The service was excellent. Dessert is not to be missed!
author: Kameelah R.

description:
Cozy little spot with good service and decent food. Had the prefix valentine menu. The meal started off with the dungeness crab appetizer in a martini glass.  It was the perfect balance of crab, avocado, roasted red peppers, and mango that was slightly tart which added a great tang to a savory dish.
For the appetizer, I chose the frisée lobster salad which was delish! The dressing was a very light tangy vinegarette and salad was mixed in with grapefruit and oranges. Lobster was buttery and cooked perfectly. Probably one of the best salads I've had out at dinner. I killed it!
My bf chose the foie gras. It came with cute lil heart shaped toasts and some pomegranate jelly. Who doesn't love foie gras? I'm not a fan of jelly but had to try the combination and it actually worked well.
For the main course, I had the duck and it was ok. It's prepared medium rare which makes it very tough to chew. My bf had the filet mignon and wasn't too fond of it. He asked for medium but it was more like over medium. Duck was preferred over the filet mignon.
For desert we had creme brûlée (not bad) and chacolate marquise. If you like chocolate desserts, order the chacolate marquise. It's rich, not too sweet, with a surprising raspberry filling inside. 
Overall I think the place is worth a try.
author: Linda P.

description:
This is my third visit to Fringale, after long periods between each visit. Not sure why we haven't come more often (part of it is because we have a family of five, and the cost can really add up!), but each time we've come here, we've thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. Staff was polite and efficient. We will definitely come back more often, and not wait years between visits! Obviously they are doing something right when the restaurant has been around for so long and still is delicious!

Some quick comments: For appetizers (my husband had three as dinner), we had the beef carpaccio, spinach and blue cheese ravioli, calamari and foie gras terrine. For my entree, I had the braised veal short ribs, and dessert, we had the the creme brûlée, and a brioche bread pudding.

We loved the flavors of everything - the only negative thing I would say is that some of the veal short ribs came out a little dry. But everything else was YUM! The ravioli pasta was thin and fresh, sauce was tasty. The foie gras was the first I've had since it's been back in SF - we liked spreading the foie gras over the bread basket bread and the fresh quince jam - too bad there wasn't more jam! We usually have fried calamari, but we really enjoyed the sautéed calamari. I guess we've had some "less tasty" sautéed calamari from other places, so we usually stick to fried calamari instead. We will definitely order their sautéed calamari again - we have been converted.
author: Denise C.

description:
May be i expected too much??? 
There was really nothing special about the place- i went in with a group of five, and did family style, tasting almost every dish... I didnt not enjoy them.. But I can't seem to remember the dishes I had here.. It wasnt all that memorable i guess...
author: Yoonmi P.

description:
Good value!
We went for a birthday celebration dinner to this French bistro and it was excellent value.
There were four of us and we all had the prix fix menu which cost 42$ and includes appetizer, entree, and dessert.
The quality of food was superb.
A great restaurant south of market.
Good food, good atmosphere and charming service!
author: Sylvette P.

description:
Met up here near the 4th & King Caltrain station for dinner several months back. Many cheers continued in the background throughout our visit here -- must've been a celebration going on.

Anyhow, I remember sharing a Calamari appetizer, then ordering a main dish of Pork Chops bacon-wrapped with apple marmalade. I liked the bacon and marmalade, but something still seemed to be missing flavor-wise... Maybe it was the wine itself, somewhat flat.

Our experience was nice overall, with informative service. Just needs an additional kick for spice.
author: Garett T.

description:
Small place ~15 tables. Excellent service. Came for v-day dinner. Prix fixe menu
My wife had scallops which were amazing followed by sea bass w risotto and artichoke hearts. I had lobster salad and the best filet mignon I've ever had. For dessert we had Creme brûlée and chocolate mousse w raspberry mousse hidden in the center. There were also two complimentary items- crab starter and macaroons. Both excellent. 

Cannot wait to come back again. Highly recommend
author: Davis C.

description:
How Fringale has a 4 star rating on Yelp really confuses me.. I've been here three times in the past few years (first review), and have never been impressed by their food. Unfortunately, the bf's parents like this restaurant, and we had to dine here once again the other night. Luckily they paid for the meal, otherwise I probably would've rounded down to one star for the meh food and high prices. We ordered:

-Frites & Aioli ($6, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=6wAG6kD89ndISddfE9K21g#PCQFQeEc1vOWCglMZyaimQ): The only dish from their menu that I've liked. The frites were nice and crispy, and went will with the aioli. However, I enjoyed the frites from L'Ardoise more.
-Roquefort & Spinach Ravioli (Toasted Pine Nuts, Basil & Cream Sauce, $12, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=6wAG6kD89ndISddfE9K21g#B52EmxnJT8HW1Fa_EgFm0Q): The only other dish that I liked. The ravioli skin seemed freshly made and was very tender. The basil and cream sauce went well with the Roquefort and spinach filling.
-Frisée Salad w/Warm Bacon Dressing, Pine Nuts, Poached Egg & Toasted Levain ($11, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=6wAG6kD89ndISddfE9K21g#ZnL1a0VRLYCjTOXIIjHivQ): This sounded enticing on the menu, but there was way too much vinaigrette, and I had to shake off excess dressing before every bite. There was also a hair in my salad (whoever has long, dark hair in the kitchen should really wear a hairnet), but I didn't make a big deal since I never intend to dine at this establishment again.
-Creekstone Farm Black Angus Ribeye Steak, Pommes Frites & Red Wine Butter Sauce ($28, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=6wAG6kD89ndISddfE9K21g#7VeqhDA5TjRnGXPJX-p3mg): It's hard to mess up a ribeye, but Fringale someone managed to achieve this rare feat. It didn't even look like a cut of ribeye, and certainly didn't taste like one with all the gristle and chewy meat.
-Spinach w/Roquefort Cheese ($6, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=6wAG6kD89ndISddfE9K21g#RuS9QAUpXSHXSKLwvt4A1g): Ok, but the sauteed spinach was very soggy.
-Haricots Verts ($6, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=6wAG6kD89ndISddfE9K21g#6wAG6kD89ndISddfE9K21g): Super limp haricots verts.. I prefer mine a little crunchier.

It didn't help that the service we received was brusque, and I don't think one of our servers smiled once. I had to continually flag them down to refill our butter, or get a to-go box, or get the check. Our small table began to get crowded since they didn't bother to remove the empty plates. Just because it's towards the end of the night doesn't mean you should slack on your service! In any case, there are much better French restaurants in the city to dine at, and even much better restaurants around this area (Coco500, Marlowe). After my most recent dining experience at Fringale, I will NOT be returning here again. Even if the meal was free.
author: Amy D.

description: Dry duck confit and underwhelming lentilles. I was really excited to visit Fringale but was overly disappointed. Apart from the cheese plate and the service, it was under average.
author: Olivier G.

description:
It's always rare to find casual French restaurants with good food, but Fringale has done it - Quite the gem. 

I ordered the scallops to start and the Roasted rack of lamb (Gruyere potato gratin, haricots verts & rosemary sauce) as my entrée. My entrée was the best dish at the table (highly recommended). 

Tip: Corkage fee waived when you order one of their bottles too.
author: Kyle M.

description:
What a great find and until the entree :-(.  Beautiful hidden away small french restaurant south of Market.  The service and apps were absolutely perfect and wonderful fresh exquisite salads.
My entree of the veal short ribs very, very disappointing....initially I was surprised by the large portion only find out it was a plate of FAT and bones.  There was almost no meat to be found and small portion of potatoes buried underneath these huge short ribs.  I brought my concern to the attention of the waiter, in which he said...I told you there was a lot of FAT when you ordered this entree.  I did not recall him saying that at all  and know I would not have ordered short ribs with lots of FAT... I really wonder if these were VEAL ribs...seemed the size of BEEF ribs and given the size of the bones and the fat do not believe I was eating veal.  

At a fine dining establishment the waiter could have done SOMETHING to redeem then entree....nothing was offered.  While I wish I could recommend Fringale with five stars...as the desserts were also very good.  The waiter blew it...and now would suggest but with reservation!!!
author: Leo K.

description:
A friend wanted to go to a French restaurant to get her fixin' of foie gras before California decided to ban it entirely out of the state.

Lucky for us, my friend called ahead for reservations, came about 15 minutes early and got seated without waiting too long. However, there was a BIG party going on that took up most of the tiny restaurant, and sadly enough, some people got turned down since it was pretty busy/packed.

Since I'm not a big French foodie, I decided to play it safe and order the roasted chicken, while my friend got her foie gras. The server did warn me that the chicken was going to take about 20-30 minutes, which I was fine with.

The chicken was good, not GREAT, not BAD, but good. I did like the little side dishes that came along with the plate, but it wasn't anything too special that I would have remembered.

Because of the party, service was on the bad side, hence the one star drop. I do understand you'll probably get more money from the party than the rest of the people eating, but what the servers should have done was shoo the people that were blocking pathways, allowing other customers to go in and out of the restaurant and the restroom with ease. Also, it took a little longer to get our check.

We did wanted to stay a bit longer, so we took a glance at the menu. Sadly enough, I couldn't find anything that stood out from the list, so we turned down the offer.
author: Tom T.

description:
Oh la la, Fringale! 

So, here's my review some ten years later! Hey, they say it's better late than never. I suppose.

But I've recently been reading a lot of reviews mentioning a variety of different pork dishes. And, to me, the one pork dish I still think about all this time later was the succulent pork tenderloin I ordered here.

That bacon wrapped pork tenderloin with braised Napa cabbage, onion & apple marmalade still resonates fond memories of a thoroughly enjoyable dining experience for me and my dinner companions that night even until this today! And for only $20, it is one of the best deals you will find for fine French dining in the city.

The pork was brined and pan-roasted to a cafefully prepared medium-rare, its brilliant pink flesh beneath a marbled crust that was as succulent and tender as any pork dish I've ever tried.

The roasted rack of lamb with potato gratin, haricots verts and rosemary sauce, $25, was my second favorite dish. I rarely order lamb because, if not well prepared, the meat tastes rather gamely to me. Not so here. The lamb was delicious, delicately seasoned, very tender, its flesh a beautifully vibrant burgundy. Roasted lamb in rosemary sauce with potatoes is always a happy marriage of flavors and texture in my opinion.

The Seafood basquaise - salmon, cod, prawns, tuna, mussels, red pepper & tomato coulis, $23, was disappointing. Generally my favorite dish at a French restaurant. Something was just off that day. I don't think the mussels were all that fresh.

I've learned that this popular French bistro has been under new ownership since 2005. I hope the tradition of great dishes and service at more reasonable prices (most dishes under $25) continues to this day.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Having seen the recent mixed reviews regarding their DAT pre-fixe offerings, I have to say that I'm inclined to agree with the harsher reviews.  My party and I arrived 10 minutes early last week for our dinner reservation, yet were seated 30 minutes after our reservation time...

I was also concerned about the quality of the service going into it as several folks mentioned an air of conceit and bias towards the younger crowd, but there was none of that and I ended up being quite pleased with our server's promptness and politeness.  

Now, onto the food:

-Sautéed prawns in Pastis, sun dried tomatoes, shallots & chives: fresh prawns and tasty sauce, but 5 small prawns for $13?  Meh.

-Steamed Alaskan halibut, fennel, asparagus, sweet  corn, fava beans & lemon coriander:  fish was nicely cooked, but the tangy sauce clashed with it and the flavors really did not come together at all.

-Braised veal short ribs, orzo, broccolini, baby carrots & morells mushrooms sauce: Quite good!  Short ribs were tender and the rice and veggies were perfectly cooked.

-Mme. Angèle's Gateau Basque: good almond torte with custard filling, though nothing exceptional.

-Pre-fixe items:
The raw scallops and calamari were both nicely done with the former having a great, zesty vinaigrette and the latter a softness that wasn't at all overly chewy.   
The filet mignon was disappointing - it was cooked well, but the meat itself was gritty rather than tender and the flavor was sorely lacking...definitely something missing here.
The creme brulee was delicious and had excellent texture, while the almond mousse cake was a let-down...good mousse, but terribly dry cake.

Less-than-stellar food aside, our server's wine recommendation was spot-on as we shared a bottle of Rully Premier Cru, Domaine Jaeger-Defaix, 2007.  It had light body with good fruit and a nice, long lingering finish.  

After sampling an array of both regular and pre-fixe items, I have to say that this place really doesn't deserve the average it's gotten from the hundreds of reviews.  The food is reasonably priced for a French restaurant, but the quality doesn't even warrant the price point.  

Oh and it IS as cramped as everyone says.
author: Eric F.

description: I got the mussels and was very pleased! They were cooked very well (not too chewy) and the sauce was light and flavorful (especially for garlic seasoning!). The waiter was a lot of fun and gave good recommendations. I would HIGHLY recommend the Apple tarte Tatin for dessert. I don't usually like apple tarts because they're pretty rich and heavy but this one was all the apple and warm crust flavor without the buttery overload.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I came here for Dine Around Town on a Saturday night with my boyfriend.  As soon as we walked in, we stood near the bar.  We were waiting for a host or hostess to bring us to our table.  I  thought it was kind of weird that the bar had no bartender .  After a few minutes, it seemed like none of the waiters noticed us.  I didn't see a hostess or host either.  Finally, I walked up to a waiter, and he asked if he can help us.  I told him that we had a reservation, and then we got seated near the window.  

Our server was extremely nice and friendly to us.  I decided to order the crab ravioli, sole, and hazelnut mousse cake.  My boyfriend ordered the pate, fillet mignon, and chocolate gourmand.  After we ordered, we were given a basket full of sourdough and bagutte slices.  The bread was good, but I would have prefered it warm and toasted..lol.

Our appetizers came out first.  There was 3 pieces of crab ravioli on my plate.  They were filled with a lot of crab, and it was very delicious in the lobster bisque.  I didn't like how it smelled a bit fishy though.

My boyfriend enjoyed his pate appetizer, too.  I tried some of the meat on his plate, and it was tasty with the toasted slice of bread.

Our entrees came out next.  The sole was seared on one side, and it was a bit hot.  I had to let it cool down before I can bite into it...lol.  The risotto was really good!!

My boyfriend loved his fillet mignon.  He requested it get cooked 'medium', and it came out perfec.  He enjoyed the potato gratin, too.

For dessert, I loved the hazelnut mousse cake.  The layers of hazelnut, almond, and cake tasted very good with the chocolate base.  My boyfriend's chocolate gourmand was super delicious!  It reminded me of a warm brownie with vanilla ice cream.

Overall, the service was good after we got seated.  All the dishes was super good and a decent size.  Parking was a bit difficult to find though, since there were no spots in the parking lot across the street. There was also no street parking, too.  I really think this place should have valet.  It would make a lot of customers very happy. =)
author: Rita V.

description:
I guess I had high expectations and I was a little disappointed.
The crab napoleon is not on the menu anymore. We had the assiette de charcuterie which was pretty good. The toasts were delicious.
They ran out of duck confit at 8pm which was the reason I came to the restaurant.
Heart broken, I opted for the Bacon wrapped pork tenderloin which was good but nothing exceptional. I had the Warm chocolate Gourmand for dessert and although the cake and ice cream were good, the coulis was so bitter that I barely finished the dessert.

Lights are bright, tables are so close I could hear our neighbor's conversation in great details. I would not consider Fringale a great date spot.
author: Marc L.

description:
After a brief trip to san francisco, a couple of good friends and I came for dinner.
This is the most authentic french bistro I have been yet.
Started with the crab napoleon which was delicious.
The main course had some lamb shank with morels mushrooms which was quite appetizing and a healthy portion.
Desserts were chocolat gourmand and gateau basque.
The food was outstanding.
Our server was top notch and was quite funny.
Do not miss eating here.
author: Luis H.

description: Food is great. I was expecting more but i'm happy. Order the sole and the lamb. This is a good place for a first date. Crowded on a Friday but the noise level was good enough so you wont have to worry about the silence in between conversations, if any. I recommend the Faiveley red wine. Goes excellent with the lamb they serve. Would go back again but not anytime soon
author: Johnny B.

description:
PROS:
- Authentic, fresh cuisine (I got the beet salad with goat cheese, recommended)
- Extremely attentive water-servers 
- I'd feel comfortable bringing my grandma or a date here, versatile atmosphere

CONS:
- Music went from subtle background instrumental to electronic. Weird vibe shift!
- Perhaps understaffed, or just bustling on a Friday night, it took longer than average to get our check

OPEN FOR INTERPRETATION: 
- Cozy/cramped dining area, depending on your perspective
- The portions are small, but just what you'd expect in a French restaurant (quality over quantity). Great for date-dining when you want something light, in order to have conversation and wine dominate.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Finally learned what it means for food to "melt in your mouth"!!
So delicious. I came here with a pretty large party (12), and it was a small restaurant. So it took us a while to get our table. However, they offered us complimentary champagne while we waited for our table. The servers were so attentive and friendly. Not at all stuck up, like at some other upscale restaurants I've been to. 
I had the pomme frites with garlic aioli, and the spinach and roquefort ravioli. 
The ravioli was definitely my favorite ravioli ever! The sauce was so cheesy and delicious. I can't say enough good about this restaurant. I only wish I had room for dessert!
author: Shilpa Y.

description:
I came to Fringale for Dine about Town with a few friends tonight. Two of us ordered off the Dine about Town menu and two ordered off the regular menu. Everybody seemed very happy with all three courses. 

For the appetizer I ordered the crab Napoleon which was REALLY good. I don't always like crab, but the crab with avocado was really light and delicious. 

For the entree, I ordered the braised lamb shank. I only started eating red meat a few months ago so I don't know much about lamb, but it was falling off the bone and pretty flavorful. I also tried the mussels and the chicken (both of which were off the regular menu) and both absolutely fantastic. The mussels were garlicky and came with fries and an aioli dip that would have been great if I liked aioli.

We finished the meal off with warm chocolate gourmands (flourless chocolate cake essentially) which came topped with vanilla ice cream and a fruit compote. I scarfed it down, it was delicious. I'm usually big on splitting desserts, but these were pretty small. Definitely meant for one person only. 

As for the service and ambiance - both were excellent. The walls had large, beautiful, colorful paintings that made the room feel simultaneously classy and cheerful. Our French waiter was pretty awesome. He was nice and brought all our appetizers at once so that nobody had to wait around with food in front of them. Well-timed and well-delivered!
author: Talia G.

description:
After spending $191.40 for 4, not including tip, our experience was good, but maybe a little disappointing.  After the late afternoon Friday of Cirque du Soleil at the AT&T parking lot, we had 8PM reservations here.  We arrived a bit early and waited nearby as the then crowded restaurant was unable to accommodate us.  After about 15 minutes, a nice table was arranged for us.  

The restaurant was a bit noisy and the background music could have been turned down some.  Our waiter, a charming French man, was attentive and helpful.  French bread and butter was immediately brought out. Two of us shared a tasty  butter lettuce salad which they kindly split for us.  It was covered with a shaved petit basque with a mild vinaigrette dressing.  Three of us enjoyed a $38 bottle of Malbec.  Though expensive, it was a better value than ordering 3 individual glasses of wine.  The Malbec had a refreshing taste.

For the entrees, we had (2) roasted rack of lamb, with gruyere potato gratin, haricots verts (green beans) & rosemary sauce,  @ $28 each; traditional duck confit, lentils "du puy", potatoes landaises, garlic, bacon & red wine sauce,  $22;and a seafood basquaise of king salmon, seabass, prawns, tuna, mussels, red pepper & tomato coulis, $26.   

The two rack of lamb dinners were cooked to perfection and the presentation looked well.  The duck confit was a big disappointment as it was too dry.  The seafood dish was rather ordinary and unsatisfying with the shrimp and mussels being the only distinctive taste.  I couldn't really tell the difference between the salmon, seabass, or tuna chunks.

For dessert, we split the hazelnut & roasted almond mousse cake with layers of hazelnut mousse and genoise topped with roasted almonds  and a warm chocolate gourmand flourless chocolate cake served with a mint sorbet.  Both desserts were good, though most of our party preferred the chocolate cake.

Afterwards, we spoke with an older gentleman, who may have been the manager and expressed our thoughts re the rack of lamb and the duck confit.  The manager blamed the California law prohibiting foie gras on the lean duck meat.  He claims that they can only get  rather thin duck legs which tend to be overly dry when prepared.  However, I thought that excuse seemed rather phoney.  If they knew the dish would be overly dry, they should take it off the menu or prepare it in some other way.

This restaurant is probably a solid 4, but the manager's comment about the duck confit knocked it down a notch.  We may come back again and try some other dishes.
author: Robert J.

description:
I've been a customer for many years.  Very special space and atmosphere.  Cozy, quietly personal and European. Kind and attendant serving staff. And each time I rediscover such wonderful dishes.  It is always good. I lean toward the calamari, mussels, frisee salad, duck confit, and my friends are delighted as well.

We went there last night to celebrate time with my eldest son. I was so happy to see him close his eyes to savor his lamb shank.  

The space is quiet, you can hear well and speak in comforting low tones, which I find contributes to a peaceful experience. They hold a couple of parking spaces in front for guests now, a considerate touch. There is a little bar where one can have a nice solo dinner.
author: Ann M.

description:
Squid appetizer strong olive taste. 3 stars
But pretty good.

Escargot Pesto sauce with pie crust. 3 stars
The pie crust and salad decent.

The duck is very tasty. 

I got the steak and it was very good. 

Overall,  it was decent service was good. 
I think place is a bit price.  Paid around 70.00 per head  at  party  of ten.
author: Taye N.

description:
Pommes Frites & aioli ($6): Not a big fan of their fries. The aioli was very rich and creamy and was really not that good as a dipping side for fries that are really oily. 

Macedoine salad, asparagus, fava beans, artichokes, beets, sweet peas & balsamic vinaigrette  ($12): This dish was pretty light and refreshing.

Spicy Monterey calamari "à la plancha", jalapenos, chorizo , piment d`Espelette & olives ($12): REALLY GOOD! This dish was very healthy and good. The squid was not deep fried and wasn't heavy tasting. Very good.

Special of the day - Salmon on a bed of risotto with this really buttery and creamy orange sauce ($22): I am so glad I got this dish, the downside was that the center wasn't truly cooked all the way in, but I didn't mind it cause it was SUPER moist. However, the orange sauce was very very rich. My co-workers also said their dishes were very very rich and one of them wasn't able to finish her dish due to that.
http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/pM_by8SvAuI_ZFZdCZW8JA/l.jpg

Over all ok experience. The service was good. The food is really rich, so be prepared.
author: Erica T.

description:
I've been to this place a while back and for some reason remembered it being a higher end French cuisine.  The place is cute, but it lacks elegance and style.  The decor is diner like, the plastic covered menus are not a very classy touch.  The waiters are authentically French and friendly though. 

To start we had the onion tart, which was really not great, the pastry was not fluffy and light, it was also cold, the onions were OK, but then it had a pile of spinach and prosciutto on top, just didn't really work well together and lacked the French quality.

For the entrees we had the short ribs and steak. Both were well done, but in a bistro style simplicity.  The plating was simple rather than elegant.  The portions were large and had nice flavor but lacked any refined preparation or taste.  The wine we had was OK but again, the glasses were the basic cheap ones, not specific to the wines or even elegant. 

For the finale we had espressos.  All in all it was a good experience but not great and for the $100 dinner tab, it lacked the atmosphere that would make us repeat a visit.
author: Inga W.

description:
Came here to try out the DAT menu, and I felt like all the dishes were prepared satisfactorily, but nothing that was out of this world. I also thought it was a bit strange that some dishes seemed to have Italian influences, even though this is a French restaurant. 

Here's what I ordered: 
1) Roquefort & spinach ravioli: So apparently roquefort is a fancy name for blue cheese, which I don't care for at all. Besides the flavor of the cheese all over the four delicate pieces of ravioli, this dish was pretty good. I thought ravioli was supposed to be Italian, so I'm not exactly sure why they're serving it here.

2) Coq au Vin: Pronounced CO-CO-VANH, which was not on the DAT menu itself, but a special that they offered (at the dine about town price). The chicken was fall off the bone good, and the sauce seemed very similar to the sauce served with the lamb shank. I'm not a huge fan of lamb, otherwise I would've ordered that. This dish was the perfect alternative; not too salty, and exactly how it should taste in my mind. BRAVO!

3) Coffee parfait: This really reminded me of a tiramisu minus the lady fingers and cream. There was quite a strong alcoholic (rum?) flavor to it too. It was basically half a wine glass of tiramisu ice cream if you can imagine that. The rum flavor started to get too strong for me in the end, and I wasn't able to finish it unfortunately. Again, Italian influences?! 

Other desserts that we ordered:
~ Creme brulee: served in what looked like a soup cup! This resulted in less surface area for the burnt sugar on top and quite a thick layer of egg on the bottom. I'll bet a lot of customers just scrape off the sugar and leave the egg custard behind. ;) Normally it's served in a flatter dish, which is what I prefer.
~ Chocolate gourmand: basically a warm chocolate cake, and what looked like the best of the three desserts.
author: Audrey L.

description: I was impressed at how cozy and friendly this restaurant is. It was full without being crowded. The table arrangements are economical but not packed. Our waiter was nice and funny in a non-intrusive, pleasantly French way, which I quite enjoyed. I was more impressed with our main courses than the appetizers - I would have expected the French onion soup to be better (it was not bad, but just not nearly as good as this dish can be). However, the duck confit was excellent! Each part of the duck was delicious, as were the lentils. Like a fool, I almost missed the potatoes Landaises, which might have been my favorite part. Personally, I did not like the pork tenderloin as much, and the desserts were a bit mundane. My the duck confit and overall atmosphere elevated the experience.
author: Lisa K.

description:
The Wife and I were down the street at 25 Lusk for one of her college socials, and it turned out that they had no tables for four at the last minute.  A quick Yelp! search showed Fringale just a short walk away, so I called and they said they could seat us in ten minutes. 

It's a very cozy restaurant with a full bar and a good selection of French dishes.  The waiter was French, but unlike most French waiters I've encountered (in Paris, anyways) he was very nice, attentive and served us promptly.  One minor point, the bread seemed like it may have been a day old, and the butter was cold.  

Our vegetarian friends quickly found something they liked, and the Wife and I both ordered a meat course; she got the steak, I got the pork.  Both were healthy portions that were better than good, but just shy of great (the sauce for the pork had a taste that was pleasant but not perfect). We already had drinks, so we stuck with water.  

Prices weren't out of the ordinary for San Francisco, and we had a very pleasant time.  I'd come again, maybe next time with a heartier appetite.
author: Dennis H.

description: Overall good food and good service.  I ate light.  Corn soup needed salt (which I typically don't add) but with that it was good, nice texture.  Good portion too.
