The Nicoise salad was good -- tuna perfectly cooked, although anchovies which was added seemed atypical for this type of salad.  But, the salad was well dressed and good.  I would go back for a more hearty meal another time.
author: Ed J.

description:
A sweet friend treated us to a celebratory dinner. 

They were out of foie gras, but we're not terribly disappointed as we've slowly consumed foie gras since earlier this year. 

We ordered charcuterie, duck confit, seafood basquaise, and the salmon special. I had a taste of the seafood and salmon (tasty).  The duck confit is served over lentils and left me full from decadent duck love. 

Intimate warm space, high quality ingredients and solid service.
author: Sophie C.

description:
Hidden gem - awesome array of wine and cheese; great entrees - delicious , right sizes and authentic french, personable, friendly and intuitive staff, a nice romantic but not claustrophobic ambience. 

The whole dining experience including reception who seated us without reservations somehow, the waiter who was extremely professional yet personable and naughty making us feel comfortable throughout and all this is before we had anything to eat. Their array of wine choices was great, entrees perfectly balanced with multiple flavor notes and the cheese oh the cheese - just get their cheese plate to finish off... Mature served with wild honey ... Icing (well honey) on a perfect evening dinner !
author: Anand D.

description: Perfect for a weekday unwind. The service is wonderful and the wine pour is generous. Make sure to try the braised veal short ribs!
author: Linda X.

description:
I met up with a friend for pre-birthday lunch and I wanted to try a new place. I've been wanting to try Fringale, it was on my never ending list of places to go and good things to eat.

We ordered a bottle of Markham, Napa Valley  Sauvignon Blanc to share. Since a salad came with my meal, we ordered pomme fritz which were soggy and not that great. It wasn't like they were on menu, so I can't fault them for not being perfect.

For lunch I had the Dungeness crab Napoleon with avocado, tomato confit and crème fraiche. This was incredible and pure genius. I just read about a new spin on a "crab cake" in a cooking magazine at home and wanted to try it. This "one upped" that recipe. This came with a side of mixed greens.

My friend ordered the Salade Niçoise with Ahi tuna , vegetables in olive oil & lemon dressing. Atop the salad was a huge piece of Ahi Tuna. I would have liked it seared and not cooked, but it wasn't my meal and I think it was ordered that way.

Definitely enjoyed my meal and every time I see the picture of my Crab Napoleon, it reminds me of how tasty it was. Check out my pics!
author: Rebekah T.

description:
Oui, Oui!  Great find on Yelp!  First time at a French Bistro and I would come definitely come back here.  

Had a party of 7 which they easily accommodated!  We had a nice space and didn't feel crowded at all.  We were celebrating a birthday so we were louder then the average guests there.  The waiters were great and I actually felt like some of the regular customers appreciated our energy and celebration.  They came over to us and wished our friend a HAPPY BIRTHDAY.

This is a real french place too.  The entire staff appeared to be french which we loved.  They know how to celebrate on a special occasion, thats for sure!  BTW, we had 7 people in our party and all 7 ordered a different meal which I am happy to report got high marks.  I know my steak was delicious.  We tried all the desserts on the menu and the sorbet dish was the most popular by far.  The apple was the crowd favorite!!!!

Thanks for a great meal and fun evening!
author: Brian S.

description:
We just went here on Friday (7/20/12). 

Food was fantastic - really enjoyed the fresh bread upon sitting - would have been nice if they could offer it warm and hot! :) 

Here is the run down on what we had: 

Appz: Sautéed prawns in Pastis - very tasty, surprisingly shrimp properly had a taste and flavor of its base and garnish.  It has a bit of kick - not spicy but just a hint of an Indian flavoring - not over-powering curry flavor, so please dont get frightened by my characterization - thats just how I am describing it.  :) I do recommend it.  

Dinner:
Pappardelle pasta: very very light, tasted amazingly fresh and mouth is watering as I even think about it!  Just awesome! The flavor is light, zesty  - so if you are used to a rich pesto or heavy marinara - this is not for you.  

Poached Alaskan halibut: also good - highly recommend that you mix around the olive tapenade that comes with it (on one-side) - once you mix it in - the entire flavor of the fish with all the seasonings together in each bite is very good.  

Sides: 
French fries: these were just regular fries the dipping sauce is a mustard aioli - the server said, "its unique" - although we did not think so, and in hindsight should have tried the mashed potatoes. 

Service: 
We were a bit disappointed, considering all the positive review (by fellow Yelpers!) our server was just a bit odd.  He asked both tables next to us - that arrived after us, for drinks and food orders before he did ours.  Honestly, it felt that he just did not want us on his service, it felt a bit racial - but I am hoping that that was just my impression and hopeful not true. definitely not very SF like (if it is true)! Anyways, we did not order dessert because we lost interest by the time he came back to even ask us.  

My rating would have been 5 w/out the service experience.  I am hoping that server was just having a bad day and hopefully was nothing else - and for that reason - until I have other data points, I would say Yes for sure! The food, environment and overall place has won me over - to forget the service and try yet again!!
author: Bhavin M.

description:
I wanted to give 5 stars but the service went for awesome to being ignored. 
Unfortunately the waiter seemed to be overwhelmed just as the dinning room filled. The food was amazing and the waiter always had amazing suggestions. It was also reasonably priced for SOMA. I would go again during off hours.
author: Eric M.

description:
The food is great, the wine the same. Shared all of our dishes so we could sample more. Endive salad Yes, potato scallop YES, steamed mussels OMG YES, Seafood basquaise YES YES, roasted rack of lamb EHH OK. I asked for medium rare and it was much more medium than rare, so go rare if you order it. Cheese plate for desert YES and Hazelnut Almond mousse YES.

Our waiter was nice, helpful, the service was great, the ambiance is comfortable not too stuffy. I'll be back.
author: Ryan U.

description: Great neighborhood bistro.  Truly French (including waiters) with great food.
author: Lee K.

description:
started to say, WOW, it just seems ti get better and better...and its always been great. sat in the dinning room opposed to the bar. carpaccio starter w/ a great cheese, capers and greens. my entree was seafood , mussels, prawns, bass and more . wish i could spell the name, you'll find it...and a great chocolate cake /fresh berries...The Best. should have written names
wish i could eat like that every night
author: marcia p.

description:
01.22.11

My 2011 inaugural DAT was, in a word, disappointing.

After quick research on location, menu items and restaurant availability, we settled on Fringale.  I was really excited because the menu had course choices, and they all looked good.

Maybe I just chose the wrong items.  I started with the dungeness crab napoleon [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=hMUA1c5YlXbPYXi73G2_0Q], which was amazing.  Since our friends were almost 30 minutes late, and it took another 20 minutes to order, I wolfed the dish down like no other.

I had heard good things about the duck confit [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=BfI-8q-XtPgtb2n8Xye_Yg].  Sadly, my experience was less than stellar.  It was dry, overcooked, and almost, just almost inedible.  But, I was still really hungry.  So, wolfed it down too.

I wish the saving grace was the dessert, but alas, the vanilla bean creme brulee [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=RX0kCZzB9EEhOLPbt4L2_g] was nothing special.

Overall, the dining experience fell short of expectations.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Quick and pleasant service.  It was easy to reserve a table.  
I had a prix fixe dinner which comes with appetizer, entrée, and dessert.  I could choose one from three options, so I chose ravioli, duck confit, and creme brûlée.  It was very filling and tasty.
author: Suki K.

description:
Another exhibit of great low key eating in San Francisco.  Fringale is tucked away just a couple blocks from the Metreon area.  It's almost right by the freeway.  So its a nice quiet place to have dinner without the hustle and bustle of the city.  The food is a little bit above a moderate price level but not in the overly expensive zone.  Let's take a tour of our meal!

Our starter.. Dungeness crab Napoleon with avocado, tomato confit and crème fraiche. Totally incredible balance of flavors. Wonderfully light. The mixed green salad gave it just the hint of bitter and acidity to balance the richness of the crab and avocado.  Also, the caviar on top gave it just the extra kick to take it up a notch!

Hangar steak with pomme frites and green beans.  Classically done.  It doesn't try to pretend to be anything it's not and it does what it does very well.  The fries were crisp, the haricots verts were crunchy, and the steak was juicy.

Hazelnut mousse cake.  A little bit heavy because of all the flavors and richness- but it's very well done.  I love the combination of the aromatic hazelnuts with the creamy mouse and the dense dark chocolate. 

Creme Brulee.  Not much to say other than it was executed and delicious.  A true mark of a well run French restaurant.

That about sums up Fringale.  Small and cozy, a few steps away from the city, it is well executed French food at a moderate price.
author: Siao J.

description:
Great wine selection, had a white and a red and both were awesome. Waiter was honest about his opinions.

Service was quick yet wasn't rushed, good service overall!

Food was very yummy but didn't have a wow factor. My bacon wrapped pork chop was a teeny bit bland (without all the garnishes and sauce) and maybe even a bit dry. Raviolis were fresh and had a homey feeling.

Creme brulee was actually one of the best, had a very thick crunchy top and delicious creme filling.

4 ladies, bill was $250, so so. Good meal though!
author: Selina W.

description: My wife and I have been coming here for years and it's always been one of my favorite restaurants: small, very good food, nice menu choices, and the appropriately smug French attitude. Well, things seem to have changed. We both ordered the same dish last Saturday evening: the braised veal short ribs with leeks, potato galette, carrots & mushroom fricassee with demi-glaze sauce. There was no there there. The meat was virtually non-existent. All fatty stuff and bone. The underlayment of the galette and fricassee turned into mush. Amazingly poor dish. And, the service was sub par at best. The kicker is that these dishes were $29 apiece! We felt we had been ripped off. Big disappointment. Someone must not be minding the store, or the kitchen, or whatever. I am really tired of paying inflated prices and getting skewered (pun intended). Probably won't go back.
author: Jackson F.

description:
We came here for DAT and the prices and menu selections were really reasonable. Reservations were a breeze to make on Opentable and the owner/manager greeted us warmly at the door. The only downside to this place was that they insisted that they had no 7:30 reservations or 7:45 reservations, yet half of the restaurant was empty when we walked in at 7:40... Minus one star for not keeping tabs of their tables and reservations since after the hoopla on the phone during the reservation making process, our table was empty and waiting for us at 7:40!

We ordered a variety of apps from the DAT menu: sauteed calamari and the crab napolean. Both were delicious... my crab napolean ended up having a large hunk of crab shell in it. It wasn't a typical small gritty piece but a 2 inch long one. I showed it to the waitress when she came around since that would have been an easy catch by the prep staff. 

I had the duck confit and Hubsters had the lamb. Lamb won over the duck. I think I prefer my duck peking style with a nice crisp skin and some buns. Their version of duck confit was done really well. The skin was crisp and crackling. The lentils that accompanied the duck was mediocre. The menu advertised it with bacon and I saw the occasional smidgen of bacon in there.

Dessert was delicious. I had the hazelnut mousse cake, Hubster ordered the molten chocolate cake. MMMMmmm... We had to rush through dessert in order to catch our train back down since the service here was extremely slow. Great ambiance and a relaxing restaurant!
author: Vicky L.

description:
I've walked by this place many times and told myself I need to try it out.  When I had some friends visiting I took the opportunity to book reservations.  It was originally for four of us then my friends called last minute and wanted to bring another couple to make it 6 on a Saturday night.  The staff was very accommodating and it was no problem. 

The food was great, and everyone had the drink special for the night which was a delight as well.  Great service and timely service overall.  Next time I want to try and get a table in the front of the house however, not a fan of being by the kitchen but then again who is?

I will most definitely be back.
author: Eran B.

description:
Came here to farewell a friend leaving town and also check out their DAT deal.

I had: 
- Dungeness Crab Napoleon (plentiful of crab and really clean/refreshing)
- Duck confit with lentils (while it didn't taste particularly like duck, meat was literally falling off the bone 
- Chocolate Gourmand (flourless chocolate cake served with ice cream)  " A.W.E.S.O.M.E"

Food portions were good (it's important for me to leave any restaurant NOT HUNGRY! :) ) and everything tasted great.

Other items on the DAT menu were:
- Sauteed calamari
- lamb shank served with mashed potatoes & spinach
- Creme brulee
- hazelnut & almond cake

All the dishes were good but if I came back, I would still have the same stuff I ordered :)

Service was great and wait staff were attentive.
author: Sujan H.

description: Great little place.  Had the duck confit which was delicious as well as one of the salads.  I think it had arugula.  We had dessert but don't remember which one.  All the food was good though.
author: Debbie L.

description: I crashed a friend's dinner party. They were so full they told me to eat their left over plates of duck and salmon. Score! Free delucious food!! The duck was amazing with this delicioua sauce, perfect peas and potatoes.  Their signature pear cosmo was so good! I want another.  I will be back for sure,  attentive nice staff also.
author: Karen T.

description:
Have you wondered why French food is always so expensive?  Check out Fringale. 

Fringale is Chapeau! (http://www.yelp.com/biz/L5vSeC_sa3TUQW_lticqyA) of SOMA.  They both serve reasonably priced French cuisine with portion size for humans, not birds.  One difference is that Fringale focuses on Basque cuisine, which has lots of seafood with Spanish influences.  I wasn't wowed by their food, but it was certainly above average.  This is a good place to remember if you need to take someone to a French restaurant.       

SEATS:  A medium size restaurant with 20-30 tables.  They have tables that fold out to make a square table into a round table, so they are pretty flexible.  Spacing was tight.

PRICE:  I would not call dinner here cheap, but for French, it is reasonable.

A sample dinner for two:
$18 - Seafood Basquaise
$18 - Pork tenderloin
$6 - Spinach and Roquefort
$6 - Potato gratin
$22 - A half bottle of wine
$18 - Tip and taxes
--------------------------------
$88 for two people

PARKING:  Unless there is a Giant's home game at AT&T park, parking during dinner hours in this SOMA area is fairly easy.
author: トモ T.

description:
We frequently go to Fringale bistro.
The food and wine items are excellent.
Most visits We bring friends in order to have a nice meal with conversation. Very friendly and great wait staff and an amazing ambuance. We defenately recommend fringale!
author: Robby C.

description:
Fringale, you really took me by surprise!  

I came here with 3 others for Dine About Town 2011 tonight and we each got different things, one of everything to share and compare! I think I was by far the happiest with my selections. 

The calamari and crab napoleon were a tie for me. 

The Crab Napoleon was clean, and very refreshing. Dressed with layers of guacamole, mango salsa and farmers greens, I kept alternating bites of calamari and this!

The Calamari was just so different! I was expecting fried calamari with jalapeño but it wasn't like that at all. It was a huge plate of sauteed calamari and it was really tasty. 

My lamb shank was amazing. I didn't have to use my knife at all and the meat just fell off it's bone. It was paired with a polenta, spinach and oyster mushrooms that went really well with the lamb!! This was by far the best lamb I've had that didn't get too game-y or too mushy (usually, at other places I've been to, the lamb comes with risotto that makes it too mushy). 

The sole and duck were pretty disappointing. Like someone warned below, the duck is pretty dry.

For dessert, I really loved the Chocolate Gourmand.  It was like a flourless rich chocolate cake that was fluffy and scrumptious topped with ice cream!

 The creme brûlée was a good choice too. 

Hazelnut almond cake and Coffee parfait were my least favorite, first one was just pretty much hazelnut creme and the second one tasted like alcohol (Which can be a good thing), but I just wanted something savory and sweet. 

Overall, I was pleasantly surprised by Fringale, maybe because I came in not knowing what to expect, but I thhink all their dishes were well thought out and paired well.  What a delicious choice for DAT!
author: Joanna S.

description:
I don't know how this place has four stars.  I think at one point it was good, but it's gone down the hill.

I will say that the service is good, not great, but good.  It took soo long to get our wine to our table.  I am only pointing this out because of what happened next.  This will literally shock you.  We ordered our dinner, two entrees, the mussels and rack of lamb, and a side of fries.  Literally 5 minutes after we put in our order, our dinner came out. OMG.  So, thank you for letting me know that the dinner was already pre-made, sitting there and waiting for someone to order.  The mussels weren't anything amazing, the lamb was salty and not hot.  The cheese on the potato gratin had obviously been sitting for a while as it was rubbery.

That wasn't the worst part.  We ordered bread pudding, it came with ice cream on top.  The bread pudding had steam coming out of it.  It was obvious in taste that this had been pre-frozen, and then microwaved.  Desserts aren't supposed to steam like that ! 

This place is a crime.
author: S G.

description:
It been 15 years since my last meal at Fringale, there was no Yelp when I was last there.But I would have given it 5 stars then, and I certainly can give it 5 stars today.
The calamari a la plancha and the seabass were delicious.
The pork tenderloin was perfectly cooked.
Great food, we'll prepared.
Nice wait staff.
Thank You Fringale.
author: Riku T.

description:
Thank goodness for DAT. It gives me the opportunity to try new places like this one!

Space-wise, this place is small... as in anything larger than a party of 2 makes things a little crowded. However, that also means that this is a great option for date night. The noise is kept pretty low and the service is spot on, with no sense of urgency to turn a table.

Dishes that we'll be returning for:
Dungeness Crab Napolean 
Roquefort and Spinach Ravioli
Lamb shank
author: Meuy S.

description:
Since I knew I was going to be yelping this joint, I came in wearing a khaki trench coat, sunglasses, a Fedora hat, a pencil tucked above my ear, and a small notebook tucked in my pocket.  You know, didn't wanna look conspicuous or anything.

Holding the menu upright w/my nose pressed up against the menu, I whispered to the waiter:

"We'll start with the Spicy Monterey calamari "à la plancha", and for my entree I'd like the Creekstone Farm black angus ribeye steak, with pommes frites"

Waiter:  "I can barely hear you madame"

G'dangit.  

The calamari isn't your typical deep fried crunchfest, it's not breaded but instead spiced up like a mofo with jalapenos and chorizo.  The ribeye...wheeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeew (let me bow my head in silence) was the BEEZNEEEEEEZ, perfectly prepared to my liking- medium rare, and, AND....per my request, they gave me a ribeye with plenty of marbled fat (yes I asked, don't judge).

For dessert we had Creme Brulee, and the Warm Chocolate Gourmand (flourless cake).  Those specific desserts were good but pretty typical, nothing to make an only trip for.  

If you're a red meat eater, I recommend the ribeye.  I know you can have ribeye at a million other joints, but you could only have one, Fringale style.
author: Rho T.

description: The food is excellent. This place is a bit of a drive for me since I live in Santa Clara but have been treated twice by my girlfriend and she hired a driver both times. The place is very small and the seasoned waiter was a bit impatient so that knocked off a star.
author: Buster H.

description: "Friendly service" someone uttered? Perhaps it was because I didn't know "Entree" in French meant "Appetizer" in English. Perhaps I reek of tech geek. Whatever the reason, the wait staff here seethed with arrogance and negativity towards us. Shrug off the arrogant wait staff in trade for some extra good food? Not to be. This food was good, but nothing remarkable. At all. I would certainly seek out another dining experience, especially for a special occasion. Last, it's in a fairly poor part of town, up for random strangers asking through the window where Irma is?
author: Kevin K.

description:
I went here for the "Dine about town" deal last Friday night with my gf and some friends and had mixed reviews.

I ordered the dungeness crab napolean, traditional duck confit, and creme brulee. 

For starters the dungeness crab was way too salty for my liking. It tasted more like imitation crab meat; and in my opinion didn't really flow with the mango and peppers. My girlfriend ordered the same thing and she refused to eat the other half as she was obviously not a fan either, so it wasn't just me.

The next dish was the traditional duck confit. This helped Fringale earn back some of their stars. I love duck and when prepared right, this is the result. The meat fell off the bone to perfection, and was so juicy and tender I couldn't believe it. I ate every bite down to the last morsel. 

The dessert of choice was the creme brulee. I thought they did a fantastic job on this as well. Golden brown on the outside and sweet as can be on the inside. 

I give them 3 stars because in order to get 4, I would've needed to be blown away by all 3 dishes instead 2/3.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Food: Excellent. Service: Lacking Decor: Excellent

I came here with a large party for a holiday dinner. The decor is quite cozy and had a very warm atmosphere. Despite being later for our reservation they had no issue seating us.

Food first:

We ordered just about one of everything on the menu and shared it, along with several appetizers, and I was pleasantly surprised. All the food was either good, or above average. The standout main dishes for me was the duck confit, which was extremely tasty and every bite a joy. Additionally the chicken dish, while simple looking and boring sound was absolutely the most moist and tender chicken I have ever eaten. I have no idea how they got the chicken this moist and tender.

My only complaint to be had was the service. Our waitress seem flustored and disorganized and times and repeatedly asked if anyone wanted white wine to the point where I had to say "Obviously nobody else wants any" because I couldn't stand her asking a 5th time.

But it didn't really detract from my enjoyment of the food and experience and I would return.
author: Jordan C.

description:
Pierre was awesome. He went above and beyond to make sure we were happy.
The Coq Au Vin was delicious and so was the flourless chocolate cake that he recommended. The table in the back left corner has a nice little heater for your feet that is cozy for ladies like me who are always cold.
author: Patricia A.

description:
Was another Dine About Town (Restaurant Week for out of towners) pick and again, was very happy with the choice.  Loved the authentically French staff and music that moments throughout dinner, you actually forget where you are and expected to see the Eiffel Tower outside.

Started with the Dungeness Crab Napoleon which is layered with avocados, mangos, and greens.  Was pleasantly surprised that it had a very decent amount of crab meat for an appetizer.  Had the lamb shank for entree which was literally fall off the bone tender and never being a fan of polenta, Fringale, yours made me a fan.  No grittiness like ones I previously had but smooth and decadently complemented the rest of the dish.  Dessert was the chocolate gourmand which is a warm flourless chocolate cake with a raspberry drizzle and vanilla ice cream which equals clean plate!!  Looking forward to returning!!
author: Joyce Z.

description:
The food is only really 2 stars, but the service was pretty good for our party of 24. We got 2 separate tables.

Frisée salad with warm bacon dressing, pine nuts, poached egg & toasted levain-this was not bad. Prob one of the best dishes of the night.  

Beef carpaccio, capers, organic greens, chives, Etorki cheese, lemon & vigin olive oil-nothign special. The beef was pink. Isn't it suppose to be bright red if it's fresh? Hmmmmm....

Dungeness crab Napoleon, avocado, lemon zest, piquillo pepper & mango salsa-this was very fresh. Lots of crab meat and went will with the mango salsa, but needed more flavor  

Steamed PEI mussels, fried garlic, fresh herbs, shallots & sherry vinegar -had very good garlic flavor BUT it was super oily! I can just see layers of oil. Heart attack.

Traditional duck confit, lentils "Du Puy", potatoes Landaises, garlic, bacon & red wine sauce-pretty dry

Frites & aioli-not crispy at all 

Brussel sprouts & bacon-its like mashed up leaves. Super soggy with some bacon. It tasted ok, but the texture was a no no for me.
author: Karen H.

description: Excellent little french restaurant. Authentic. Affordable. Great cuisine with unique taste. I highly recommend it for foodies and those who want to (re)discover french cuisine!
author: Tom C.

description: Really enjoyed my dinner here.  Ambiance is very nice: classy and sophisticated but absolutely no pretension.  Staff was friendly and helpful (and real French people!).  We were the last ones there and closed the place, but no one ever even hinted that it was getting late.  Good wine list.  Food was excellent (I have to admit that my sole was kind of dry) but my friends loved their dishes: duck confit, rack of lamb, ravioli.  Creme brulee was exceptional.  Highly recommend.  Definitely plan to come back and try more of the menu.
author: JJ M.

description:
AMBIANCE: 
Upon arrival, I knew Fringale was the real deal with its bright yellow walls, quaint interior, dim lights, and authentic French waiters, with the accent and all. Although Fringale is a small restaurant (prob. can't fit more than 30 if even), I never once felt squished, but instead, felt like I was in France (reminiscing my most recent trip to France).

FOOD: 
+ Braised veal short ribs -- Yum yum yum! The ribs felt like they were braised for hours -- they easily melted off of the bone into your mouth. It really didn't take much to chew on them at all! I never had such tender veal before. I really liked the sauce that came with it - it was a tomato puree that although very acidic, didn't actually taste too heavy and went very well the leeks and mushrooms.

+ Duck confit - The duck was perfectly crisp on the outside, yet so tender and silky smooth. I usually don't eat lentils, but they were cooked till they were very soft and complimented the duck. My only complaint was that sometimes the duck felt a bit dry -- maybe a bit overcooked to get that crisp on the outside?

+ Spicy calamari - Definitely on the spicy side. Calamari was very very fresh, chewy, and didn't have that seafood fishy-ness to it at all! Liked the addition of the peppers, and how it was just all grilled in olive oil. Must eat hot though, or else the olive oil starts to sit on the bottom. 

SERVICE:
Excellent! I was waiting for my friend for a good 30 minutes, but the waiter never shot me a weird look for not ordering anything, instead, came by twice to ask if I wanted any water or appetizer to start off with. He was also very knowledgable about the whole menu when we had questions, and periodically stopped by during service to take away our plates and ask how our food was.

****BIG TIP: Frenchies are known to have long 2 hour dinners, because they never rush you to eat. So that means as long as you have your appetizer unfinished still on the table, they won't serve you your entree, even if it's ready in the back. We waited for our entrees for awhile, kind of confused about the slow service, and then our server finally asked if we wanted our entrees to come out. Oopsies! So remember to tell them to just have the food come out when it's ready or else you'll be waiting for your food forever!
author: Evelyn S.

description:
It always a treat to dine at Fringale, so when a board member suggested that we meet there for lunch, I was spot on 10 minutes early. 

Jean-Marie, the very friendly restaurateur, exchanged my five-dollar bill for 2 hours worth of quarters. The parking meter took all my change and was as hungry as I was. I had some serious dental work recently done and I was so tired of pudding, potatoes, frijoles refritos, and Tang!

The store was not that busy, yet, so we enjoyed service of a pleasant Asian monsieur  and a delighted and lovely mademoiselle. Just so professional, helpful, but not too chatty.

While reviewing the menu, I was loving the best Arnold Palmer I've ever tasted. The lemonade was homemade for sure. Very tart, and not too sweet. 

Even though Lamb Shank was the special and a real favorite of mine, I decided on the Roquefort and Spinach Ravioli in a yummy cream sauce with pine nuts and basil and a salad with Prosciutto, thinly sliced Pears, mix greens, goat cheese topped with candied walnuts. My table mate ordered the same salad of the day and the Sautéed prawns in a yummy sauce of pastis, sun-dried tomatoes, shallots, and chives.

With every bite, I was thinking "this is soooo goood..." There was little time for me to talk, which is a rare occasion. I just sat there beaming and just enjoying all the flavors of my delicious lunch! 

I traded a ravioli for a prawn. While the ravioli was really good, I could have eaten a dozen of the Sautéed Prawns! The combination of the pastis liquor and sun-dried tomatoes was just perfect. Despite my Mother's training, I "mopped" up all the sauce with baguette!

My meal was topped more pears with carmel and vanilla ice cream. I wanted to lick the bowl!

You think you're in the communes of the Pyrénées-Atlantiques département with this classic french basque cuisine. One and 1/2 hours and five bucks worth of quarters later, life seems perfect.
author: David N.

description:
Fringale = Friggin' FAIL!

Perhaps, it's red flag when a DAT participating restaurant has numerous reservations available the SAME day just hours away from your chosen time slot?

My friend and I originally wanted to go to Slanted Door for dinner, but b/c it was booked and we wanted to eat nearby District, so we choose Fringale. It boosts a FOUR STAR rating on YELP, so how bad could it be? Well, can we just say OVERRATED!?!?!

On Thursday, 6.10.10, we were 18 minutes late for our 6 PM reservations b/c a car blocked my car along w/ four others at a parking lot near my office. My friend called in at 5:51 PM to tell them we would be late and we were told we "may" or "may not" be seated at a table b/c they were going to be busy. That's odd b/c when we arrived, the restaurant was only 50% filled. 

FOOD:
*PEI Mussels ($18): My friend liked it, but I thought it was meh to borderline ok. The mussels were TINY and the size of a nickel. Although they were tender and sweet, I didn't care for the sauce which was like a balsamic vinegar. It was too tangy and overpowered the mussels. 

*DAT MENU ($34.95)
-Spicy Calamari w/ Jalapeño and Chorizo: Eeeck! This basically was like a Chinese stir-fry type dish. The calamari was tender, but a bit chewy. I hate olives and I didn't know it was served w/ it. The olives were pungent and overpowered the entire dish. Chorizo? What chorizo? I carefully combed through the entire dish and found none. 

-Filet Mignon w/ Frites: It was ok. A filet is my fav cut of meat and I can say, the quality of the filet was quite poor. Although it was cooked medium rare, it was tough and chewy, and tasted more like a beef "tenderloin". Ummm, at least it was well-seasoned? The frites was very crisp and light, so no complaints there.

-Hazelnut and Roasted Almond Mousse cake: I wasn't too fond of this dessert. The were 2 layers of cake filled with hazelnut mousse. The cake was dense, dry and the mousse didn't have much hazelnut flavor to it. The best part was the roasted almond slices and chocolate sauce. 

SERVICE:
I totally agree with Anna T; the service at Fringale is pretentious, rude, and not attentive, to the "younger" crowd at least. The place wasn't even busy and it took a while for our waiter to even come and take out order who had a very uptight and condescending attitude. I asked him for wine recommendations and he just pointed to the most expensive one. I don't mind paying for good food and drinks, but it would help if he explained WHY he recommends it. 

The staff is completely unorganized and was running back and forth w/ dishes, not knowing what table ordered what. Then, as they passed through the tables, they kept on bumping into my chair and the lady in back of me w/ no apologies. 

Our waiter only checked in w/ us once towards the ends of our meal; mind you, this place is TINY and it wasn't crowded. I'm not asking for the Sun, the Moon, and the Stars, but if you're going to ask others how they are doing multiple times, you need to be consistent and make sure ALL your customers are doing ok. 

AMBIANCE/DÉCOR:
Fringale is "cozy" w/ a max capacity of about 40 in the main dining area. It has a very "fresh" vibe w/ the bright yellow walls, crisp white linen tables, and auburn furnishings. B/c it's a very small area and the tables are crammed close to each other, it can be quite difficult to hold an intimate conversation.

PARKING:
Street parking which is easy after 6 PM on a non-game night.

Looking for a true French bistro experience at reasonable prices? I highly recommend going to Chapeau instead where the Executive Chef and staff welcome you w/ open arms, the food is delectable, and the ambiance is classy and intimate. 

Sorry Fringale, you FAIL when it comes to having the "urge to eat" at your establishment...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Yum. The calamari app was on point with the right amount of olive oil, cayenne pepper (I think??), jalapeños balance. I had the rack of lamb wishing was also cooked and flavored perfectly with a tasty side of potato au gratin that had the perfect cheese crust.....though the portion of the lamb was on the small side. The best dish of the night however I thought was the seafood basquaise which my companion ordered. It had a rich flavorful tomato sauce that captured the full essence of the clams, prawns and mussels that accompanied the dish. This will definitely be my go to dish next time I visit again.
author: Chris S.

description:
Busy place so that is good.  Nice service and people.  Food was tasty sauce burning or the rib eye steak, and it was cooked too long for med rare.  Too fatty too for a $34 dollar steak.

Nice atmosphere, very nice waiter, food average.
author: Anthony B.

description:
Fringale....finally.  I adore, I'm enamored, I'm charmed.  You're quaint, subtle, sophisticated, and you could easily be five stars with me...

Lovely is a perfect way to describe Fringale.  From food to ambiance to service, lovely.  The spring vegetable salad and green beans, paired with a fitting wine, were a perfect way to start things off.  Another bit of loveiness for her veginess, they prepared a special starch-free vegetable dish that was seasoned and cooked to perfection.

Onto my favorite course...desserts.  Spectacular.  Memorable.  Classic.  Yet another reason to return.

All that's left is one more star.  Fringale, I have to play a little hard-to-get; I'll hold out on the coveted five stars upon my return :)
author: Angella S.

description:
Came here for my birthday dinner and it was okay. 

We started with the onion tarte, which was pretty good. I got the veal short ribs, which were delicious. However, my SO's sea bass was way overcooked; it tasted like it had been frozen for a while because it was so chewy and didn't flake like perfectly cooked fish could. I just expect more for $27 at a nice restaurant. 

Ended with the hazelnut & almond mousse cake, which was a little too sweet for me. It wasn't amazing, just okay.

Additionally, the service was pretty slow towards the end. 

Overall, the food is hit or miss, and for the prices and service, I would not come back here again. In retrospect, we wish we had chosen a different restaurant, especially for a birthday dinner.
author: Rhea K.

description:
Dine-about-town. June 1-15.  SoMa area 
Mentioned in James Patterson's "12th of Never", a little slice of France. Salad- dish of frisée with bacon dressing, pine nuts, and a pouched egg.
author: KaeRae Art C.

description:
Just Ok. 

We wanted to try a new place and with Dine About Town we decided to test out Fringale. It is just like being in France actually because the servers are very cold and almost rude. The food was fine, nothing tasted bad but absolutely nothing was great or exceptional. 

We had:
Duck Confit - good
Lamb Shank - good
frisee salad - best thing we had. warm bacon dressing and and egg
Spinach Ravioli - tons of spinach
Creme Brulee - pretty good but cold in the middle and warm around the edge.
Bread Pudding - nothing like standard bread pudding

I do not see any reason to come back unless you love French flavors and just want an A-OK meal.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Oh my goodness, what a pleasant surprise this turned out to be.
Andre, our waiter was the consummate professional. Friendly, warm, patient, and helpful. Helped make the experience wonderful.
The food was fantastic. We started out with the calamari. Cooked just right with such wonderful flavors.
We then ordered the Roasted rack of lamb, the rib eye steak, & the Seafood Basquaise.
We all shared and agreed that all were wonderfully delicious. 
For dessert we shared the Warm chocolate gourmand.
What a nice finish! 
We'll definitely be back!
author: Charles L.

description:
I loved the atmosphere and our waiter.  He had such a lovely accent I made him repeat himself. Hahaha.  The service was great and our waiter was so cute! I love DAT!
 
The crab cake had a layer of avocado topped with mango salsa!   I admit I'm not a huge fan of mango salsa, but this was wonderful and refreshing. It came feathered in arugula! YUM.

I ordered the lamb shank and it was HUGE. The meat was so tender I barely used my knife.  The spinach was lovely and the mushrooms were cut in such a way I thought it was noodles because of the romantic lighting. :) It tasted beautiful!

I had the coffee parfait and I loved it. Yes, it had a very strong alcohol taste, but the combination made it so delicious.  There was a prune adorned on top... oh nostalgia.  I haven't had a prune since I was a teenager and I love that stuff!
author: Amy L.

description: Very good below the radar French bistro which is perfect for a weeknight dinner when you haven't made reservations elsewhere.
author: Matt M.

description:
Although Fringale has been around since the early '90s, I've never gone. I finally went there for a casual business lunch.  The food was outstanding, the service top-notch (very European). We lingered there far beyond lunch time, but were left alone, and occasionally asked if we wanted more water or drinks.  Highly recommended.  It's probably better (in terms of lingering over the meal) for dinner.  Must investigate further.

Michael D. (from SF)
author: Michael D.

description:
DINNER ONLY

Man I really wanted to like this place. It wasn't bad but it wasn't great. Came here during restaurant week. Ordered their foie grad Terrine (say goodbye starting July 1!). not my favorite but the accompanying sauce was pretty good. Ordered the salmon which wasn't anything special. Ordered the ravioli with goat cheese which normally i would love but the cheese overpowered the entire dish. Was really hoping for a winner here but it didn't come through.
author: Diana Y.

description:
I went here at Dine about Town with 3 friends. They had a pre-fix menu with 3 items for each starter, main and dessert. All the food tasted amazing. We got couscous, salmon, pork and lam dishes, 3 appetizers and 3 desserts. Overall great quality, nice ambience.
However our waiter seemed a little impatient and slightly rude. But other than that great experience for the price we paid.
author: Haleh H.

description: This is a pretty small place so probably come with a reservation.  We were a group of 10 and sat at the one large table they had.  For starters I had the soup du jour, which was a creamy asparagus soup.  It lacked flavor for my taste.  The Mr. ordered the calamari which was the winner.  I ordered the sea bass for my main--not super memorable.  He ordered the bacon wrapped tenderloin; winner again.  I usually win at ordering food, but the 3 stars is not because I'm a sore loser.  I think at least one of my dishes should've left me satisfied.  Sad that neither did.
author: Thi D.

description:
Just had dinner for 3 here and my suspicion turned out true! Came here cause of the prix fixe but waiter said there wasn't any, which was odd (on site + yelp) but thought it was maybe not avail then? :/

2 people ordered the special of filet mignon and was quoted $30 for entree only. Checking it now, their site is listing $25 entrees and $38 special prix fixe!! No fine print nothing. 
To top it off the "specials" sucked. Dry and definitely not Zagat quality. The calamari was ok though. (*EDIT: looks like they added a +$5 fine print on one section of their site now. Sneaky... But left out the edit on another part, hah!)

Also I can attest to the waiters rudeness. They knocked (moved me too!) my chair twice(!!!) throughout the night and never apologized or mentioned anything despite my disapproving glare. Pricks.

(Warning: Avoid!! all the reviews mentioning price here should check difference first. They jack the price up from what is listed. More about the principle! Got conned!)
(*Edit: in response to comment reply below.)
author: Han T.

description: We went to this restaurant for our Ladies Night out and the food was soooo delecious!  Don't miss out the Layer of hazel mousse and genoise topped with roasted almonds for dessert. Totally love this place!
author: Maries M.

description:
Fringale is one of the better French restaurants in the city within the $$$ price range. I came here for a friend's birthday awhile ago and, overall, it was a good experience. 

Things I liked here: the foie gras and the duck. I typically prefer my foie gras seared (and not terrine), but the foie gras terrine here was pretty good. I remember the duck being solid, as well.  

The restaurant itself is small and cozy. Although our long table was a bit cramped (making it difficult for those of us sitting on the booth side to get in and out), I was impressed that they were able to accomodate a fairly large group. Although the dishes weren't particularly inventive, this is a solid place if you're craving some authentic French food.
author: Sarah T.

description:
This place never disappoints me. I had gone several times since my last review of this place and I went back again last weekend. It was the same warm and cozy environment with great service that I have become accustomed to. They started me off with a kir royale to drink.  This time I ordered the salad frisee and the seafood basquaise, both of which were delicious and meticulously prepared and presented.  They have also come to know my preference for olive oil instead of butter with my bread as I did not even have to remind them.

I continue to maintain that this is one of the finest spots to dine in the city and very reasonably priced.  If you are with a group of friend or even a hot date and want to impress with your since of taste and style, then La Fringale continues to be a great choice!
author: Mike L.

description:
4.5 stars.  Only a ho-hum salad away from 5.

Our party of four had an all-around wonderful experience, from gracious servers letting us in a few minutes before opening time to an excellent wine recommendation and superb food.  We hadn't been here in a while, despite enjoying it each time in the past, but based on this visit, we resolved to come back more frequently.

The Mussels were exceptional -- as good as any in Brussels (the moules frites capital of the world) and quite possibly better.  Dungeness crab Napoleon was a great seasonal treat.  Almost everything else was flawless and fantastically flavored -- ravioli, haricots verts, butternut squash soup, gateau basque, pain perdu, and a few more things I can't remember.  Unfortunately the butter lettuce salad fell flat; it was just too bland and boring, even for butter lettuce.  But that was the only minor hitch in an otherwise perfect meal.
author: Jay G.

description: Five of us came to this little gem on a Saturday night in August. While it was odd that our drinks at the bar were on a different tab (instead of being part of our table tab), the food was very good and service was great. The only thing was that our table set up was a bit awkward. For an upscale place, I was expecting a better overall experience.  We paid about $80/person including drinks and dessert. It is a pity that I don't know if the experience enough for us to return.
author: William L.

description:
My new favorite French place. It was quite  hike to get to--we walked from Montgomery BART--so I suggest you drive or cab. I think seeing how a restaurant deals with a large party is very telling for their service overall... We were here with a large party of probably 16 and the service was great. No one had to ask for water or drinks and they didn't mix up anyone's orders.

I had the duck confit and it was delicious. I saw what the others ordered and can't wait for the next special occasion to come back. The salads, entrees and even the fries looked amazing.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Came for Dine About Town.

I arrived about 5:50 for our 6pm reservation. We were seated right away, and in a few minutes we ordered. The appetizer arrived in a few minutes after ordering.

Tried the "Roquefort and Spinach Ravioli" which was delicious. Very tender and the cheese with the hint of blue cheese made a great difference.

They added "Coq au vin" as a nightly special and was available for Dine About Town. So I ordered it. The meat fell off the bone and all pieces were savory and tender. I used the bread to soak up the sauce, my plate was clean by the end of the meal.

Finally I had the "Chocolate Gourmand" dessert with a little raspberry sauce around the side and ice cream on top, which was excellent.

Overall I was quite satisfied with the portions and the meal overall, this being my fifth visit over the years.
author: Brandon W.

description:
This is one of my wife and my favorite restaurants in our neighborhood.

We had the Jambon de Bayonne, Cassoulet de Toulouse, and Gateau basque.

It was very tasty though not filling however a good value prix fixe meal.
author: Francis M.

description: A restaurant I will come back for more. Price and quality matches well. Traditional food that would be consistent and not disappoint you. We had the smoked duck salad, foie gras paired with a yummy dessert wine, lamb chops and seafood basket, finalised with creme brûlée, which was okey.
author: Zici L.

description:
Cozy bistro in the SOMA. Our waiter gave us the authentic feel with his heavy accent.

Roquefort and Spinach Ravioli toasted pine nuts, basic and cream sauce- Not too rich or heavy on the cheese. I was nervous that the blue cheese would be too strong but it was okay. The pasta was thin and al dente

Calamary a la Pancha jalapenos, chorizo and olives- Although I liked this dish for its great flavors and spicy kick, I was pretty disappointed that I did not see one piece of chorizo in there

Petrole sole, mashed potato carots, zucchini and piquillo pepper beurre blanc- Fresh and cooked well. I particularly enjoyed the bright orange pepper sauce.

Coffee parfait- meh

Hazelnut and almond cake- Light and not too sweet. I loved the combination of the light cake texture with the crispy almonds.
author: Schelly Y.

description:
It was a OK restaurant for me. 
Came here with my hubby on Friday night. I could get a reservation on the day via Open table, which is nice. 

FOOD 
1) Foie Gras Pate -It was ok. I like more creamy, rich fore gras.... In my opinion, the best way to eat foie gras is to have it as saute.  Also, the portion was a bit too big, for me.., buy I like the way they put toast and chutnee.
2) Crab Napoleon pie -The presentation was beautiful, but again it has just a ordinary taste. 
3) Bacon wrapped pork loin -Good. The pork was tender and tasty. But I am not a big fan of the "bistro" like sauce they put on it...
4) Spinach and rockfall cheese ravioli -Disaster... just I am not the fan of this kind of taste. 
5) Ice cream with chocolate souffle -So yummy! I am not a desert person but I really liked this. 

DECOR / ATMOSPHERE
Clean and beautiful but still casual. Comfortable. 

SERVICE
Nice and friendly. All the waiters had a French accent ;-) Nice!

PRICE
Not reasonable, but decent I think. We had a half bottle of red wine and coffee in addition with the above dishes and it was almost $100.
author: Heidi M.

description:
I'd been wanting to try Fringale for ages, and thanks to Dine About Town, I finally got the chance Sunday night.  Fringale's DAT menu is VERY good.  You have great choices.  As I sat there, skimming my options, I had difficulty narrowing it down.  I wanted everything.  

For January 2010 DAT, they've got 3 excellent choices for each course, and might I add that each course comes in a generous portion = WIN:
Apps: mussels, charcuterie, or dungeness crab ravioli
Entrees: coq au vin, filet mignon, or petrale sole
Desserts: warm chocolate gourmand, creme brulee, or an almond and hazelnut mousse cake

My meal of crab ravioli, coq au vin, and creme brulee was solid all the way through.  The crab ravioli in lobster bisque was some of the best I've ever had.  Flavorful, hearty, and good portions too.  The coq au vin was oh-so-tender, meat fell off the bones, though it was a tad bit salty for my taste.  Subtract a star.  The creme brulee was fantastic.  Too bad I don't like sweet things because I ended up only eating half of it, and giving the rest of it to one of my foodmates.  But seriously, it was a very well-made creme brulee, and it's apparently what they're known for.  

I love classy-casual restaurants, and Fringale's definitely one of those. One of my friends came decked out in a full suit, and another foodmate arrived, fresh from a basketball game, in a bright green t-shirt with rabbits all over it.  Awesome.  I love it.  Suit, t-shirt, and everything in between works.  Although if I were you, I would opt for something in between a suit and a green rabbit t-shirt.  But hey, whatever works!  

So, yeah, the atmosphere was really cozy and casual, though at times I thought it was odd that the lighting kept flickering between light and dark.  Maybe there's something wrong with my eyes.  

Service was also excellent.  Our waiter kept refilling our bread basket (good bread, by the way) and our waters.  That's the way I like it.  Getting stuffed on carbs and hydrated on H20 in between courses.  Good stuff.

Everyone else in our party of 7 enjoyed their meals, and this place seems like one of the better DAT deals.  I don't know about you, but for me, it was intimidating seeing that entire list of DAT restaurants and figuring out which one(s) to choose.  I mean, you don't want to go wrong and plop down $40+ on lackluster food, right? 

Well, Fringale's a good bet.  I know I'm just one person, but something's gotta be right if the almost-500 reviews here rave about the eats.
author: Vivian C.

description: Beet salad was delicious. Sea bass was slightly over cooked...
author: Tikisha O.

description:
Delish!!!!

Came for my anniversary and experienced the following:

-Perfect Food
-Perfect Service
-Perfect ambiance

I knew it was going to be good when I saw how packed it was and the people hanging around the door praying to get a reservation that night (seems like they had openings and were able to be seated quickly)

If your worried about price it's 100% worth it. I left with leftovers that were devoured on my trip home to Oakland. The lamb really is fall off the bone tender, and my boyfriends rib eye was cooked medium well and Fringale is the only place Ive been so far to cook it perfectly as asked.

Oh and all the waiters are French, it's was nice to experience the full effect.
author: Wynter D.

description:
Had coq au vin and duck confit, both were excellent. Loved the bits of mushroom and bacon in the potatoes for duck confit. Salad was meh. Creme brule was good but expensive. 
I definitely would visit again since it's next door, but I will probably just order main plait.
author: Lisa D.

description:
Really more like 4.5 stars.

The whole experience was really nice- the food was cooked very well, fresh ingredients, nice service.  The only thing is that the area isn't the nicest and the dessert recommendation was a bit underwhelming.  Overally, it was a solid place and nothing was unpleasant.
author: Cathy U.

description:
Fringale has an amazing atmosphere which really makes up for the so-so food.

My boyfriend took me here last night for a celebratory dinner. The ambiance is romantic, cozy and intimate. I loved it. We sat in the corner table, lit with a small votive candle. We ordered a bottle of champagne to start off the night!

Our appetizer was the Assiette de charcuterie. It's basically a small assortments of meats/pate that you eat with bread that's provided. In the charcuterie was saucisson sec, duck rillettes, pate, Serrano ham, cornichons and grain mustard. The grain mustard was too strong for my personal tastes, but I loved the pate. Very delicious! 

My main dish was the cassoulet. It happened to be the monthly special. It's an extremely rich, slow-cooked casserole with meats such as duck, sausage, pork cooked within it. Very very heavy, but delicious. My boyfriend ordered the traditional duck confit with came with lentils, potatoes "Landaises" and a sauce of garlic, bacon and red wine. He seemed to really enjoy it, however, I did not try it so I cannot give my own personal review. For dessert we ordered the warm chocolate Gourmand which is basically a small, round, flourless chocolate cake served with a mint sorbet on top. I normally do not like mint at all, but I could barely taste it and it seemed to compliment the chocolate cake very very well. 

All in all, good meal and great for couples!
author: Angela K.

description:
Fringale is one of my favorite little places to bring a friend and catch up. It can fill up later in the week so grab a reservation to be sure. It's conveniently located near Caltrain if you have someone visiting from the South Bay.

You can't go wrong with anything on the menu, but my favorite items are the bacon-wrapped pork loin, duck confit, and rack of lamb, with a hot chocolate gourmand topped with fruit & ice cream for dessert. I look forward to seeing how their menu changes with the season and will definitely be back often.
author: Stephanie P.

description: We have enjoyed dinner 3 times at Fringale now and have had excellent service and food.  The Frisée salad is a must.  The lamb shank is hearty and very flavorful.  We followed dinner with the apple tart which was also very tasty.  What a charming place.  We will be regulars.
author: Carey B.

description:
To start off dramatically, Fringale has the worst French food I've had in San Francisco.  You may notice that I've still given it four stars - that's because even though I've had better, Fringale was still very good!

A few friends and I came for Dine About Town, though after looking at the menu you can definitely get a great three course dinner under $40 on a regular night.

For my appetizer, I tried the calamari, which wasn't very memorable.  It was an impressively large plate of calamari, but that was about it.  The flavors were bland to salty, and the texture was rubbery instead of that great calamari crunch.

The duck confit was out of this world!  The best duck confit I've ever had - it really elevated this meal.  The meat was falling off the bone, lentils sitting in delicious sauce, and I think there must have been some bacon in there.  Really, really fantastic.

Unfortunately the duck confit had to end and then came the creme brulee for dessert.  If creme brulee is on the dessert menu, there's a 85% chance I will order it.  Love the stuff.  Fringale's creme brulee, however, left my scratching my head.  You know when you're at a casual restaurant and you have the option of either a cup or bowl of soup?  Imagine that cup firmly in your mind.  That is what my creme brulee came in.  It was deep, it was narrow, and it had a terrible creme-to-carmelized goodness ratio.

So, really, only one of my three courses warrants a rating above two or three stars.  But man, that was some great duck confit.
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Short and sweet: 

Order the bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin (juicy, flavorful, great sauce!), the hazelnut cake (heavenly, especially with the chocolate under it!). 

Especially for DAT, for those who hate the seafood, fishy taste, don't order Dungeness crab with lobster bisque (too overwhelmingly fishy). Filet mignon was good and cooked to perfection but it wasn't exciting or new.
author: Tina T.

description:
Delicious, very authentic French food. This is a really quaint and cozy French restaurant, with excellent service and great food. I tried the soup and the duck confit. They were excellent, albeit predictable. 

A warm place for friends' gathering or a nice date.
author: Vivien S.

description: Had my birthday dinner here on Saturday night, group of 10 of us and all loved their food.  I had the crab napoleon and rack of lamb - both were delicious!  Other great items at the table - calamari, scallops, frisee salad.  All were great would definitely recommend Fringale.
author: Ben D.

description:
Love this place.  This past weekend, I was there with 4 other friends and everything was fantastic.  The experience made it a perfect night for me.  This is my first time there and it was suggested by 2 people in my group who had been there before.

We shared 5 appetizers which we all scraped the plates cleaned.  The most memorable ones for me were the Crab Salad and the Calamari.  The calamari wasn't at all what I expected.  Better than I expected I have to clarify.  I was sort of sauteed and not deep fried like I normally would see elsewhere.

For entrée, I ordered the Duck Confit.  The duck meat just stripped right off the bone.  Very tasty.  I had a bite of my friend's sea bass dish which was also so yummy!

I had Crème Brûlee for dessert, which was creamy and not to sweet at all.  Just the perfect amount of sweetness, the way I like it.

The waiter at our table was a french guy who was kind and charming.  Three out of us five study french and we were able to speak to him in french a little and he just kindly responded back to us in french too.  No attitude at all even though I'm sure we probably didn't say everything correctly.

Fringale isn't a big place, but the seatings are set in the way that accommodate all parties well.  There wasn't a time when we had to yell because the conversation from other tables were interfering ours at all.  Very intimate within my group even when other groups weren't too far from us.  Wonderful experience and will definitely come back again soon.
author: Joe C.

description:
Fringale deserves every star that AAA and Yelp give it.  The food is exquisitely flavored, and by that, I mean it inspired me. I hadn't realized that I was not bringing the full flavor out of my food when I cooked at home and feel inspired to try something new.

We had a charming older gentleman as a waiter who joked around with us a little and was both patient and attentive.

Fringale is spotless and has a relaxing muted decor (light green, pale purple, blonde wood)

I recommend a reservation, because we booked for 5:45 pm on a Saturday and within the next 15 minutes, all of the other tables were filled (of which there are a about 11 total, seating 40-50 people), and there were 2-3 at the bar (which looked to seat maybe 7)

For attire, my fellow diners were in clothing ranging from casual to dressy.

Parking is available across the street (no pay for Starbucks and Wells Fargo customers and pay in the other lot, or cruise for a street spot). (Fringale will be on your right on 4th street, which is a one-way street.)

About that inspiring food:
Butter lettuce salad tasted like it was picked that day.
The duck confit (medium rare) was moist, only slightly gamey (just enough to be tasty but not overwhelming).
The flavor of the vegetables in the couscous "popped" against the canvas of couscous. (Now I realize how fennel is meant to be used :-)
Rack of lamb has a beautiful display. We made a mistake and ordered it well done (which it was) but that made it tough and next time, I would order it medium rare. It came with perfectly blanched green beans. It came with a potato-and-cheese (Gruyere) gratin which was different (and delicious) in that it was more like a personal pancake than a slice of casserole. 
Creme brûlée was a generous serving, and had the wonderful richness of eggs, cream, and vanilla. It was served slightly cooled.
The plate of cheese had a selection of six distinctively-flavored cheeses (some more pungent than others), and all of which I enjoyed.
author: Kathy M.

description:
This is one of the best meal We ve had in San francisco.
And We would love to return to the restaurant.
The seafood Basquiat was perfect.
The duck con fit was very crispy and delicious.
Excellent french cuisine in a quaint setting.
Excellent and well priced wine list.
Even though the restaurant was full of people, the service was very good.
author: Freddy D.

description: This is more like a 3, but I'll give it a 4 because it was a place to grab a bite on a weeknight without feeling overly cramped (like many SF establishments), and the mussels were pretty good -- although a little overseasoned.
author: Mel G.

description: We tried to find a place to eat around our condo recently and couldn't find anything so thought we'd try Fringale even though we didn't have a reservation.  They were super accommodating and we got in in no time and had a wonderful meal.  I had the Creekstone Farm black angus ribeye steak which was perfectly cooked and the fries were delicious.
author: Blake B.

description: Four of us had a great time, all the dishes that we ordered were a hit. We especially enjoyed the scallop appetizers and the duck confit main. The desserts were all just incredible. We usually share but I protected my gateau basque with my fork - and my knife. Don't miss it.
author: Deb S.

description:
Came here today with my wife for the dine about town special. Place is very quaint. This is the first time I've been to a French restaurant. Servers are very friendly and welcoming.

Appetizers: 
I got the Spicy Monterey calamari "a la plancha". Very good. Not over cooked. Not too spicy. For once I ate a calamari appetizer that wasn't deep fried. +1 for the jalapenos in the dish.
The wife got the dungeness crab napoleon, avocado, lemon zest, piquillo peppers, & mango salsa. This was GOOD. I honestly like this one better than mine. Crab was abundant and tasted fresh. The avocado and crab went well together. My first time trying that combo. The wife loved it.

Main Course:
I got the Traditional duck confit, lentils "Du Puy", potatoes Landaises, garlic, bacon & red wine sauce. The duck was cooked to perfection. Meat fell off the bones. The garlic and bacon went well with the taste of the duck fat. I could tell the bacon fat was used to cook the potatoes. That's another +1 in my book.

Wife got the fish...unfortunately, I do not remember the name of the dish. It's currently not on their website. It tasted good though. The risotto the fish was placed on was moist, not dry. 

Desserts were pretty much standard. Overall, the wife and I had a good time. We will definitely come back next time we are in the city craving French food. I would recommend this place to my friends. I wonder how their macaroni and cheese taste like?
author: Patrick D.

description:
I went to Fringale last Sunday with the wifey, on the first day of "Dine About Town" and we couldn't have been happier with our food and service. They were a bit overwhelmed because it was prime dinner time (around 8pm) and they were clearly having more customers than they anticipated. So we had to wait for some 20-30 minutes, which we used to wash down some delicious Rioja and Bordeaux at the bar. The place is small, maybe a dozen tables total, and let's say cozy, but not uncomfortably so. Not too noisy either, so you could have a pleasant conversation while dining or waiting to be served.

And now to the food. We had the DaT prix fixe menu, which had 3 choices for appetizers, entree and dessert. I started with the grilled calamari, packing a bit of a spice punch (unexpected at a French place, but pleasant), and she had the dungeness crab patties, which was superior in my opinion. The layered avocado and cabbage made it a winner, simple and refreshing. Then she followed with the sole over risotto, which was pretty good if not spectacular, but I had the most amazing lamb shank I remember in a long time. The meat was a tad crunchy on the outside, juicy and extra tender inside. I'm still salivating over that. Finally, I had the coffee mousse for dessert (yummy, but forgettable), while she had the chocolate gourmand, clearly a better choice (I would have gone for it if she hadn't ordered it first, since we wanted to try different things).

I would like to say I'll be back soon, but Fringale is on the pricey side for us. We'll definitely return next time there's a deal like this, or perhaps on a special occasion.
author: Pablo D.

description:
So I've been coming to Fringale for years. When I decided to bring my kids I was a bit nervious. Since they are 10&12 yr old girls. If you you have young kids you know what I mean. Well my 12 yr old ordered the duck confit(YUM!), my 10 yr old got the fish special(Yum!) my wife got steak Frits (Yum). I just ordered the salad frisée( the dressing was perfect).  Well as you can see my wife and I enjoyed all. When my 12 yr old started on the duck my wife and I were holding our breath. To out amazinment she abosolutely loved the duck. She basic my licked the plate clean. My 10 yet old loves everything and of cause loved all the dishes. 
So I must say if I could rate higher then 5 stars I would. 
It was a very pleasurefull dining experience. The service was top notch and they were very accommodating to the kids. 
Thank you Frigale for a special diner with my family. Continue the 5 star food and service.  
Merci et bonne journée:-)
author: Howard C.

description: One star for the cute waiter that provided us three course long conversation topic. Food is very delicate. Recommend the almond and hazel nut mousse.
author: Yiqiu Z.

description:
We decided to try the prix fixe menu here on New Years Eve. To start, we had a very interesting asparagus veloute as an "amuse bouche". My appetizer of oysters was a bit underwhelming, but not terrible. The oysters themselves were on the smaller side, and I much prefer the larger varieties. However my main of seared scallops with risotto was absolutely amazing. Seriously an ideal dish for me and one of the best dishes I have ever tasted - I wish I could go back and order it again. Finally, my dessert, a sorbet trio including a peach chardonnay sorbet, was light and refreshing and really delicious. 

The service was wonderful and polished and the atmosphere was elegant and sophisticated. My only minor complaint is the tables are crammed together because space is at a premium when the restaurant is busy. I would love to give this place 4.5 stars with half a star deducted for the so-so appetizer and cramped space. But next time I'm in San Fran, I would definitely come back to try some items on the regular menu.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
If I had to use one word to describe Fringale it would be quaint. It is a nice smallish but airy restaurant and this is a great place to have lunch or dinner on a warm day because they open up the huge front windows allowing you to look at the many people passing by.

The restaurant is well lit and clean. You will also notice the amazing classy wood floors and nice little bar which add to the restaurants classy looks.
The service was amazing and all of the servers have thick French accents which was different and nice. They also have senses of humor.  This was my second visit and the food was really good. I would highly recommend the duck confit which is served with lentils "Du Puy", garlic, bacon & red wine sauce and the Endive & watercress salad with persimmons, candied walnuts, goat cheese in champagne vinaigrette. I will definitely go back.
author: Chocoolate I.

description:
Went to Fringale last night because they are supporting the East Bay Humane Society by donating a portion of the night's proceeds to the shelter.   

We had a late reservation, but the restaurant was still more than half full, which was nice because I like to dine in a lively environment with music and all.  

The waiter was very nice, casual yet very polite.   He briefed us the daily special, but we decided to go with other dishes.  And here are what we ordered:

Appetizers:

1.  FOIE GRAS TERRINE.  Loved it.  They substituted the pineapple chutney with black mission figs instead.  When we make foie gras at home, we use figs jam too.  With the sea salt and cayenne pepper and toasted brioche, this definitely is one of my favorite appetizers.

2.  SPICY MONTEREY CALAMARI.  This tasted more like a Spanish tapas to me, but it's very delicious.  The right amount of spiciness induced my appetite.  It's a big plate for an appetizer!

Entrees:

1.  ROASTED RACK OF LAMB.  Tender meat, perfect medium, but only two bones!  But with the potato gratin, it's pretty filling.

2.  STEAMED ALASKAN HALIBUT.  I rarely order fish, but I was looking for a light meal so this entree was perfect for me.  Too bad I didn't like it much, the fish was kind of overcooked, and the vinaigrette didn't help to bring out the flavor of the fish.  I guess I like grilled fish more.  But if you check out the picture, this dish had a very nice presentation.

Dessert:

We shared the POACHED PEACH WITH TOASTED ALMONDS AND CREAM.  I took of one star because their dessert menu was plain.

Overall experience:

Awesome.  This was our second visit to Fringale and both times we received great service and great ambiance.  Foie gras is a must-have!
author: Tadaa T.

description: OK but not great.  French onion soup was ok but not really that authentic French flavor.  Petrale Sole's delicate flavor was totally overpowered by a strong tomato-based sauce that drowned the poor Petrale!  Chocolate lave cake desert was delicious!  2 in our party of 6 ordered the lamb chops, one medium, one medium rare.  Both came so underdone they both had to be sent back.  Also, entrees did not all arrive at the same time. Off by several minutes, so us polite people had to wait to start digging in.  Is the kitchen too small to get 6 entrees out at the same time?  Any decent chef knows how to do this...it's not rocket science.  Waiter was not especially friendly or helpful.  Given all the great SF restaurant choices, I doubt we will go back to Fringale.
author: M B.

description: Very good, consistent food and friendly service. You can't really go wrong.
author: Russell S.

description:
My husband found a last minute reservation here on a Friday night and I didn't know what to expect. 

The environment is really warm, cozy, and not pretentious. More importantly, I really appreciated their service and consideration for us. My husband was walking on crutches and they were extremely accommodating. The manager (I'm assuming), moved tables for us, so that my husband can move around comfortably throughout the night. He also took his crutches and placed them next to the front door. Then, when he had to go to the restroom, a waitstaff went ahead of him and opened the door for him. They could've grumbled about the situation, but they made our night out extremely enjoyable. 

The food was also pretty good. We got the calamari appetizer, the lamb, and short ribs. Some of the food was a little salty for my taste, but it was generally tasty. The prices were also extremely reasonable. 

One thing I must RAVE about is their creme brulee. My goodness. It was seriously the best creme brulee I've ever had, and I have a desire to go back just to try more of their desserts. YUM
author: Grace L.

description:
Staff was very accommodating, we were running late to see our show, so as soon as we sat, I ordered and our food came out very quickly.  

The food itself was very good and fresh.  The crab cake was divine.  (thanks yelpers!)  I also had the mixed greens salad with pears which is hard to mess up.

The entrees weren't as fantastic.  The pork tenderloin was very undercooked and SUPER SUPER chewy.  The lamb was a bit easier to chew.

The most disappointing part of the meal was dessert.  I had read a yelpers review of their basque cake being the only dessert item not house made but being the BEST basque cake they've ate....this was not true for us.  Trying eating Sen's basque cake in the embarcadero.  

All in all, the food was decent, the staff were very nice, quick, and accomodating.  The ambiance was cozy and romantic, but can get very crowded - the restaurant is small and they pack you in.

Can't really say I'd be back though, there's just too many choices in the City.
author: Janet L.

description:
We need to stop ordering from the prefixed meal and order what we prefer instead. I need to go back here.

The girl ordered the prefixed and I ordered the crab napoleon which was actually very good but not very filling. We also order Mac and Cheese cause that's what we do at french restaurants. It was very weird, it had squash in it which I didn't like at all. Minus the squash, the Mac and Cheese was pretty good. Her main course was some kind of goulash that she found very good. 

The service was great and I could see at the other tables, they had a lot of dishes I'd like to try. I didn't order right and would like to try again. I think this place has some great potential on being on our list of goto restaurants.
author: Ryan R.

description: The menu is very good and service is friendly and prompt. We tried the pork and seafood dinners. Mood was perfect for carrying a conversation. Easy to reserve a table for the same night and not super crowded like the other places in the neighborhood.
author: Joe S.

description:
Fringale is a great restaurant!

I really enjoyed my food and experience. It's small and casual but still elegant. The service is great and they have a really nice wine list. I had the duck confit, of course, and it was moist and full flavor just ad I had expected. Veggies were great, spinach ravioli appetizer was wonderful and the quinoa was delish. And si ce you cant have a French meal without dessert, I had to have the cremd brulee which was perfect.

Fringale is on my go to list.
author: Denise S.

description:
Very solid French food and reasonably priced!

Fringale is a great little gem in SOMA.  It is unmistakably French: the menu, the wine list, the waiters, and their accent.  

+ Food is very well-executed with very balanced flavors.  Standouts include:
The Lamb.  Before we even finished asking for recommendations, the waiter had already cut in with "ze lamb", and it did not disappoint.  
Braised Short Ribs.  So rich and flavorful.  The sauce was very rich but the slight acidity from the tomatoes really helped cut through it.  
Spicy Calamari 'a la plancha'.  Grilled to perfection - nicely charred but tender. 

+ Wine list is not huge, but has a good range of variety and prices.  

+ Waiters are very knowledgeable - and opinionated.  Just go with their recommendations, if you need to, on both food and wine.  You will be in safe hands.

- Only complaint is the restaurant is small and the tables are packed tight.  Not the most comfortable seating.
author: Thomas L.

description:
Thank you SF Dine About Town for introducting me to this lovely food establishment. A cute, quaint, and cozy place south of market offering an array of french food. Here is what we ordered:
 
-Calamari: This is real calamari folks...not that deep fried crap lol. Its super yummy and the olives and peppers give it an amazing flavor. 
-Dungeness crab ravioli: 3 pieces of deliciously filled ravioli and a lobster bisque...so good
- Duck confit: The duck was cooked perfectly and the lentils were a great match. The meat on the duck fell right off the bone. 
 -Filet mignon: OH WOW! One of the best ive had. You can definitely taste that this fellow was grass fed. They cooked it perfectly just as I asked...medium-rare. They paired it with potatos au grautin. Talk about buttery and creamy goodness! I think the potatoes alone wouldve sufficed for my 4-star review!
-Chocolate Gourmand: chocolate and gelato? Cannot go wrong!
 -Hazelnut & roasted almond mousse cake: flavors were pungent...in a great way!

The service was excellent...our waiter was very attentive...although it was busy, he always managed to make his way over. Drinks were good too. For dinner we asked our waiter to pair our entree up with whatever he recommended and he brought out a lovely Bordeaux...it matched our food perfectly.
