At the end of the evening I asked him to call us a cab. We finished dessert and paid the bill and left.

As I was smoking a cigarette outside, he ran out to tell us that our cab would be a blue desoto. How nice of him to take the time out and let me know as we completely forget (1 too many cocktails I suppose).

This place is service and food at its best. The only reason I gave it 4 stars and not 5 is because the venue is just a little to cramped for my style. If you werent watching yourself you could easily run into people/tables/food lol. We will definitely come back and try all the other items on the menu...cant wait!
author: Catie N.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend for the last night of Dine About Town, so it was $35 for a 3 course meal. 

--Appetizers--
I got the spicy calamari, which was super delicious. I loved how soft the calamari was to chew, but my boyfriend was not accustomed to non-fried calamari, so I don't think he liked it as much hahaha. The sauce was really good and made it taste almost like a chewy pasta (I mean this to sound good, not gross...). There were also jalapeno peppers and regular red peppers and strips of salami/pepperoni inside. Mmmm! My boyfriend chose the spinach ravioli as his appetizer. Omg this was sooo not worth it that it's hilarious. Regular price was $11 or $12, but you get 4 pieces of ravioli. It was pretty good but nothing amazing...just spinach inside ravioli.

--Main Course--
Another cause for laughter - the size of my entree in comparison to my boyfriend's. I got the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin and I really did not enjoy it. I got exactly 4 small pieces of meat (4 was apparently our lucky number that night...) and it was on a bed of really nasty pickled cabbage...My boyfriend got a GIANT lamb shank. It looked very caveman-ish and there was a considerable more amount of meat on it. 

--Dessert--
I got the creme brulee. SO DELICIOUS! It was my first time trying creme brulee but I liked how light it tasted. My boyfriend got the chocolate gourmand, which was a flour-less chocolate cake?! It was SUPER sweet compared to my creme brulee but still really rich. 

Despite the disappointment of my main course, I would still say that this place is a solid 4 stars because my other 2 courses were good, service was amazing, and maybe I just chose the wrong main course...
author: Jenny M.

description:
Brought my mom and sister out for DAT. The menu was fairly extensive compared to other restaurants that participated in DAT. We ordered one of each item on the menu. 

Appetizer 
The roquefort cheese and spinach ravioli were amazing. The cheese was pungent but perfectly balanced by the spinach. The dungeness crab napoleon was to die for. The crab was fresh and flavorful, the avocado adds some fattiness and the mango relish adds sweetness. A fork-full of all three was just amazing! The calamari was A-okay. The jalapenos added a bit of spiciness, but the dish was a bit flat when it came to flavor.

Entree
The sole lacked seasoning, but the risotto was super delicious. I ate every bite of risotto and the sauce that accompanied the fish. The meat on the lamb shank fell off the bone. The sauce was perfect and the mash potatoes were fluffy and light. The lamb itself was flavorful and tender, but the mushrooms definitely added layers of flavor and complexity. The duck confit was delicious, but a bit dry. The duck skin was seared to a perfect crispy, but the dish could have benefited with a little more sauce.

Dessert
The creme brulee was more creamy than custard-y. Not too sweet, but a little too burnt for my liking. The parfait was reminscent of a tiramisu, but the parfait had too strong of an alcohol taste. The warm chocolate gourmand was easily the favorite dish I had the entire night. The warm cake balanced well with the scoop of vanilla icing. The berries added different levels of sweetness and texture to the dessert. 

Overall, the meal was amazing. The food is really good as a whole and I'm glad I chose this restaurant to try. Next time, I would love to try the mussels. Many tables order the dish and it was very aromatic!
author: Derrick H.

description:
I've been here twice, and thought the food was pretty good.  The first time I went was with a group of 8 people, and we were tightly packed in the corner.  

Short ribs were wonderful:  very tender, and a generous portion that I couldn't finish by myself.

Service was solid.  We were served by an older gentleman who seemed like he had been working here for a while.  I would come back.
author: Peter L.

description:
I went to Fringale last night with a group of friends for Dine About Town.  After looking at the DAT menu and the regular menu, I opted to go with the regular menu and got three courses that totaled $37 versus the $35 DAT deal.  Of my three dinner mates, two ordered from the DAT menu and another went with the regular menu.

Everyone ordered different appetizers and entrees and I don't think there was a dud in the bunch.  From salad to soup to seafood, all four appetizers were delicious.  For dinner, I ordered the roasted chicken breast.  The chicken was cooked perfectly (moist, but fully cooked) and the mashed potatoes/brussel sprouts/bacon/mushrooms on the side were great additions.  The other three entrees on the table were lamb shank, duck confit and mussels and everyone was quite pleased with the food!

Finally, we finished off our meal with dessert.  I had the chocolate gourmand which came topped with vanilla ice cream.  After having already eaten two course, the dessert was the perfect size to enjoy without feeling like I was going to explode.

All in all, I really enjoyed the meal and thought the service was great.  The only thing that kept this from being a five-star review was my recent experience at a different French restaurant in SF that was just slightly better.  Totally worth a visit regardless of whether it is DAT season or not!
author: Liz H.

description:
THE BEST FOOD YOU WILL EVER ENJOY!!!
I love the Frisee Salad with the warm dressing and two kinds of fresh bagette.  The chicken is so delicious warm and succulent, the best I have ever had.  The Hazelnut Mouse Cake is divine.  The service is impeccable and attentive.  The prices are reasonable and the ambience is warm, and inviting.
author: Meghan J.

description:
This place feels like a classic French bistro, tucked away in a nice quiet location.  The cuisine is traditional French as well, which is surprisingly rare to see in such a city as SF.

I started with the ravioli, which was decent, if not great, only because I'm not a big fan of gorgonzola.  Outside of the cheese, the rest of the dish was superb though.  I then had the chicken coq au vin and duck confit, both of which were excellent and reminded me of any number of solid French restaurants.  To cap off the night, our gateau basque, which was soft and fluffy, just the right degree of sweet, and a perfect ending to our dinner.

Overall, it was a tasty (and reasonably priced) meal which I would gladly experience again.
author: Josh Q.

description: Ate here with a friend who was visiting from out of town. My friend is from France so I was not sure what he would think of the place. It was really good. We both enjoyed our apps and entrees. They also had a pretty good wine menu to select from. The service was probably the best part of the meal. Overall, a great dinner!
author: J. L.

description: Food and waiter/waitress desert 4 stars, but the manager gets 1 star " you have to leave now, I am giving your table away" before we paid the bill and got back the credit card??? If you managed it better, we would have got out of your way sooner. I guess the guaranteed tips made him forget we were the clients. We were a big group, and seating us next to the kitchen was a terrible mistake. It was hard to justify if we were blocking the kitchen/bar/bathroom, or the manager was treating us right with bad faces and impatient voice. It shows that it is not so high end restaurant, that's why. You would appreciate the food, but be prepared to be treated less respectful.
author: Victoria L.

description: The squid ink pasta was quite tasty. The flavors meld wonderfully with the al dente pasta.
author: Kristen T.

description: Mussels and heirloom tomato salad are my favorites here.  Love the atmosphere and coziness of the restaurant.
author: Jiyoung K.

description: Came here for DAT with hubby. We shared Dungeness Crab Napoleon n Spicy Calamari for appetizers. For entree, he got the Duck Confit which was kind of dry. Mine was the Lamb Shank, it was very tender but after having that, I dont think I will have lamb for quite some time now. For dessert, hubby got the Chocolate Gourmand (very good) and I got the Creme Brulee which taste the same with any other Creme Brulee out there. This is a truly French place tho, from the host to the waiters, they're all French. But this is not a date spot, the place is small and bright.
author: Lovetoeat A.

description: Good and quick service. Ravioli was a bit salty but the flavor was good. I also had bacon wrapped pork loin, which was cooked perfectly. I would definitely recommend this place.
author: K N.

description:
A nice little gem in the heart of the Soma district here in SF, Fringale continues to amaze me every time I've frequent their establishment.  This is yet another example of what a cozy little establishment can bring forth when compiled with a deep selection of fine wine and friendly atmosphere. 

I had one of the better chocolate gourmand here before and portions of food for the price they charge is very reasonable.  They're not as good as chez papa in my mind but a good little french bistro nonetheless.
author: Ronald N.

description:
I like this place for what it is- a cozy French bistro with solid, classic French food.

I came with a friend for DAT. Their DAT menu has some decent choices, with three options per course.

First course: 
Spicy calamari: this was really yummy. It wasn't a typical breaded and fried calamari. It was simply pan-fried with olives, jalapenos, and a lot of spicy powder. The calamari was really tender and a bit chewy, it was spicy but not overly so. I enjoyed it.

Basil, roquefort, spinach ravioli: four delicate ravioli with paper-thin wrapping. There's spinach inside and a roquefort cream as a topping. There's also some basil and pine nuts scattered on top. I love cheese and this had a strong blue cheese flavor, which was very satisfying.

Second course:
Lamb shank: I got a HUGE lamb shank on a big bone. The lamb was fork-tender and flavorful. It was accompanied with polenta, which was kind of tasteless... but also some king trumpet mushrooms, which I really enjoyed. Probably the best entree for DAT (although I didn't try any others)

Third course:
Hazelnut almond cake: I really liked this. Kind of a joconde cake layered with hazelnut buttercream and a generous topping of sliced almonds on top. I like nutty desserts so this was great.

Coffee parfait: basically this was frozen cream with strong coffee flavor. It was nice but I preferred the cake (although my friend preferred the parfait- perfect!)

We also got a half bottle of Chinon, which was surprisingly a very nice red wine.

Overall, I enjoyed the food, which was solid French bistro fare. The service was decent (and very French!!) However, the interior is nothing special and the tables were SO close together that every time I left my seat I would have to literally squeeze past the neighboring table very intimately, which was kind of embarrassing considering my neighbors were having an intense business dinner meeting!
author: Cathy S.

description:
My dear husband and I came here for a friend's dinner party, and we had a lovely time. Very moderately priced. We had four bottles of wine, about 8 appetizers, 14 entrees, and 7 desserts, and the bill only came out to about $860.

The ambiance is more cozy and intimate, but not necessarily romantic. At least it didn't feel particularly romantic to me. 

The food and menu are self-proclaimed French, but I thought there were some not so French-y things in the accoutrements of the dishes, such as balsamic vinegar all over my onion tarte and capers in my friend's salad. 

All of the appetizers I tried were pretty delicious. The terrine of foie gras, onion tart, charcuterie assortment (assiette) were the special standouts. I thought the foie gras was just pate, and I felt so guilty afterwards. :( Sorry, duckies.

For dinner, I had the roast chicken with mashed potatoes and vegetables. The chicken was very moist but it needed a sauce to bring the dish all together. Whatever sauce was on the plate was not enough for me, but maybe i'm too saucy! Haaaa.

Anyway, my husband had the rabbit, which was a special of that night, and the dish was pretty good but maybe it was so well-seasoned and sauced, that you could not taste the rabbit? 

Either way, the food was pretty good, but there is room for some improvement. 

Dessert was pretty yummy, the hazelnut cake and warm chocolate gourmand are highly recommended. So gooooooood. 

Service was really nice. Our server was really patient with our group of 12, some of whom did not know what to order and what wines went best with what entrees/appetizers. I did not drink, so that wasn't a big deal for me that night. 

Loved my experience here.
author: Anh D.

description:
Fringale has exceptionally amazing food. We happened to book a dinner-for-two on Valentine's Day, and we were pleased with our Lobster appetizers, and our amazing beet salad. They do not use iceberg lettuce, but instead use fresh pieces of spinach and various other fresh products to enhance the flavours. Really makes you enjoy your salad. They do not have a variety of main courses, but even with the limit, the main courses are extremely good. (2/2 Stars)

The restaurant's ambiance was okay. Nothing too great. (0/1 Star)

It was a bit pricey, but that's what you expect when you come to this sort of establishment (1/1 Star)

The service was nothing to complain about, and they did check up on us enough without going overboard. (1/1 Star)

Total = 4 Stars
author: Saleem C.

description: Fringale is a nice place for an intimate dinner. Think wine with a couple of close friends or your partner. It's quiet, clean, and the staff is friendly and helpful with orders. The menu is short but I'm guessing that's why what they do is so good. Just a few things done well rather than a plethora of mediocre. They have one vegetarian entrée; a delicious couscous dish with a lovely mix of vegetables. I have tried two of their desserts and been very pleased with both. I am looking forward to the chance to try the rest!
author: Jaedra D.

description:
I took my boyfriend  here for his birthday last year after looking for French places on Yelp since he'd never been to one and it was just what I was looking for! 
Yes, it is an incredibly small restaurant, but the atmosphere is incredibly romantic and the table for two for us against the wall was private enough for us.
The food was very well-prepared and flavorful, but what really did it for us was the dessert.  The desserts here are to die for, especially the beignets.  I don't exactly remember what I ate there for my entree (I just remember it being delicious and the brussel sprouts being done well), but we still talk about the beignets.
The only issue is that it's a little out of the way to get to (we're students so it was BART and then walking) and the outside looks a little meh, but inside, it's like a whole different world!
author: Sharyu B.

description:
Bad food, bad service, waste of money, waste of time!
My steak was pretty gross not to mention the soggy pomme frite! Waiter practically "threw" the food at us! There are much better french bistros in town and we'd never go back!
author: Havana H.

description:
i've been here for a birthday dinner twice now. The food is high quality and it's a very cute little bistro. The entree's are mostly meat dishes and the wine is mostly international. I had the special which, to put in simple non-foodie terms, was chicken that'd been good over a long period of time with a great sauce with potato's and spinach. It's a good choice to go with. 

They did a fairly good job of accommodating us given that we were a large group in a small restaurant but I'd probably stick to parties of two or four from here on out as it's a bit cramped and actually seems like a bit of a burden to be there.
author: Lauren B.

description: Go to neighborhood gem!  Great food for a great price.  The staff is always welcoming and knows their locals.  Love the quaint atmosphere and it's great for every type of occasion...romantic, friends, business, etc.  Top dishes - calamari, ravioli (my favorite), frisee salad, halibut.
author: Christine D.

description: Really cute, quiet little restaurant. Loved the ambience here. I enjoyed their calamari and carpaccio dish, but not the steak dish. The creme brulee was okay. Higher star rating due to the service- the waiter was super attentive and friendly.
author: J L.

description: My food (the seafood basquaise) was cold.  I'm not talking room temp but COLD like out of a fridge...the cheery waiter took it back for warming, and when I got it, it was still cold, but maybe room temp.   It was delicious, but watch out...this kitchen is out of control.
author: Charles J.

description:
i kept saying, "this is soooo good"
butternutsquash soup-yummy
garlic mussels-best mussels ive ever had!!! the portions were huge!!! soooo garlicky, the sherry vinegar added great balance.
veal braised-freaking delicious!!! 
hazelnut cake-yes please!
creme bulee-best ive tasted, creamy vanilla-y and caramely! 

walter was our server and he was very professional & on yop of his game.

thank you for making my last night in sf sooo tasty!
author: Phuong T.

description: Returned for the first time in a couple years.  Had one of the best experiences in ages anywhere.  The service was pleasant, the server made good recommendations when asked about the relative merits of different dishes, the food was exquisitely prepared, the prices were reasonable.  And you could hear yourself talk!
author: S K.

description: Had lunch here.  It's a cozy place with a nice feel to it.  Classy but not stuffy.  All the dishes we had were outstanding - including perfectly cooked fish on a bed of vegetables.  Service was impeccable.  There were many yummy sounding entrees on the menu.  I'll have to come back to try more of the items.  This is a place worth trying!
author: Lewis C.

description:
Dine About Town review

I went to Fringale with four friends on a Sunday night.

The restaurant was a lot smaller than I had expected, and the door was somewhat difficult to see. We sat at a round table in the middle of the restaurant and I felt somewhat claustrophobic.

We all ordered the same appetizers and entrees because we couldn't bear to share what we were about to order! We all got the dungeness crab ravioli as our appetizer. It didn't come with that many pieces (about five?), but there was a lot of crab inside the ravioli, so it was still decently filling. It also wasn't covered in sauce like it tends to be at some restaurants, which was a nice change so that I could actually taste the crab. The wrap for the ravioli was pretty interesting and made it taste more Asian; it tasted slightly like a wonton wrapper. That wasn't anything negative, but just unexpected. I would get this again.

We all got the filet mignon. I asked for mine to be cooked medium-rare and it was absolutely perfect! However, one of my friends also asked for medium-rare and his was cooked to more of a medium level. He didn't seem to get full satisfaction out of the meal until he finished his and I gave him some of mine because I was so full. He really loved my filet mignon (which was cooked more to his liking), but minus points for not cooking it consistently. Also, another one of my friends didn't hear the waiter when he asked how she wanted her filet mignon cooked, and she didn't respond, so they made hers a lot more rare than she had wanted. However, they took it back to the kitchen and gave her another one that she was more satisfied with.

We all got different desserts. I ordered the hazelnut and roasted almond mousse cake, which was amazing! It had the perfect balance of hazelnut, mousse, and chocolate underneath. The thinly sliced almonds also gave it a good texture with a slight crunch, which was a nice contrast to the smooth and creamy cake itself. Some people got the creme brulee, which was pretty good, but I've had better. I also got to try my friend's chocolate gourmand, which is basically a warm chocolate souffle/cake that came with ice cream and raspberry sauce. I wasn't a huge fan, although I normally love that kind of dessert. I would recommend the hazelnut cake out of the three desserts that they offered.

Parking was really easy, so that wasn't an issue -- I parked at a meter just down the street.

Definitely a worthwhile experience for Dine About Town!
author: Angela K.

description: My wife had the Duck Confit, which she felt was 'ok', and I had the Braised Veal short ribs, which I found to be very tasty.   I wouldn't go out of my way to try this place again, but I wouldn't say no if someone suggested it. There are tons of stuff still to try on the menu.
author: Andy W.

description: Had a wonderful anniversary dinner last night.  Started off with the fresh Dungeness crab napoleon which was outstanding.  The flavors were so fresh.  I had the rack of lamb with the potato gratin and haricots verts. The lamb was cooked perfectly as was the rest of the food.  Could cut my lamb with a fork.  My BF had the rib eye and said it was the best he had ever had.  Wonderful unrushed service.  Highly recommend.
author: Katherine B.

description: Came here for dine about down. The only think I remember is the dungeness crab napoloeon. That was really good. I wish there was a little more. The flavors of the crab, avocado and the third item worked really well together. I forgot what my enet
author: Vanessa K.

description:
This place is very cute and quaint.

Make sure you make reservations! I went on a Monday night and it was packed!

Service: 4.5/5
Food: 4/5 ( I am a very hard person to please--in order to get a 5/5, the food has to be one-of-a-kind, where you cannot get anywhere else; and the experience has to be amazing)
Ambiance: cute place to take your friends/loved ones--very romantic
Location: the place was a little difficult to get to with public transportation. You had to take the muni--not bart accessible 

Food: 
Wine: Savignon Blanc-Delish! Very light!
App: Lobster Ravioli--it was okay--nothting too special--very light though--not drench in cream sauce
Entre- Duck--pretty good- good portion size
Dessert-Hazel almond cake? not too sure what it was called, but DELICIOUS! I am a sucker for sweets! and they ddid very well with this dessert!

I came here wiht my BFF. The bartender/host was really nice. She greeted us and then at the end of our dinner, she came by to ask how everything was.
author: Jen H.

description: Went to Fringale for dinner tonight.  The service is still excellent and the food is delicious as usual!!  The dining area is a bit crowded, but everything else from the service, ambiance, food and drinks are just consistently superb.  We had the Bastille Day special 3 course pre-fixe.  Frisee Salad, Carpaccio, braised lamb shank, duck confit, crème brulee, and the almond cake.  All delicious and fulfilling!
author: Gina W.

description:
Quite good.  In fact, very good.  And great value.  For being frugally gourmet, it approaches 4.5 stars.

Started with the frisee salad with hot bacon dressing with a poached egg -- the egg was perfect, and how can you go wrong with hot bacon dressing? I don't love frisee but this was still great.  I think I'd still prefer a more substantive leaf, but I'll overlook it for now.

Then had the bacon wrapped pork loin -- that pork was perfect (they normally serve it pink, but i asked them to cook it a little more and they did).  It was so tender and juicy and flavorful.  Even the cabbage/onion thing under it was tasty.

The chocolate dessert was good.  Not earth shattering, but good.  Part of cake was just sort of hard.  It didn't make me melt in my chair, but it didn't repulse me either.  

Service is friendly and fast (in a place that small, I'd hope service is good!).

The dine-about-town menu was super limited -- that was a disappointment (and also another reason I just can't give it the full 5 stars).  I went off menu and was so satisfied.  The lamb, from what I hear, was just ok.  So I'm glad I went off menu.  Don't know why they don't expand it, since they'd probably get more repeat business if they put some of the better stuff on it!

I'd definitely go back!
author: Traci H.

description:
I heard lots of good things about this place, and I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised.  

First of all, the bar scene here sure is swanky.  Beautiful open floor and bar, and it looks to be always a hip crowd here.  

The appetizers and red meats here were also great.  All the salads I tasted were fantastic, fresh, and well balanced, and all of the steaks and braised meats that I had here were also treated well (not over cooked) and not over seasoned.  For the price, you really are getting quality ingredients par to what you are paying.

On the other hand, the fish and other white meats we had here were disappointing.  The mahi we had needed seasoning and better sides (too lightly seasoned calamari) to pair with.  

Lastly, the service here was excellent.  We had a very large table and lots of change orders, and the staff bent over backwards for us.  Kudos!
author: Mark M.

description: The spot is comfortable and intimate and the ambiance is relaxing.  The waiters are nice and polite.  But the reason I'm giving this place 2 stars is because we waited over an hour for our food and the restaurant was less than half full.  The pesto fettuccine we ordered came out over cooked and it felt like I was eating instant noodle that was microwaved for 10 minutes and left to sit for 1 hour (our wait time for food), reiterated. The rack of lam(b)e was decent, so just average. But the essence of the lamb (fat) was cut off, so I was sad. 3 dollar signs for 2 star food. Meh.
author: cindy n.

description: Dined here last evening for our anniversary... Wonderful!  The Basque cuisine is fantastic, and the charcuterie plate didn't have a bad choice on it.  I had the Seafood Basquaise and my wife had the steak frite, and both were excellent.
author: Sean M.

description: My friend and I had calamari and veg starters, followed by bacon wrapped tenderloin and duck confit, all excellent.  The clientile is mature and sophisticated, not sure how Basque it was, but certainly French and well prepared!
author: Jennifer Y.

description: 3.5 stars for the food. It's good but not amazing. I did like the calamari and clams on the appetizer section
author: Annie Z.

description:
2.5 bumping up to 3 because I'm a nice bitch. If you like stuffiness (or perhaps an authentic French experience?), this is your place. 

The Good:

The food and wine was pretty good. Honestly, I can't say I remember a lot about the dinner, but I don't remember it being awful. The one thing I do remember is that they do a deliciously seared foie gras. 

The Bad: The service was ok, it actually felt well suited for the atmosphere (mostly older crowd with one man taken out of his hospital bed for what seemed like his last Bastille Day). Once the waiter found out my husband is from France, the conversation switched to French and it was like my friend Viv and I were invisible. 

The Ugly: What is up with French restaurants cramming SO many tables on the main dining room floor? Is the demand and money THAT good? There was a scuffle behind our table when some arrogant older woman elbowed the man sitting basically on top of her, and pretended like it didn't happen. I dont blame these people! I wanted to sneak in a word about the man in front of me fresh out of the hospital, making a pile of food around his chair on the floor! He caught me off guard once, totally stuck with a spoonful of food halfway to his gaping mouth, and all the folks at his table not helping  him! I nearly spit my wine out but I would have soaked him. TOO CLOSE!

It had a Bastlle Day Special that we skipped, but it seemed like a decent deal. Not sure if it's worth the $80, but a good place to take your parents or someone who has no sense of interior decoration.
author: nina B.

description:
I came here on a rainy Saturday evening and was treated to a delicious and romantic dinner. 
The place is small and cozy, but the food and service were excellent. 
We had the grilled shrimp appetizer and the sun-dried tomato sauce was to die for..I wanted to soak a basket of bread in the plate! I had the seafood stew which included mussels, salmon and cod. It was nice and hearty. The bf had the bacon wrapped pork which was sinfully yummy. 
We sat in the corner by the window and I couldn't have asked for a better table. I highly recommend this place for a romantic night out.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Let me preface by saying that I ate here on Valentine's Day and that Fringale may have been a bit overwhelmed as a result.  Nevertheless, I may have been here on cupid's holiday, but I definitely did not fall in love with the restaurant.

Food was actually good - 4 stars, although their fish was excellent.
Atmosphere was nice - 4 stars too.
Service was a disaster.  We had 8 PM reservations but were not seated until 8:45 PM, after which it took another 30 minutes to get our appetizers and an additional 30 minutes for our main course.  Dishes were being served to the wrong tables and plopped down almost angrily.  All of this done without a smile and without an apology.

Bill was $75 per person without drinks.

I will probably give Fringale another shot at some point, just am not in a rush to do so.
author: David A.

description:
I really enjoyed this place! After having lived in Paris for a year and having visited so many authentic brasseries, I was really pleased to step into this little piece of France. I haven't been back in the US for more than a few weeks and I was really missing my Parisian life. When I walked into Fringale, I heard French being spoken by all the staff and the dishes on the table looked like what I was accustomed to in France. 

Their wine list is fantastic - I was so happy to find rose wines on the card. I'd recommend their fish, duck, and steaks. I ordered the filet mignon "saignant" (medium-rare) and it came out perfectly. I ended up speaking to the servers and host in French the whole evening and got a great sense for the place. Gastronomy is clearly their major and like all French, they know quite a bit about good cuisine. At the end of the night, I ordered le chocolat gourmand for us to share and our waiter brought us a hazelnut cake on the house. 

The next time I'm in California again, I'll definitely go back to Fringale. Makes me miss my little apartment in the 3eme!
author: Ann Y.

description:
Went here with the bf for DAT. Tiny little place but super cute and has a realllly good wine list.

Endive frisee salad: Came with roquefort but I opted out on that. I'm not a fan of stinky cheeses. Light dressing and a refreshing little salad. I think it would've been really good with some other, nonstinky cheese. 

Petrale sole: Cooked perrrrfectly. Light tender sweet fish with a slight cripsy sear to it. The sauce was buttery without being too rich. Even the seafood hating bf said it was good!

Apple tart: Meh. Puff pastry with apple slices on top and vanilla ice cream. Even I could've made this.

Beef carpaccio: High quality beef, oh so finely sliced served with capers and some sort of hard cheese. Verrrrry good. 

Veal osso bucco: I don't eat veal. It's just jacked up plumping up a cute baby cow then killing it but the bf does. He wasn't a fan and thought it was just "ok". Not as tender or juicy as veal typically is. I really like the sauce and ricey grains the dish came with. 

Chocolate hazelnut mousse: OHMIGAWD. If you like ferrero rocher chocolates, get this. It tasted EXACTLY like it. Soooo good. Layers of light, rich chocolate and hazelnut mousse. The only thing that would've been icing on the cake with this would've been some sort of texture. The entire thing was all mousse so I would've liked maybe a crispy wafer layer in there.
author: Beverly T.

description:
This was a cool little place in SOMA that I actually really enjoyed.  

I went there on a Friday afternoon and considering it was a business day, in SOMA, with not too many businesses around, it was actually packed (a good sign).

I walked into a nicely decorated restaurant - the colors were mostly pastel, which made for a warm and welcoming experience.  My friend and I were greeted nicely and seated immediately.

The food was great - I started off with a pate plate that was fantastic - well-flavored pate with toast...they provide you with bread as well so you can use that to help with eating the pate since they give you a decent portion and the three small slices of toast won't really cut it.  My next item was a beef bourguignon that was savory and slightly sweet...the beef was so tender it almost melted in your mouth.  My friend and I shared two desserts - banana bread pudding with chocolate and a creme brulee - both were very good.  

Considering the quality of the food and the price point, I'd definitely recommend this restaurant - it's reasonably priced for a French restaurant (lunch entrees are only $15-$17) and the food is very good and the service was great.  While I did go for lunch, I can imagine this being a great place for dinner as well since it's a cozy restaurant and in a great location South of Market.  

I'd recommend making a reservation since it was packed when I was there and this seems to be a popular spot for those in the area.
author: Ken G.

description: Food is great, great service, upscale casual atmosphere. Had the calamari for appetizer. It could have been a bit more lemony but was good as is. The Nicoise salad and chicken were great. Chicken takes time but was really good. The couscous with it was so-so. We skipped dessert. Excellent lunch spot.
author: Rutuja K.

description:
Such a cute little place! I loved that it's kind of unassuming and isn't your typical stuffy french restaurant. The decor is nice and is somewhat reminiscent of that European cafe feel. It's a little small and rather intimate and sets the scene nicely if you know what I mean and for the record I felt really young in here. No complaints! 

We shared the Roquefort & spinach ravioli and the Frisée salad with warm bacon dressing - very yummy, no complaints what so ever from either of us. I had the pork tenderloin and he had the steak - again right on the mark. The dessert is where it kind of got a bit disappointing. Being a french restaurant we had high expectations of dessert. The Flourless chocolate cake seriously delivered but the Fig Tart did not. It was virtually flavourless and a huge disappointment to us. Thank god we ordered two desserts!

The service was great, even after the waiter noticed we barely touched the fig tart. He was very pleasant and apologetic about our disappointment.

Mussels and frites for me next time though!
author: Leanne S.

description:
We live around the corner and had never been in, were looking for a place for a nice dinner on the fly during a holiday when all was closed and we made a reservation on opentable - thankfully as the place was PACKED.

Fringale is Basque country french. I love Basque country, it is so mysterious. The food here is very french with some light California flare. 
Everything we put in our mouths was eye-closing-to-savor delicious.

We started with a simple gem salad. Which was not so simple. A smattering of a green delicious sauce-dressing and delicious hard cheese thinly sliced, all paired with wheat-style crusty bread. It may very well be the best salad we ever had. Plus they put it on two plates for us without us even asking. Mmm I can still taste it...

Entrees - 
Ribeye med-rare covered with a wine butter, frites and perfectly cooked skinny string beans. 5 stars hands down.
Veal braised short ribs, with an exotic mushroom sauce, the best creamy polenta I have ever had topped over a delectable spinach,onion bottom. 5 stars no question.

Service was very polite, owner was gracious, everyone in the restaurant seemed to be enjoying their meals and sharing items with exclamation, no one was rushed at all. The food is heavy - it is French after all - but so worth it.

Four stars only because they absolutely should have staffed one more person on the busy holiday evening. We waited a loooong time to sign our bill.

There is also a cute bar if you just wanted dessert. Evening sun shines on the windows, which makes for a cozy and romatic place. Nice table clothes & good vibes.

I am so glad this is around the corner! We will be back.
author: AK S.

description:
I went to Fringale with a couple friends during Dine About Town, which is always hectic and when servers/restaurants are usually the rudest because they're overbooked and practically giving away food for free.

But not at Fringale.

The service was phenomenal. We had the most pleasant male French server who was witty and charming and gave us great recommendations for dishes. You usually think French restaurant, snooty service (particularly if they're actually French), but not here. I can't remember what we ordered exactly (whatever was on the Dine About Town menu), but it was delicious and I'd return here in a second the next time a craving for spectacular French cuisine got the best of me.
author: Kristin L.

description:
I would give 5 to the chef and 0 to the wait staff.  The waiter was rude, smacked glasses down on the table, reached across my face a number of times.  Very rude.  My guests even remarked how I had to lean up to the wall to avoid being hit in the face.  He appeared annoyed & angry from the start.  We were a party of 5 professionally dressed and we spared no expense ordering our wine of 2 bottles of Burgundy and meals.  I was embarrassed as I had been here b4 with a different waiter.
He rushed us and I intentionally ate really slow to offset his again being rude and rushing us through the meal.

Don't go here.  If you are somehow unfortunately invited walk out if u get the French salt & pepper very short haired French waiter.  The elderly gentleman who was there is very kind.    Feel sorry 4 the chef as this review has to cover the front of house fatal flaw.
author: Chris J.

description:
Went on an off evening for a late dinner. Great service great food and great port! Put simply, was great french food. The menu wasn't too intimidating for those of us who are non-french speaking.

Good for a date, small so i wouldnt reccommend a group larger than 3 or 4
author: Loni A.

description:
Met a friend for a birthday dinner here after searching Yelp for a nice French Restaurant. Came up with Fringale and chose to come here for dinner. When we arrived, we waited a bit for a table even with reservations and 4 empty tables in the restaurant. I got the potato garlic soup and the pork tenderloin. The soup was soso while the   Bacon wrapped Pork tenderloin, braised savoy cabbage w/caramelized onion sauce was AMAZING. I have never had a piece of pork that was so soft, juicy and tender. The cabbage that came with it was a bit strange, but the meat and the sauce made up for it. We shared the creme brule which was also fantastic. 

My only peeve was that they only had 1 choice for "glass" champagne. It was a french champagne that was about $20 for a glass. It seemed a lot for just one glass. A choice of moderately priced champagnes would have been nice. 

Easy parking if you get there early. Staff is questionable as service was slow at times. Then again, the French take their time. Food was excellent. Will definitely come back again!
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Pros:
Great bistro food, but there are so many bistro options, and this one was forgettable.

Cons:
The neighborhood is rough (even though a few blocks away in other directions is nice), and that just messes with the whole ambiance of the place.  

Fun:
Stumbling drunk people walking down 4th--you can almost always find them, and some are interesting characters.
author: Mike G.

description:
Definitely disappointed. The menu here sounded deelicious, which is why I chose this place for Dine about Town. 

This is what I had that I can comment on: 

Appetizer: crab napoleon, didn't like it. The crab or whole thing was too salty. It didn't taste like dungeness crab, I thought it tasted like imitated crab. Calamari was okay, not special so I don't remember much about it. 

Entrees: Duck confit, this was okay. I've had better though. Lamb, this was terrible. I don't know how they cooked the lamb, but the meat tasted as though it was boiled. Then they drizzled sauce on top. 

Dessert: creme brulee, nothing to rave or praise. 

Definitely not my favorite experience for DAT, should read my review for Isa. Fringale had a nice setting, but when the food fails me, so does everything else. Maybe I'll come back one day and it'll be great.
author: Jen L.

description:
The food is undoubtedly good and the space is undoubtedly tight. I had to suck in my stomach to walk to our table at the far end by the window. I dare not stretch for fear of hitting the table behind and next to us. 

We ordered calamari, foie gras, and spinach ravioli to start off the dinner. Calamari was lightly seasoned and plentiful. The strips of chorizo was a good touch. Spinach ravioli was also delicious, the spinach was still crunchy and the subtle pine nuts added alot to the dish. The foie gras was weird, it was a big block with not nearly enough toast. The duck confit was nice and tender. That was a win.

However, it's not a romantic spot. The tables were so close together, I felt like the dog from Up. SQUIRREL. I could hear everything in the table behind me, which was really distracting.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
This place is probably one of my favorite places to eat in the City.  I've never been disappointed here.  The staff is great.  The food is even better.  Oh yeah, the prices aren't bad either!  Fringale is a nice small romantic place with crazy good food.  Non-pretentious is my main draw to this place.  The food is fancy but not the attitude.  The menu is pretty simple which I really like.  The "A la Plancha" calamari is a must try.  The roasted chicken is superb as well.  I'm getting hungry thinking about the food again!

The only con is the place being so small.  Not that it doesn't hold a lot of people but that I'm so big its hard to get in and out with bumping people : x
author: Steven H.

description:
Everyone needs a "go to" spot that includes being a crowd pleaser, has a full bar with sharp bartenders that whip up quality drinks and makes some of the best French Fries you will find in the City. 

Fringale is this place. 

I've been a return visitor to Fringale for the past four plus years and each and every time have enjoyed excellent service and served up some of the most creative French food you will find anywhere. 

The seating is cramped, but adds to the charm of this bistro. The waiters are polished and are well versed with the menu and are eager to help you made decisions and offer any advice on any of the many tasty selections offered up. 

The wine list includes varietals from all over the world but there is an emphasis on the French wines. Again they will help you navigate the list and help you pick out the perfect bottle for the evening. 

Excellent service and easy street parking.
author: Rene C.

description:
Don't believe the Yelp hype. I would have traded my foie gras and PEI mussels mariniere for BREAD from Clementine. 

At least I had a good pinot noir!
author: Susy C.

description:
Ce lieu est la bombe! I really enjoyed the professional waitstaff. Even the way the slid the bread into the basket was so cool.Our server was wonderful. He were attentive and knew the menu very well.

THE FOOD: I had the braised short ribs, which was so tender. Forget the small portion stereotype, It was very satisfying.

THE DESSERT: i partook of Madame Angele's gateau, so creamy and delicious. My friends had the flourless chocolate cake, and they seriously considered licking the plate(Deanna!)

Vous ne regettera pas votre visite!
author: Leslie S.

description:
My 100th review goes to Fringale.

I had a great time here! The waiter was adorable, and recommended the right appetizers and dishes, but I think anything on the menu would've been delicious.

We shared Foie gras, Calamari, Rack of Lamb, Steak and Pomme Frites, and for dessert-refreshing Sorbet.

Man, with the foie gras dish, even the bread was toasted perfectly. Everything was so good. This restaurant is going to be one of my all-time favorites. The calamari wasn't chewy at all. It was very easy to eat. Rack of lamb and steak were cooked so well. My mouth is watering just remembering the dinner.

Sigh

I need to go again soon. Fringale craving.
xoxo

(The portions are good, and the prices won't break the bank. You -will- leave a happy camper.)
author: Kay N.

description:
Fingale's food was very good, and the ambiance was nice. However, what you get isn't quite worth the price. Worth going to if someone else is footing the bill, but not some place I would go out of my way to eat at again.

Seating is limited, so make a reservation!
author: S P.

description:
After reading fellow Yelper Hao L.'s DAT experience at Fringale, I just knew I had to try it. 

I, too, loved the beef carpaccio appetizer -- absolutely delicious! For my second course, I chose the filet of sole since neither the ling cod nor the ribeye with pomme frittes was available on tonite's DAT menu. The fish was very tender and nicely prepared. Finally for dessert, I was torn between the flourless chocolate cake and the hazelnut mousse cake. When I asked our waiter which one was better, he cleverly responded with "Following your heart is the way to go" ;) so I went with the hazelnut with roasted almond mousse cake. It was delectable! 

Fringale serves excellent French basque cuisine and the service is outstanding. Our waiter was friendly and very attentive. Definitely coming back!
author: Helen Y.

description:
Small restaurant that was very crowded. Seemed to be slightly older crowd. 
French waiters. 
Had the charcuterie plate as an app which had duck terrine, pate, and salame. I didn't care for the duck terrine much. 
I had the duck which was perfectly cooked. 

Overall very good. I'll come back
author: Michelle P.

description:
Fringale: The urge to eat

After spending nearly an hour in traffic on the 101, my "fringale" was beginning to overwhelm me. Considering the amount of time spent in traffic, I was only 15 minutes late for my reservation and delighted to get street parking a block away from the restaurant.

Fringale was the choice for my 3-course DAT venture. Having looked at the prix-fixe menu beforehand, I was excited to sample what this French bistro had to offer. Seated promptly in this cozy place, I overlooked the menu to see if there were any changes to the menu from the one on the DAT website, of which there were none. 

-Sweet gem lettuce salad, herb vinaigrette, croutons with Basque cheese: Delicate, crisp lettuce leaves lightly coated with the tangy herb vinaigrette. Thin shavings of the creamy Basque cheese gave the salad a mild saltiness. Crispy croutons provided a nice textural contrast and gratefully were small in size. 

-Boeuf Bourguignon, fingerling potatoes, carrots, bacon with red wine jus: Essentially a French beef stew containing several pieces of slow cooked beef that falls apart when you cut it with a fork accompanied with vegetables which were still firm as you bit into them. The bacon was so subtle that I didn't know it was there. Disappointed about that. But the robust, hearty red wine jus was so good I had to abandon my bread limit and sop it up.

-Warm chocolate Gourmand with macerated berries and vanilla ice cream: Perfect ending to the meal. Almost brownie-like but lighter and more moist. The various berries were macerated in red wine and were still structurally maintained. Enjoyed the cooling of the vanilla ice cream, the warm dark chocolate cake, and the soft berries coming together in each bite. Surprisingly, this dessert was not overly sweet at all. So good that I could have had 2 more plates.

A few minor downsides:
-Water wasn't refilled automatically without asking. I was patiently waiting for a refill that I had to munch on the ice for refreshment. Finally I couldn't wait any longer and had to ask.

-After using the knife to cut up some large pieces of lettuce from the salad, I left it on the plate when I finished up the appetizer. I was expecting a new one to replace it. It was interesting to use my spare fork to spread butter on my bread. Finally, I had to ask for a replacement knife.

-Some of the bread was downright chewy. Had to gnaw on it for quite a while to tear a piece off. Also it was room temperature. Bread is always better served hot or at least warm, in my opinion.

Having a delicious lunch here satisfied my "fringale". Though looking at the tower of PEI mussels (one of the other DAT entrees) served at an adjacent table almost brought it back again.

Overall: 3.5 stars
author: Randy T.

description:
After a busy night on the town, the 4 of us wanted dessert.  We yelped the closest place with great desserts - Fringale!

We ended up having second dinner and desserts.  I had the Onion Tart for my entree.  Beautiful pastry dough with a great amount of butter in the recipe.  Great flake and crisp.  Carmelized onions, blue cheese, and a mixed green salad piled on top.

The other had the duck and scallions (x2).  Nothing but raves from them as well.  Apparently the duck is cooked for 8 hours in its own fat and is mindblowing.  As a vegetarian I took their word on it.

For dessert, Almond Tart, Flourless Chocolate Cake, and Creme Brulee.  The Creme Brulee is one of the most boring desserts, but there's blew my mind.  The custard base was the best I've had in a creme brulee.  The almond tart was excellent and the chocolate cake average (I've had some mind-blowing chocolate cake (this was just good)).

I love the ambiance.  It reads high end bistro to me - so you get an intimate atmoshpere, while still elegant and refined.  The service was top notch.
author: Brian K.

description:
A SOMA bistro with serious charm. The service was excellent, our French accented waiter was responsive and very friendly. He didn't even bat an eye when we turned down the wine list for some dirty martinis (yeah strange starting point for a boys night out, I know). 

We started with prosciutto wrapped asparagus, and as it turns out just as everything is better with bacon, everything is better with prosciutto too! I had the lamb entree which was flawless, they hit medium well on the mark.

Tables along the back wall are positioned like a real French bistro, aka very close. You can't avoid listening in on the people next to you, ok well I couldn't avoid listening on the people next to me (my own issue perhaps :). The rest of the seating is sufficiently spaced for better privacy. Decor is date-worthy, but doesn't have the sex appeal of some of the other newer establishments like Oola.

Full Disclosure: At the time of my yelping Fringale is a Yelp advertiser.
author: Jeremy S.

description: We had a large reservation for 14 girls on Saturday night. They food and service was impeccable! Highly recommend it!
author: Jonathan M.

description:
I went there twice already and I love it. A little bit pricey but well worth it. The size of the plates are just right, you don't feel overly full when you get out.

The first time I had the Duck confit, quite tasty, that came with Du Puy lentils that were cooked to perfection. The second time I had the roasted rack of lamb, which was fantastic.

The ambiance is very nice. Small restaurant but not crammed at all. We were able to have a normal conversation without feeling like everyone was listening to us. The waiters were very helpful and nice.

A very good experience. I will definitely go back!
author: Gabriel M.

description: Always one of my go to spots in SOMA. Great French food...love their duck entree and wide wine selection.
author: Camellia P.

description:
My mother in law wanted to do dine about town so we decided to come here. I was excited since I saw 4 stars overall on their review but man quality must have gone down since other people reviewed or they don't try with their dine about town dishes. 

For the starter, my mother in law and I got the spinach ravioli with pine nuts and a blue cheese sauce. The blue cheese is overwhelming and takes away from the actual ravioli. I think I would have enjoyed it if not for the overwhelming blue cheese. My husband and my father in law got the calamari which was a lot better but I didn't think it was that flavorful.

Main course, I got the duck confit. The only thing I liked about this dish was the mushrooms. The duck was too salty and dry- how disappointing. i understand that it's supposed to be cooked to fall-off-the-bone, but where's all the flavor from being cooked for hours?! 

My father in law got the salmon. We thought it was going to be good since it looked like it was cooked perfectly but I think it was bland since he kept sprinkling salt on it (they must have used all the salt on my dish). 

My mother in law got the lamb shank. Also not good and overcooked. She didn't even finish it since it was so bad. 

My husband got the coque a vin which he enjoyed. 

Dessert I got the Coffee & Armagna parfait - overwhelming coffee flavor. I believe there's a prune in there which was weird and sour. Husband got the creme brulee & Vanilla bean - nice vanilla flavor but too thick and not creamy enough for my taste. Father in law got the Hazelnut and Almond cake - he did not like. Not sure what my mother in law got because it wasn't on the menu but it was a chocolate cake with a sorbet on top. She liked the sorbet and ate all that. But took one bite of the chocolate cake and called it quits. So I gave a taste and it was gross. So i had to eat some creme brulee to get the taste out of my mouth.
author: Lang T.

description:
Suprisingly underwhelming. Four of us came for Dine About Town and while we enjoyed our meal, we really expected to be WOWed. Of the 5 dishes that we tried, two were really good, two were just good, and one was less than good.

REALLY GOOD:
Dungeness crab napolean - generous portion of crab topped with delicious mango salsa
Rib-eye - Amazing goodness!

LESS THAN GOOD:
Duck confit - somehow the duck came out dry! Two people got this dish and both servings were dry. This was supposed to be one of the best dishes at Fringale, so we were quite surprised.

I'm wondering if maybe we came on an off-night or if they were overwhelmed by the DAT diners?
author: Samantha C.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place for a long time now, and i have to say i really regret not coming here sooner since it's in my hood. Even though when we walked in, it smelled a bit musty and seemed like an older crowd, the food and service was top notch.

I was quite impressed with the portion size. You would think at a French resto, the portions are tiny and bite sized, but this place had belt busting size portions...hold on, while I loosen up my belt a few notches so I can breathe. We ordered the Foie Gras terrine, I do have to say I prefer the seared kind over terrine or torchon, but this livery goodness was buttery, rich and the pineapple compote was the perfect counterpart to this rich buttery flavor of the foie. 

The summer endive salad was sweet and tart and just absolute yummyness in my tummyness! I just love crunchy and crisp endives with the creamy and mild goat cheese.
Another special of the day was the scallop and asparagus dish with a spicy garlic aioli drizzled on top. We were shocked at the size of the dish. I would say, I do prefer Dayboat scallops over little bay scallops, that was a little disappointing for me, but the overall flavor was amazing.

Thank goodness we decided to share an entree due the generous portions of everything, we had the steak frites...perfectly cooked the way I like it, medium rare to rare. 

I'm always impressed when real French people are dining at a French resto, it makes me feel like it's legit.
author: Kristina L.

description:
This place was as fabulous as I hoped it would be. I came here for Dine About Town, and the service and food were wonderful. It's an adorable little French place that feels very authentic, with an attentive, unpretentious French wait staff who sat us next to the window and adjacent to some feisty nonagenerians celebrating a birthday.

I started off my dining experience with a glass of velvety Cabernet Franc, yum. The first course of Dungeness Crab Napoleon looked and tasted wonderful. The entrée of Petrole Sole, sitting atop mashed potatoes, was absolutely delicious. The Chocolat Gourmand dessert in all its melty, chocolaty goodness was the perfect way to end the meal.

It seems to be a lovely place to meet up with good friends or a significant other for a warm, intimate meal. I look forward to coming back soon!
author: Jamie T.

description:
Came here for the appetite stimulus deal but didn't order off that menu. It's a sweet deal, $35 for 3 courses. My dad got the crab ravioli with lobster sauce with osso bucco and a hazelnut creme cake. the dessert was "eh," but everything else was very good. I'd give the service 3 stars though. the restaurant was not full, but i felt like we were rushed through dinner. Our reservations were at 6 PM, and half our party (of 4), came at 5:40 PM. It's not like we were late. I didn't understand.

i had the crab napoleon and it was super fresh. You can tell because the avocados did not turn in color and I did not taste a hint of lemon juice. the creme fresh added a perfect balance of sour creaminess to the tomato avocado and crab mixture.

i had to have the duck confit because i can't resist and it was good. juicy meat, off the bone and crispy succulent skin.. mmm. what really made the dish a "WOW," was the LENTILS! Who would have thought lentils could be so buttery yet not heavy?


I had the sorbet du jour (what's what? sorbet of the day. oh, that sounds good. i'll have that)... sweet pear, fresh strawberry and tart tart cranberry. the cranberry tasted like if you froze the Chinese candy that is tart and sweet round thing in the size of a quarter (san ja bang) 

i would come back to try out the other items.
author: Lauren Y.

description: Everything was excellent. We had the duck confit, Roquefort ravioli and an endive salad.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Went here for DAT on Friday June 3rd.  GF did not have DAT but had a Salad Frisee which had a poached egg and bacon over salad.  I had some spinachravioli appetizer which was awesome.  She had mussells as an entree and I had the lamb shank.  Damn...I got a big piece of meat with great mushrooms on a bed of polenta.  Super good!  Lastly had creme brulee for dessert and it was great as well.  The waiter was excellent and was not at our table too much but just the right amount of times.

I would go back here again outside of DAT.
author: Mark M.

description:
I was contacted by Jean Marie who is allegedly the owner to clear things up. I contacted her, and no response. Goes to show this place is still terrible with customer service, and can care less about it's customers. 

Avoid this place at all cost.
author: Peter C.

description:
When I heard the owner and wait staff speaking French upon walking in, I knew Fringale would not disappoint me.  The French fanatic in me wanted to "parle francais" with them, but I had to refrain myself from sounding like a complete idiot.

"Les plats" ordered that night consisted of: Confit of duck leg with green lentils du Puy and some fish dish which I cannot remember the name of.  Our knowledgeable waiter recommended 2 wines paired with our dishes that were fantastic!  

AND I love the fact that on the menu, "Entrees" are appetizers and "Les Plats" are main courses.  THE WAY IT SHOULD BE!!

Prices are totally reasonable, if not dirt cheap. The portions look small, but I could barely even finish off my plate.  

I can't wait to go back and try other dishes, as well as the dessert menu ;D
author: Tiff T.

description: Haven't been at Fringale for a few years since we don't live in the city. Went there a few nights ago and had a very nice dinner. The food and services were wonderful as always. The ambiance is casual, unpretentious, but sophisticated. The place was bustling without being too loud so you can actually hear each other and enjoy a conversation. The group of four of us all had different appetizers, main courses and desserts, and each one was well executed. I love the menu because it's a nice fusion of French, Californian with a distinctly basque flair.
author: Spiderkitties Z.

description:
Went here with a group of close friends and have to say, although the food was nothing out of this world, the ambiance and attentiveness of the service made our dining experience very pleasant.

I recommend trying the confit of duck leg, the meat was so tender it melts in your mouth.   The foie gras terrine was absolutely divine as it delivered a savory yet piquant flavor to the fruit and the buttery brioche.  

The interior of the restaurant is warm, inviting, and cozy.  Spending several hours with a good red wine, great friends, and wonderful conversation made this one of my favorite dining experiences.
author: Miika M.

description: Great food. Owner/manager and waiters had major attitude. Wine selection was lacking at best. If they allow it, bring your own wine. If your company is great, you'll just have to ignore the poor service and attitude.
author: Ali S.

description:
Decided we were going to be major fatties so we got 3 DAT prix fixe meals. 

Bread and Butter. DELISH! Lives up to my French restaurant baguette expectations. NOMS. 

Dungeness Crab Napoleon. Crab with Avocado, Mango Salsa and fresh Veggies topped with freshly ground Black Pepper. NOMS. I liked this a lot, it was very fresh and delicious. The tangy and sweet mango salsa complemented the oceany crab very well. I also liked all the different textures in it, especially the creamy avocado in the crab. 

Spicy Monterey Calamari ala Plancha. With Jalapenos, Chorizo and Olives. Not spicy at all! But it was really yummy, I liked that it wasn't fried because it's healthier. Definitely worth it even though I wish it was spicier. I even ate the peppers and I didn't taste any spice at all. 

Roquefort and Spinach Ravioli. With Toasted Pine Nuts, Basil and Cream Sauce. YUMS. I remember learning way back in my second year of college about roquefort and it's stench. And I was expecting worse, but I liked this a lot even though I'm not a fan of blue cheese, it kind of had a similar aroma to it, but fortunately I wasn't too bothered by it. Though this was cheesy and creamy, I was surprised to find it not the least bit heavy. DELISH!

Traditional Coq Au Vin. Chicken in Red Wine Sauce (I believe) with Mushrooms and Veggies. I usually don't like eating chicken at restaurants because I find it made tough and chewy, but I liked this chicken a lot. It was really tender and literally fell off the bone. I also liked the wine sauce a lot, gave the chicken even more flavor when I had it as leftovers the day after. 

Petrale Sole. With Mashed Potatoes, Carrots, Zucchini and Piquillo Pepper Beurre Blan. This was alright, it was more like a stuffed sole or julienned carrots/zucchini wrapped with sole. Very interesting nonetheless, but nothing to write home about. I thought this could have been better flavorwise since it was more on the bland side, especially after eating my own wine-strong flavored coq au vin.

Lamb Shank. With Mashed Potatoes and Veggies. NOMS. This was really good, the lamb was nice and tender and fell off the bone as well. Very yummy, definitely gotta try the rack of lamb next time, I saw a lot of people ordering that even though it wasn't on the DAT menu. 

Creme Brulee. With a Blackberry and a Raspberry. I thought this was alright, they definitely put real vanilla beans in it because I saw the flecks, so I appreciated that. And they toasted the sugar to a nice almost burnt, but caramelized consistency which I liked also. It was pretty good, though I must admit I'm not really a fan of ordering this or chocolate lava cake at restaurants since I can make it myself at home. 

Coffee Parfait. With Prune and Cookie. My mom and I both got this because we didn't feel like getting a rich chocolate cake since we were so full. This was alright, very strong on the alcohol. Definitely was not a fan of this. I only ended up getting this because they switched out the menus on us and when we were waiting for our table it had the Hazelnut and Almond Mousse Cake on it. SADFACE. 

I also ended up getting the Coq Au Vin because the Duck Confit was no longer on the menu when we got to our table. I was uber sad they switched the menu on us. So foodies beware, what you see initially may not be what you can order later on. And note, we did have reservations so I'm not sure why exactly what we intended to order could have run out. 

3 stars only because though food was pretty good and by itself would have warranted 4 stars, but the service was lacking and the fact that they switched the menu on us wasn't cool.
author: Constance C.

description:
Fringale is my favorite "you can afford to go more than once a year" French restaurant in the City. I love the relaxed feeling of the place and the food never disappoints. Except of course when the freezer breaks and they don't have the fromage blanc sorbet.

Order the:
steak with red wine butter and pommes frites
author: Miriam W.

description:
What did Joan P. NOT divulge about our splendid evening!?!?  

The untouched moments are few and far between:

1) Joan P. likes richer foods that me: I enjoyed the salad immensely, but I was privy to the frisee and beet portion of the dish, rather than the goat cheese. 

2) French prawns can taste eerily similar to Chinese prawns, in a good way.  

3) Flourless chocolate cake shaped like a souffle can be rich and delicious too.

4) Wrapping cellophane around the takeout box for your guests, saves their car any potential mess!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Came here during DAT for a family dinner after recommendations from a friend, however I left unimpressed with the quality and ambience of the restaurant. For the price you pay, you definitely expect more refinement.

We ordered 2 DAT set dinners, bay scallops appetizer, coq au vin, and black cod. Like most other Yelp reviewers, the crab and avocado appetizer was the winning dish of the night. I'd definitely recommend getting this. The bay scallops were just okay, the chicken meat from the coq au vin was old and tasted something I could make without too much effort. My black cod was the best entree dish of the night, but it's pretty difficult to get black cod wrong. The sole and lamb entrees from the DAT were tasty, but also average and mediocre.

Nothing too special about Fringale, and I probably won't come back again.

Note: There is free parking across the street in the Wells Fargo Parking lot.
author: Jennifer W.

description: I love the lamb , my sister likes the pork ,  is a bit small for thee amount of tables sometimes I feel like the next person can hear my conversation
author: A. M.

description:
Wonderful place! Our waiter was so charming and helpful and never once made us feel rushed, even though we were the last to leave..

Food - wow!  To start I had the Frisée salad with warm bacon dressing.  I am not a fan of poached eggs, but the poached egg in the middle of the salad was like a present waiting to be unwrapped.  Perfectly cooked and it went very well with the bitterness of the salad topped off with the dressing.  Yes bacon makes everything better, but this salad takes it to a whole new level.

My main course was the Bacon Wrapped Pork Tenderloin.  Yes I am a fan of the pig..  This was the most perfectly cooked with pink center, tender piece of pork I've ever had.  I didn't need a knife really.

For dessert I had the Warm Chocolate Gourmand. I would have gone all shameless and licked that plate had I not been in public.  It was gooey perfection.  Even their cafe au lait was delicious.

I will definately be going back.
author: Yvette T.

description:
You had me at "Bacon Wrapped Pork Tenderloin".  What a great experience!  Came here with my parents and BF and we all had an enjoyable time!  From wine, service and food, it was "tre magnifique"!

Let's cut to the chase:

Appetizers: Frisee salad with bacon dressing and a poached egg.  So simple, yet amazing flavors.  My favorite appetizer.  Another favorite was the Dungeonous Crab Napoleon.  Very fresh...

Entrees: Bacon Wrapped Pork Tenderloin: I can't even believe I pondered getting the Veal instead!  So tender and and apple cooked in it was such a wonderful pairing.  The other winner was the Mussels.  Talk about a mound of mussels!  Save some bread for the wine, butter and garlic juicyness...and you thought you were full...
 
To not-so-win-ner was the duck confit.  It was overcooked and dry.  The lentils didn't make for much of a partner.  Boo.

All in all, a wonderful experience and we will definitely be returning!  Happy Birthday, Dad!
author: Jennifer L.

description: This was my first time at Fringale and I tried their Dine About Town menu.  I started the evening with the Spicy Monterey Calamari.  A colorful dish arrived that was well seasoned, smoky, and cooked perfectly.   I would come back for this.  Next I had the Lamb Shank.  The lamb was super tender, falling off the bone.  The flavor was forgettable and tasted more gamey than I prefer.  I finished with their Creme Brûlée, which was prepared well, but again, forgettable.   The seating was very cramped.  The staff was attentive, but hovered.  I probably should have tried something else on the menu.  With so many restaurants to choose from in San Francisco, I probably would not make a great effort to come back here.
author: Anna L.

description:
Let's start with comfortable ambiance, exceptional service and delicious food in this basque influenced french restaurant. My wife & I came to San Francisco for a long weekend/birthday celebration. For a restaurant for dinner on Sunday evening (Mother's Day) we asked friends and Fringale was one that was suggested.  Fringale was convenient to our hotel (Marriott on 4th St.), was well rated on Yelp and had reservations available when we needed them (7:30 pm on a Sunday). Being a bit off the beaten path and not the usual tourist hangout was a plus. 

We walked the 4 blocks from the hotel and were seated within moments of our arrival. The good service we expected began right away.   My salad included lettuce, mango, papaya and shaved Parmesan followed by an entree of bacon wrapped pork tenderloin, braised Napa cabbage, onion & apple marmalade; outstanding! 

The wife's salad included Fava beans, artichokes, carrots...and I don't remember the rest but she described it as wonderful. Her entree, poached black cod, potato puree, piperade, artichokes, capers & olive tapenade she described as delicious.  We shared a side of green beans that were perfectly cooked and just lightly seasoned.  Of course we had to have dessert, it's Mother's Day.  The warm chocolate gourmand flourless chocolate cake was the topper...yummm.

Our waiter was a very efficient, pleasant and knowledgeable young fellow named Sam who managed the flow of food and beverages perfectly and was very helpful in selecting the perfect bottle of wine. 

The dining room is small with one side occupied by a small bar area. The neighborhood is an odd mix of old and new, commercial and apartments in the SOMA area.  Looks to be a short distance from AT&T Park. Don't let this put you off for a moment Fringale is a delightful dining experience.
author: Mike F.

description: This is one of my favorite places to bring a date.  It's quiet and cozy with incredibly good food and wine.  Also, the staff is top-notch and very attentive.  The desserts are "out of this world".  My favorites are the creme brulee (not sure how any could possibly be better) and the warm chocolate gourmand with the mint sorbet.  In addition to it being a great date spot, my tennis club group always holds our annual holiday party here.  Last year, we reserved the entire restaurant and everyone that attended was thoroughly impressed with the quality of the food, wine, and the staff.  Definitely a great restaurant for some excellent food and wine at a very reasonable price!
author: Chester S.

description:
We were not here during dining about town, how presumptuous of you..
We paid full price, unfortunately, wish we HAD been here during the discounted DAT!
author: Pug P.

description:
Location:  Fringale
Meal:  Dinner
Scenario:  Bad date # I-can't-even-keep-track-anymore.

Ever have awkward conversation ruin a meal for you?  Even for a food-lover like myself, nothing could save Fringale.

- Limited menu.  I ordered mussels, and it was just okay.  A big bowl of steamed mussels with garlic, and I got tired of shucking them and eating them after about mussel no. 10.  Nothing special about them.  There were about 15 more to go.  Other things on the menu included bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin, steak and chicken.

- Usually I love French desserts, but nothing caught my eye.  We had the cheese plate, and the cheeses were all very good, but no crackers?  Thanks for the bread that's clearly too thick and big for the cheese.  And seriously, the smallest smidgen of honeycomb.  Samovar has this beat like no other.

- The bad conversation wasn't Fringale's fault, but limited service on their end (although they were nice when they did come by) made the night drag on longer than it should have.

- What is this "dressy" attire listed on Yelp?  People were wearing jeans and sneakers!  New dress and hot shoes fail.

This was one expensive, unmemorable dinner that I peaced out early on.  Luckily I didn't have to pick up the tab.  Score one for Vicky.
author: Tori S.

description:
I've had the pleasure of lunching at Fringale for many years. Quite near my office, this is one of the first San Francisco restaurants that I truly looked forward to visiting again and again after relocating here from New York in 2003. I am not alone in that. Usually this place is very crowded, and for good reason.

Fringale is a smallish Basque inspired French bistro in the heart of the South of Market neighborhood on Fourth Street near Brannan. According to their web site, the name means "the urge to eat." It has a contemporary, understated interior; white linens covered in crisp white paper with elegant white dishes and gleaming flatware; and a small, chic open bar by the entrance. To me the restaurant always feels warm and inviting. The walls are adorned with abstract art from local artists, which changes periodically and is often for sale.

The ingredients are always fresh; service is good; staff are efficient, pleasant without being intrusive, and what I like the most, clearly know the menu. The day that we were there, a special soup du jour of roasted butternut squash was on the menu. Our waitperson described the ingredients of the soup and specifically noted that it was made with chicken stock without needing to be asked. In my opinion, it is the little things like this that make a good place great.

Read the full blog article here:
http://weirdcombinations.com/2011/01/fringale-restaurant-san-francisco/
author: Jerome, Jerome T.

description:
I just came here last night for DAT (Dine About Town) 2011. 

I had: 

* dungeness crab appetizer: very "fresh" / clean-taste. It had bits of avocado and thin mango slices that added a nice flavor to the crab. As for portions - it's on the smaller side.. 

* lamb shank

* creme brulee: I'm a big fan of creme brulee... and this was good, but nothing AMAZING. If I were to order again, I'd DEFINITELY go with the chocolate cake & ice cream! The cake was AMAZING! 

My friend had:
* calamari appetizer: this is more of a sauteed calamari (and not your typical fried calamari). The portions were VERY generous (especially compared to my small crab appetizer)

* lamb shank

* warm flourless chocolate cake & ice cream: one word - PERFECTION!

Like the previous posts, the lamb shank was surprisingly VERY good. Lamb is usually difficult to cook (I feel like they're usually undercooked or overcooked). It was VERY tender, and I did not have to use my knife to cut at all! 

We also had a glass of wine to go along with the meal which was nice.  

**con: 
The restaurant is very small, so when you're sitting down, you're literally sitting RIGHT NEXT to your neighbor. If I wanted to, I could probably listen in on my neighbors conversation without too much effort. 

**pro: 
Service is very good. I'm a big sucker when waiters / waittresses are very attentive about re-filling your water. Plus, everyone has a HOT and sexy French accent ;)
author: Sarah C.

description: I wouldn't say this place was bad, I just wouldn't say it was very good especially for the price. I had the roasted rack of lamb for dinner and it was NOT worth the $28. I have no problem with small portions at a semi-expensive/spend-y restaurant if the food is full of flavor and takes my palate on a roller coaster of greatness, however when the food is mediocre at best I just feel cheated. At least give me a lot of food if it's going be average in terms of quality. Maybe I just had a poor dish but our appetizers weren't much better - just average at best. Small portions and high price with mediocre quality have crossed this place off my list despite the fact I work around the corner. There are far better options in SF for French food in my opinion.
author: Jackson B.

description: Classic french food in a convenient location in soma near caltrain in a comfortable environment.  A great choice.  I had the calamari as an appetizer and the rib eye as a main.  both were properly prepared though the menu should probably note that the calamari is not fried in batter which is what we expected.  still it was well prepared.
author: Daniel Y.

description: We were so impressed with every aspect of our meal! This is definitely one of our new favorite places. Andre, our server, was so sincere and charming. Absolutely a 5 star restaurant. Delicious food, amazing service, great wine, romantic and satisfying!
author: Carla H.

description:
Probably one of my favorite restaurants in SF.  The restaurant is really cute and small.  I first ran into this restaurant in 2008 when they had Dine about town and I've been coming back ever since.


Food:  Duck Confit and the foie gras is really good.  The steaks are really good here too.  Always cooked right.

Service: Pretty quick and relatively attentive.

Parking - Street parking or you can park at the lot across the street near the Starbucks.
