Con: Ball games.   Sorry Giants fans but this area is cool until there's a baseball game going on.  Then I cannot find parking.

Also, keep in mind that this restaurant is really small, so the bar and waiting area is very limited, you may have to wait outside.  I recommend getting a reservation.
author: Omar L.

description:
My Goodness! What a fantastic way to brighten up an otherwise wet, damp and dreary day in The City! My boss and I had a very relaxing lunch here and I honestly was blown away at this place. I seriously loved everything! 

We ordered the spicy calamari for a starter and it was great. My first thought when I saw the plate was, "Uh-oh, I'm not sure about this." But i was soon inhaling it! Perfectly cooked; no rubbery bits or chewy parts whatsoever! Perfectly seasoned and all the ingredients came together so freakin' well! I then had the tuna sandwich (minus the onions) with the fries. Absolutely phenomenal! The tuna was of high quality, perfectly cooked along with some greens and bits of red peppers. The buns were absolutely delicious. They were brushed with some kind of buttery sauce that I couldn't get enough of! The fries were yummy. Perfectly cooked, not soggy or overcooked. Just the way I like them! 

I then finished the meal off with the cheese plate. Again, wonderful assortment of cheeses. The bleu cheese was amazingly strong, just the way it should be! 

I honestly loved my experience here and didn't mind the somewhat pricey meal. It certainly was worth the $$$. Please keep up the wonderful food, I really loved every bit of it.
author: Michael M.

description:
quaint intimate french spot SOMA. pleasant service and plenty of attention for our group of 12.  i decided on a euro surf and turf. prawns in a creamy citrusy sun-dried tomato sauce and a steak with pommes frites. the prawns were slightly overcooked but the sauce was tasty. it great to sop up with the bread at the table. the steak was superb! and the frites were perfect.  i finished the evening affair with a wonderful palate cleanser - the trio of sorbet. this evening was apricot, blood orange and watermelon.  the space is somewhat on the small side but everything about this dining experience was pleasant. and another nod to our server for the evening who spoke fluent French had alluring eyes and a great attitude.
JYW may be a regular here soon.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Came here for lunch with a friend during their Dine About Town run. For the area the restaurant was in, the place was pretty busy, and it is recommended that you make reservations. For starters, I had the  Pate de campagne served with mache salad, cornichons & toasts while my friend had the Sautéed prawns in Pastis with sun dried tomatoes. Both very good. The pate was very subtle and wasn't overpowering in the liver taste which is what I like. The prawns were cooked perfectly and sauce was nice and creamy. 

For our entree, I had the Beef Bourguignon and my friend had the petrale sole. Both were also very good. The wine taste was subtle in the beef, but added an extra umph to it.  The fish was moist and had a nice crust on the outside. mm... Their Yukon gold puree was mashed potatoes, but nonetheless, delicious.

For dessert, we had the hazelnut mousse cake and the chocolate and banana bread pudding. man of man is the bread pudding awesome. Super warm when it comes out and topped with a scoop of coconut ice cream. they compliment each other well! and the creamy sauce it swims in tastes like nothing, but helps soothes the hot bread pudding! the hazelnut mousse cake was ok. It was a little too sweet for me, but others might like it.

The service was ok. But it's not a fast paced type restaurant, so can't complain about the duration. There are plenty of meter parking around.
author: My C.

description:
Since 1991, Fringale has been a stalwart of the SF dining scene.  Originally founded by Gerald Hirigoyen (later of Piperade, Pastis, and Bocadillos), Fringale pioneered the culinary renaissance in SoMA.  One of the first true French bistros in San Francisco, Fringale has remained true to its roots until today.

While limited, the menu offers an array of choices to please any palate.  For starters you can enjoy a roasted Monterey calamari "à la plancha" with jalapenos & chorizo, endive and frisée salad with goat cheese, or Dungeness crab ravioli with lobster sauce.  For your main course, you can partake in dishes ranging from veal osso bucco to grilled barramudi.  For dessert, you may revel in selections ranging from tarte au limon to a traditional crème brûlée or warm flourless chocolate cake with mint sorbet.

As most of the staff is French, the service is a little brisk.  But once you realize that it is just their nature, you are transported to the little bistro that you remember from the Rue St. Jacques.  The wine list is small, but focused and not over priced for SF.

All in all, Fringale is one of the best French bistros in The City.  (Dinner for 2 with 2 glasses of wine and corkage:  $120.)
author: CJ G.

description:
Went here again, this time with my family and grandparents. The food didn't quite live up to my memory of it, but it was still quite good.

I got the seafood basquaise which was quite tasty. The few bites I had of my husband's appetizer of scallops was really really good.

Unfortunately, though, the service was pretty slow and they messed up my grandpa's order (cooking his beef barely medium instead of well). They took it back to cook it more but the rest of us had long since finished our meals by the time 

The experience was still good enough that I'll leave my original 4 stars but I'm slightly less enthused about going back a third time
author: Sydney L.

description:
I recently chose Fringale as the locale to celebrate a special occasion, and found the food to be good, the service to be proficient, and the ambiance nice.  

Everything was solid, but not quite as amazing or interesting as I'd hoped.  I felt the flavors to be somewhat tired and at $96 for two, a bit higher than I would normally spend on dinner, I left more than a little disappointed.    Honestly, I much prefer Chapeau! to Fringale.
author: Joanne G.

description:
This is a cute French restaurant in the busy soma neighborhood. They have a good selection of traditional French dishes and make them all fairly well. My favorites include the mussels, seared bay scallops, and the steak with pomme fries. The specials that vary by day are exceptions as well. Huge fan of the coq au vin (thurs) and petrale sole(tues)

They have great service, a slightly older crowd, and generous portions. Fringale is also one of the few places that sell my favorite French white wine, Sancerre. The waiters at the place has changed in the last year and now it has an even stronger French flair. Most of the staff speaks to each other in French. 

This is one of the few places where I almost always go for 3 courses + wine. The dessert menu here is impressive: a very wide selection you can't go wrong with. The creme brulee is one of my favorites in the city. 

Tip: Order a bottle of wine while you wait. =)
author: Yue Z.

description:
Being the wanderluster that I am, I've been fortunate enough to experience many memorable meals around the world. From India to Italy, Thailand to Peru, many fabulous meals stand out in my mind. However, it's always comforting to find a perfect meal without having to travel far. 

Fringale serves my "I can now die a happy woman" meal: 

Spicy calamari a la plancha 
Duck confit paired with a glass of Beaucanon Cabernet Franc
Pain perdu au chocolat et bananes
Hazelnut & roasted almond mousse cake
Mme. Angèle's Gateau Basque

Now if only Fringale was in France...
author: Anastasia B.

description:
Located in a random corner right off of the fourth street exit,  this cozy  small French restaurant  who serves basque-inspired French food, was our first stop for the Dine About Town 2008 program. his is my first year participating in the Dine About Town program and we ordered off their 3 course set menu. 

Between the four of us, we had:

- pate
- Steamed PEI mussels in fried garlic, mixed herbs and sherry vinegar
-Hanger steak served with haricot verts, pommes frites in a red wine sauce,
- Apple tarte tatin served warm with vanilla ice cream
- Warm chocolate Gourmand

Everything was super delicious! The pate was not too rich and they gave a huge portion of the steamed mussels as an appetizer. The wine sauce that the mussels were in was awesome. It was soooo good that I had to dip my bread in it and soak it up to get the full flavor. MmmmMMMMmm.. yummy. 

The hanger steak was nice and juicy and super tender. The red wine sauce on the steak was to die for!  Can you tell I'm a saucey person? ha ha! This is probably the best steak I've had in a long time. The french fries and green beans were good too! 

The apple tart was freshly baked and the crust was nice and crispy. When you bite into it, feels like it melts in your mouth! What a great way to end a great meal. Yummmmmmy! Will definitely be back here again!!
author: Cynthia C.

description: I have received a response from the owner (?) of the restaurant who showed a concern about the quality of the duck confit and promised to look into kitchen standards to address my complaint. That does not happen very often and it shows the pride and responsibility of ownership. I am very impressed by how Fringale handled my complaint and vow to visit the place again!
author: Skate K.

description: We each had the DAT dinners here, each different: cheese/spinach ravioli + rack of lamb, calamari + roast pork, and another calamari with petrale sole (so not-overpoweringly buttery and fresh). Desserts were almond cake (WOW) and a chocolate cake with ice cream. A pear cocktail and two nice glasses of cab sav. The service here is exceptional. Every dish was delicious. I can't recall having a meal this satisfying in SF in a long while.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Snotty waitstaff trumps exceptional food.

What a disappointment. I visited this cozy-looking basque/french restaurant with a party of eleven. We made our reservation here (as opposed to the eight zillion other great restaurants in the area) because when we called ahead, they assured us that they could meet my friend's strict dietary needs. Not only did they not listen carefully to her order (plain chicken breast with no oil, no seasoning and plain steamed veggies), but they managed to mess it up three times. How embarrassing for her and how awkward as we had our food long before she did. Eventually, she was given a plate of green beans. 

As for the rest of us, the food was amazing. (Whatever they do for their interesting dressing on the gem salad- it's magical.) Several folks ordered the evening's prix fix, while others opted for various a la carte choices. It takes a lot for a plate of mac & cheese to be worth the $18 they charge... but let me tell you, it was fan-freakin-tastic. Everyone enjoyed their food and the desserts were no exception.

Unfortunately, we all walked out furious. In addition to the screw up with my friend's green bean extravaganza, they also treated her as though she was a lower class citizen. In fact, we all felt pretty disgusted with the snooty treatment we received. When we walked in on time for our reservation, they acted as though we were putting them out and made us stand awkwardly while they pulled tables together for us. Compliments we gave about the food were met with... nothing. Just brisk, cold snobbery.. (And we were a fun group!) When our bill came, we were met with another surprise. They charged everyone for dessert... even those who'd ordered prix fix (dessert included). We missed our train due to the time we wasted trying to get our bill adjusted to the correct amount. We finally gave up and left. And then went to Bar Basic down the street to hang out and wait for the next train... and wonder together at how much of the waiter's spit we'd all ingested that night at Fringale.

It pains me to give this place two stars, as I'd really rather give them one, but I must admit that the food was pretty great. My recommendation would be to fake a French accent, don't have dietary needs, and bring a lawyer to help settle your bill.
author: Danielle F.

description:
This place is the epitome of French snobbery.  I've read that other yelpers compare Fringale to Chapeau! but dude, sorry, but ya'll are TRIPPEN.  

The first thing I noticed when we went into Fringale was that the staff ignored us.  Again and again, my friends are discriminated against because we look young.  Oh PLEASE I'll bet we tip more generously than half the old geezers up in that joint.  They made us stand there for like a good five minutes until seating us despite the fact that we had a reservation.  No one smiled, no warm welcome, just wait at the door.  Chapeau! is totally different; everyone there is warm, talkative, and charming despite the fact that we are young adults.  

We went with the Dine About Town Menu and damn were we disappointed.  Seriously?!? My friend's soup wasn't very tasty or savory and my other friend's salad was seriously just greens and like a handful of diced tomatoes.  Simplicity can be great, but in this case it just sucked.  My pate was good, but probably the only good thing there. 

The beef bourguignon was so salty.  No one enjoyed that at all.  The salmon with risotto was so freaking dry.  I've never had salmon that was so dry and bland before.  It tasted decent mixed with the risotto, but it was so disappointing to have dry salmon.  I can seriously make better salmon, and that is sad.

The vibe of Fringale was just pretentious for food that was not even delicious.  Don't go here because their service is cold and inattentive, bordering rude half the time.  They need to stop hating on young people because we are going to grow up to be your next generation of wealthy yuppies that patronize your establishment.  Go to Chapeau where everyone is friendly, your water gets filled constantly, and the food is delicious!
author: Anna T.

description:
Food was good, service not so much. It took over 20 minutes for the waiter to even approach our table once we sat down. We didn't even get water. And when he came over finally he asked if we were ready to order. He didn't take a drink order or even go over any specials. They had a board next to the front door and it said specials and listed some wines below. We asked about if one on the list was available and the waiter said the list was old and hadn't been updated in days. Really? Then why have it?

In a city like SF with great dining options I wouldn't go back unless the service improves. Too bad because the place was cute and the meal was good.
author: Sam B.

description:
Some scallops en croute, duck confit, cozy ambiance. and a few glasses of bordeaux. Makes for a heavenly night.
Oh yes, and if it's good enough for the Michelin man, it's good enough for me.
Bon appetit. :)
author: Hung T.

description:
We came here at lunch for the Pellegrino special.
The staff were less than thrilled to see a group of 8 (yes, we had a reservation) but they semi-politely accomodated us.  It was busy, and besides,who expects French waiters to be friendly?

The quality and flavors of our meals were good.  Quantity, not so much, but again, this is par for the French course.

Desserts were generally very good, except for the strange "floater" at the top of my creme brulee.  Props to the waiter for noticing me staring at it, and he took it back.  However,  he either cleaned it off or then there are two identically cracked bowls there, because the crack was in the exact same spot.  

I convinced myself that perhaps they pulled the top layer off and reflamed it.  Except it wasn't warm when it came back to me.
Yeah, I ate it anyway.  You really think I was going to leave dessert on the table?

I would return if I were looking for reasonably priced French cuisine.

One note - we didn't get the promised free bottle of Pellegrino.  Friends who ate there the week before didn't get it either.  If a company is sponsoring you, perhaps you should actually promote their product as promised?
author: dan s.

description:
C'est tres magnifique! J'adore Fringale, mais mon portefeuille ne l'aime pas.

Delicious and distinctively French. French staff, accents, and all. Loud, but slightly intimate. Cramped chairs and booths, and non-existent aisles between tables, just like in France. The waiters even brought us somebody else's credit card and check. I think they may have been sipping on the vino.

Portions are on the small side, and from what I hear, entree sizes were a little different 2 or 3 years ago. Besides that, spectacular dishes. Rack of lamb was my favorite.
author: Chelsea P.

description: I love this place.  The food is excellent, and the restaurant is very cozy.  Highly recommend!
author: Chelsea C.

description:
Came here for dine about town.  We have half of a bottle wine and the food was good.  We had the duck and lamb.  The meat was perfect.  I didn't need the knife they provided at all, and the meat just came off the bone.  The calamari was good (thought it was like a stir fry dish).  I had the coffee parfait for dessert. It was just perfect and not too sweet.

However, I was expecting a little nicer decor for a french restaurant.
author: Deb L.

description:
Delicious, authentic french restaurant.

Everything about this place is so french, from the french waiter to the french music playing softly in the background. 

To start I had a salad with peas, asparagus, beets, artichoke hearts and carrots that was fresh and delicious. For my entree I ordered the rack of lamb which was excellent - cooked to perfection and served with tasty potatoes au gratin. My father ordered the veal short ribs and thoroughly enjoyed them. We were too full to order dessert but I will definitely come back and try it. Their menu looked amazing.

I hope I can go back to Fringale soon!
author: Jeanette L.

description: Loved it! Our dinner was fabulous, service was top notch. Highly recommend it! Just remember to lock your car and conceal your valuables;)
author: Estee L.

description:
Next DAT in the queue (only if you're following me closely!). 

Though I made reservations at 8pm on a Thursday, we still had to wait about 20-25 mins to get seated. We took a while to look through the menu and pick out a wine, but food came out pretty quickly after that. The bread, wine, and water came out after we ordered. Bread was warm and soft, with a yummy crust. 

Was starting to fill up on bread when my crab napoleon came out. 2 layers of crab, with an avocado mixture in the middle, and a mango salsa on top. Pretty good, though I felt like there was a slightly overpowering taste to it... maybe the mayo? Next on my menu was the lamb shank on top of polenta and bed of spinach. Lamb was tender, easy to get off the bone, and the portion size was pretty big. I stuffed myself because there wasn't enough to take home (or so I say....). There was a slight wait between main course and dessert, but that helped the digestion process. And it was by dessert that we figured out we were given 2 different menus! Haha, but only 2 of the desserts were different. Instead of the hazelnut almond mousse, creme brulee was listed on my menu, but I was really glad because I loved it. A strong vanilla flavor, and the caramelized sugar was deeeelicious. Mmm... I want more just thinking about it...

2 cool side notes:
1) All the waiters there spoke French to each other. So that was nice. And they were all really great and friendly servers.
2) I looked up "fringale" on google translate, and it said "munchies." teehee
author: Veronica C.

description:
What a waste of money!

Our group of 12 came here for Dine-About-Town to celebrate our friend's birthday.  

For a $$$ French restaurant, we expect superb service and professionalism from the waiter and staff, but it was the oppositive. The waiter was unfriendly, unattentive and straight up RUDE! Bumped into my friend without saying sorry, spilled water on my other friend's nap without a sense of regard, plus how many time do we have to remind them to get a Diet Coke for the birthday girl?!

We thought maybe because (1) We're a young group so they might think we can't afford the meal or (2) it's DAT week and they're busy.  Whatever the reason is, it's not acceptable.

So moving on to the food.  Seriously? Seriously? This is $$$ French food? Because of our large group, we ordered everything on the DAT menu.  The apetizers were good but the entres were disapointing.  The steak and fish were so unflavorable and unimpressed, I could have made them myself! And don't get me start with the lamb shack.  One word - DRY!

One of my gfs ended up getting food poisoning that night (poor girl) and told us that  everything came out in all directions (sorry TMI).  We each paid close to $70 and were not impressed. I would not come back here again...especially not for DAT.
author: TU B.

description: Deelissh! I came here for a work dinner and had the roasted chicken with their potato gratin- so good!! Paired with wine from Bordeaux, it was so authentic and perfect!
author: Dirty M.

description:
came here on a sunday night around 7 for dinner and only about half the restaurant was full...it's a smallish restaurant...well-lit...the crowd seemed a bit older...and kind of quiet...a little too quiet, actually...

i thought the food was very good...but no wow factor...no new combinations of flavors...most were pretty much versions of tried and true pairings...i guess which is good if you're a little less than adventurous...or... just want to stick with something you know you'll like...nonetheless, it was a nice dining experience...reasonable price point as well...

belgian endive with granny smith apples, candied pecans, and blue cheese
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=esIoUYN2rrdeWaajmNbXiQ

plateau de fromages, camembert, garocha, petit basque, roquefort, and quince paste
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=cMJpG8Ov6uSaCwAV8Plo4g
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=c-1xIxae1lXyWdW3AKOnDg


dungeness crab napoleon, avocado, tomato confit, lemon zest, and crème fraiche
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=ntiWk4eUFFCjZAPaF42W8g
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=W0KSNiTxs1UMfflY04m-Mw

macaroni & cheese pasta, wild mushrooms, artichokes, kabocha squash, and gruyere 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=_0BremqXqsPOFaS1WMHvHQ
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=oJPypjK9TMSa4PL3YBKHXw

braised veal short ribs, potatoes, leeks, oyster mushroom, and caramelized parsnips
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=IILKjaj2OAphUuAO6VGyHg
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=w7my6bXwiletJjJHr98Zng

almond cake with créme anglaise
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ug9a63OBRBje0796bFFPgA?select=OF0sOum7PkOmFBmBucZ0ZQ
author: Amanda S.

description: LOVE this place! The waiters are friendly and charming and the food is delicious. The short ribs, lamb chops, and creme brulee are must trys. The location is a bit random but the parking is easy so that's a plus.
author: Diana G.

description:
Alright, the good: service very attentive, very helpful with sequestering a baby carriage away.  Nice atmosphere,and for the city, easy to park.  

The food - generally quite good.  Not fabulous, but solid for most of the food.  Great cheese plate, great charcuterie plate, great appetizer ravioli, but the calamari from two tables away smelled fishy, so glad we didn't order that.  The pomme frites were a bit ho-hum.

My husband's roast chicken had an AMAZING skin on it.  Very good dish.  The steak was good, the spinach and gorgonzola side was wonderful.  Drink was tasty, wine pleasant... yes, yes, it almost was all great.

Until we got to my dish.  The pasta.  Alright, I get it, what was I thinking ordering pasta in a basque-esque restaurant?  I was thinking I didn't want a big hunk of meat for dinner.  And that it was on the menu.  So I ordered the vegetarian entree.  It was barely cooked, dry, sticky rigatoni with barely anything on top.  It was an insult to pasta.  An insult to the rest of the meal.  An EMBARASSMENT.  Should I have sent it back?  I don't know.  I really didn't think they could do anything else to make it better - there WAS NO SAUCE.  The dish was a poorly designed and badly executed travesty.  So what to do?  Sadly, in my case, not return.  

Which is a shame because I thought it was definitely do-able until that point.  But the entree is the main dish.  Its the part that SHOULD stick in my mind, not in my craw.
author: amy l.

description: I was so happy to find this lovely little piece of France. I have been to France several times and I really felt like I was back there again. Food is memory and the food brought back a flood of memories for me. I truly enjoyed every dish. The Prawn dish and the cheese platter were my favorites and I completely trusted the staff to pick our wine as well, which was paired perfectly. Thank you and don't miss this little corner of France in the middle of San Francisco.
author: Shellie R.

description: Had dinner here last night. Quiet restaurant with subtle music in the background. Made reservation for 730 on Sunday but saw that was not needed since the place was half full. We sat by the window so it was nice people watching while waiting for our food. The Hostess was nice and attentive. We got the beef carpaccio which was  sour as expected.  Beef was fresh. Would probably not order again. Nothing special. We ordered the seafood basquise which tasted delicious. Very flavorful . I opted for the bacon wrapped pork loin which I enjoyed. I didn't care for the sweet onions but the meat itself was good. This place was on my restaurant to try as I live in the area but would probably not be back as there are so many options in San Francisco.
author: Amy L.

description: Attention falters when large groups come in. Chicken was excellent, seafood dish sub par. Ok, but not something to seek out.
author: Joe A.

description: My husband and I went here for our very first date. The place feels authentic as many of the waiters here speak French and they are also very efficient and friendly.  The price is very reasonable as well and best of all, the quality of food is better than lots of more prestige French restaurants.  They have been around for a while and just celebrated their 20-years. Highly recommend for first date, dinner with family.
author: Lian F.

description:
This place is damn cute! Besides the bum outside trying to usher you into a parking spot for tips, this place is ADORABLE!

A girlfriend and I went here for Dine About Town and it was delicious! The portions were a smaller than the normal portions but still, it was enough to get me full.

Mussels - delicious, delicious, delicious. I dropped a shell on the ground but THANK YOU kind server, for picking it up without even thinking and not making me feel like a complete imbecile :) The sauce was light but still very tasty.

Filet Mignon - ME OH MY. ME. OH. MY. Sooooo good. I love meat and I love it rare. Perfect.

Creme Brulee - Not a huge fan of desserts but this was okay. I wouldn't order it again though.

Our server was very sweet and efficient. The wine list was okay.

Best part was, the prices are very affordable! For good French dishes, the prices were great.

Fringale is a great starter restaurant into French cuisine. Everything about it was charming!

Minus that bum.
author: T L.

description:
The food was very good but the filet mignon was truly outstanding. If i  hadn't been treating my roommate to a Dine About Town birthday dinner, I might have tried to steal it from her. (fortunately she's awesome and let me have a few bites, which actually might a cruel way to tease me...) our apps - the mussels and the charcuterie - were both delicious, as were the desserts. 

Service was fair. The clipped French accent of the waiter fit the rather clipped attention we got. It was disappointing to watch him splash some of our Grand Cru wine on the table and then leave me to wave down the busboy to get coffee with dessert.
author: Bill B.

description: Delicious lamb shank with fennel, celery and mushrooms. Can't wait to return.
author: Vena V.

description:
I was here for the DAT event in Jan 2011, and it's totally a waste of money. The only thing that I liked was the dessert, some sort of chocolate mousse. 

I had the spinach ravioli, which tasted very plain. It's missing a cheesy flavor. Don't ever ever get that spinach ravioli....Additionally, there was nothing special about that lamb.

I would NOT come back.
author: JFer C.

description:
So with all the high reviews for this place I was expecting a fantastic meal, especially for DAT, but my overall consensus, it was average at best. 

We had 5 in our group and we tried a majority of the DAT menu- 2 of the 3 appetizers, 2 of the 3 entrees and all of the dessert. Based on everything I tasted,  I think a little salt could have been used to heighten the flavor but overall everything was cooked extremely well. 

Appetizers:
- Dungeness Crab Ravioli in a Lobster Bisque- this smelled heavenly as it was placed in front of me; however, in tasting it, I thought it was just ok
- Mussels in a savory broth with fried garlic pices- delicious- highly recommended and my pick out of the two I tried.
* I highly recommend sopping up the sauce from both dishes with the bread- yum!

Entrees:
- Filet mignon- Cooked perfectly but definitely needed some kind of seasoning. I enjoyed the salad that was served with it and the potatoes were a fave of my fellow diners
- Coq au vin- I love when chicken is so tender it falls off the bone, which is exactly what this did. More flavorful than the steak and I thought it was cooked extremely well.

Dessert:
- Hazelnut cake- It was ok
- Wam chocolate cake with ice cream- nothing new nor special
- Creme Brulee- Probably the best out of the 3

The restaurant itself was extremely cute and the service was good. I appreciated the waiter cracking jokes with us and not minding our rambunctious bunch. I'd definitely say it's a great place to take a date because of the romantic ambiance. 

For the DAT meal and a bottle of wine split amongst five (Saint Josephs, I believe was the name of the one we got) including tax and tip, it was approximately $55 per person.

For parking there's plenty of street parking nearby so I don't think it should be that hard to find a spot.

FYI: Double check your bill at the end, they charged us for 6 instead of 5 and I know it was an innocent mistake but just a heads up
author: Nadia L.

description:
I admitted that I was not a huge French cuisine fan. This is my kind of restaurant. Cozy, authentic, great services (even the waiter is a Frenchman), reasonable price and very good French food. I will come back again try other dishes. 

Beacon Wrapped Pork Tenderloin (*****) 
Duck Confit (*****) 
Fires with Aioli (I like the Aioli but fries is good but not the best I had) 
Vouvray, Remy Pannier '05 (Very Dry, my new fav!)
author: Flora C.

description:
This place is very reliable for me ... when I try to find a place to eat around my area ... i always end up picking Fringale.

The place is nice and cozy .. and the servers are friendly. I always come in as a walk in .. and no matter how full they are, they always try to accommodate me and my partner.

Food is excellent. Never let me down. From chicken to halibut to duck. Great flavors, cooked very well.

Desserts are fantastic too!


** Update 07/27/2011

I still love this place. It's about as authentic as you can get. I just wish they update their menu once in awhile. Ive come here numerous times since last year and they havent changed a single thing in their menu. 

The service is still great and the staff are all friendly.... with cute french accent ;)
author: RED C.

description:
Had lunch once at Fringale and was pretty pleased with the choice. The Frisée salad with warm bacon dressing is amazing. For entry, I had spinach ravioli. It was also tasty. The Warm chocolate Gourmand cake was pretty nice with an icecream on top.  

The service was relatively quick comparing to other French restaurants.
author: X L.

description: Fringale has been one of my favorite French restaurants in the City for the past five years.  Everything is delicious, especially the desserts.  Tables are close together in a small space, but the overall atmosphere is warm and relaxed.  Bon appetit!
author: Sherri C.

description:
Two words - duck confit. We went there for my mother's birthday and she got sick off of the skin. It was so crispy and delicious that she ate the rest of mine. The veggies it came with were perfectly cooked as well. 

The atmosphere is pretty uninspired and the music made me laugh, but the food was spot on. The dessert was pretty good too. I'd definitely go again.
author: Jessica L.

description: Went here for a birthday dinner and everything was great.  We had wonderful service and the pacing of the meal was great.  The bread was fresh and the spinach ravioli appetizer was delicious.  We also had the lamb special and the meat fell right off the bone.  The potatoes gratin and pommes frites were great side dishes that we ordered.  Unfortunately we were too full for dessert but next time we will definitely save room.  Overall this was a great find.  The various dishes were exceptionally prepared and had great flavors.  It isn't cheap but delicious food is worth the price.
author: Justin T.

description: My boyfriend and I went here for Valentine's day last year. I still think about their delicious lamb. The staff are kind for being such a fancy restaurant. Thank goodness Bloomspot had a coupon for it (I swooned when I saw it) and we'll be going there for my bf's birthday dinner YUM
author: Angela S.

description:
I was excited about eating here after reading many positive reviews, so arrived with a positive attitude and pretty high expectations.

The experience was disappointing.

Waited at the bar for 10-15 mins before being attended to, which is forgivable on a busy Sat night. Then served a couple of drinks including the worst G&T I've ever tasted. Tonic was flat, there was too much of it, the lime was a dried up wedge which had been cut hours earlier.

We were seated promptly at reservation time, but our waiter seemed to want to be anywhere but there. I actually like stand-offish French wait service rather than false cheeriness, but this was something else. Tired and begrudging. The guy could have been having a bad night, I've been in his shoes and know what it feels like, but you still make the effort to hide that from paying customers.

We had:

Carpaccio: decent but nothing to write home about, very small portion for the price
Lobster Bisque: quite good
Rack of Lamb: asked for medium rare, got medium well, not what I expected at a French place. The meat itself was very good quality. 
Pain Perdu: excellent desert, the star of the night
Creme Brulee: a classic very well executed, desert was the high point of this meal

When the bill came it was incorrect, including a drink that we didn't order. At that point, despite really fantastic deserts, the overall sense of carelessness was hard to ignore so we left feeling let down and disappointed by Fringale. I'm sure they can do better, but I won't be returning to find out any time soon.

I'd like to give 2.5 stars but as this was not 3-star A-OK for various reasons, I'm sticking with the "Meh" and a 2 star rating.
author: Aodhan M.

description:
Michael Bauer 's 100 it did not make .It should get an extra star for this distinction!

The food is very good French. It is small and you feel a bit cramped.The service is only pretty good because the kitchen is slow.

It certainly ranks in the top 100 best SF restaurants.The only thing I can figure is that Michael Bauer probably had to pay for his meal and therefore didn't consider it.
author: Robert N.

description:
Yea, Dine About Town here sucked. It was not memorable at all.

The beef bourguignon was crazy salty and the salmon was bland. The skin was good, but that was about it. I personally thought the salmon was just a little undercooked. The pate was meh.... I've definitely had better.

My friend and I had a really late lunch at 2 something so we were the last to leave. The waitress was nice and came to fill our glasses with water every now and then. But really, the entire experience was just meh. 

Honestly, I don't know why they give sub-par food/service to people, especially young people, ordering from their dine about town menu. Even though so many people had great experiences at Fringale, I don't want to go back ever.
author: Lucy D.

description: Among a party of 11 food lovers and chefs and all the different dishes ordered, my order of the Roasted rack of lamb was the hit and was passed around for all to try.
author: Michaela F.

description: I really enjoyed our meal here. The service was outstanding.  The food was equally amazing.  I had lamb chops. My boyfriend had pork tenderloin wrapped in bacon. Our friends also had the tenderloin and the veal short ribs. All the meats were tender and juicy and the sides fit perfectly.  I'm under the impression that anything you have here is great. They have a decent selection of wine and very yummy cocktails made with fresh ingredients and to your taste preference. It is expensive.  Maybe if you have a drink and an entree you can spend just under 50. Oh, you must try the onion tart.
author: Jasmine N.

description:
Came here for dine about town with a group of girl friends. It's a really cute ambiance and very intimate setting. 

I had the Dungeness crab Napoleon, avocado, arugula, lemon zest, piquillo pepper & mango salsa as my first course. It  was REALLY good. Never knew that fresh mango can turn up the notch by so many levels. I then chose the Traditional duck confit, lentils "Du Puy", garlic, bacon & red wine sauce as my main course. It was good and the duck was very tender. Lastly, I had the chocolate lava cake thing. The texture was so smooth, it was warm, soft and chocolatety! It was good but not sure if I would pay the regular price for everything. But one of the better selections for dine about town!
author: Keara C.

description:
Ha - I never cancelled my reservation.   If you had taken 2 seconds to listen to your customers you would have known that.  But, as you said, you "are very busy and have a full restaurant".  So you clearly weren't interested.  

No skin off my back.  I had a great dinner at Coco's right next door to you.  A nice place where people aren't too busy to pay attention to their customers.  What a concept.  Go figure.
author: greg f.

description:
Yum!  We came here for DAT and were very happy we did.  The starters were so savory, especially the roquefort & spinach ravioli!  We also ordered the dungeness crab napoleon, which was good, but not as good as the ravioli.  The entrees were just mediocre.  I'd give them 3 stars.  However, the desserts deserve 5 stars!  We ordered the Warm chocolate Gourmand and Hazelnut & roasted almond mousse cake.  Both were DELICIOUS!  I'd come back just to order desserts and the ravioli.

In addition, the service was good and our drinks were strong!  What more can you ask for?
author: K V.

description:
A most civilized place to heave lunch, especially on a hot sunny day like today.  If you could imagine cobblestones and olive groves instead of 4th St and a parking lot, you could think you were in Avignon or Aix-en-Provence instead of San Francisco.

Lunch was simply fab.  I got the crispy skin salmon served with roasted tomatoes, asparagus, arugula & caper berries  The perfect thing for summer.  The hubby got portabello mushroom napoleon with polenta.  He couldn't stop raving about the polenta.  Of course it wouldn't be a civilized meal without some wine - Cote de Provence rose of course! (ssshhhh... don't tell my employer).

Topped it all off with Mme. Angle's Gateau Basque, which sure beats the pants off of Dianda's Almond Torte, sad as I am to report this.  The gateau basque was in a league of it's own.  And when we asked for espresso topped with steamed milk to go with dessert, they actually knew it was a macchiato.  We'd given up asking for macchiatos because no one would know what it was.  

Like I said, extremely civilized - a rare find these days.

Bike Parking: none!  You can park to the meter or the tree.  And of course parking to the tree with two old school English bikes only enhances the continental feel of the meal.
author: Jean K.

description:
Good atmosphere and service is good too for a neighborhood corner french restaurant.

I wouldn't say there is anything extraordinary on the menu but the food is good.  For appetizer we at a salad and beef carpacio. It was okay.

We at the pork tenderloin  which was nothing special and a bit boring.  The Australian sea bass with lobster sauce, was tasty with the bed of mushrooms.  

Dessert was the chocolate breadpudding.  Good.
author: Louise G.

description:
Had their Salad Nicoise. They forgot that I asked for the lemon dressing on the side, but it wasn't a big deal since they didn't put that much dressing in the dish anyway. I loved loved loooved the seared tuna! The texture was perfect. Although I have to remember to ask for no olives next time - I really hate the taste of olives in my salad! Great service, as always. 

Still docking that one star for a fly buzzing around the table!
author: Christine A.

description:
On Sunday night, we decided to finally try Fringale.  We arrived at 6:15 and the restaurant was charming and quaint and we were probably the youngest people to eat dinner there at that time.  The hostess brought us to a cozy table where we had plenty of space to have a comfy conversation.  

Food:  We ordered the Crab napoleon, french onion soup, the special of the day, which was braised short ribs and mussels with frites.  The mussles and frites were awesome and we highly recommend everyone to order that entree.  The french onion soup was one of the best we had ever.  The onions were sweet and the soup was just the right flavor.  The crab napolean was refreshing.  The short ribs were tender but didn't have the "wow" factor of the mussels.

We finished off our dinner by having the banana chocolate bread pudding dessert, which was fantastic!  We licked our spoons with delight!  Overall, Fringale did NOT disappoint.  The atmosphere was charming, the service was GREAT and the food was DEELISH!
author: Betty C.

description:
Romantic, classy, and very charming.  The food was top notch, the service perfect.  Why would you stop by an adorable french bistro if you want to be on the road in 20 minutes?  That's why McDonald's exists.

Started with Dungeness crab napolean, which tasted spectacular.  It tingled on my tounge with the happiest little tingle I've ever experienced.  I had the traditional duck confit with lentils, and the lentils were exquisite.  The duck was perfectly prepared.  By now, I was beyond stuffed, so my husband finished off my plate and I took all his polenta.  He had ordered the veal plat du jour, and I don't like veal, but I actually did like his meal.  Best spinach I've ever had, altho I know if was soaked in butter.  Hey, that's why you shouldn't eat out every day.  But any man or chef who can make spinach taste like that is a magician.  

Skipped dessert, but had to try a cappuccino since their cappuccino machine took over half of their usable bar space -- figured it had to be worth that sort of space investment.  And it was.  ^-^ 

Loved it.
author: Tasha D.

description:
Came here for Dine About Town since I figured it'd be a good deal for this normally pricier place. We were going to be an hour late, but when we called to let them know, they were completely understanding and accommodating. When we got there, we didn't have to wait too long to get seated, but there really isn't a waiting area except for the ramp up to the dining area. It felt kind of awkward just being in people's way when they were trying to enter or leave. We squished close to the end of the bar, but the bartender completely ignored us. Kind of odd. However, after we were seated, service picked up. Our waiters were very polite, informative. I wouldn't say nice, but not standoffish either. Professional, even with the crumb scrapers. 

Food was lackluster. Maybe I was expecting too much, or maybe they were holding back for the DAT menu. Scallops with mango salsa was good. Calamari with jalapeno and peppers - would not order again, as much as I love jalapenos. Had too much of that capsicum aftertaste, if that makes sense. Duck Confit with lentils was eh. Duck was very tender, good but nothing special. Dessert was hazelnut almond mousse - also tasty but nothing special. 

Overall, service and ambiance greatly outpaced the food leading to 3.5 stars. Maybe I'll come back if I happen to be in the area or if they have a different menu at the next DAT... but very unlikely.
author: Joyce C.

description:
Excellent food:  Foie gras was delicious and not too heavy as foie gras is wont to be.  Pomme frittes classic French yummy.  And the pork tenderloin cooked to perfection and full of flavor.

Service impeccable:  Efficient, unobtrusive, genuine and friendly.

Loved it.  Will return.
author: Joon-Soo K.

description: I have dinner reservations for tomorrow night that I will not be using. Why you may ask? I picked this restaurant for its reviews and the fact that I could get a table a specific time that I need given the other plans I have for tomorrow night. Today, as is typical, I received the phone call from the restaurant to confirm my reservations. After I confirmed that I will be there tomorrow night the gentleman told me something to the effect that they had tables available if I wanted to arrive a little earlier. I told the gentleman that I cannot as I have very specific plans and that is why I made the reservations for the time I did. Then he proceeds to tell me that I need to come earlier because the kitchen closes at the exact same time as they made my dinner reservation for. Needless to say, this level of professionalism will not be rewarded with my dollars. They will be voted to an establishment who actually is interested in providing the dining experience that they advertise.
author: Don V.

description:
I did the DAT (Dine About Town) here recently. A friend and I were on time, but our other 2 friends were 20 minutes late. The floor manager was pretty discombobulated. He said we could sit down, but then he wasn't sure, but then we should go over to the bar (which we did), then we could sit down, no wait till we know what's happening with the table, sit, don't sit, wait, uh, okay, after 5 minutes we were able to sit at the table in the so far 1/2 full restaurant. Not a big deal, but kind of awkward.

There were 3 choices each for DAT's - appetizer, entree, and dessert. I forget all the options now, but I got the Calamari for the appetizer - that was good, but not super memorable. The entrees I think were Filet Mignon, Salmon, and Duck. I got the Salmon, and that was really good. My friends all got the Filet Mignon. For dessert I got the Creme Brulee.

The service was, well, French. Our waitress was hot, so I'm probably being more lenient than normal. Actually, even aside from that, service was fine. I don't know that this place was memorable enough for me to come back though. 

Parking in the area on a Friday night sucked. I think I parked two blocks away, way the fuck down on Bryant & 6th. Not a big deal to me either, but be prepared to look for a while, or drive around if you want free parking (after 6pm).

As others have said, it was fairly small, but I would describe it more as intimate than cramped, but I'm pretty easy-going. The bus boy bumped into me with his ass a few times, but whatever.
author: Ken L.

description:
I was here with a big group so they split us into the two booths that are near the back. The place is small and cozy and the price range is not too bad. Because it was a big group, I had the luxury of tasting all the different dishes everyone ordered.

The Frisee salad with warm bacon dressing, poached egg, and toasted levain was amazing. It had just the right touch of dressing to it and the warm egg yolk that drizzled out was so good! 

The Spicy Monterey calamari "a la plancha" with jalapenos and chorizo was also amazing. I love spicy and this was very different from what I've normally had when it comes to calamari. Definitely eat up those jalapenos!

For the entree, I had the traditional duck confit in the bacon and red wine sauce. Very very good. The two desserts that rocked were the hazelnut and roasted almond mousse cake as well as the Mme. Angele's Gateau Basque...
author: Jamie T.

description:
A-ok is right.

It's good, but certainly not the best French food I have had. Service was really friendly. Ambiance was okay. Came at 9 pm and the place was packed.

We ordered the calamari to start. Not bad. It wasn't chewy and fried. Flavor was nice and it was well seasoned.

I ordered duck breast at medium rare. Came on top of parsnip puree. It was good, but not the best like I mentioned earlier. Something about it didn't make me thin WOWOWOWOWOWOWOWWW. But it was good.
author: Beverly T.

description:
Dine about town review

Came here with 7 of my girl friends with an 8:30pm reservation (that's all that they had left!).  Upon arriving at the restaurant, we almost missed the door because it doesn't look like a regular door! Looked like the back side door or something... but we're smart so we figured out that this was the entrance to the restaurant.  At first glance, the restaurant is very casual, yet nice and had a very nice cozy feeling to it. It's small, but can surprisingly hold a lot of tables given the arrangement of the tables. We were a lil squished with 7 people at a normal 6 person table.

We waited for our 2 friends to come, but in the meantime, we were all starving and requested some bread.  Despite our request for bread early, the waiter didn't bring it out until everyone at our table had arrived, about 15 minutes later. Bad service in my opinion.  Anyway, we paid a $20 corkage fee for our own wine and at least had some wine to sip on while waiting.  

I debated on doing DAT or just ordering from the regular menu, but as soon as I saw "filet mignon" int he DAT menu, my mind was made up and there was no turning back.  The DAT menu is a little different than shown on the official DAT website, but for the better. 

For appetizers, you have the choice of: 
- dungeness crab ravioli
- spicy calamari (not really spicy at all)
- Assiette de charcuterie maison, saucisson sec, rillette, pate & frisee

Entrees:
- Coq au vin, mashed potato, mushrooms, spinach, pearl onion & red wine sauce 
- Sautee petrale sole, squash, English peas risotto & sorell beurre blanc
- Grass fed filet mignon, pomme frites, mixed greens & shallots sauce

Desserts:
- Crème brulee
- Hazelnut & almond cake
- Chocolat gourmand

I ordered the spicy calamari, filet mignon and hazelnut almond cake.  The calamari was good but could have used more jalapenos for a spicy flavor. It looks exactly as it does in the pictures--not breaded or fried, but still had good flavor to it. The crab ravioli was also really good, filled with lots of dungeness crab.  It only comes with 4-5 pieces, but it's so filling that quantity doesn't matter.  My filet was cooked medium rare and came out perfectly.  At first glance, I was disappointed in it's tiny size... but in reality, it was the perfect size because of it's thickness.  I was definitely stuffed!  The filet was very juicy, tender, and very flavorful. No one was disappointed.  My friend order the macaroni pasta with mushrooms and artichoke since she's a vegetarian.  It was pretty bland and dry.  I'm sure after seeing our filets she wished she was a carnivore. haha  My other friend got the sole with risotto, which she loved and inhaled. She was finished before any of us steak eaters were done.  I'm sure if she could, she would have picked up the plate to lick it.  The desserts were also amazing!  Despite having difficulty finishing my filet mignon, we had no problems finishing the desserts.  The hazelnut almond mousse cake was fantastic!  It was light yet flavorful. The toasted almonds on top also added a nice touch to it.  The creme brulee did not disappoint!  The chocolate cake was just ok to me, but that's because I'm not a big fan of chocolate.  Out of the 3 desserts, my fav was the mousse cake, then creme brulee.

Overall, our experience at Fringale was great.  It was a good atmosphere with dim lights and quaint, cozy feel.  The food was delicious!  I would recommend all my friends to come here for their DAT menu, if not DAT, then just to eat!  With corkage and DAT, each person paid about $48.
author: Diane L.

description:
This was my first and will be my last DAT outing.  I decided to go here with a friend after reading the glorious reviews on Yelp and left the place completely unsatisfied.  If only I can give 5 stars for their service, but the food was lacking BIG time!  I'm not sure if it was quantity vs. quality due to DAT but everything was super bland.  Started off with a bottle of bubbly which was probably the highlight of the meal!  Thank god I was a bit buzzed by the time food arrived; otherwise, I would give this place 2 star!

Pomme frites - perfectly fried.  The best thing we had all night

Crab Napoleon - where was the salt?  

Calamari - Did they double up the salt on this dish bc there were none on the crab?  All I could taste was salt, where was the kick?

Duck Confit - dry, dry, dry... lentils were more than al dente, they were undercooked!

Sole - bland, needed salt

Hazelnut almond cake - nothing special

Chocolate cake - nothing special

Maybe I went on a bad night, but honestly, DAT is the same price as most restaurant offering for a 3 course meal.  I think it is best to stay away during DAT where food is not rushed out and prepared properly.  Maybe I'll give them a second chance if I am in the area again.
author: Amy L.

description: Great restaurant with great service and delicious food.  I like jetting over here for a quick lunch when I need to get out of the office.  I would definitely come back!
author: Tracy N.

description: Nice little French/Basque restaurant about a block north of the SF Caltrain station.  Came here twice recently.  The first time I came for dessert.  Had the pain perdu au chocolat et bananes.  It was basically like a fancy "french toast", but it was very good, probably because of the bread and other ingredients used.  Second time was when we had a visitor from out of town and decided to go here because it was down the street from the hotel.  I had the Seafood Basquaise.  It had fish, mussels and prawns, all cooked to perfection.  It was presented elegantly and filled me up, although I still wanted more.  The staff seemed genuinely friendly and our waiter was very helpful in describing the menu items and suggesting ones for us to order.  We will definitely be back.
author: Bryan P.

description:
Ok.. why the 2 stars?
1. Service was bad..tried to get our waiter and he said "Oh, sorry I forgot ALL about you!" wtf...O_o
2. Halibut- was not tender.. but more.. mushy, along with the orange sauce which I didn't think was palate pleasing... 
3. Bacon wrapped pork.. nothing spectacular
4. Price 

This place would be fine.. if I was paying like $12 a dish.. not $25...then I wouldn't expect exceptional food... 

and fyi.. if you're coming here.. it's small, and lots of "older" folks.. felt like I was eating an early bird special with the gramps and grandmas.. but it's cool...

prob not coming here again..
author: Kristina L.

description: The calamari looks spicy but it was not.  it sat on top of a lake of red oil.  The spinach ravioli was not bad, but not great.  I forgot what it taste like already.  The duck confit was nice, but I almost mistaken it for chicken.  The ribs had a lot of fat but the meat was super soft.  The hazel nut mousse was not very soft.  The chocolate gourmand was nice.   The service was mediocre.  If not for Bloomspot, I will not come here and pay full price.
author: Byron L.

description:
December, its a month where you crave warm hearty meals full of flavors, alongside a nice glass of wine.  And what better way to enjoy in your finest clothing, on a Friday night at a Company holiday dinner at Fringale. 

Fringale means..the urge to eat!  And I sure had the urge!

We started off with appetizers:
-spicy monterey calamari: it wasn't too spicy.  It's not your typical breaded and deep fried calamari. But it was a bit different with the chorizo and olives!  It gave it a nice flavor
- Assiette de charcuterie: pate and all.. it was pretty good!!!
-  Foie gras terrine: this was the winner of the bunch! The Foie gras had a sweet taste to it.  It was paired with a pineapple chutney that really complemented each other.  This was delicious!

Soup:
Leek soup..the special of the day was REALLY good!

Entree:
- Bacon wrapped pork tenderloin:  It was very tender!  And I usually don't like bacon, but I think the pork tenderloin was wrapped in bacon and removed.  I definitely tasted the bacon flavor.  The dish was full of flavors.  And the onion and apple marmalade along with the pork tenderloin, it was like a party in my mouth.
- I also tried the duck breast (special of the day) and the veak short ribs! Both were quite tasty and very tender!

Dessert:
- Warm chocolate Gourmand, flourless chocolate cake. It's like rich chocolate chocolate warm chocolate choclate cake that melts in your month, with a sweet raspberry syrup and mint sorbet! YUM-O

wine: bottles and bottles of wines, BOTH of my wine glasses were never empty.  I forgot to write down the white wine beacuse that was probably one of the best white wines I've had.  And the red wine was really good with my entree.  Both from france

Service:  The service was actually quite AMAZING!. She was a cute french girl.  I never saw the bottom of any of my glasses, she always made sure we had everything we need.  

I love the decor, the ambiance, the service, and the french-ness of this place.  Great place to try!
author: Joanne H.

description: Wow. And that response is foremost for the service here - absolutely terrific! We had a reservation, were greeted pleasantly & promptly on arrival and the next few hours we were treated to some of the best wait service I have had in the city since living here. And I eat out a LOT! The food & ambiance was terrific too. I have walked by this place so many times before eating here, the restaurant front is easy to miss in this area. But inside, its cozy, tastefully decorated & not too cramped. All of our meals were delicious too: a mix of the prix fixe meal/filet, duck confit, & my combination of the spinach raviolis &  scallop small plates, to make a meal. The desserts are fantastic too, my fave being the almond gateau. Sure, the wine by the glass list was not extensive, but the bordeaux I had was very good & well priced. Don't bypass this place, if in the food for french bistro cooking, you won't be disappointed.
author: Jen S.

description:
I took a date to Fringale on the recommendation of someone that I trusted that used to live in the neighborhood, and he was spot on!  This place was definitely one of the best fine dining experience that I've had in San Francisco!  It's a real intimate space, with a very friendly and knowledgeable staff.  I highly recommend coming here to check it out at least once!

We ordered a mussel dish and a wild Atlantic Salmon dish.  We also got a bottle of wine on the recommendation of the waiter, which was very refreshing and delicious!  The food came out fairly quickly, and at just the right temperature.  The flavors were intense, but not overwhelming.  The sauce on the mussel dish was creamy and tasty, but it didn't feel heavy.  Portions were just right.  We had a very good dining experience there, both in terms of the quality of food and service.  This place deserves one of my stingy 5-star ratings!
author: Leo C.

description:
I'm not going to spend much time on this place, but felt I needed to say something.  We were super excited about coming here after looking at their menu online.  It did not live up to expectations.

1.  Our waiter was not cool.  He treated us as if we were an inconvenience.  He was french so maybe that's to be expected.
2. He wasn't really french, his accent sucked.
3.  The food was just ok, the mac n cheese we got was not cheesy and more just oily pasta.
4.  For the end price tag it was not worth it.  But Hot Tub Time Machine was.
author: jessica b.

description:
To be honest I am not a big French food fan. I had seen this place many times, walked by, looked through the window but never gone in. Finally went there last night to give it a shot. 
WOW! 
Really amazing food! I had a seafood dish with lots of different types of fish (salmon, cod, mussels) in a well seasoned tomato broth. My bf ordered the LAMB and that was just melting off the bone. :) yum yum yum all around! Will definitely rethink things when I come across a french restaurant. This was a delight! 
And service was great! It's a small restaurant, feels nice and cozy.
author: Priscilla E.

description:
We came at last minute on a Tuesday night at 7:00 and they were able to accommodate us- no reservation. Within an hour the place was full so we were lucky. The room is nice -well spaced -LOW noise levels. Nice bar at entrance. Bathroom was very clean. Table we had was spacious for two and near window. Nice linens. 
The menu was thoughtfully done with a nice variety of choices -some standard such as fois gras and salads -plus wide selection of mains. A prix fixe was available.
We had the soup of the day- onion leek gratinee- was excellent - and a very good beet salad mix with excellent dressing. Next we had lamb shank based on a plate of it a nearby diner had (huge portion, smelled great) and the veal short ribs - which were so tender they literally melted in mouth. Quality of meat for both was first rate, sauces very very tasty and authentic, sides excellent (pommes cooked to perfection). Meal tasted. As if cooked by a little tiny French country grandma was in the kitchen. The dessert we shared was the almond cake - fresh, tasty, not too sweet but very delicious. Good glasses of red wine with meal the helpful and charming owner(?) recommended was perfect. Waitstaff super professional. Not overly engaged as often noted in so many (too many) restaurants in San Fran. Bread excellent - butter was very very good (good enough to notice). With tip dinner for two pricey at $175 (2 glasses wine plus 2 glasses cocktails total) but definitely worth it. A quiet evening with amazing quality meat superbly cooked and attentive yet not intrusive service- that is pretty rare in our experience in San Fran dining- made it well worth it (plus we were celebrating a Bday). This would be perfect for a romantic dinner out - not for large groups unless you reserve their special part room. It is just quiet French country style comfort food. We will definitely be back!
author: Robyn G.

description:
Came to here for dine about town with Alli T., Nadia L., and some others.  My expectations were high after reading the reviews but alas, the dining experience didn't meet expectations.  

Of everything that night, I'd have to say the the mussel appetizer was the best dish of the night.  Give me a triple order of that, unlimited bread, and I would have been very happy.  I went for the dungeness crab ravioli which was good but it wasn't amazing.  

For the entrees, the coq au vin was very good.  The meat just fell right off the bone and the flavor was exquisite.  The filet mignon, on the other hand was cooked perfectly but lacked something.  I'm not sure if it was a little more seasoning but it just felt like it was incomplete.  The sides of potatoes and salad next to the filet were much more impressive.  

I might be a bit of a dessert nazi but of the three desserts we tried, all of them were unimpressive.  There was a hazelnut cake, warm choc cake, and creme brulee.  I didn't really like the hazelnut cake or the warm choc cake.  The creme brulee was tolerable.  

The highlight of the weekend was the waiter who would constantly make jokes.  I'm heavily debating giving this place 3 or 4 stars.  Ideally, it'd be 3.5 but I'll give it four because of the ambiance, the mussels, and the waiter.
author: Eddie L.

description:
From the Dine about Town menu (~$35.00) I ordered the octopus for appetizer, sole on risotto and creme brulee for dessert.  The octopus appetizer was almost a meal in itself, prepared with a savory sauce of jalapenos and olives, I finished the entire plate.  The sole on risotto was amazing.  The sole was baked in a light batter and placed on top a bed of creamy risotto with squash.  The sole was a perfect complement to the more savory appetizer.  As for desert, you can never go wrong with Creme Brulee.  The waiter forgot the strawberries on top of my creme brulee so I asked him and he didn't hesitate to bring me a fresh topping of strawberries.  

I also tried the ravioli appetizer and filet mignon and they were not bad as well.  The filet mignon was perfectly cooked as medium rare and seemed well-aged. The portions were perfect.  I finished all my food and did not have to take any home in a doggy-bag, but then again I eat more than your average girl.

One of my friends brought in wine to complement our meal and the corkage fee was only $20 per bottle. For a party of 7 with all of us ordering the Dine-about-Town menu, our bill came to ~$50/person (gratuity and tax included)

A small cozy restaurant.  We had party of 7 and the restaurant had placed a chair at the head of 3 aligned tables.  The party of 2 who had their table behind the head seat where I sat seemed a bit annoyed that we were so close and in their comfort zone. I'm thinking that the maximum allowance per table should be about 6 or else other people aren't very happy.

Otherwise the food and service was average.  Our waters glasses were never left empty but our waiter rarely checked on us, but that's okay with me. Parking should be okay since there are not a lot of clubs or other businesses to compete with street parking.  If you're looking for an intimate, cozy get away this is a good spot.
author: Shirley W.

description:
The only reason why I did not give this establishment 5 stars is because the restaurant is smaller than a gym locker room! I respect the restaurant 100% I just wish it was bigger?

Anyways on to the food. Dungeonous Crab Napoleon was fresh,full of flavor, and well presented and i ordered the lamb shanks that were succulent to the bone. The staff were very nice and friendly! Good place to go on a date
author: Steve M.

description: Not only is the food excellent in an old-fashioned bistro type of way, but the owner and servers make you feel like family.
author: Jennifer K.

description: Three of us had a wonderful dinner at Fringale last night! The service was attentive, helpful, and patient. The food was exquisitely flavored and the prices reasonable. The shrimp in pastis sauce as a starter was so amazing that I am looking for the recipe online.......the spinach ravioli in roquefort sauce delicious, and the seabass with piperade and tapenade out of this world! I can't wait to go back.
author: Susan S.

description:
We came here for dinner this past weekend.  The restaurant is very cozy and warm and we found the service to be ok.    
We enjoyed a nice bottle of cabernet-reasonable at around $40.  I was pleasantly surprised with all the bottle options. The hubby had the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin, it was moist and tender-very good and I had the dungenous crab napolean ( there were two pieces of shells ;-( so they should be more diligent )  but otherwise the crab and mango was full of flavor. We ended the meal with the creme brulee and it was excellent.  We intend to return and try other items on the menu.
author: Lizete S.

description:
Came here for January 2010 DAT.  The quality of the food was good, service was good.  

I only have two complaints.  The place was so small, it seemed like they added more tables to accommodate DAT diners and sometimes the waiter would walk by and knock into my chair.  That was annoying. 

Furthermore, I felt slightly rushed towards the end of our meal due to the fact the waiters were asking us if we were done and clearing our plates rapidly.  I understand that you're trying to accommodate more diners and it's busy...but I don't like to be rushed when eating.  

I had the charcuterie, very good.  I tasted the crab ravioli, but it needed more sauce and it came out warm instead of hot.  

I had the filet for main course, cooked perfectly.  I tasted the coq au vin, that was delicious, the chicken was delicate and full of flavor.  

I had the hazelnut mousse cake for dessert, absolutely great! It was so light and not too sweet.  The chocolate cake dessert was good too, it was served with vanilla ice cream.  I heard that the creme brulee was great as well.
author: May L.

description: Everything was amazing from the braised scallops, to the veal short ribs, to Mom's rack of lamb and our shared warm chocolate Gourmand. My taste buds were in heaven.
author: Kelly M.

description:
Eaters Beware! 

Are the Jim Crow Laws still in effect?

I am totally disgusted by the snooty arrogance of the host and lack of table service even after a reservation was made.  I guess to them I was not a human and was shrugged off like a third class citizen.

Mind you, I live and work across the street in SOMA and just wanted to have a decent meal. 

This is the FIRST time this has happened to me in the Bay Area. I will never set foot or recommend this establishment to anyone. I am not saying the food is good or bad but there are etiquette restaurants must follow. This one FAILS.
author: Francois M.

description:
4 adults, a 9 month old, one of us had some serious celebrating to do, so we took the dad who flew in (it's hard to afford otherwise), and went to Fringale. I'm vegetarian, my 9 months old is... 9 months - very well behaved, but still 9 months, my husband requested a place with calamari and we're all foodies. This made us ALL happy. The 9 month old had gratin and the coconut sorbet from grandpa's pain perdu. I had their delightfully fresh mac 'n' cheese a la real cheese and veggies. Hubby had the duck with lentils, sister had the chicken and grandpa had the lamb - everyone was super impressed. The calamari was a hit, as well as the spinach and Roquefort appetizer.

The wine - Malbec, was incredible. The servers were so accommodating and wonderful - they even helped put a napkin under the baby so that she could eat her gratin with her own two hands.

And all that was before desert... the chocolat gourmand is.... merveilleux! really. Definitely will be a repeat visit!!
author: May D.

description: Liked my meal a lot here, even though I'm not a big French food fan.  Came for father's day and I had the rib-eye with the wine butter dollop on the side.  Ordered medium rare, but could have done medium here.  You just never know.  Still enjoyed it.  Exceptional flavor, perfect portion, nice fries.  Wine prices were reasonable.  Friendly service.  Easy free parking on a Sunday if you're driving, probably pretty easy any evening other than Fri or Sat or Giants game night given the odd location this spot resides.
author: Marc S.

description: A group of us came for dineabout town. I had the crab-stuffed ravioli to start. You get three small raviolis that come in a good lobster bisque but it's just really not worth what you'd pay for it as a separate appetizer. For my entree, I had the filet...while it was cooked perfectly, there was nothing special about the flavor of the meat.. I'd much rather spend the money at Ruth's Chris or House of Prime. Dessert was not really spectacular either - I had the almond-something cake and I was done after one bite. (To be fair, I don't really like dessert..) So two stars is about right "Meh. I've experienced better." Maybe French food is just not my thing, but $45 after tax and tip with the pre-fixe dineabout town menu is just money that is way better spent elsewhere. Oh, the bread was great though...
author: Kimberly S.

description: Fringale is an outstanding find - courteous and refined service, cosy and intimate atmosphere.  The grilled calamari, seafood and steaks are excellent and you can't go wrong with almost any combination off their menu.  The wine selection complements the food well.  I have been a long time regular and find this a great place for a quiet elegant meal in a fun part of the city.
author: Tip M.

description:
Went for lunch and was worried when we arrived to a little bit of host gas-face. I think it was just because we were the first customers to arrive, because after that the service was great. 

This was a 2 vs 2 business lunch, so pretty casual, although it seemed like a heavy hitter atmosphere inside (dude with trophy wife who brought his own wine, etc.). Atmospehere is definitely "bistro" but I agree with the other reviewer who said the food was closer to "gastromonique." I was disappointed the roast chicken takes 20+ minutes, so went with the filet, which was by far the best piece of beef I've eaten in months. Perfectly prepared and seasoned, with a great sauce. Fries were good too. 

I especially appreicated the attentive service, with big bonus points for the quiet refilling of the bread bowl. My dining companions all cleaned their plates (pork tenderloin, duck confit and the coq au vin). My co-worker described the pork as "perfectly prepared."

It seemed like there was a little bit of a locals scene at the bar, which was cool. Some of the other reviews of the service on Yelp are horrifying, but based on my experience, this is a new go-to lunch spot for clients.
author: Chris C.

description:
Came here for DAT.  There was a bit of a mixup with our reservation, which we made through opentable.com.  It eventually got resolved and we were seated, but I felt the maitre'd and the wait staff could've been a bit more gracious about it. I felt like we were getting some dirty looks.  I did, however, enjoy the small and cozy feeling at the restaurant.

But, anyhoo, onto the food. I had the following things:

Prawns: DELICIOUS sauce, kept scooping it up with my bread. I think I nearly ruined my appetite with it! I was personally sad that the dungeness crab ravioli wasn't a choice for DAT on the day we went, but the prawns were a hit!
Octopus: This was also on some of the DAT menus but not the day we went. Sounded really tasty so we ordered it for the table anyway.  It was not nearly as spicy as one would expect - it could've definitely used that extra kick.
Filet Mignon: The meat itself was pretty good but wasn't the best I'd ever had. The potatoes gratin that came with it were so, so rich and velvety and cheesy and delicious.
Creme Brulee: We were kind of in a rush to leave for our show, unfortunately....I wish I had the time to sit there and slowly enjoy this!

A friend had the petrale sole and the hazelnut cake, which was also delicious. The duck confit was just ok from what I tried.  I dunno if I'll be back again but the food we had definitely was pretty tasty. I'm just not  sure that it was super duper memorable.
author: Alice C.

description:
It's been months since the last time I visited Fringale. 
I feel like I owe you a review, so here I am.

I love love love the organic chicken basquaise.
So tender....so juicy.... so gooooooood. 

The place is really small, I will not recommend big party to come.
Other than that, service is good.

At the end, they also gave us some dessert on the house. 
Creme Brulee and almond mousse cake.
I love their dessert, I am glad I got a chance to try.
author: Marlis T.

description:
I got to try out this Basque-style French bistro during my weekend in SF over the xmas holidays.  This cozy little restaurant with its unassuming front is located in a somewhat sketchy part of SF near the warehouse district and AT&T park.  The first impression I got was how French it was, down to the stereotyped accents of the host (I guess maitre d?) and waiters. 

Being part of a large dinner party it gave me the opportunity to sample many of the dinner menu items and I can honestly say I enjoyed all of them. Among the appetizers I sampled were the foie gras terrine (I really have to stop eating fatty goose liver or my own liver will turn into one) Monterey calamari and Roasted Butternut Squash soup.  Dinner items included the steamed Mussels, traditional Duck Confit, braised Veal short ribs (cruelty never tasted more delicious) and poached Black Cod.  

The combination of decently priced dishes with friendly and attentive service capped off with the cozy, smart yet family friendly ambiance makes this bistro a solid recommendation to anyone who wants a nice group dinner or date in SF
author: Ed K.

description:
We arrived for lunch around 1145 on a Thursday.  Initially our waitress was rather attentive, but she soon became rather scarce and it rapidly became apparent that the staff on hand were insufficient to the task of taking care of the dining room.  2 waits and one manager for about 45 diners is tough, but this kind of situation is manageable for people who know what they're doing and hustle.  Unfortunately, the manager stood behind the bar occasionally chatting with guests and was of absolutely no use to anyone.  The other two cooperated reasonably well, but he moved with a speed and energy appropriate to a person with late-stage tuberculosis, and she was nice enough but unfocused and rather inexperienced.  The result was a 45-minute wait between the salads and the main course, during which we all ran out of water / tea / Coke / etc.  When it came time for dessert and coffee, it was clear from context that nobody suspected a connection between the lack of interest in coffee or dessert and the impossibly long wait for the main course.  Everyone now tardy for afternoon meetings, general irritation all around.

This all said, my beet salad was extravagantly delicious, worthy of any restaurant I have ever visited, and the duck confit was basically sound despite marginally lame treatment for the accompanying lentils.  My side of Brussels sprouts was simply grand.  The fresh bread, well, brilliant.  

In summary, good food, but from today's experience, they don't actually understand very well the nuts and bolts of running a restaurant.  I would consider going again given unlimited time to enjoy the meal.

There was construction outside, with a huge crane / drill thing idling the whole time we were there.  Inexplicably, the staff kept the front door open most of the time despite a C-weighted sound pressure level in the mid-eighty decibel range with a bowel-loosening peak intensity right around 45 Hz.  Gotta love the iPhone real-time analyzer applications.  Great stuff.  How loud is it?  That's right.  Hella loud.  Anyway...I am rating it loud but today it was actually VERY LOUD and why, oh God why would you leave the front door propped open for that?  Goodness gracious.
