Ah.  For the price, I suppose you could do as well or better.  Hmm.  I guess that gets me down to 2 stars rather than 3, but I did like some things about the atmosphere, so I'm rounding up.
author: Jeff F.

description:
You know how when you are really hungry and you find an open restaurant, make the reservation and the entire time, all you can think about is eating? Anything?  

Well, that didn't happen. 

Why? Well, I was an idiot to go here with an important business partner and even talked up how great the restaurant is, how wonderful the food and service is... 

I insisted that we would love this place.

Fast forward: Reservation made for 9:15. Walked into a half filled restaurant at 9:10. 

Note: Restaurant hours:

Sun - Thu, 5:30pm - 10:00pm
Fri and Sat, 5:30pm - 11:00pm

Me: "Hi, I have a reservation." 

Bartender: "Yeah, we are closed."

Me: "Um, what? I have a reservation."

Bartender: *smirking* "Yeah, I just canceled that."

Hard to know what to think about what just happened, but in my low-blood sugar condition, ass clown buffoonery was not appropriate.  

I won't recommend this to anyone and I won't be going back. 

The people at the other restaurant who fed us are now our first choice in the neighborhood.
author: thrasher b.

description: Our go to restaurant before a show. The family run restaurant makes us feel welcome and serves delicious Basque cuisine.
author: Jules A.

description: First time ever at a French restaurant and everything was delicious. Thank gosh, one of my friend that went to dinner with us has a little French in her and grew up in Paris. We had her order everything! The appetizer plate with the different kinds of meat and cheese was delectable. The endive and arugula salad was refreshing. We all shared the duck confit, chicken breast and seafood basquaise. It was well cooked and approved by my French buddy. We also had the coffee and shared some cookies. Additionally we also had one and a half bottle of wine to go with our entire meal. Service was okay but they did seem kind of pretentious until they realize my friend was French and then they were more nice. Restaurant is small so you really are back to back with other diners. Overall it was a lovely but waaaayyyy expensive dinner so be warned!
author: Judy C.

description:
I came here tonight with my friends for their DAT (Dine About Town) special.
Yes, it's the first time I've dined here.
Yes, there were plenty of orientals dinning.
No, I'm not cheap, I even got a glass of wine!

But wtf.. the wait staff, the mistress at the bar, and the manager along w/the guests sitting at the bar kept whispering, staring, talking/laughing about us during the entire dinner.  Their body language says it all!

Not once was my water refilled!
Not once was I asked how my dinner went/was.

The only good thing was food came EXTREMELY fast.  We seated at 5:45 and got our main entree by 6:15.  I felt like they were just asking us to leave.  I don't like to be rushed through dinner.

Just because I bring you business on a night when no one is at the restaurant, does not mean you can treat me w/such disrespect. 
Will definitely NOT go here again. 
Had better service elsewhere. 
IE. Cassis Restaurant for their Dine About Town was better than this place.
author: Christi S.

description:
Went to Fringale with good friends Andy and Ron. Andy works at Six Apart, just a few doors away and had eaten here before, recommended the mussels highly. None of had the mussels but Ron had the Seafood Basquaise and said it was fantastic. Andy's Rosemary Chicken was great too, my lambchop had to be sent back for being completely raw in the center but was good after that. A sauce of some kind would have been nice but there was none, a pretty naked service from my experience of French restaurants. 

My haricots verts were not cooked all the way through, were crunchy. I hate crunchy beans so elected not to finish them. This was the only real fail though, as the potato escallope was outstanding and after cooking, the lamb rocked and the beet salad I had for starters was excellent.

Flourless chocolate cake and creme brulee for dessert were spectacular, all agreed. We also thought the creme brulee could have been a bit creamier and the sugar crust could have been a bit thicker.

Having said all that it was a beautiful experience, you could hear your dinner companions speak which was very nice and they made a kick-ass cappucino. Our server was oh-so-French and was quite attentive. 

I'll return some day with the hubby, he'd get a kick out of this place.
author: Maryam W.

description: I took my husband here for his birthday, the food was very yummy, one of the best french restaurant in SF. Staff was very nice and friendly. must try their duck confit, and the lamb shank just fell off the bone, also the crab n avocado napoleon was to die for
author: Lillian K.

description: Went for my birthday dinner and it was amazing.  Granted I was still pretty jetlagged so i was rather tired but i still had a good time and the food was very tasty.  Made reservations for 5 but ended up with 4 so it took them a second to seat us.   I had the beet salad to start (yum!) and rabbit as my entree (double yum).  We had a nice red wine from France though I was rather tired so it made me very sleepy very quickly.  The atmosphere was nice and not stuffy and service was very nice.  Didn't try dessert because I had cake at home but I saw other people's desserts and they looked mighty good.  I would def go back though it is a little pricey.
author: Madeline W.

description:
I love zee French. I do. I dated an international French student in college and he was so romantic. He taught me a lot of words in French. He recited French poems to me. He played the guitar and wrote several French songs for me. He fed me chocolate-dipped strawberries. He wrote French short stories about our romance.  And it was a little too lovey-dovey. He kissed my hand every 2 seconds. It was getting to be way too much. 

I admit that I did stay with him for about a month since I loved his home cooked meals (he learned from his grandma), but in the end, I realized that I didn't need to endure all the lovey-dovey abuse just to get some good French food. We have many great French restaurants in the city - and Fringale is one of my favorites now. 

This place is very small. A friendly bartender greets you as you enter. The restaurant is tiny and everyone is packed in. It's cozy. The waiters and bussers scurry around all the tables and are very polite. 

We started off with the Dungeness crab Napoleon with avocado, tomato confit, crème fraiche [$15] - it was the perfect appetizer - creamy and all the flavors just melted in your mouth. Napoleon would have been very proud that such a delicious appetizer was named after him.

Steamed PEI mussels in fried garlic, fresh herbs & sherry vinegar [$17] showed that Fringale was certainly not frugal when it came to the amount of mussels. They were juicy and the sauce was perfect for bread-dipping.

The Sauteed Lock Duart salmon served with kale, pickled mushrooms, lobster sauce [$21] was cooked perfectly and the salmon was flaky. The sauce that accompanied it was also great for bread-dipping.

The glass of Rose, Cotes de Provence '05 [$8] is a very girly wine but it was the perfect wine throughout my meal. It was light and crisp so it wasn't competing with the flavorful and heaviness of the Basque-inspired dishes.

I had a lovely meal here - and it made me think of my ex-French lova's cooking --- without all the romantic abuse.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
braised veal short ribs: fall off the bone goodness! the veal was so tender, it was delicious. 

frites & aioli: most people would probably think,  french fries are french fries , they all taste the same. i personally love the simple stuff. if you can make something as simple as french fries really good, then i believe you're good. i didn't like the frites & aioli here...it was very oily. it was crunchy but where did the soft potato center go? the aioli wasn't good either.

sautéed prawns in pastis: the shrimps were very small, and i think it would've been better if the sauce was thicker. maybe i just like my food more flavorful because i thought it was missing something...

poached covina seabass: i'm not a big fan of tomatoes sauce (unless it's pasta), so i didn't think my dish wash great. i liked the potato puree with the fish though. but overall, it was too much tomatoes! 

dungeness crab napoleon: this dish was good. i liked the combination of fresh crabs, avocado, mangoes, etc. it was a great light appetizer. 

hazelnut mousse cake: mmmm so good! i really liked the almonds with it because it provided an added texture. the chocolate syrup  made it extra sweet but it wouldn't be the same without it. 

overall, a nice, small, cozy, romantic restaurant. the staff is attentive and friendly but i thought the food was so-so.  it is also misleading to have $$$ dollar signs. i think it's more like $$
author: Connie Y.

description:
Finally able to take advantage of DAT. 3 course meal for $35 per person. I had the gem salad, pasta with veggies and the creme brulee. 

All dining companions had chosen different things off the menu: hanger steak, sole, lamb. Everyone seemed to enjoy their food. The waitstaff was not overly aggressive, friendly, over-the-top French. Instead, they were more like Parisian, stand-offish French, which we preferred. Allows you to feel comfortable and enjoy your meal without interruption. 

Parking, even with a Giants game going on, was available. My husband was going to just drop me off and then go park. But the waitstaff was SOOO nice when they saw my pregnant belly getting dropped off at the loading zone right in front of the restaurant, they allowed us to stay and park there! Rockstar parking! I guess there are pluses to being pregnant! 

2 DAT meals, 1 vodka tonic(for husband), tax and tip: $102.00...not bad for a nice evening out with good company!
author: Caroline C.

description:
I have been to Fringale three times. It has a nice, cozy atmosphere and could be very well be situated in France. One of the waiters is from Chambery, and the restaurant could be very well be situated right there.

The first two times I have been satisfied with the food received, but not during my last visit. This week I ordered the "basquaise", a seafood stew. First the dishes arrived so quickly that it has been impossible that they have been cooked fresh. The fish has the dried out texture which is common if you warm it in a microwave. The dish has almost a soup like consistency, and it was served on a cold plate. This means by the time I was halfway through my dish it was completely cold. The taste wasn't as great either.

My friend had the "coq au vin" and was reasonable satisfied, except the cold plate his food was served on as well. On one of my previous visits I had the "duck confit" which is one of their better dishes as well.

While the waiters are nice, I probably won't visit this restaurant soon again, as the food is not up to par.
author: Steve M.

description:
This place a cute little restaurant! This is my first time in SF. My fiancé and I stumbled upon this spot by mistake. We were really looking for sushi, but we settled on French food instead.

The cuisine was satisfying. Everything from the fresh calamari starter to the mussels (fee fee) and rigatoni(me) was tasty. The wimp selection was solid and the dessert (bread pudding) capped off the night perfectly.

I would recommend the spot to others. The downsides of the joint were cramped space, fruit flies in my face, and I couldn't understand the waiter's thick accents.

Give it a try though!
author: Jo Jo C.

description: Not much to add that isn't covered in the 500+ other reviews here.  I had a glass of Cabernet Franc, the beet salad, and the steamed petrale sole (and have tried to recreate the latter at home with marginal success).  All were excellent, and I look forward to returning.
author: Zain K.

description:
We were able to get  a same day early dinner reservation on Sunday.  It is cute little restaurant. 

The menu isn't very extensive but it gets a little bit of everything. 

We had the Beef Carpaccio to start and it  was absolutely delicious even though I am not a big meat eater. The Frisse salad was very interesting as it was warm but a bit too acidic. 

The special for that day was the Lamb Shank. Too bad we didn't order that as that seemed to be the signature dish 

We ordered the Sea bass which was good.  However, the seafood basket was a bit too bland. The seafood didn't' taste very fresh. Price was reasonable  though for all the entree. 

This place definitely deserves a 5 if we have picked another entree. Will come back and try the duct confit and other dishes. 

There is also a wonderful desert selection.
author: Angie W.

description: Quintessential French restaurant.  Professional service.  Great wine selection.  Traditional french food!
author: Mark G.

description:
Truly wonderful!
Staff were sensitive to my every request - and not too modest too improve on my initial choice of wine to better match the lamb, even if the   Chinon was less expensive.
Even more impressively, I was genuinely surprised by the tastefulness of the lamb. It was simply superb!

Only minor area of improvement was the speed in which the courses were served; a bit more time to savour each delicious course before the next is presented would be nice - but this would appear to be a trait shared with many American restaurants.
author: Mokkaman V.

description:
I was a little hesitant about our dinner at Fringale after reading the mixed reviews, but it was fantastic. I loved it.
I wasn't aware of the Dine About Town offering being in effect last night when we went, but it was, and all the dishes I wanted happened to be included so I got an amazing bargain. Spicy calamari, filet mignon and creme brûlée were all absolutely amazing - cooked perfectly (including the sides) and very flavorful. The creme brûlée was maybe the best I've ever had. All for $35!!  
The restaurant is cozy and inviting, the service was great and it was a wonderful place to share an evening with friends. Will definitely be back soon - and won't mind paying full price!
author: Kristi W.

description:
Found this place on yelp, many reviews and highly rated so I gave it a try.

The dining room is a bit cramped, felt like the waiter was going to hit my arm everytime he passed by the table, but thankfully he didn't. Our waitress was very friendly with a french accent, recommended a good wine. 
We started with the salmon appetizer which was very clean and comforting in a sense.
I ordered the bacon wrapped tenderloin while my girlfriend had the rack of lamb. Both were very flavorful and filling. Lamb was very tastful and the bacon on my tenderloin didn't cover up the taste of the pork.

Great experience, random location. recommended
author: Aaron C.

description:
Really quaint French restaurant in SOMA. It's across the street from the abandoned ghost town that is The Palms. 

Easy parking. The food is tasty. We like.
author: Kel S.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed this restaurant. 

My friend and I had the steamed PEI mussels and the fettuccine pasta, both amazingly delicious. The mussels are the best I've had anywhere! And I've had many Belgian moules frites. Their seasoning is absolutely delicious. Pasta was flavorful and very natural-tasting, opposite of oily and saucy you find at most places.

Dessert was hazelnut and roasted almond mousse cake. Yum.

We sat at the bar which was great. Only thing is I would not recommend the Pinot Noir, tasted a bit flat to me.
author: Susan T.

description:
A fabulous day in the city with the love of my life ended with a fantastic dinner for two at Fringale.  A small quaint little French restaurant tucked into the SOMA district.  It's warm, cozy and inviting, and the service is fantastic.
I started with the Frisée salad with warm bacon dressing and my husband had the Butternut squash soup.  Both were interesting and delicious.  The salad had a little tang to it which was balanced by the yolk of the poached egg.  The Butternut squash soup was not as creamy as others that I have had, but it was delicious.
For entrees we had Poached Alaskan Halibut and the Creekstone Farm Black Angus ribeye steak.  Yum, yum, yum!
My salmon was perfectly poached and the potatoes it was served on were pillowy and flavorful.  The salmon was topped with a tapenade, which was a little strong at times, but was a necessary accessory.
The ribeye was full of flavor and the red wine butter was a great addition.  The service was attentive but not smothering.  
Overall, the food is reasonably priced, the service was great, the wine selection good, and the food was top notch.  I would highly recommend Fringale and we will return.
author: Dana B.

description: I now understand why fringale has 4 start. I made a reservation the day before, for Dinner on a friday Night at 730. We arrived about ten minutes early,and got seated almost immidiately. We started with roquefort ravioli and onion tarte. For the main course we had sea bass and veal short ribs. For dessert, creme brulee and chocolate gournand. Very nice resturaunt with a friendly staff and nicely executed classics. I would definately come here again and suggest it to anyone.
author: Marcos E.

description:
Fringale how I love thee. 

Ate there the night before the GIANTS WORLD SERIES PARADE....and had another PERFECT meal.

I had the pork tenderloins...so freakin' good. 

My wife had the lamb chops...terrific. 

My son had the duck confit. 

The service was great, the food simply could not have been better.

Dessert was wonderful.

This was perhaps my 10th time in Fringale and each time they blow me away with their food. 

Anyone who does not like this place must suffer from cranium rectal inversion.
author: bill r.

description:
It was my first time visiting Fringale.  I will have to admit, the restaurant was a lot smaller than I expected.  But perhaps it's that cozy, tight-knit feeling they are trying to achieve.  I took a peek around the restaurant as I entered. I noticed that only about 1/2 of the restaurant was occupied... which I thought wasn't too bad for the Tuesday evening.

The atmosphere for the evening was nice.  It was definintely a pleasant dining experience.  Our waiter was quite the professional.  He kept on top of everything and was eager to please and serve us.

Our group of 4 started off with some appetizers:
(1) Roasted beet salad, goat cheese, mache, pear, candied walnuts & balsamic vinaigrette 
(2) Spicy Monterey calamari "à la plancha", jalapenos, chorizo & olives
(3) Sautéed prawns in Pastis, sun dried tomatoes, shallots & chives
(4) Dungeness crab Napoleon, avocado, tomato confit, lemon zest & crème fraiche 

Everything was quite yummy.  Although the spicy calamari lacked spicyness... or at least I thought so.  Other than that, each dish was very unique and tasty.

For our entrees, we ordered: 
(1) Traditional duck confit, lentils "Du Puy",garlic,bacon & red wine sauce 
(2)  Seafood basquaise, salmon, cod, prawns, tuna, mussels, red pepper & tomato coulis
(3)  Creekstone Farm black angus ribeye steak, pommes frites, red wine butter sauce
(4) The special roasted chicken 

I thought the duck was so-so.  A little dry if you ask me.  The seafood dish was tasty, but there wasn't a huge wow factor.  The ribeye was seared to perfection and the red wine butter sauce that came with it was a wonderful compliment to the meat.  The roasted chicken (which was the special for the evening) was good as well, but not one of these 4 dishes truly stood out nor made me feel like the price I was paying was indeed worth it.

Lastly, we ended up ordering a few desserts to share:
(1) Warm sponge cake bread pudding with chocolate and bananas 
(2) Creamy custard with a caramelized sugar crust 
(3) Assortment of house made sorbets

I will have to say that the highlight of the evening was probably the dessert and the company I was with that made the meal an enjoyable one.... even though it was on the pricey side.

I was glad to have tried Fringale since I've driven by it numerous times but never had a chance to make it in tilll yesterday.   I think in comparison to other French restaurants in the city, Fringale would rank in mid-way somewhere if I had to rank it.  A nice place to try if you've never been, but there isn't much to rave about in terms of the food.... in my opinion at least.
author: Vindy C.

description: Good service.  Food was good, but not memorable or out of this world.
author: David M.

description: cute little place, you cant guess its going to burn hole in your pocket
author: Vrushali P.

description: Traditional duck confit, lentils "Du Puy", potatoes Landaises, garlic, bacon & red wine sauce. Miam.
author: Aileen C.

description:
OMG!!! Cute! Cute! Cute!!

This place was amazing!  The service was lovely and the food was wonderful!!

It's a very small, cozy, homelike, quaint atmosphere!  It's warm and friendly!  The staff was amazing and wonderful!  

The portions are reasonable and price to me are normal SF restaurant pricing!

I was so full, thank goodness I had to walk to BART cuz I could barely move!  

I will return again!!
author: Monique T.

description: My duck confit was a bit dry which is a huge mistake for a French restaurant. Overall the food was good, but nothing really impressive that would make want to come back.
author: Maria M.

description:
Very good food but not very convinced by the place.
The waiters don't live you alone. They will ask you if you are ok every 5 minutes when they will not being asking you to move your chair to rich an other table... 
I would suggest them to hire a French interior designer too. Because I can't enjoy French food in such a plain place.
author: Alexis M.

description:
Love....love...love..and adore this place!  This Basque-influenced bistro is a San Francisco favorite.  They're consistent and affordable (for the quality of freshness they serve).

My advice on lunch:
*Foie Gras terrine (my favorite) - they serve it with pineapple chutney and it's just delicious! (but then again, maybe I'm just biased.)
*Duck confit, if you like duck, will melt in your mouth.  Pair this with a nice bottle of JC Trocard Grand Cru and you're set! 
*You can't go wrong with their Steamed mussels and their Black Cod with piperade, if you like seafood.
*AND if you like dessert, you'll love ANY from their dessert menu...and I mean any ...even their Cheese Plate.

I would give this a 5 but I hate that this place is so small.  It's hard to get reservations on the fly...you would have to pretty much work around their schedule.  But overall, this place is one of the best in SF.
author: Reese M.

description: I really good restaurant at a decent price. It's a nice place in SOMA that isn't too expensive. The food and service were all very good. I would definitely go back here. I enjoyed everything, especially my rack of lamb. The foie gras was good but not as good as I've had at other places. Overall, nice experience and I;m happy to have them in the area.
author: Dalia M.

description:
Came here to celebrate my friend's birthday and partake on the dine around town menu.  

Appetizer: 
Calamari: no bad, great taste, great texture, and huge portion.
Foie Gras: Yums! Love how the pineapple chutney brings out the flavor!
Entree: 
Sole: SALTY, rice under cook, pea seems to be frozen, sauce had no taste.
Dessert: 
Creme Brulee: average, had much better.

Would have given it a 3 star, but the fact that I was in the bathroom 20 mins after I left did not sit very well with me.  I concluded that it might be the fish because i was the only one who order sole. 

My reviews are usually more detailed but I am still in pain. =(
author: Winny L.

description:
I find that the higher the price range of a restaurant on yelp, the higher their stars usually are.  Just a thought.

So I am definitely not an expert on food, but after living in France for half a year, this french food is just meh.  The napolean appetizer was yummy, but too rich for one person and best to share.  I got the duck confit and it was okayyyy....

I went with 6 other people and no one thought the food was anything spectacular. Also, it was one of the only places I could get reservations for by calling the day before...hm..I guess that really says something about a place. 

It's not terrible, but I would most likely not go here again. Can't wait to try Chapeau!
author: Skye W.

description:
My favorite upscale restaurant in SF to have lunch.

Food is EXTREMELY fresh, which also means that it can take longer until it is served but that is well worth it if you are not in a hurry.

Personal recommendation is "Seafood basquaise". It has salmon, halibut, prawns, tuna, mussels, red pepper & tomato coulis. Very delicious and very light.

Pricing for that kind of restaurant is also very reasonable. ~$20 is the most expensive dish.

If the place wasn't good, then it wouldn't be crowded all the time, so keep in mind to make a reservation. My friend and I never made any reservations :-) Yet I can't remember that we were ever turned away. I think that's noteworthy.

The manager is a character. I would say he is a little snooty but in a funny way. Just enough to feel like in France. He is French after all :-) We would always ask him what the soup of the day was just to hear him speak French. It was usually tomato soup but he would still describe it very passionately with his hands and fingers.

I can only recommend coming here.
author: Peter K.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised with Fringale.
First the restaurant itself was a very nice space. not too big not too small.

Our server, Sam was outstanding. We were there for our anniversary and he made sure our drinks were regularly filled and did not ignore us once. Top marks for his service.

The food was delicious. I started with the spicy calamari, then had the seafood basquaise. I found both dishes to be extremely tasty.

Food and service were both excellent!
author: Jenna L.

description:
Lovely little French place that my husband and I went to for dine about town.
Everything I ordered was spot-on delicious....

APPETIZER:
Prawns: I LOVED the sauce that they came in, which was a wonderful blend of sweet and spicy...it was served in a pastis sauce, which went really well with the butter and other spices.  The sauce was great for dipping my bread into.

MAIN COURSE:
-Filet Mignon:  perfectly cooked; per my request, it was medium-rare and and succulent, served with melt-in-your mouth potatoes au gratin (a very gourmet version) and a mixed green salad with a light vinaigrette.  My tastebuds were singing.

DESSERT:
-Hazelut and roasted almond mousse cake:  unique, hazelnut-y, and not too sweet; an experience that I didn't want to end, but it was a great way to end my meal.

I ordered the rose wine to go with my meal.  At first, I thought the wine was too sharp, but then it grew on me as I paired it with my meal.

The waiter was very attentive and friendly, and checked back with us to see how we were enjoying every course.

I will definitely come back here to try the a la carte menu.  What a great little treasure in SOMA!  It's the perfect place for a date night....
author: Nina B.

description:
i had a really good time here.
Was a bit hesitant at first when i saw some of the reviews but i thought i should give it a try for the last day of DAT.

The entrees weren't the best that were offered but sure beats most of the restaurants i had for DAT.

between 2 people, we had:

Appetizers:
-BLACK ANGUS BEEF CARPACCIO SERVED W/ CAPERS, ETORKI CHEESE & OLIVE OIL
-SPICY MONTEREY CALAMARI "A LA PLANCHA" W/ JALAPENOS & CHORIZOS

Both were very good. 
Carpaccio was light in flavor and broke apart nicely. yummy
I really dig the flavors on their calamari dish.  We even took our sourdough bread and scooped up the olive oil that was left.

Entrees:
-VEAL OSSO BUCCO SERVED W/ FARO, EGGPLANT & CHERRY TOMATOES
-PETRALE SOLE SERVED W/ YUKON GOLD PUREE & CHAMPAGNE BEURRE BLANC

Sauce for the veal osso bucco weren't bad but the meat was on the dry-side for me.  there were parts where it broke apart  easily and parts that weren't. We also would like it to be juicier.
I was content with my sole.  i liked the sauce a lot.  very light. i thought that there should've put some more of it on the fish instead of sparingly placed it on the plate around the mashed potatoes.  it would've been perfect if it was on the fish because the mashed potatoes soaked up all the sauce.  i'm all about sauce

Dessert:  (my favorite part..i always look forward to desserts)
-CREME BRULEE
-HAZELNUT & ROASTED ALMOND MOUSSE CAKE

Creme brulee tasted like Dan Tat's custard but of course the texture is of any other creme brulee's.  As a creme brulee, i wasnt a fan... but my oh my, if they had this in a tart crust like Dan Tat's it would've been perfect.
Lastly, the hazelnut cake, OMG... i love hazelnut so this might be bias on my part.  I LOVE IT.  it wasn't heavy and overwhelming with the sweets. it was perfect.  if i break it down to how the cake is done, it's not the best. it was on the dry side but altogether in my mouth... DIVINE.  i wanted so badly to order another one to-go so i can pig out in the car... but how badly i'd look in front of my date.  He did say go for it.... shouldve went for it.

Wine: again, i forgot to check what we ordered. We werent a fan of it and it was suggested by our server that would've went well with the veal.

Service:  i like how our server didnt kiss ass. He did what he had to as a server.
author: Joanne H.

description:
Superb ambiance
Superb food
Superb service

and reasonable price!

Will come again.

I had: Ravioli, Short Ribs
She had: Calamari, Rib Eye Steak

Both wonderful and well done.  The rib eye steak is juicy and flavorful while my short rib is tender and nicely served with rice and broccolini..
author: Gary T.

description:
After a long weekend of partying and no sleep, I had to pamper myself.

Fringale it is! What a cute little place! The crowd there was a little fancier than what I'm used to, but the ambiance and food were to die for!

I ordered the prucitto and asian pear salad with a glass of chardonney. YUM. Then I proceeded onto the Seared Lamb with roasted red and yellow bell peppers and au gratin potatoes. YUM again. Then topped it off with an espresso to keep me awake for the rest of the evening from the lack of sleep and fully belly. 

Cute place to go and spoil yourself cuz you deserve it every now and again. Very romantic too if you wanna impress your date *hint hint*. This is my favorite new French restaurant in the city!
author: Geneva X.

description:
Came here for dine about town and unfortunately we were not that impressed.  The endive salad was delicious but the ravioli appetizer was just so so, it lacked flavor.  The BF had the seafood entree which he said was good but not great.  I had the veggie pasta which came out in one clump and was raw in the middle.  When I told the waiter this he was perfectly polite and offered to re do it but then the manager came over and  asked if the pasta "was to al dente for me".  No it wasn't al dente it was raw, call a spade a spade and just apologize and get me something else.  Don't try to make it sound like its my fault.
Desert was good, the creme brulee was delicious, the parfait was ok.
author: Smigor r.

description:
3.5

My Dine About Town experience with this restaurant was mixed with pleasant surprises along with some disbelief.  

Let's start with the good news:  With such rave reviews, my friend and I were excited to try out all of the course options on the prix-fixed menu.  Nice, clean ambiance with glowing yellow and cream-colored interior.  Andre, our server, greeted us with a warm smile (who said the French weren't friendly?).  

The delicious: spicy calamari "a la plancha" and fresh beef carpaccio slices.  Great complementary dishes in flavor with wonderful chewy, soft, and buttery textures.  We also enjoyed the sole and yukon mashed potato entree - light and creamy taste.  Hazelnut mousse & burnt almond dessert was also enjoyable, though I like a lighter texture for my mousse.

The disappointment: the veal entree was a bit dry and reminded me more of a pot roast than a gourmet dish.  The creme brulee sugary top had the lingering taste of char and lighter fluid.  And the half bottle of Chinon red wine wasn't distilled properly and left behind a residue of deposits in our glasses.

To be fair, I imagine that many of the patrons were ordering mass amounts of the Dine About Town options.  These may not be their most expensive and shining dishes.  However, isn't the purpose of Dine About Town meant to bring their customers back?  With all of the accolades this restaurant received, I am disappointed that they didn't put more care and attention to all of their dishes - DAT or not.
author: Pauline L.

description:
I ate here during Dine About Town. This is what I had:

Assiette de charcuterie maison, saucisson sec, rillette, pate & frisee - good
Sautee petrale sole, squash, English peas risotto & sorell beurre blanc - great
Crème brulee - effin awesome

I have to admit something, I had no idea what any of the items were so I looked them up on my iPhone. After deciding what to eat based on my google searches I was met with a great array of foods that left me satiated and satisfied after my dinner. 

My friend had the chicken and the chocolate and we both agreed that I had the better dishes.
author: Kay A.

description: Great French food! I ordered the sea bass which was a very warm dish - fish on a tomato stew which was very flavorful and rich. I will eat here again to try additional dishes.
author: Raj P.

description: Cute little restaurant in SOMA. It was clean with good service, yummy food and good wine. The food was a french style. I had a light spring salad with mango, beans and peas along with the roasted chicken for dinner and a bottle of cab sav. All of the food was good. I would go back to this place for sure.
author: Shanna T.

description:
Elegant little restaurant that is nestled in Soma! 

After a random night of wandering aimlessly with friends, one recommended his "favorite" restaurant in the city and Fringale did not disappoint! 

We showed up around 9pm on a Friday night and somehow still managed to snag a cozy little table for 6. The restaurant is intimate but not overly crowded and would be perfect as a date night restaurant or a dinner with a few friends.

Everything on the menu looked unbelievable. Everyone was agonizing over what to eat because everything looked so good! I settled on the seafood basque which is sort of like a bouillabaisse. It wasn't a huge portion but it had the perfect mix of scallops, mussels, shrimp, fish and other seafood and was light, flavorful and very delicious! My friend got the mac n cheese which was very tasty. Basically a gourmet, grown-up version that is SOOO good! A couple people also ordered the lamb, duck and the rib-eye and nobody came away from dinner disappointed.

Service was fantastic. Our waiter was french, and very friendly! He made great recommendations and made sure we were all happy.

Dinner with cocktails came out to about $35/person. So not bad for an upscale, french restaurant.

So delicious. Perfect restaurant for french food that is incredibly flavorful without being too heavy.
author: Liz S.

description:
1 star for the tasty appetizers and another for huge portions. The service can tone down on the rudeness factor! My friend was buttering her bread when the server came with our dishes and literally took the knife out of her hands and set it down the table so he can make room for the new plates. That's just not right!

The best thing in our meal were the fries, and i'm a pretty qualified fry-judge! Anyways, my friends ordered the veal from the DAT menu; but why is the veal swimming (and drowning) in its own fat? yuckkk! I ordered the duck confit., which was highly recommended by the server. He convinced me that it was the best duck in the USofA, and i can only find something better if i went to France; but after a little bite, I think I would have found one twice as good in Chinatown! bleh! And don't even bother with the foie gras pate; it looked like canned meat (think spam fresh out of the can, or even liverwurst); when it first came to the table, it was frozen and we had to wait until it thawed. 

Never again!
author: natassia s.

description:
I would have given this place a 4 for the food but had to drop it to a 3.5 when I realized that the dishes tasted good because they were drowing in butter. Here's what we tried:
 
Apps:
Haricots Verts - Tasteless, drowning in butter - don't order 
Spinach with Roquefort - Delicious, drowning in butter - worth ordering
Potato gratin - Good, too much butter, but order if you're a fan of potato gratin
Shredded Brussel Sprouts w/ bacon - worth trying if you've never had but also lots of butter
 
Entree:
Rib Eye - The steak was decent. I did like the way it was spiced but, again, there was a dollop of butter melting on top of it. - Consider ordering but ask for the red wine butter on the side. 
 
Desserts:
Bread Pudding - Horrible. Don't order.
Flourless Chocolate cake - Decent but order only if you really love this dessert. If you're on the fence about it you may not think much of it. 
Creme Brulee - Wow. This one was unbelievable. After trying it I did place a subtle death grip on the bowl in hopes of not losing it to the rest of the group. Unfortunately they became suspicious so I had to slowly release it. 
 
Overall, I felt like they cheated on taste by substituting it with butter. That said..it was pretty good. The decor is decent. Cute but not memorable. The service was great. Our waiter looked like a brunette version of Johnny Lee Miller. I considered placing my subtle death grip on him as well but figured that may freak him out. Maybe next time.
author: Shreya C.

description:
It's not haute cuisine, but it's classy.
Order some wine and have the beouf bourguinon.
Don't talk about vaginas while you eat the shellfish; you'll be sure to get looks from other patrons.
Don't order the prawns. Too rich/fennel-y.
author: Y K.

description:
The first reason for going to SF was to visit MOMA.

The second was to participate in DAT.  (Okay... the two reasons had a constant battle for first.)

Is French food better when it's served with a French accent?  I think it is.

This place it truly great. It's LITTLE, and the bar can get in the way of traffic in and out.  We had reservations and arrived within 2 minutes of them.  (I'm German.)  We walked into an absolutely packed restaurant aside from ONE little table right next to the window.

THANK YOU!!!!  I guess it takes a European to know what a reservation means.  We were seated, provided the menu and asked if we would like a cocktail.  Since we were using cabs for the evening, the answer was a resounding HELL YEAH!!!

I asked for a martini slightly dirty...  I didn't get that.  I got it simply dry, but that was ok.  I'm not the kind to send back a cocktail unless it was really bad.  Amazing's Sidecar was prepared perfectly.

Rather than run down what I and Amazing had, I'll tell you it was all very well done.  This is classic French food done perfectly.  You won't find adventurous combinations of food or rare ingredients, but you will find the French dishes you may try at home.  Come here to experience what it should taste like.

I was surprised our server didn't know anything about wine.  Even though I'm usually the wealth of wine knowledge to my group of friends, I often will defer to the expertise of someone in the industry.  The best recommendation we got was 'something white' with the fish.

Sole in a white wine butter sauce?  There was a Viognier blend that went perfect.  There is a Saint Emilion Grand Cru Bordeaux half bottle that just must be had.  (And it paired very well with the Coq au Vin.  I would also have it with any steak.)

What ever you do.... order that half bottle.  

Apparently it's a fairly popular place to just get a drink too.  Some of the servers had to rearrange patrons at the bar so they could get through.  So again... if you are there to have a drink with friends.  Order that half-bottle.

This place is cute...quaint...and what you would expect out of a small restaurant doing it's best to give it's patrons a taste of France.  Kudos to them for accomplishing that in Spades.

No doubt I'll be back.  If I lived in SF, I might be a regular here.

Now I'm off to try making a Coq Au Vin.
author: Micah R.

description:
Dined at Fringale during SF's Restaurant Week back in January.
If you weren't looking for this restaurant, you'd absolutely miss it. It's small outside and in. But that added to the coziness of the restaurant. Right from the moment we stepped into the restaurant we were warmly greeted by our host who promptly took our coat. Fancyyyyy.

Because it was a special pre-fixe menu, our choices were slim. I had the:
- Black Angus beef carpacio served with capers, Etorki cheese & olive oil 
- Sole with Lemon Sauce
- Crème brûlée

The carpacio was okay, nice light way to begin the meal.
The Sole was amazing! But it wasn't the fish that was amazing but the SAUCE. I was tempted to lick the plate clean, it was THAT good. The Crème brûlée was one of the BEST I've ever had. Highly recommended.

Overall, the restaurant was a delight and provided a great fine dining experience. I would definitely consider coming back here, even when it isn't restaurant week to try the rest of their menu.
author: Danvin R.

description:
I'm not sure how well my little band of misfits fit in with Fringale's clientele on New Years Eve.  Leslie wore pastelle striped stockings with knee-high boots.  I had a corsette, fake eyelashes and giant poofy mermaid skirt.  Steve work huge black miss velvet cream pants and eyeliner.  Nope, the nice middle aged rich ladies in single strands of perls had little choice other than to give us funny looks.

The wait staff, bless their hearts, tried to act like we ordinary customers as we dined discussing recent playa trips rather than gout --or whatever it is old people talk about at dinner.

The food was good, but it wasn't amazing.  Nothing really knocked my socks off. 

The place was so crowded that I couldn't scoot my chair back without bumping into some disapproving guy my dads age in a "sport coat".  They packed people in there like sardines.  In fact, you had to climb your way through piles of people--and the kitchen--to get to the ladies room.

The meal was prix fixe at $75/ea plus wine.  Total for three came to $400.  Now I may be a rebel but I'm not against shelling out a few clams for a nice meal.  However, there are many more impressive places in this town, for instance Spruce or Farallon, where you can get exciting food and better service for less money.  

Also, if you're going to charge +$100/person, you should at least offer valet parking so your customers don't have to walk 3 blocks in the rain.

So sadly, Frigale, I give you a three.
author: Amy A.

description:
Great little restaurant for a pleasant meal.  It is small, so I would not recommend it for large groups.  It is perfect for an intimate dinner with 2-4 people.

If you can get there early go for the pre fix; it is an amazing deal.  I would also recommend the warm chocolate gourmand, chocolate heaven on a plate.
author: Mike M.

description: The food here was good, two thumbs up to the chefs in the kitchen. The creme brulee was really good and the salmon entree was delicious. The only thing that was lacking was great service. We had a couple of waiters bump our shoulders with our dishes numerous times, they forgot our utensils, and I even had a waiter try to make room in front of me by clashing my appetizer plate with my entree several times until I picked up the appetizer plate and handed it to him. The waiters we had were very rude and unprofessional, they are very lucky that there was a 20% gratuity automatically added, because I wouldn't of tipped them as much.
author: JP O.

description: Delicious warm bread basket. Very tasty potato cheese gratin with the lamb. The fresh seafood basquaise was good. Hazelnut mouse cake with almonds was very light and delicious.
author: Christian E.

description:
Ahh the French... while America's current vision of France may have been warped by media to support todays political climate (or turmoil if you want to be a dick about it), casting of the French as a bunch of cowards incapable of taking risks, I think as a whole people are smart enough to realize that when it comes to the things that actually matter (FOOD AND FUN) the French are far, far ahead of us. 

When my parents visited San Francisco, I wanted to take them someplace nice; I wanted them to sample the cuisine the Bay Area is world-famous for, and I wanted them to do it in a place my father can make the fart jokes he is so incapable of NOT making. So for the good of my family, and my fathers incessant need to not take things TOO seriously, I made reservations for Fringale.

I'm very glad I did.

Friends and family in tow, we made the long trek from Hayes Valley in an uneventful (but this is a good thing in a cab ride, because an eventful cab trip probably means you've struck and killed a pedestrian; funny in Hunter S. Thompson novels, fairly tragic in reality.) We arrived, and were seated by a what can only be described as a stylish (A FRENCHMAN WITH STYLE AND GRACE? WHY I NEVER!) waiter seated us quite promptly, which was only the beginning of the trend this man was setting for the night; service was always quick, efficient and attentive. 

Our glasses were always filled, our plates were quietly whisked away at just the right time, and most importantly for places like this, the waiter never lingered long enough to interrupt our conversation, or the chastising of my dad for making poop jokes.

------- QUICK ANECDOTE ABOUT MY FATHER: Love the guy to death, always supported me in my hopes and dreams, offered me advice and insight to situations that I thought unsolvable... He also loves a good poop joke. Can't fault the man for it. I prefer dead baby jokes; they tend to lend a bit more class to any situation.

But lets get back to what the French are so well known for: food. If you know me, you'll know that I'll go for the cheapest possible jokes no matter what the situation, so lets get the "surrender" jokes out of the way right now. We may as well surrender to the French right now: the French have already invaded us, and they've invaded us through our mouths. Which sounds dirty, but like anything done the French way, it tastes great.

I notice that a lot of people are talking about what dishes they and their dining partners had; I'm not going to do that, because the most important criteria were met for me to give this place five stars: when we left, we were more than satisfied. My Mom, my Dad and my friend were all completely happy with everything here; great food, great wine, great service.
author: Adam M.

description:
French is such a sexy language. I get weak in the knees whenever I'm called "Madamoiselle." ooh la la! (smooches to my hottie part French fiancee) 

So lovely madamoiselles Irene S. and Carol C. and I decided to kick off DAT 2007 with some French Basque cuisine at Fringale on Saturday night. The cute little spot was warm and inviting, and it seemed that everyone there was taking advantage of the $31.95 pre-fixe menu, which had several wonderful dishes to choose from. 

For starters, Irene and I both had the chicken terrine mousse, and Carol had the sauteed prawns in pastis. The mousse was like a light and fluffy pate served on a bed of greens with crostini to spread it on. The prawns were in a delicious sauce - much more flavorful, making the mousse taste a bit bland in comparison.  

For our main entree, Irene and I again got the same dish - lamb osso bucco (shank), and Carol got the black angus rib eye steak with fries. The lamb shank was so extremely tender and didn't have that strong gamey flavor to overpower it. It was perfectly prepared. The rib eye steak was very tasty as well, but the fries were a little dry, like In-n-out fries, which aren't my favorite. 

We decided to order different desserts so we could all share. I got the warm chocolate cake, Carol got the hazelnut mousse cake, and Irene got the creme brulee. The creme brulee was my favorite (it was reminiscent of the custard in Beard Papas creme puffs), and even though the first order we received was a bit runny, it still tasted delicious. Our attentive server noticed that it wasn't at the right consistency and immediately brought us a new one, even though we had already scarfed half of it down. 

I'll definitely be back again to try their regular menu with mon amie.
author: Connie C.

description:
Pretend I had a really witty parody of the French Chef's "Les Poisonns" song here. I'm not creative enough for that nonsense. Except, of course,

Sacre Bleu! Fringale est merveilleux!

My mom and I went here as part of a French-themed evening that culminated in watching the absolutely astonishing Kooza. I loved the casual elegance of the restaurant - I was particularly impressed with the heating fans they brought in to warm up the drafty room before the rest of the diners filled in. The French waiters were so cute and friendly - we kept ordering our server over just to hear him speak!

The wine list is simple yet impressive, and offers a lot of options for those dining on a budget.

We ordered the salmon tartare, it was fresh and fantastic. We also enjoy a couple basketsof bread, which was disappointing only in that it was not heated.

I had the duck confit with lardons and lentils. My mom had the roast chicken with garlic mashed potatoes. Both meals, while fairly basic, were quite impressive. 

For dessert, we shared a cheese plate with grapes and walnuts. It was rather good (with the exception of one kind of stanky goat cheese), and paired well with my muscat and my mom's cappuchino. 

I loved my experience here. For now, it's my favorite restaurant in the city. And because I don't want to be too cliched, es muy bueno!
author: Devon S.

description:
My BFF treated me to Fringale for my b-day many moons ago and I'd been meaning to go back. But part of me feared that because I had such a great time, I'd only be disappointed the second time around.

I decided to take that chance and made a reservation for their Dine About Town promotion.  Our party of 4 arrived early for our 7:45 reservation. While waiting for the other group to pay the bill and clear out, we ordered drinks at the bar and perused the menu. While the restaurant provided lots of different options for Dine About Town (3 appetizers - prawns, salad, or chicken pate; 3 entrees - lamb osso bucco, steamed sole, or pork crepinette, and 3 desserts - pear tarte, chocolate gourmand, or a mousse cake) their regular menu also sounded very tempting.

At the end 2 of us took advantage of their DAT promotion while the other 2 ordered off the regular menu. The prawns were delicious, in a sundried tomato sauce which vaguely tasted Thai. The lamb was tender, tasty, and not at all gamey. And the chocolate gourmand (flourless chocolate cake) was YUM with a scoop of ice cream. I also got to try the spicy calamari with jalapenos and chorizo as well as the duck confit and the seafood stew.  All excellent.

Service was impeccable. As soon as we were seated, we were promptly poured water and provided a basket of bread. My friend relied on our waiter's recommendations and she was not disappointed with her duck confit and her bread pudding. Oh, and it sure didn't hurt that the bartender and our waiter both sported exquisite French accents. Ooh la la.

Now that Fringale proved that my first time here was not a fluke and this is indeed a fabulous restaurant, I will not wait so long to come back.
author: .elin f.

description:
people that know me know I go to a place for the food first, service second, ambience third.  Fringale was good on all fronts.  I have not a single complaint about my experience here.

We thought about doing the Pelligrino dine out special 3 course for $35, but the non-special dishes were simply too tempting, given the small price difference.  We ordered the frisee salad (with bacon dressing and a poached egg), and the prawn ravioli in a lobster bisque to start.  The frisee salad was tasty, but the prawn ravioli was to die for.  The lobster bisque was much better than most I've had, with some slightly latin inspired spicing I think, and more of the lobster "yellow" (from the head) that the chinese love so much.  amazing way to start the meal.  

 For entrees, we got the ribeye and the lamb chops.  Man, they were both excellent.  Ribeye was perfectly prepared (a perfect medium rare), and so were the lamb chops.  THe lamb chops came with these potatoes au gratin baked in a cylindrical shape with this nice crispy crust on top.  The balance of flavors and the presentation were all impeccable.

To go with the meal, we got a bottle of the reserve de la comtesse Pauillac bordeaux (I think it was a 2003...but I can't remember for sure), which was a well crafted red with a long finish, though not with the boldness I was hoping for with a full-on cabernet sauvignon.  I figured this was a french/basque restaurant so I'd go for a bordeaux.  It went well with just about everything, but was overpowered by the lamb and ribeye.  Still a beautiful wine though.

The desserts...wow.  The chocolate bread pudding with bananas and vanilla ice cream.... [shudder].... not as sweet as I expected (which is good) with more chocolatey goodness, and a unique texture more like a moist cake than a bread pudding.  I had the apple tart with vanilla ice cream (homemade) special, but it wasn't your typical apple pie a la mode.  It came with caramel on top and a strawberry compote (I believe) strewn over it in a gorgeous arrangement, with a couple strawberry halves too.  The balance of textures and flavors sent tingles down my spine that I did not expect form a simple apple tart with vanilla ice cream.

All that, and our waitress, who was from paris, served us perfectly, even apologizing for spilling a small drop of wine on the table when she poured for me.  My water was always filled quickly, and whenever I felt the urge to pick up the bottle of wine and refill our glasses, she was already there picking up the bottle.  Simply perfect.

The place was not too big, but not too small, with warm lighting.  cozy, with some decent soundproofing, so everything around was a dull murmur, and we chatted easily without raising our voices.

The other items on the menu looked interesting, with a boquerones dish, and some latin-inspired dishes as well--clearly the basque influence.  I was in more the french mood, so I did that this time, but when I come back, I might just do more of the spanish options.

Great restaurant, decently priced.  I'm definitely a fan!  Thanks Hao!  your review inspired me to come.
author: Fong L.

description: This is a charming restaurant right in the heart of Soma. The food was excellent and the service was great. We arrived shortly before our reservation at 6 PM and were promptly seated by the window. We decided to start with some prawns and pastis and it was delicious. I had the Halibut, which was very moist and very flavorful. The Halibut was accompanied with some piperade which was very pleasing. For dessert I had the chocolate bread pudding and it was absolutely phenomenal. Overall this was a great experience and a wonderful first night in San Francisco I will definitely be back, possibly before I go back home!
author: Jeff C.

description:
Came here for a Dine About Town experience, and was very disappointed with the rudeness as well. My boyfriend and I showed up on time for a reservation on a Wednesday evening. We noticed immediately we were about 15 years younger than anyone else dining there, and we didn't happen to be decked out business-casual. This earned us the table furthest from the other guests, and closest to the kitchen entrance. It was one of those moments where you knew that they were just embarrassed to have you in the restaurant and they put you in the least visible place possible.
The food was fine, hence the two stars. We had the Veal osso bucco and I had the Lamb shanks. They forgot our wine order, and once they brought our glasses, we were never asked whether we would like another. Surely, had we been drunker we might not have remembered their blatant disregard for us.
author: Michelle L.

description:
This is generally one of my favorite DAT destinations. 
It never disappoints. 
I invited my CEO to lunch here. First of all he is the best boss I could ever ask for and secondly he has fantastic taste. 
He had the Dungeness crab with greens and the risotto. 
I had the DAT menu. Beet and goat cheese salad, sole with champagne buerre blanc sauce on Yukon gold potato's and the dessert was a pear tart tatin. 
Everything was super flavorful and cooked to perfection. 
The service was friendly and attentive. 
This place was a full house on a Wednesday afternoon. I recommend reservations on opentable.com
author: Jennifer S.

description:
First Time Fringale Dining Experience:

 First time was a work holiday party in December 2005.   Can't remember much about that night except us virgin-drinkers ended up paying for our co-workers'  alc drinks. Now, that was a lot of wasted $$$ and pretty much ruined the whole dining experience.


Second-Time Fringale Dining Experience;

Then I went back with boyfriend about a year ago.   

What I remember:

1.  Date was on  August 2, 2007 @ 5:30 PM (Unearthed this date from my Opentable profile)

2.  Occassion:  Boyfriend was in the City for work. Surprised me with impromptu weekday dinner.

3.  Ambiance and Social Scene:  Elegant.  White table linens.  Well-dressed. Serious. Mature.

3.  Drink and Taste:  I was still full from lunch and could not bring myself to eat dinner yet.  I told the server that I just wanted dessert and wine while boyfriend gets a main course. BF ordered an expensive steak dinner with appetizer.

4. Service:  Snooty.  Not rude but not friendly.  Granted that I only ordered a chocolate souffle dessert and wine, we made sure that we ordered enough, i.e., our tab was still pretty hefty.  We did not stay long either, so we did not take up a lot of time and space.

Overall:

The food at Fringale is good but not memorable.  Given that the City is inundated with fine cuisine and very diverse dining options,  Fringale's snobby service took away from the warm fuzzy feeling that good food and wine bring--good side effects of having an enjoyable meal.

BTW, my experience is not unique at Fringale.  One of my girlfriends also experienced the same snooty attitude at this restaurant while dining with her hubby.

Fringale is a respected San Francisco dining mainstay but I will not go back.  Service is as important to me as the food.
author: Leah E.

description:
cozy french bistro...warm and bright with a friendly atmosphere...affordable array of appetizers, entrees and desserts to entertain your palate....with a variety of beers, spirits and wines to compliment......

shrimp ravioli appetizer..rich and buttery lobster bisque...a creamy delite.........foie  gras with browned sliced toast....mixed reviews from the table...some prefer seared foie gras...while i enjoyed the pure block form....a treat nonetheless........skirt steak (ordered rare)...perfectly seared....flavors of the flesh locked in....a juicy and tender choice....

wine wine wine....ever flowing wine and beer...friendly staff...always quick and attentive to our needs...first impressions to a first time patron are always so important....

meals will range under $20 for an entree....$30 with an appetizer....$40++ with drink(s)........(with ever flowing wine and beer...my dinner came out to $70 per person)
author: Hen A.

description:
The other night, my dining partner, Kevin L. thought it would be  a good idea for us to walk to Fringale.  Half a mile of walking in heels in the pouring rain = BAD IDEA and bad hair for Katherine.  After some convincing speech on my part (me telling him 'it was over' about 9 times, 'it' being our relationship) we decided that it would be best if we took a cab.

Although our reservation wasn't until 7:15, when we arrived early, around 6:50, they were able to seat us right away.  We were promptly asked given some french bread and butter and asked for drink orders.  

I did the Dine About Town menu, but my picky partner decided he wanted to order off the regular menu.  

I had the... 
-Oyster appetizer: HUGE bowl of steamed oysters in a white wine butter sauce, along with garlic toast...AMAZing.

-Hanger steak & pommes frites entree: Plethora of pomme frites, a little lacking in the hanger steak area, but delicious all the same, moist and juicy with a yummy red wine sauce.

-Chocolate Gourmand: Freaking delicious, warm melts-in-your-mouth chocolate cake topped with vanilla ice cream and berries, the happy ending to my meal.

He had...
-Calamari appetizer: Sauteed not fried, which at first turned me off, but there was pepperoni in this baby!  You need to get this, GIANT portion of calamari with pepperoni, red peppers (not too many) and spices.

-Crispy Skin chicken over mashed potatoes: I wasn't too impressed with this chicken, it was good, but not great, the mashed potatoes however were so yummy...smooth and buttery with a hint of garlic.

-Chocolate and Banana dessert: Warm moist chocolate cake with banana pieces topped with vanilla ice cream...delicious, but I preferred the Chocolate Gourmand.

Another great french restaurant that you should definitely check out.  The only downfall of the night was that I was forced to walk from the restaurant back to BART...it was still raining...
author: Katherine C.

description:
3.5

It was definitely a toss up between Le Charm vs. Fringale, but after driving around aimlessly, we decided to go to the one whichever had easier parking. 

Fringale's great. Quite a tiny, and I mean TINY bistro in the heart of SOMA serving basque-inspired French food. YUM! Their food was extremely tasty and yet, their service could've been a tad bit better. 

We started off with a Dungeness crab appetizer $13 (peek foto) which was perfected in everyway possible. The tomato, avocado and the crab, w/ a splash of sour cream vinaigrette was perfect - the complimentary bread they give you is not only toasted with perfection, but it actually goes well the crabby appetizer, and honestyl can be considered as a meal of its own.  (sry oinky! Everytime I think of eating crab, I think about how crabby it must be.. jk)...  their stuffed quail $16 (quite a solid quail that was stuffed w/rice, bacon, brussel sprouts w/pomegranate sauce) was *super* yummy... oh, and their chicken ($17) was also quite tasty -- tossed in w/spinach and garlic sauce. Mmm.. but yeah, I would *totally* recommend the stuffed quail. Even though it's a bit small in size, it was definitely one worthy dish.

I say overall, the pricing was very reasonable and appropriate for a French restaurant. I shall be back in due time...
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Being French does not give you a right to be snooty--except when you are a server from Fringale. Twice I've been here. Two different waiters. One kind of attitude. 

The first time I got the halibut. The second time I got the seafood basquaise. Neither struck me as anything special or worth enduring a night of condescending service for. At least they don't try to make their menu seem like more than what it actually is by using vague descriptions or non-sense words--that would just be them fooling themselves.

I have real issues with servers who expect everyone to order a 4-course meal along with their entire cellar of wine in one setting. My only comment for Fringale is that if you actually served food worthy of 4 courses, maybe it wouldn't be such a big issue for all your servers. My goodness, leaving that tip at the end of the meal was like signing my name away in blood.  

With all the good French restaurants in the city (Chapeau, Clementine, etc), there is no reason to come here for average food and rude service.
author: Rona J.

description:
I was in the mood for some fancy comfort food so the other half took me here. 

For starters I had the frisee salad with warm bacon dressing with a poached egg. The warm bacon dressing was delicious with the greens. For my entree I had the seafood basquaise and it was exactly what the doctor ordered for this gloomy day. The spicy tomato sauce was the perfect backdrop for the fresh seafood. The other half had the angus rib eye and  pommes frites. The steak was broiled to a prefect medium rare. Of course I didn't want him to finish the pomme frites all by himself so I helped him. Those frites were crisp and tasted fresh. For dessert we had the freshly made truffles and cookies that were to die for! All the food was beautifully presented to us as pieces of French artwork.

Impressive wine list and of course there's a bar that features bottles of liquor lined against a mirrored wall. Decor is minimal with warm brown tones, white tables cloth and dim lighting for a romantic feel. The waiters were friendly and attentive. Get there early as parking can be a pain.
author: Lola L.

description:
What!?  How can my review for Fringale not be here?  Oh well.

Let me put this short and sweet.  When I need place with excellent food and great people my fall back list always has Fringale near the top.  Hell!  My fall forward list has Fringle near the top too!

Some may complain of the close quarters but if you can get over the sometimes tight fit due to the amount of people in the place you will fine a nice little French bistro that will never fail you to amuse your palate at an affordable price.  Sorry about some others peoples experience but my service and food has always been perfect for every visit.  I'll come back again and again for sure!
author: Chris R.

description: Came here on Saturday for dinner. Staff were nice the food was great. I had the sea bass but my friend had the lamb which was cooked to perfection. I wish I ordered the lamb instead
author: Tobi A.

description:
I enjoyed the food at this very intimate little restaurant, it was clean, delicious and thoughtfully prepared. The service was above average, and that is noteworthy these days in any restaurant. 

It's a great place for dinner for two, in a mellow neighborhood where you can usually find parking. Simple, reliable and satisfying.
author: Schuyler W.

description:
Ok, a few reviews back I may have mentioned that I wasnt really down with french food, and that I didnt even really know what good french food was, well that all changed today!

My super assistant and I were one of the few people that ventured out of the office for lunch on this cold rainy day, I think we both had a little office cabin fever and needed to comfort ourselves with cocktails and fabulous food.  This place totally hit the spot!

The place is small and and quite, but I would love to come back on a warm summers day cause I noticed that the big windows we sat next to fully open up. The menu was chock full of amazing choices.  I settled on the crispy chicked with yukon gold mashed potatoes and spinach....sweet god in heaven!

It was so good I had to eat it slow, which never happens.  We had a copuple cocktails and they were STRONG, just what I needed. I ended the meal with a warm flourless chocolate cake with banana....perfection.

I learned what good french food was today!  Thanks Michael!
author: Alicia K.

description:
Minus half a star for a dirty wine glass that was not even close to drinkable.

Other than that? Absolutely amazing.  We came here on the recommendation of a friend, and for Dine About Town, which needless to say is one of my favorite events.  Everything was delicious and well made.  Nothing was too heavy, or got sickening after a while.  It was all rather perfect.  Would come back here in a a heartbeat.

The meal:
     Calamari - Amazing! Light and very flavorful.  Highly recommend if your trying to decide between the three choices.
     Spinach Ravioli - Was worried this would be too heavy for an appetizer but ended up being just perfect.  Its served with pine nuts and a cream sauce, and the cream sauce was just added flavor, no heaviness.
     Duck Confit - The bf really liked this dish.  He thought the lentils went perfectly with it.  It might've been the piece I ate, but I found it a little dry.  I'll have to get him to post a review to get a more accurate assessment. 
     Lamb Shank - OMG.  Delicious. The meat just melted off the bone.  It was served with polenta, spinach and king's mushroom, and all just went perfectly with each other.
     Warm Chocolate Gourmand - Om. Nom. Nom.  That's all I can say.
     Hazelnut & Almond Mousse - The chocolate gourmand won my heart.  This dessert was a bit sweeter than I'd liked, and I found myself eyeing bf's dessert instead.  But I tend to like dark chocolate over other sweets.  If you like mousses, however, I believe you'll really enjoy this dish.

The service was great, and surprisingly, finding parking took  no time at all!  The ambience is quaint, not super duper fancy, but intimate enough that it still makes a great date night.

I really can't wait to come back.
author: Pamada K.

description:
There's nothing more disappointing than when French restaurants live up to the snobby French stereotype.

Ate here for lunch because it's close to my office and my lunch companion had heard good things. While the food (halibut over peas) was delicious, the service was utterly lacking. So much so that we felt it necessary to reflect it in the tip. However, I am big believer that if you're not going to tip well, an explanation is necessary, so we quietly called the manager aside as we were leaving.

"How can I help you?" he said in his french accent that suddenly seemed far more snooty and condescending than charming.

"I just wanted to let you know that we were unhappy with the service, and that was reflected in the tip," my dining companion said.

"Oh, zell, I am sorry," he said, although his actually meaning, "I could care less what you think" was loud and clear.

We turned to walk away, but his utter lack of regard for our dining experience was just too much for me to handle. "Clearly you don't care," I said to him.

"WHY DO YOU SAY THAT? Why do you say I don't care?!" His voice got louder, and yes, people were starting to look at us.

"Because if you cared, you would have asked us WHY we had a bad experience!"

"I am going to ask THEM," he said, nodding towards the waitstaff.

"But you have to ask US since we're the people who had the bad experience," I tried to reason.

"Fine," he scoffed. "What was so wrong?"

"Well," I started, "We thought all our servers were completely unfriendly. But CLEARLY that's just how this place is."

And, with that, I walked out. After all, you can't explain the importance of charm to someone who has none.

Sure, our $19 entrees were good, but at that price, I'd much rather eat at a restaurant where smiles are not discouraged.
author: daisy b.

description:
I love this place! I've been coming here for 10 years now and although the restaurant has gone through many changes (as with any business), I know I can come here for consistently tasty, bistro comfort food. Jean-Marie and Andre are awesome! We came in a group of six on our last visit, half of which were late. Even though the restaurant was packed, they didn't give us a hard time or rush us through our dinner! 

We ordered the prawns in pastis (a classic!) and crab napolean for our appetizers. The frisee salad is also highly recommended and the majority of the table ordered the rib eye steak with pommes frites for their main course. I ordered the salmon and planned on eating only half (watching my waistline), but it was so nice and crispy on the outside, and moist and tender on the inside, I practically licked my plate clean! Feeling guilty, I looked up and noticed everyone else's plate was clean as well! Whew! The hubby and I had to fight over the last of the french fries.

For dessert, we ordered the hazelnut mousse cake and they gave it to us on the house along with a lime dessert.

Great food, great service, strong drinks, an intimate and cozy atmosphere...what more can you ask for?
author: Bernadette A.

description:
It had been since 2000 (pre-kids) since me and the Mrs. had been to Fringale, so when we went out for date-night the other night as a warm up for Valentine's Day, Fringale seemed like just the right choice.

It was packed (as usual) on a Tuesday night and we were glad to have a reservation.  It is small and intimate but not loud.

OK, this is going to sound really dumb, but how do the French reliably make the best frites in the world?  (Told you).  My better half ordered the rib-eye and frites, which is just what she ordered the last time we were here (7 years ago) and it was as good as she remembered.  For those not in the know, it comes with this incredible butter concoction that melts on the meat.  Seriously good.

I got a basquese or something like that which amounted to a bouillabaisse-style dish with chunks of fish and some mussels.  I was glad she had some fries that I was able to dunk into the amazing broth which was delicate, bold and savory all at once.

We shared an appetizer, had two entrees, 1 glass of wine, 1 cocktail, split a dessert and two coffees for $65 including tip.
author: Brad P.

description:
BF & I looked for a unique spot for a rare 'date night' in the city.  Originally booked Pesce, but decided against it when realized the Union Street Fair was happening in close proximity.  Friends recommended Fringale.  Boy, I'm I glad they did!

Should be noted my bf is French, and so are his friends, so their opinion of French restaurants carry a lot of weight.  I don't think I've ever had a more perfect meal.  

It was DAT time (which I have never participated in before) and it proved to be a happy coincindence.  All the items I wanted to try were on that pre-selected menu...and all were divine!  Spinich & pine nut ravioli that quite literally melted in my mouth.  Duck Confit on lentils that was so scrumptious, I almost licked my plate!  Almond & hazlenut cake that was so light & delicate, the perfect ending to the perfect meal.

My bf had the filet mignon, the scallop appetizer and the chocolate gourmannd dessert.  Equally divine.  We were happily tasting each others' selections and having a hard time deciding who had the best meal.

Service was excellent.  Attentive.  Perfectly timed.  Unobtrusive.  The restaurant itself is very small & a little cramped, that's the only negative I can find.  It was a rather warm night in the city, so ceiling fans or opening the windows would've made the whole atmosphere much improved.

This is not a sexy looking venue...no 'views' or ambiance to speak of, but lots of parking, a short hop to the Embarcadero, where we completed our evening with a walk along the bay.

Give Fringale a try.  You won't be disappointed in the exquisite food.
author: laura c.

description: This place is just perfect if you like real French Bistro experiences and you want to make your date feel beautiful.
author: Clarke H.

description:
Came here with Ms. Linh L. and another one of our friends for the Dine About Town menu. Both Linh and I ordered the charcuterie/pate plate as appetizer, while friend Randy ordered the lobster ravioli. Charcuterie plate hit the spot - nice slab of pate, a few pieces of salami and prosciutto, 2 baby pickles and a few slabs of bread. The lobster ravioli looked quite hearty, perhaps 4-5 big sized raviolis in delicious thick sauce.

Entree, we all ordered filet mignon, medium rare. This shit was good. It was served with some mixed greens and the most delicious fries ever. Perfectly crispy and salty. Everything was devoured. For dessert, I got the chocolate gourmand. Thick dense chocolate cake with some ice cream on top. Good...not awesome, but good. I left the restaurant feeling completely satisfied. 

Service was great, atmosphere was friendly and unpretentious. Seemed like all the servers had french accents (very cool). The place was packed like sardines though. When I took off my coat, I swear I elbowed someone in the head. Sorry!
author: Carol L.

description:
The "Dungeness crab Napoleon, avocado, tomato confit, crème fraiche" appetizer is delicious. Although it costs almost as much as my entree, it is very good and I would definitely get it again.

The  "Bacon wrapped Pork tenderloin, braised savoy cabbage, caramelized onion sauce" was also pretty good.  The service is great and I try to swing by whenever I am by the Hall of Justice for work.
author: Bert N.

description:
Woww.... all i can say is, I cannot believe how consistent this place has been over all the years!  I haven't been back in at least 6 yrs, and the steamed mussels are still amazing, as is the duck confit.  Normally I don't like lentils, but they were made with such smokey flavor that they were a perfect compliment to the crisp duck leg served on top.  Amazing almond basque cake with custard inside... definitely overate on this trip and did NOT leave fringale in the least.

The crowd is definitely mellow and an older set, since the restaurant has been around for so long and not a hipster scene.  However, the quality of the ingredients and the execution are just really worth the visit!  Prices are also not exorbitant for what you get!
author: lulu p.

description:
JF, TW and I had our annual DAT get together this year at Fringale. Unfortunately, I was sick for our date, so my review of the food is a bit second hand.

We all ordered off the DAT prix fixe menu-- JF ordered calamari and the veal osso bucco. TW had the beef carpaccio and the veal. I had the beef carpaccio and the sole. The spices the calamari was cooked with definitely had some Asian flair, which was unexpected. The portion was also quite generous. I couldn't really taste the beef carpaccio, but I thought the cheese that came with it was pretty delicious (one of the only flavors strong enough to penetrate through my sickness induced taste-blindness). 

For the main course... I had a taste of JF's osso bucco... verdict: my sole was much more delicious. I couldn't even taste much and I still thought that was the case. In terms of texture, the sole was a little overcooked, and the sauce surrounding it was too buttery. But the fillet was well seasoned, and the greens in the dish were really good.

The three of use ordered one of each dessert that was available. JF and TW both thought the creme brulee was one of the better ones they had tasted. I of course couldn't taste anything. It did however have a nice creamy consistency. According to JF the hazelnut mousse cake was too sweet, and the apple tart very plain.

Overall I thought that based on the prix fixe menu, Fringale lacked creativity. The execution of each dish was fine, but nothing to make me sit on the edge of my seat anticipating the next course. I also didn't leave with giddy and rambling on about how delicious the food was... I should probably return at least once to sample the food when I can actually appreciate subtle flavors.
author: Susanna W.

description:
