Mmm... the Portabello mushroom & polenta napoleon was just a wonderfully delicious lunch! A little pricey for lunch at $14, but yummy! Along with the French bread and butter, it was a perfect sized meal. 

The coffee is STRONG. Whoa. I could only drink about five sips of it, and that was with two sugar cubes and as much cream as the cup would hold. (It forced things through, if you know what I mean. Within minutes.) 

The creme brulee was a bit large for a dessert, but very creamy and with a lot of nice crunchy carmelized sugar on top! C'est Magnifique! 

Our waitress was very sweet, and had a French accent. The entire staff was attentive and friendly. The atmosphere busy, but full of competence and good manners.

I'd definitely return! I'd love to try them for dinner... could be tres dangereux, I think you'd have to ROLL me out of here. So bring the guerney and let's go!
author: Shari D.

description: This is my favorite French restaurant in the City. I eat here several times a year and each time the food is consistently very good. The service is always stellar. As a couple people have stated the manager can kinda be a jurk, but I feel it just adds to the "french feel" of the place. The location is nice just up the street from Caltrain and a block away from K&L wines (were I usually pick up a bottle of wine before heading to dinner). For price vs quality this is the best place in town for French food.
author: Aaron S.

description:
My wife and I have had Fringale on our list of places to try for a while, so we were happy to walk by this evening and find that they had a table available.  We started with the spicy calamari appetizer, which was good though I probably would try something else the next time.  For dinner I had the pork loin and my wife had the short ribs, both of which were really excellent.  We didn't have room for dessert, but the list certainly looked good.

Great service, a very pleasant atmosphere and really good food.  We'll definitely go back again.
author: Richard M.

description:
Fringale was an all-around pretty good meal.
I had dinner here on Friday night and thought about it until now, unable to decide 3 or 4 stars...
No matter which way I turned it, it hovered between 3.25-3.75 w/ only one dish exceeding 4 stars.  That alone cannot really take the entire rating over 4 stars, can it?

I've uploaded the photos of the food.

It's a very small place that is designed in such a way that when you walk in, the whole restaurant is actually looking at you.  They have a small bar to your left, with seating, and the full menu is available there.  It would almost be better to sit there in order to have it be somewhat private, I think, as the remainder of the tables are really packed in together.  I know that the woman to my left hates Bush - and I know that the guy diagonally to my right had been dating that girl for two months and feels that things are going well.  He told her so... and I overheard.  They, in turn, probably know my whole life story too, though - so life is fair.

Now, for good food, I don't much care how you treat me like a sardine - - but this is where Fringale lacks.

Before I get into the food, though - - service was mediocre.
When I enter a restaurant, and have reservations - - it'd be nice to have someone up front  asking if I have a reservation or saying hello.  Nobody was there, and if there was an official maitre'd - - I never saw him because he was either serving or acting as a server and host?  In San Francisco, w/ such a wide array of "California French" or even French cuisine-type places available, there's no excuse for shoddy service, or lack of attention.  I definitely am not one that likes to be doted on through the meal, but how a person is treated upon walking into an establishment is crucial in the service world.  Ask me if I have a reservation, and if you're not ready to seat me just yet-  show me where I should be until you are.... offer a drink or tell me something.
When someone finally did approach - - I can't say they were rude.  Everyone was nice enough - but nowhere near the caliber of a 5-star, or even 4-star establishment.  
I will add that our own waiter was very pleasant and sweet, but he alone cannot carry the whole restaurant.  (The food can.)

Unimpressed.

Now, the food.
We ordered a bottle of an '03 Cabernet, a Stonehedge Reserve Cabernet.  Very nice wine, I've had it before and I enjoyed it just as much this time.  We had some bread served to us w/ butter - - and it was good.

Appetizers included their calamari and their shrimp ravioli.
- The shrimp ravioli was strange.  The filling was a bit too shrimpy (fishy?) and SWEET.  Not a good combination.  The sauce that accompanied it was not a good match either, though it was a tasty sauce on its own, but it was just an all around odd combination.
- The grilled octopus, however, was QUITE good.  It's a pretty spicy dish, and has a definite Asian flair to it.  Good, yes... but I'd expect it at Schezuan ________ or Korea Palace, not at Fringale.  Still, it was very good w/ fresh octopus and perfectly cooked.  It was actually, for you Koreans, typical "Ojinguh-bokkeum".

For entrees - we ordered the Pork Tenderloin w/ Cabbage and Apples, and the Ribeye Steak.
- A+ for giving us medium-rare steak when we asked for medium-rare.  Was it good?  Yes.  Excellent?  No.  There was nothing special about it, but I love ribeye steak so it worked out just fine, but nothing about this dish was stellar except that it was seasoned well and cooked as requested - but the cut of meat was actually too thin - and too fatty.  That said --  the pomme frites that accompanied it were AMAZING.  I loved these fries... whoo boy.  Fried just perfectly.  This was the most expensive dish offered on the menu, though the price evades me now.
- The Pork Tenderloin was 5-star material.  Juicy, cooked perfectly, seasoned perfectly - and the accompaniments were great too.  Apples were perfect, and even the cabbage, which I don't usually like, supported the pork just perfectly.  Sweet, meaty goodness on a plate.  EXCELLENT.

We skipped dessert and didn't order coffee.  Aside from the pork dish - - there was nothing there to be salvaged after that meal. 

For me, 3-stars signifies, "I'd eat there again, but not at my own suggestion" - and that is about what Fringale is.  Having seen other entrees being served, I'm curious to try the duck and the lamb one day, but don't have my hopes up for it.

While the pricing is very reasonable for a French restaurant - - this is good only if the food is still stellar w/ lower prices.  If you're going to give me mediocre food for better prices - then I'd opt for higher priced spectacular food any day of the week.
author: Grace K.

description:
The best duck confit ever-
crispy skin w/ succulent meat. mmmm.
great service- a nice space.
Dining companions had the steak and the lamb and raved about them.
we saw sort of an older crowd- so if you want a place that is focused on non-food things, like "being seen and dressed" -don't go here.

go here when you want to eat well and pretend you are in France.
author: Scrantz L.

description: Fringale never disappoints. Staff is right on point with great wine recommendations that don't break the bank. Still dreaming about the Braised Shortribs.
author: Sharon C.

description:
A San Francisco classic, and one of my favorite French restaurants in the city. Some of my favorite dishes include the roast rack of lamb and the pork tenderloin, but their seafood dishes change on occasion, and these are excellent as well. Above all else, make sure to order a side or two of their wonderful pommes frites.

A well-selected, and surprisingly reasonable wine list make for a perfect evening, whether that be on a date or with a few good friends.
author: Nish N.

description:
Rating: 4.5 stars

Came here the other day with Cynthia C (fellow Yelp Elite) to check out the DAT 2007. Ah, if it wasn't for her, I wouldn't be as motivated to drive my ass to SF to deal with the 1 hour drive, 30 minute parking fiasco, and pouring rain. 

Ah, but we did even though earlier we were secretly thinking of calling it off. It was a weeknight and we were tired from work, and it was late and freezing. =)

After driving in circles for awhile, we finally got to Fringale and lucked out on parking - we parked RIGHT next to the restaurant - score! This was going to be a good night. 

Fringale is a small, cozy, and private restaurant. I was pleasantly surprised to see actual French people working there. Cool! It was nice to speak to our friendly waiter in my broken French. 

We ordered:

Beet and goat cheese salad - WOW, I've never really had beets. I mean really taste them. This salad was REALLY good. I love cheese, and the cheese on this salad was deliceux! I really enjoyed the beets as well - sweet and fresh. 

Sauted prawns in pastis with sun dried tomatoes - YUM. I loved these. The combination of the cream sauce, tomatoes, and lemon squeezed on top was tres bon!

Sole with mashed potatoes, spinach, with a cream sauce - LOVED it. I'm not a big fish person (although I am starting to be), but this dish was absolutely devine. Again, it's all about the sauce! And the freshly squeezed lemon.

Lamb w/ sliced veggies - slow cooked lamb. By the time Cynthia and I split plates, then switched, I had one bite and was already pretty full. But I thought this was very good despite just having one bite. It came with thinly sliced and sauteed carrots and onions. Brought the leftovers for the bf and he liked it a lot - said the veggies were cooked very well.

Warm chocolate Gourmand - this flourless chocolate cake isn't your typical flourless chocolate cake. It was rich, but not too rich, and wasn't a candy bar on a plate. I loved it! Came with a side of vanilla sorbet/ice-cream and strawberry compote.

Tarte Tatin de poire aux aromates - If you like cinnamon, ginger, and pears, then this dessert is for you. The pears had an explosion of flavor and was placed atop a layer of pastry. Note to self - try this before eating the rich chocolate. Very strong on the ginger/cinnamon, and very tasty. Came with a side of vanilla sorbet/ice-cream, fresh strawberries and kiwi.

Overall, a great dining experience. It's a casual, elegant, and intimate setting. Service was good and non-obtrusive. (Except for the time that another waiter was moving Cynthia's plate as she was still eating off of it. That was kind of weird). Our waiter was patient with my broken/slow French, and also helped me practice. I checked out the regular menu, and the most expensive thing was $24. Pretty decent prices for the quality of food. I will be back to check out some of their more traditional dishes like duck confit, etc. 

C'est tres bon ! Merci beaucoup, Fringale !
author: Ta G.

description:
I went to this restaurant a while ago. It features French country style.
My favorite were the quail and Mme. Angèle's Gateau Basque.
author: coco b.

description:
I hate to say it, but Fringale was a disappointment. My husband and I went for dinner a couple of weeks ago, very excited to see what all the good reviews were about. Here's what we had:

Prawn appetizer--great prawns in a delectable sauce that reminded me of lemongrass. Frisee salad--one of my favorite things to eat. Egg was tender with a runny but warm yok. Delicious dressing.

Steak frites--very tender cut with a delicious red wine butter sauce, but the meat actually lacked beefy flavor. Mussels--terrible. Lots of empty shells. The food was cold. Some of the mussels were the size of peas. Broth was nothing special. 

Apple tart a la mode dessert was the highlight of the meal. Perfectly warm with nice flakey, buttery crust. Service was great. Atmosphere was cozy. Tight spaces. But the decor and lighting seemed a little dated. I'm in no rush to go back.
author: Jen C.

description:
Ce restaurant aide mon kir obession. Si delicieux. Si addictif. Le meilleur! Les aliments sont bons, aussi.

Ok, I can't speak French for shoot anymore (per mon pere, je parle comme "a two-year old"), but this is a fun little restaurant to enjoy either with a group of people, or with your husband.  Jake, I hope you're reading this!  Dad, sorry the eight years of French didn't take...
author: J T.

description:
How do you say, "Damn!  That was super yummy!" en Francais?  Parce que, it was. Absolument!!  Oui oui oui!!

I would describe the room more intimate than I would small.  And, yes, it is small.  But, although there were two tables very close to mine, I did not feel like I was at the same table as these people.  The room was actually mellow and lively all at once.  You were having a good time and you knew that people at the other tables were, but you didn't feel like anyone was overpowering the room.  You were having fun amongst others having fun while not dragging other people away from their good time into yours.  Make sense?  Maybe that's what French bistrots are really about.  People getting together for great conversation set among others doing the same.  Peut-etre?

Anyway . . .  the food was very delicieux! We both started with the Frisee salad with warm bacon dressing, poached egg and toasted levain.  I ordered it not realizing that toasted levain was just toast (yummy toast though).  I didn't care wtf it was.  I was like "wait, does that really say bacon dressing?  Warm fuckin' bacon dressing?  Bacon dressing?!?  I am so in!"  I'd never had a poached egg before and I didn't care.  All I knew was that I had to get me some bacon dressing.  Oh, Maman!  I'm glad I did.  That was just a grassy-bacony-eggy bowl of goodness with some special toast and fresh ground pepper on top.  Yum (en Francais)!

As an intermezzo . . . Our table was along the front wall, nearest the door.  And there was heat pouring out of the wall and I thought me and my merino were gonna catch on fire.  It was like sitting in front of a roaring fire.  Nu-uh! Non! Non! Non!    We asked our waiter if something could be done.  He really took some good French accented care of us.  He said that people had been complaining that it was cold so they could not turn off the heat.  He pulled our table a bit from the wall and opened the window a smidge.  He said he was very chaud himself.  And, then he got the heat turned off.  No one complained and we were able to dine without being singed!  Merci Mister Garcon!

Le Main Course:  I had the pork tenderloin.  It came with rings of apple that were so out of this monde.  They added quite a bit to the dish.  The pork sat on some very fancy schmancy cole slaw.  The sauce was rich and excellent.  Me likey.  The bf had seabass that he said was excellent.  He never offered me a taste so that's all I can tell you.  It all washed down well with the Schug Pinot Noir we had.  

In sum, en Franglais . . .  really bien food in a tres pleasant room with bon service.  Reasonable prix.  Next time, I gotta get me some pommes frites.
author: Jeff P.

description:
So we went to Fringale for dine about town...

service was great. the guy was super nice. european accent old guy charm. atmosphere was pretty cool too. some people were dressed up like they were gonna get engaged, and some were dressed up like... me - jeans and a vneck sweater. 

we came in even numbers, so we decided to share each dish to get a taste of everything.

the calamari was a winner. pretty decent appetizer dish. not fried as i'm usually accustomed too. the beef carpacio was something entirely new. it was pretty good too, granted i have nothing to make a comparison too. portions are small, but who really goes to a french restaurant for portions? naturally, i'm a person interested in getting one's bang for his buck. quantity and quality included, i'd go with the calamari again.

now the entrees. the majority of the table went with the veal. it tasted as if it was slow cooked, almost stewed. it was super tender, got a nice piece with the bone in it. it was... good i guess, but thats not typically how i like my veal. in fact, i couldn't even tell or taste it was veal just by eating it.

my friend thought that the pasta on the menu would end up being real good, either pretty decent sized portions, or real tasty. on both accounts, as i assumed, he was very wrong. if i had paid $10 bucks for the same pasta i'd be pretty disappointed. lacking in flavor, no meat. nothing at all special with the dish. this was the big lose of the night.

desserts were okay. nothing mind blowing. creme brulee was pretty quality, one of the best i'd had. apple tart was decent. the hazelnut mousse cake... didn't taste like mousse. but was still decent

i was originally gonna give the restaurant a 2, so there ya go fringale! i say you are a okay. dont' think i'd come back tho
author: Garrett W.

description: Great experience from start to finish. Service was attentive but unintrusive for an intimate experience. I still can't get the frisee salad w/poached egg and warm bacon dressing out of my head... insane! The environment is warm, friendly and surprisingly not that loud for a small space. The owner was so kind as to hail a taxi for us after our dinner; most places would not go out of the way like that but would rather just call. Kudos to the French people at Fringale: class, courtesy and darned good French basque food.
author: Meredith R.

description:
I throughly enjoyed this quaint/quiet, and small, cozy restaurant.  They sat us for a table of two right at the window, and the staff were nice and friendly.  

Started out with their appetizers, Sautéed prawns in Pastis, sun dried tomatoes, shallots & chives  - and the calamari melody of some olives/bell pepers in a light vingarette sauce.  Both were delicious, but the prawns swimming in their buttery tomato sauce was to die for.  I wiped the plate dry with the bottomless baugettes at the table.

Hubby ordred the special "off the menu" swordfish, in a bed of beans, and arugala.  It was light, and topped with some vinegarette style sauce.  I ordered the Seafood basquaise, salmon, halibut, prawns, tuna, mussels, red pepper & tomato coulis, and almost couldnt figure out which dish I liked more.  

Only reason for the 1 star less is their portion size.  Although it was enough for me, I know for a regular average person with a descent appetite, the portions are rather small.  I would definately go back there, and make this place a recommendation.

Oh, and because the waiter forgot to bring out my truffles for the bday celebration, he shared with us some port wine in the end.  It was a nice make-up.
author: Ricaa W.

description:
Walking from a friend's loft in the SoMa to our destination (Bacaar) was treacherous.  Blocks seemed never-ending and the wind blew us to the closest restaurant, CoCo 500. (Un)fortunately, they couldn't accommodate a table of four at 7:00pm without a reservation, and the bar was full too.  We trudged down the block to Frinagle, and were seated in a matter of minutes.  

The restaurant is adorable -- quaint, with simple elegance.  Our waiter was great.  Recommended a great Syrah ($45 a bottle is definitely reasonable.  Would order it again.)  Appetizers came in no time (only one ordered), and entrees followed accordingly.  I had the bacon pork tenderloin with braised savoy cabbage, caramelized onion sauce.  It was delectable.  The bacon wasn't overwhelming and was wrapped very neatly around the sides of the pork slices.  The pork itself was succulent, not a dry piece, albeit there were only four slices.  I was pleasantly surprised how tasty the cabbage was--chopped fine and taking the color of the caramelized onion sauce.  Desserts were excellent.  The four of us shared the chocolate bread pudding and the vanilla ice cream with chocolate sauce.  Such simple presentation and components, but together so decadent and rich.  I enjoyed every bite.

I'm definitely going again.  I think I'll order the foi gras (haven't had good foi gras in awhile) and the duck.

Heck, after writing that I'll give Fringale a 4.5 stars!
author: Marie B.

description:
Great place for a date.  Nice lighting, feels warm/romantic, doesn't feel like you are in SF.  This place is not  hip/trendy like its neighbors (Coco500, Orson), nor is it too stuffy.  Yes, the crowd is a bit more subdued/older than what you'd find at Coco500 and Orson and Soma in general.  It feels a bit more on the formal side, but the staff is very nice and friendly.  You don't have to shout to be heard.

The mussels are delicious.  Loved soaking up the sauce with bread.  Roasted chicken for main was delicious.  Moist, not dry at all.  And the spongey warm chocolate banana cake was deeelicious.
author: Caroline I.

description:
The website freetranslation.com defines the word "fringale" as "raging hunger", which is quite humorous for inexplicable reasons.  The restaurant itself is intimate and sports a congenial waitstaff, certainly contrary to the images of berserker fury (MY LOVE FOR YOU IS LIKE A TRUCK) conjured by its name.  As far as French bistros (WOULD YOU LIKE SOME MAKING FUCK) go, Fringale is tops, and I will gladly testify before any grand jury that this is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco (THE BERSERKER IS JUST SO OBSCENE).

I've had the opportunity to both dine and drink wine at the bar here, both of which were pleasant experiences.  In the war against hunger, the food goes above and beyond the call of duty in terms of flavor and presentation (though be warned that, like any decent European restaurant, the portions are neither gargantuan nor pantagruelian in size; rather, they are more befitting the typical human's stomach, and not the corn-fed Average American's).  The food looks just as good as it tastes.  You can't go wrong with any of the entrees, but I found the grilled (not FRIED) calamari appetizer absolutely delicious.  It was a taste sensation like no other.  I couldn't shovel it into my gaping maw fast enough.  Yeah, it was THAT good.  The wine list is not very broad, but quite deep.  They have a great selection of Bordeauxs for your sipping pleasure.

The atmosphere at Fringale is quiet and romantic.  This is a perfect place for date night, so please leave your incalcitrant, malodorous children at home.  The waitstaff is very friendly and gives suitable recommendations for your food and drink.

French cuisine has certainly made amazing advances since Pepe Le Pew first presented a dish of limburger cheese to that poor feline with the painted white stripe on her dorsal side (my sympathy has certain limits, however, since it was her own carelessness that precipitated the advances of that amorous skunk; i.e., she was totally asking for it).  Fringale is the paragon of this progress.

You would do well to experience the fare at Fringale.  It will certainly make you more attractive, rid you of your herpes, and put you on the path to enlightenment.

HA HA HA!  I'M JUST KIDDING!

There is no cure for herpes.
author: Rajiv B.

description:
We got off the highway on the way from Napa to our friends' house in Los Altos where we were staying (for free), went up about two blocks, and parked.  This here looks like a neighborhood that used to be crappy and industrial, but is now gentrified and unaffordable, I said.

Fringale is a little restaurant, minimalist decor, and a modestly sized but extremely well thought out menu.  The cusine is "basque," but the Basque I was dining with (my husband) said that the only Basque thing about the food was the name "piquillo pepper."  That being said, it was delicious!

Mussels in sherry vinegar with fried garlic, those piquillo peppers, crispy coarsely salted pommes frites, and asian pear salad - perfect for a Sunday after wine tasting.  I couldn't believe it, but we actually ordered MORE wine, too - switching to French from California.

The damage? $70.  Decent!

Vacationing is fun.
author: Sasha R.

description:
Man, this place is DELICIOUS!! I went for dine about town last year for lunch here and everything was so delicious. It has a great ambiance as well because it's so small and intimate and the service is great. 

I highly recommend eating here :)
author: caitlin k.

description:
Wonderful dining experience even though we were seated right before the kitchen at no time did it seem we were next to the kitchen.
We were quickly greeted at the door and after finding the door on the street.. people are eating in there where is the door?
The restaurant is intimate and warm, thankfully because it was freezing outside. Our waitress was nice and french and very kind and helpful in explaining the menu and specials to us; she was a little harried though. Kudos to the clairvoyant guy filling our water glasses at the moment I thought i might want more water the pitcher was floating over my glass.
As for the Prix Fix menu we had the 
prawns in a delectable sauce, not enough bread to wipe up the sauce just lick the bowl
chicken mousse, never had chicken that looked like tofu so this is a first. peg s. came up with chicken SPAM. do they make that?
pork tenderloin, the mustard grain, shavings of cabbage was dreamy to eat, didn't understand the gerkin and cocktail onion on the plate, I gave this up to Peg for a lighter meal
lamb shank, rich and savory, delicious, filling, I ended up eating this and was full after.
warm chocolate cake, yummie yummie, get got it good! the strawberries and cake are FANTASTIC. Peg S. amazingly was no longer full and wanted a bigger piece... something plate size i think.
hazelnut cake, ok went good with the vanilla ice cream from the chocolate cake.

Only thing missing is a better beer and wine selection by the glass. Most 80% of the wines were from California by the glass. 3 beers?!? I am sure without looking they could come up with a little better selection.
Overall the portions were good and the value was excellent along with the service and atmosphere. I could eat here about once a month.
Ask for the plate sized chocolate cake!
author: Lawrence T.

description:
Went to Fringale last night for the first time. Having been in the restaurant business for over 30 years, i know what i am talking about when it comes to food!
Service was good, waiter was helpful and friendly..
Nice wine list and good slection of wines by the glass..
Appetizers (spinach raviolis and bay scallops) were very tasty..
Entrees ( duck confits and filet mignon) were delightful..
Dessert (hazelnut pie and molten chocolat) were awsome..
Fringale gets busy very quickly, tables are close to eachother and if you are looking for privacy, it might  the right place. otherwise the portions are just right, you will definitely leave fringale very satisfied, we will go back again soon..
author: Jacques R.

description: Excellent food, excellent service - fast and friendly. Charming and not pretentious. It's a lovely neighborhood restaurant. Highly recommend. Delightful experience.
author: Lauren N.

description:
A few friends and I went to Fringale for an intimate and low key New Year's Eve dinner.  The restaurant is small and elegant, like many restaurants around the bay area.  It was around $75 for three courses (appetizer, main entree, dessert), and it also came with an amuse bouche and a cheese plate.  

So!  Was it worth it?  Yes, because it was a nice dinner.  Yes, because it was a nice place.  Yes, because the waiter was very nice and the service was good...even though they flubbed the dessert (some people didn't get theirs) they comped our drinks.  But why three stars?

The food itself was good - but not foodgasmic or awe-inspiring.  The foie gras was very fatty and buttery, but the steak was just...okay.  There weren't any fabulous flavors there, and the creme brulee was like any other.  If you're itching for a place to and have a good meal, go here.  But when you walk out, you'll still have your socks on because it won't knock you over.
author: Shay F.

description:
There's something to be said about restaurants that lean towards more traditional flavors; in this case the flavors come from the Basque region of France. It's the simplicity of the food that won me over. Everything I had was carefully prepared, and that made all the difference.

I went w/my dining buddy and I will definitely come back again. We shared:
-Chicken and vegetable terrine
-beet and goat cheese salad (my favorite)

-roasted chicken with squash and brussell sprouts. The chicken was juicy and not at all dry.
-steamed sole over yukon gold, served w/champagne beurre blanc. The fish was fork tender and the mashed potatoes were like mouth fulls of buttery goodness!

-warm chocolate gourmand, not really my thing but good nonetheless
-almond/hazelnut mousse cake. I'm not much of an almond fan but I loved this dish.

As stated before I will be back. C'etait tres delicieux!
author: X marks the spot ..

description:
I went for dinner, and the dishes seemed uninspired, or maybe it was just an off night. 
 
I started off with the frisee salad (frisee lettuce, poached egg, toasted levain, and bacon dressing), and it was quite tasty, but mostly because it had been drowned in bacon fat. This is not my idea of an interesting dish. If I doused everything with butter and oil, it would no doubt taste good. The best part of the salad was that it was served warm (due to the bacon dressing). For my entree, I had the duck confit. It was served with lentils, and that was the best part of the dish. The sauce was interesting, but the duck was not as tender as I would have liked.

My boyfriend started with pimento stuffed dungeness crab on a bed of arugula. The crab was quite tasty. For his entree, he had a Hawaiian white fish, the name of which, escapes me now. The dish came with a variety of mushrooms as well. It was decent, but the sauce seemed off.

Wine: our request for a recommendation for a light drinkable red yielded a 2003 Burgundy, which was too dry for my tastes. I also can't remember the name of the winery. 

The best part of the meal was when the otherwise calm restaurant started playing music. All of a sudden the theme song from the Love Boat filled the dining area. As we looked around to see where it was coming from, our waiting approached us beginning to dance and sang "the looooooove boat". It was quite entertaining and unexpected from our otherwise stoic French waiter. 

The ambiance was quite nice. There was a large party sitting near us, but also lots of couples enjoying a romantic evening. It appears that they have a lot of regulars as well. A few lonesome stragglers sat down at the bar to have dinner halfway into our meal (maybe around 9:30 - kind of late to begin having dinner on a week night). when the place had mostly emptied out. Also, the kitchen staff and host began having dinner in the dining room around this time as well. I really liked that the environment seemed comfortable even for a fancier restaurant. I would give Fringale another try given the good reviews on Yelp, attentiveness of the staff and vibe, but the food left something to be desired last night.
author: kathy c.

description:
Fringale for lunch, anyone?

I had lunch here today to celebrate telecommuting instead of commuting to SiValley. Only 4 of the tables were filled so I was immediately given a table with a view of the sidewalk. This is the second in a trend of yelp reviews of Patricia Unterman's recommendations. 

I started with the bread basket and a glass of Concannon pinot noir ($9). Both were outstanding. I ordered the pinot as I had decided on having the "Crispy skin salmon served with roasted tomatoes, asparagus, arugula & caper berries" ($16). Every ingredient was superbly prepared and worked well together and well with the wine. The salmon was perfectly cooked for my taste; probably a little rare for some.

I especially enjoyed the finely sliced caper berries. I asked the chef to remind me what they were and he said he used the caper berries to offset the sharpness of the arugula. It must have worked as the arugula did not taste sharp to me. ( I have had some sharp arugula in my time.)

I completed my meal with the "Mme. Angle's Gateau Basque - Dense almond torte filled with a layer of custard cream" ($7). [Aren't online menus great? The wine menu is out of date but I was happy to look up Concannon and discover it is a Livermore vineyard] The almond flavor of the torte was just right, not too demure - not too bold,  and (again) went very well with the custard cream. I especially like the sprouts sprinkled on top.

My only disappointment was the waitress (yes, she had a wonderful French accent) forgot to bring the coffee I ordered with the torte. Neither of us said anything about this omission. However, she spent a lot of time at the bar with white-out to update my bill which I found amusing enough to not complain and still give a good tip....:^)

I will definitely return here for lunch again soon; great service and food  that will be remembered for some time.
author: carson s.

description:
Food aside, lunch at Fringale was perfect. Service is sweet and attentive but not overbearing, in lovely French-accented English. Fringale is a tiny space with natural colors and lots of light that shines through the windows, and an array of French pop fills the air, with Phoenix leading the pack. The experience is intimate and cheerful, and it really put a bright spot in my day.

The food, however, is hit-or-miss. We opted for the Dine About Town menu, which was great at Fringale because the menu featured selections from the regular menu (usually a plus. I hate it when participating restaurants churn out a "sample menu" apart from their regular for DAT that ends up to be a transparent and unexciting ploy at penny-pinching). We started with Arnold Palmers which were perfectly refreshing-- fresh, acidic and with the perfect (restrained) amount of sweetness-- and the complementary bread basket with rich butter that I'm guessing was either Plugra or at least another type of Euro style butter. The rundown of the rest:

Sweet gem lettuce salad w/ herb vinaigrette and shaved petit basque: Y's app was a good start, a cross between a typical butter lettuce salad and a caesar. Predominantly baby romaine with a nice, floral-fragrant dressing and long shavings of Petit Basque, a great semi-hard cheese. This was a surprisingly generous portion.

Prawns in pastis with sun-dried tomato: I was hoping they'd have the calamari on the menu, but settled for this. The prawns were a bit strong in flavor but it were paired with a great sauce, ideal for dipping. Didn't taste much of the pastis, but shallots and sun-dried tomatoes added contrasting sweetness and acidity. This was quite heavy, though.

Y. and I ordered Boeuf Bourguignon and Coq au Vin, respectively. The meats were both cooked well, braised properly; but the seasonings were lacking. Though the meat off of my chicken thighs fell of the bone, the flavors fell short. I guess that's what you get when you order chicken.

Our desserts were both a touch too sweet. I would have liked more vanilla in my creme brulee and thought it a bit too thick, almost reaching the point of being curdled. Y.'s bread pudding with chocolate and banana had a nice, silky consistency with a delicious sauce, but a tad too sweet and not enough banana flavor.

If the food promised to be better next time, I wouldn't hesitate to return. But I'd probably rather risk trying out another restaurant for now.
author: Nuri K.

description:
I really like this classic French bistro in Soma. I ate here probably over 5 years ago with my family for my mom's birthday, and last night's meal reminded me how I should come back here more often! 

My friend and I started with the spicy calamari for our appetizer. The portions were huge! We got a huge pile of calamari sauteed with red peppers and jalapenos. They were very tasty and I loved the hint of spiciness.

For my entree, I had the shellfish and seafood stew. The bowl was filled with mussels, shrimp, and chunks of salmon and cod cooked in a sweet tomato and onion sauce. My friend had the pork tenderloin with cabbage and apples. I loved his dish!! The pork was flavored really nicely with the thyme sauce and the meat was very juicy. Served with the pork was a bed of cooked cabbage. It almost looked like "cold slaw," but it was really cabbage. Along with the cabbage were sliced of apples to sweeten the entire dish. Yummy! Luckily my friend was nice enough to share half of his dish with me. (and of course I gave him half of mine.. )

For two glasses of wine and the food above, our bill was only $75! For the quality of food and service, this is a wonderful deal.
author: Denise L.

description: Came here for a light lunch last week.  I had the Onion Soup and it was delicious!  I also had the grilled prawns with tomato sauce.  Cute little restaurant and reasonable pricing.
author: Jacky L.

description:
The place itself is small, not that much decoration...looks very classy, romantic and relaxing with their dark lighting they use. I was impressed from the minute I woke in with the service and attention that I received. Our waitress was a French girl with the most sexiest accent you can find and she was helpful, detailed and friendly. The food was FANTASTIC. To tell you the truth I am a big fan of small portions and I expected this restaurant to have smaller portions, but I finished all of my food, because it was sooooooo goooooood. 

I love that they offer half bottles of wine, I tried 2 different French wines and my selection was great as well. I had a seafood dish (included mussels, shrimps, like a mix of everything with fresh spinach and a very tasty sauce). 

Go there and enjoy it. I'm coming back for more of that crme brule and wine and cheeses! :-) You won't be disappointed.
author: Katja S.

description:
Walked in on a Sunday night with no reservations, needing a table for 3. Do you sense a trend here? =) 

They sat us in 15 minutes. Let me say, I know this place has been around for a while but I've never been here. I was asking myself why? We really enjoyed the food, the ambience and the service. They were packed and there were a lot of people lingering over a bottle of wine. 

We had a bottle of chateauneuf .. ok I can't spell! But the bottle was good! I am glad we tried it! Will surely stop at a costplus to buy a bottle. I took the cork home! Yey for me since I can read or pronounce french to save my life. 

I had the frise with the poached egg and little pine nuts, hubby had the apple/pear/prosciutto salad, and guest had the plum/arugula salad. The salads were ok. Not mind blowing but a 2. 

For dinner i had the seafood stew in a tomato base. This was fabulous! The flavors really went well together and the sauce was  good I had to keep sopping it up with bread. I had to stop midway though cause I still had dessert to think of! Hubby has the halibut in a bed of peas and spinach with a lemon/bechamel sauce. The sauce again was fabulous! Guest had the veal osso bucco. This he kept saying was way too much food, but he ate it all! Must've been good! I would rate the entrees a 3.5 out of 5.

We each had a dessert, an almond torte with curd, a warm flourless cake and an almond sponge cake with a chocolate sauce.  The deserts were not bad, but also not great. They kind of seemed lie afer thoughts. I would rate them a 2.

We left the restaurant feeling good and happy, probably because of the wine and hey lets face it, we live in the Bay area, whats not to be happy about. After doing the review, I can't really say we had anything we couldn't get elsewhere. Don't get me wrong, its a very respectable restaurant and a nice meal. I would come around again if I was in a pinch on a Sunday night. Would I be back again in the next couple of months? Probably not, there are so many other restaurants to try. Mind you, if the food is spectacular, I almost always eat ALL OF IT despite the prospect of dessert. We just linger. =) 

All in all we spent $165 without tip. Not a bad amount.
author: Pica L.

description:
Fringale is amidst the barren waste of SOMA.  The room is bright, the tables well-spaced, the staff efficiently disinterested.  But they get the food to you while it is hot.

A dungeness crab napolean is a circular tower of fresh crab, avocado, and tomato confit, surrounded by a drizzle of creme fraiche.  The crab is fresh and not overwhelmed by the other components of this fresh, lively dish. A good way to start a meal. 

Rack of lamb is three chops served medium rare.  The chops are tasty, but unseasoned and not crisped about the edges.  The chops are accompanied by potato gratin, that is hot at the edges but lukewarm in the center, and some fresh and piping hot eggplant & squash ratatouille.  Nice food.  

Dessert is hazelnut & roasted almond mousse cake topped with roasted almonds.  The cake is in a puddle of not too sweet chocolate.  Nice, rich, and very much to my taste.
author: David D.

description:
Really good, but not as good as Chapeau. 

And they thought my boyfriend was a girl. I know gender is a culturally-constructed myth and all...but still.
author: Annee T.

description:
Fringale makes the best creme brulee in town.  Bar none. 

Go, order some food for dinner or lunch.  You'll love it.  

But save room for dessert.   

See if you agree with me.
author: Bevy M.

description:
So I have heard a lot about Fringale and have always wanted to go - but for some reason had not made it until, much to my excitement, I saw they were participating in Dine About Town.  I went on the very first DAT night out.

Ordering - you get one of three appetizer choices, one of three entree choices and one of three dessert choices.  Not bad!

I started out with the Spicy Monterey Calamari with jalapenos and chorizo.  FANTASTIC!  If you are not a fan of the spice, then definitely do NOT order this.  The spice was just right for me - not to little and not tearing up my stomach either (and the next day wasn't painful either, if you know what I mean).  Beware - the serving is quite generous, and if you have filled up on bread and still have your entree and dessert to go - you will run out of room.

Next was the Veal Osso Bucco.  Again, Fantastic.  Just the right amount of Veal mixed with a very flavorful faro, eggplant and tomatoes.  I even had a little bone with some marrow in it, and although I'm not a huge fan, the person next to me was slurping the marrow out of his bone.  I say, when in Rome....

For dessert I had the apple tart.  Very good - Ice cream they served with it was actually better.

Service is Fantastic and Very Attentive.  I booked my reservation on OpenTable and for some reason the host at Fringale didn't check me in, so I got a "no show" that I had to reverse (FYI).
author: Jason I.

description:
Recommended by one of my accounts, we had a business lunch at this French/Basque restaurant.  The food was fantastic.  I had the salmon which was perfectly prepared.  The duck confit and ribeye were also highly recommended.  Come to think of it, it seems that my business associate recommended everything on the menu.  

The restaurant atmosphere is cozy and warm.  A wonderful place for a nice and intimate meal.

What's better, I've discovered that my friend Helen has also reviewed and given this restaurant raving reviews.  That should be enough.  I've only given the restaurant 4 stars because I haven't tried enough of the menu...I guess I'll just have to go back.  ;)
author: Brian L.

description: I celebrated my bday here tonight. Food was good. I had the lamb. The waiter was really nice and knew his job. The guy we talked on the phone was really nice too.
author: Candice C.

description: 3.5. I always order the steak and fries with a bottle of their best red wine. You never go wrong there. Top 3 French bistros in SF for me.
author: Betty N.

description: Incredible restaurant, whether for an intimate lunch or a elegant dinner. They have a great wine list or can make you a wonderful cocktail. I have never had anything that I didn't like on their menu, everything is prepared with the upmost care. The service is attentive and the owners are very pleasant people. Recommend highly!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
For a Sunday night, even though the venue is on the smaller side, we were seated pretty quickly without a reservation.  Service was very friendly and just what you'd expect for a $$$ type of restaurant.

The food, wine and dessert were all really good.  I loved the glass of Pinot Noir that I had, it was excellent.  Light and smooth and perfect.  The fettuccine pasta was delicious, the artichokes were cooked very well and the seasoning was just right.  My favorite of all that I had was definitely dessert.  The warm chocolate gourmand was one of the best desserts I've had in my life.  No joke, it made the top 5, and this is coming from a gal with a HUGE sweet tooth.

All in all this place was great and I would totally recommend if you're looking for a cozy meal with a genuine French feel.
author: Swetha G.

description:
I had heard great things about this place but I have to say I was a tad disappointed.  Although it should be noted that there was a group of about 22 of us, and the place can barely hold 50 so we were crammed into this passageway between the kitchen and the bar.

The place is supposedly Michelin recommended, so that's another level of anticipation.  The appetizers were very good, the carpaccio, calamari, and foie gras were excellent.  Then came the entrees, and at our table, everyone seemed disappointed except for me.  Most people either got the ribeye or the sea bass.  The ribeye was tender but woefully underseasoned and apparently not aged very long.  It simply had little taste.  The sea bass was shockingly small and I think it left the people who ordered them a bit hungry and unsatisfied.

I, however, ordered the coq a vin.  I rarely see it on a menu so I had to get it and when I asked the waiter whether to get that or the ribeye, he said in a heavy French accent "of course, the coq a vin!"  It was fantastic.  The chicken had been stewed for 3-4 days and was infused with the wine and the mirapois and the collagen from the chicken made the sauce thick and scrumptious.

Despite my good experience, I'm taking everyone's dishes into account so this place gets a 3.  I tasted the ribeye and it was indeed flavorless, so no real chance of a 4 here.  

The desserts were pretty good as well.  However, the total bill came to about $70/person.  To be totally honest, I felt a bit cheated and it seemed too steep a price to pay when taking my friends' experiences into account.
author: Dave K.

description:
A reasonably price, not stuffy french bistro. I went on a day where they were offering prix fixe menu for $30. We had a shrimp appetizer and a foie gras. The shrimp appetizer was so good that we clean the plate with the compliementary bread. The table next to us did the same thing:)
The steak was done nicely and the rack of lamb was good. The halibut meanwhile, paired nicely with the slightly spicy pepper. 
We had the Almond torte for dessert and it was quite good too.
Bottomline: For not a lot of money ($70 for 3 including wine), we had 2 great dishes (shrimp appetizer and halibut) and the rest was good. 
Service was a little slow, but I was willing to put up with it for the price:)
author: hsiao c.

description:
A French bistro with an absolutely amazing baker. We stopped in for coffee and a dessert, and ordered a second dessert after plowing through the first.

The decor is tired and dated, the Basque influence negligible, the space a bit stinky (old carpet) -- but the most important aspects, service and food were damn near perfect. An excellent restaurant.
author: Ben G.

description:
I have to say that I had one of my best dining experiences in SF *ever* here.  The food was excellent.  The atmosphere was welcoming and comfortable, and the service was oustanding.  My waiter did mess up on one item (an appetizer, I believe), but was extremely apolegetic and took it off the bill.  We had 2 appetizers, 2 entrees, wine, dessert, and drinks (yes, we were there awhile - partly because it was so comfortable and we didn't feel rushed at all), and everything was delicious.  Oh yeah, AND it was reasonably priced!  (relative to other french/basque restaurants in the city)

UPDATE:  Been back and it still gets the 5 star rating.  I love this place.  Excellent food, excellent service, excellent atmosphere, more than decent prices.
author: Kerry L.

description:
After a single lunch, I can easily say Fringale is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. It's a tiny bistro with a special flair. Our waiter was very "frenchie" and flirted with one of my coworkers. Wowza ;) 

The pate for starter was just delicious. The lamb dish was very well made. Best thing about the place: your food is presented nicely and does not overwhelm you. For lunch, the portion size was perfect.

If you want great French food, I'd recommend Fringale - 5 stars!
author: Han C.

description:
Je suis tres contente!  I enjoyed every part of this meal - and left thoroughly full for it being French food...We had a huge party of girls so I commend the waiter for being so patient with us...tho he was kinda loopy at times...but all in all - our servers were attentive and took good care of us!

As for the food - tres bon!  I personally enjoy their mussels - its usually an appetizer but I always order it as an entree....its that big!  The crab cake was good, but I've had better...however, they did add their own twist and topped it off with tuna tartare...Make sure you order les frites (fries) on the side of your mussel - they complement each other well...and top it off with some red wine - I am one happy girl...

Everyone seemed happy with their meal...too many girls - but I heard no complaints with the duck, the halibut and some bacon wrapped dish...

Desserts are a must have!  We had the sorbet (refreshing), truffles (decadent), bread pudding (my fav) and the triffle (can't recall)...
author: Julie H.

description:
Fringale: French for "the urge to eat"...and this is probably the best name for a Basque-inspired hole in the wall like this place.

I came here for a work lunch, and we all had nothing bad to say.  I ordered the the poached Alaskan halibut, and the fish was perfectly cooked.  The piperade, artichoke and olive side complemented it quite well.  My coworkers ordered the Duck Confit, which was swimming in a pool lentils and a red wine sauce.  I was fortunate to have a piece, and when I bit into it, the meat seemed to just melt in my mouth.  At one point, I was regretting my order and wanting more of that duck.  The wine selection is amazing and made for a very "happy" lunch.  I will definitely be back here...this time, I'm ordering the Duck (maybe 2).
author: Mark P.

description: Absolutely delicious! Bacon wrapped pork, ravioli stuffed with Roquefort, creme brûlée! Out of this world. And the service was dynamite too!! Will be back!
author: Traci H.

description:
It is always so wonderful to stumble upon nice restaurants in your neighborhood...that is exactly how I felt after a late lunch at Fringale with hubby dear. 

The service was awesome and the decor was simple and elegant. Our sweet, young waiter spoke with a heavy French accent and the guy who looked like the restaurant's owner/manager (and was also perhaps the waiter's uncle! :P) seemed like a strict Frenchman! hehe 

The lunch menu was quite limited but we were very happy with what we ordered. 

Hadn't intended to have an expensive lunch but the bill came to over 60 bucks for the 2 of us. Oh well, it was French food after all!
author: Shradha B.

description:
I concur, this place is excellent. Some of the waiters are French and are awfully patient with people who want to "practice" their French. To top it off, they are also darn cute.

The food is D-lish but the wine list is also amazing. The best glass of wine I ever had was here. It was an Italian Pinot Grigio that was like taking a bite of a fresh green apple every time I took a sip. I will be back.
author: Alotta F.

description:
everytime i go to a french restaurant, i use a "upgrade, downgrade" system. if something pleases me, i think "upgrade", and "downgrade" if i am displeased. i found myself downgrading at least 3 times during the meal. i felt that the service was slow, only 2 people working the whole restaurant, about 10 small tables. the food was mediocre, and the attention to detail - almost non existent. every table had a bottle of beaujolais...very french.

i had foie gras terrine on toasted brioche to start and then *cue the music...dun dun dun* i ate venison. yes i ate BAMBI...and it was RARE! ok i'll stop the carnivorous talk...someone had escargot which was not seasoned properly and basically TASTELESS chewing gum. someone else had ribeye. another had carpaccio (ok) and monkfish which was fishy and overcooked. the flesh was not flakey but actually quite rubbery. someone else had the rack of lamb which was not bad.

and of course, the best and most anticipated part of the meal is dessert! but i was fairly disappointed. we ordered a chocolate banana bread pudding. it ended up being chocolate cake with mashed bananas in some yogurty soup...blah. then a flourless chocolate cake which was safe yet disappointing since it was quite spongy...meaning it was flour-ful? and a creme brulee which was the worst dessert out of all three since the sugar crust was half an inch thick...ok i'm exaggerating but that's not how creme brulee should be. the thick slab of burnt sugar stuck to our teeth and had a terrible bitter aftertaste. therefore...DOWNGRADE!

i hate it when restaurants serve food that is just edible, not delicious. but i'm glad i tried it for myself. seems like a lot of people love this place...so more the better for them that i won't be competing for a reservation.
author: Charmaine L.

description: I went here last night with my boyfriend for diiner.  I had never been here before, but after reading the reviews I thought we'd give it a try.  Wow!  The scallops were absolutely delicious and the creme brulee was some of the better brulee I've had.  I ordered a side of spinage to have with the duck, and I'm not a huge, huge spinage fan generally but it was just perfect .  Service was attentive, but not overly so and the atmosphere was favorable for an intimate dinner for two.  I'd give a 4.5 rating for this establishment.
author: Dana P.

description:
Had date night with the boyfriend and we did the Dine About Town ($35 each per person). We got the best table in the place (it's cozy and intimate, which I like)! We had the calamari and crab something-or-other for appetizers. They were both great- the calamari was perfectly cooked and had a great bold flavor. The crab thingy was very tasty and the flavors blended well together. 
For entrees we had the hanger steak and the petrale sole. The steak was juicy and had a great sauce :) and the sole was very rich. For dessert we had the gourmand and the creme brulee. Both were great but the creme brule was super creamy and it was a generous portion. 
The service was very good and if we didn't do the Dine About Town, the prices aren't actually that bad... so I might return at a later date!
author: Amanda W.

description:
I held my birthday dinner gathering here (on bastille day inadvertantly). I was impressed that they were able to accomodate two parties of 14, one of which was mine, in such a small french restaurant on bastille day! 

The food was good, but nothing out of the ordinary - yes, I am a spoiled SF foodie. I wouldn't make an effort to go back anytime soon given all the other food options we luckily have in SF.
author: Karen C.

description:
I've walked past Fringale tons of times, but never actually made the decision to eat there until a friend and I were waiting for more people to celebrate my birthday.  What a treat it was to have to wait.  Most of the time, I'm quite impatient, but I savored every minute I sat at the bar, drinking the house Bordeaux.

My friend ordered the rib eye with the pommes frites and I had the mushroom risotto.  It was hard to resist when I was offered to have a bite of the steak.  It was oh so buttery and oh so yummy!  Had I not had red meat the day before, I would have devoured my friend's steak, but I'm glad I was able to sample that melt in your mouth goodness.  Next time I go to Fringale, I'm ordering the steak!

Not to say that the risotto wasn't any good because it, too, was quite delicious!  I ate the risotto in no time.  The wine went very well with the steak and the risotto.

I only wish we had enough time to consume some of the decadent looking desserts.  

I don't think I can wait till my next birthday to stop in.  Fringale!  I'm coming back soon!
author: Annalynn C.

description:
We went here for Dine About Town last night, but ended up ordering off the regular menu.  This was a good call, because it was the best meal I've had in a LONG time.

It started with the shrimp ravioli in lobster sauce.  AMAZING.  For my main course, I had quinoa (similar to cous cous) with spinach and truffles.  DOUBLE AMAZING.  Even meat lovers should pass up the duck or chicken for this unbelievable dish.

My boyfriend was less impressed with his potato and leek soup and duck.  He should have let me order.

-------------
update 2/17.  Fringale has a new chef and new menu.   Those dishes I raved about are no longer available :(
author: Zuzzi E.

description:
tried and true bistro offerings executed well and at an affordable price.  came here on a whim for a steak.
we shared a split Frisée salad with warm bacon dressing, pine nuts, poached egg & toasted levain
Bacon wrapped pork tenderloin, braised Napa cabbage, onion & apple marmalade
and Creekstone Farm black angus ribeye steak, pommes frites, string beans & red wine butter sauce
the salad had the perfect poached egg, one for each (split), very classic
the tenderloin medallions were cooked superbly, moist, over a moist bed of chopped cabbage delicious with an excellent sauce and just the right amount of sweetness with the apple bits
the ribeye steak, large cut without bone, had a generous red wine butter sauce and was cooked perfectly
at this price point, i enjoyed it.
author: Rob C.

description:
South Park/Mission Bay/whatever this area is called seems full of forgettable French-ish bistros like this one.

I went here for lunch today and ordered the mussels. You'd think for $14, they'd come with french fries as is traditional. I was not going to spend an extra $5 just for some fries, so I stuck with the bread.The mussels themselves were small and tender, but the broth was too garlicky and oily for my taste. The bread was also just so-so, which is not acceptable at a French restaurant. 

My co-worker ordered the special salad, which for $9, I'd expect a lot better, although I am getting used to overpriced salads in this neighborhood. Anyway, it was so oily that the leaves glistened from across the table.

It isn't worth the price for lunch, and it doesn't have the ambiance for a nice dinner, so I won't be rushing back. Too bad.
author: Lauren H.

description:
I hadn't been here for close to 10 years.  A friend of mine wanted to hang out and she treated me to dinner here.  

Parking - no prob.  It's right off the 4th street exit with plenty of street parking.   Plus, there's a lot for $10 right across the street if you can't find that.

Food - Started with the mussels and they were good.  Sauce was flavorful, but not overpowering.  Had the salmon for an entree and it was great.  Firm, but not dry.

Service - The waiter was very helpful with our wine selection while the table staff kept the water filled and cleared dishes promptly.  We had a long leisurely dinner (close to 2 1/2 hours) and yet we weren't rushed or anything.  

Ambiance - The place is a bit small and a bit noisy, but it works fine.  We had a table by the window.  Not much to look at but the parking lot across the street.  But, it must be near some Asian club cuz as the evening wore on, there was quite a few Asian gals dressed in (ahem) provocative club attire walking by.  My friend was a bit less generous in her opinion of how they were dressed.  8)  

I had a great evening.  I'll be back in less than a decade for sure.
author: H C.

description:
I came here on a Wednesday night pretty close to closing time.  I hate doing that, by the way, but I was hungry and in the neighborhood.  When I asked if they were still seating I was greeted with a smile and taken right away to a nice window seat.

I ordered the steak and pomme frites which were delicious.  My friend ordered the bacon wrapped porkchop which happened to just be so-so.  We both drank a glass of Bordeaux, at his suggestion, which was phenomenal.  

Why four stars?  It didn't blow my mind.  However, what I do love is that the waiters here are knowledgeable.  It doesn't seem as though they hire any server with a nice skill set.
author: Gemma S.

description:
the calamari was very tasty and just the right amount of chewyness, spinach ravioli had a great hit of blue cheese without too much texture of the cheese (i thnk it was in the sauce), lamb was fork pull.

service was alright. Yes the waiter seemed a lil bit of the frenchy-aloofness at first, but when he accidentally delivered spinach as a side instead of the spinach ravioli that we ordered, he politely and quickily switched the order for us w/o any questions.

the place is a bit off the downtown/SOMA vibe, feels slightly too quiet at night on the streets, would recommend going earlier in the day if that kind of environment bothers you.
author: Jenny Z.

description:
Had a lovely dinner here with my partner a couple of months ago. Like restaurants of this type in France, the food here is a winning combination of comfortable standards plus interesting in-house dishes, served with easy flair. Super fresh and delicious.

I love how small the place is, but it didn't feel cramped. The atmosphere was like eating in someone's home. Our waiter was great and un vrais Francais. We were well tended to and we'll be back.
author: Randall J.

description:
I had a business lunch at Fringale today. My associate is from Atlanta and was already on cloud 9 because of the weather, but then she ate at Fringale. Let's just say it help negotiations. For starters she ordered the butternut squash soup and almost licked the bowl clean, and I had the calamari with chorizo and roasted bell peppers which was fabulous.

For our lunch entrees, she ordered the special: Beef Stroganoff and I had the Basque Tuna sandwich with frites--rare (I had to take half the sando home--hey you can't miss out on a killer starter when someone else is buying!). We were both extremely full and happy.

Although I did not pay, lunch is not low budget, but it was extremely good and I will go back--even when I pick up the tab.
author: Deborah S.

description:
If you've read my other reviews, you'll know I tend to be pretty picky. About pretty much everything. So last night, we made it to Fringale as we've been there for many many years, but for some reason, had not gone back in a while.

This place has not changed one bit. Same layout, similar french staff. The food is solid and the wine list is actually reasonably priced, with good choices. So last night, they actually messed up my order as they "forgot" my main course. Some miscommunication I figured. Once I pointed it out to our waitress, she actually rushed it and all was good. 

But they also went beyond this and comped us desert. Hey, they clearly did not have to, but this is customer service 101, and is way too rare and this earned them a fifth star. 

Solid food, solid wine list, great service and friendly staff. Sometimes this sort of evening makes you realize why a place has been in business for so long: consistency, and great customer service goes a long way. Many restaurants in the City could learn from Fringale.
author: Frederic B.

description:
Yelp.com calls it a Spanish/Basque, French restaurant, but it was pure French when we went.

And it was damn good.

The menu is  all very classic fare (I know this because my chef boyfriend told me). But I think I would have picked that up eventually, who knows.

I'll get to the important stuff and leave off the narrative.

dirty martini - the most perfect amount of olive juice I've ever had in a dirty martini. You wouldn't think it would be such a delicate balance, but it is and I didn't realize it until I had it done exactly right.

Campari and soda - Jason said it was also mixed just right.

Beef Carpaccio with toasted horseradish, chives, greens and a light mustard sauce. My first time with raw beef and I really enjoyed it. All the flavors were pure and simple, but excellent.

Black Angus Rib Eye with red wine butter and pomme frites - beautiful. So tender and good and the haricots vertes were yummy. I think the french fries were some of the best I've ever had, they were light and airy with the perfect amount of crunch.

Rack of Lamb with potato gratin - This wins the prize. The lamb was without any gameyness and perfectly tender. It was a wonderfully rounded plate.

Cross Point Pinot Noir 2005 - a perfect match for both dishes. Oh my god, it was an excellent wine both with and without food. Bright, but also complex and deep.

Service - Awesome. There was slight confusion among the two waiters as to who was serving our table at the beginning. But it didn't matter, we seemed to get better service because of it. We had both waiters and the hostess bringing us stuff and making sure we were happy. Our waiter in the end was perfectly French, but warm and sweet. He poured us some extra wine on the house when we asked to look at the bottle. He answered my questions about "terroir" and patiently pronounced and explained it to us. He matched the perfect wine with our food.

Fringale is a French Bistro and nothing but. They did not surprise me with inventive dishes, but they do the French thing so well and give such great service, that I was happy they don't diverge from the classics.

... and their fraunsch fries were amazing. I know nothing of their Fraunsch toast or Fraunsch dressing.
author: cindy p.

description:
I went here for my birthday this year with Dad is Rad,my lil homie Cheri, and my platonic girlfriend Nicole and we all had an amazing meal.


The food is so damn good. like every friggin thing is amazing. We all were eating off one anothers plated basking in the glow of one anothers tastiness. Great wine menu, as well as sparkling wines(which is my jam).the waiters are super hot too,lil french homies. Loving you fringale...ill definitely be back(when im not so broke)
author: Lauren V.

description:
I enjoyed the duck confit and a salad.  The service was good and the food well prepared.  Nothing stole the show however and I can't say that I found the menu compelling enough to return unless the person I'm meeting suggests it first.

It was fairly pricey once you throw in a moderate bottle of wine, some sparkling water and a glass of madeira.

I think there are better meals out there for the price, but everything was certainly done well in terms of food and service.
author: Adam B.

description:
Top-notch French dining at mid-notch prices. A three-course meal with a glass of wine will run you about $100 pre-tip for two. It's worth every dollar -- the food is nicely portioned (doesn't look like a lot at first but definitely fills you up) and tastes amazing.

I've been there for dinner twice so far. The first time was exquisite -- the shrimp and lobster bisque starter was perfect, and the pork entree was excellent. I stole a few fries from my partner's steak frites, and they were thin, light, and crisp -- just as you'd expect. For dessert, the home-made ice cream and chocolate sauce was one of the best sundaes I've had. C'est magnifique!

The second time was quite good, but admittedly not as great. My partner ordered the shrimp and lobster bisque this time, but the sauce was darker and a little different -- still good, but not as good. My rabbit pate was good, but not spectacular. Our entrees, chicken and salmon, were both nicely done, though. I ordered the same dessert, but this time it came with almost no chocolate sauce. Bummer.

So the exact quality of the food may depend on the night you visit, but I'm willing to give them the benefit of the doubt -- it's a quaint place with a friendly staff, and we'll be back for more.
author: Jase W.

description:
Fringale is a San Francisco restaurant not to be missed.  While it is pricey, the food is to die for.  We went with a large group for my birthday weekend, and although it was a bit cramped, everyone had an amazing night.  

The calamari appetizer was delicious and from there we moved on to the main course.  My family is very into sharing, so we each ordered something different and passed around.  The scallop dish was the best I have ever had, and the steak and fish dishes were amazing, too.  

The waiters never let our wineglasses get below half full (much to the delight of all of my friends) and brought out a wonderful creme brulee with a candle in it as a birthday treat.

The restaurant most certainly deserves 5 stars for the food and service, but the fact that one of my best friends arrived at the end of the meal as a birthday surprise definitely sealed the deal!  Great restaurant for a group or a date.
author: Corrie M.

description:
Fringale is a great French restaurant.  It's a great place for a romantic dinner.  The restaurant is slightly formal in decor and service compared to other French restaurants in this category / price range.  The decor is also more classical even though it's fairly bright and updated.

I had a 3 course dinner.  The French food is very solid here.  I had a Endive salad, the Halibut and dessert.   All were excellent and better t han most in this price range.

Parking was easy, even on a Saturday night.
author: Paul K.

description: I haven't been to Fringale in many years (too many to count). The neighborhood has changed and so refreshing to see the young neighborhood has embraced the place.  We ordered the Duck special and the veal short ribs.  The servings were substantial. The sides perfectly married to the main dish.  We ate at Boulevard last night and I can honestly say that the food here was more satisfying (nothing against Boulevard ...excellent restaurant, but Fringale is that good).  Very small space. Limited menu.  But perfect execution of what they make.
author: Patty D.

description: So I really love this place but I had such a bad experience with a group that I can no longer recommend it for more than a one on one meal.  We were not even offered dessert because they basically kicked us out since they had another group after us.  Very bad.  We weren't late for our reservation, we didn't lally gag in ordering and I would actually call us fast eaters.  It was very rude and I won't come back with a group but I would eat there again.
author: Karen C.

description: Food's decent every time we come here for dinner. Service is good too with friendly staff.
author: Ann L.

description: A very nice French restaurant just south of the 80 Freeway. I went her on my anniversary. We started with the Assiette de charcuterie and the Endive & arugula salad. I always eat charcuterie  when it's on the menu. Fringale added a nice mustard to go along with the meat. The salad was a great mix of sweet and savory with the endives and apples. For the main course we got the rack of lamb and the ribeye steak. The steak was amazing. Perfectly cooked and melt in your mouth. The lamb however was severely underseasoned. It took a lot of salt and pepper to get some flavor out of it. That was a major setback for the dinner, but the overall experience and meal was still quite good and I would have no problem going back there again.
author: Joel W.

description:
This is one of my favorite French restaurants in SF.  I first went here last September for the Pellegrino Dine Out (like dine-about-town), and got a really great three-course meal for $35 (including the Pellegrino water). This was one of my best dine-about-town like experiences, and a really great value for the money.  I had the foie gras terrine which was really great, a steak dish for the entree, and warm chocolate cake for dessert.  Yum!

I returned here for Valentine's day last February, and though that one was more expensive (all restaurants jack up their prices), I saved some money by bringing in my own special bottle of champagne I brought back from France for $20 corkage.  I was a little worried they might be snobby about bringing in my own wine, they were very nice about it.  Seeing our choice of champagne, the waiter even recommended a few of his favorite champagnes and where to buy them in SF!  It helps a lot that everyone from the host and bartender to the servers (at least the ones I got) seem to be French so it adds a lot of authenticity to the place.  I gotta say I can't fault anything about the service at this place, the waiters I've gotten on both occassons have been very attentive and warm.  And of course the food is always excellent!

Since this place is pretty small, It's tough to get a reservation on a weekend, so look at Opentable a couple weeks in advance.
author: Arlene M.

description:
Went for DAT during lunch.  Made the mistake of ordering the chicken.  Who orders chicken?  I did.  However, my friend ordered the Cod and that was delicious.  Non-chocolate mousse was light, fluffly and not-too rich.  A great way to end a 'fancy' lunch.  Attentive staff (they speak French!), place is small but well-decorated and intimate.

Spongebob Awesomeness:  Spongebob would give it a shot, but would check out other places before coming back.
author: Ronald M.

description:
Meh. Decided to come here with the hubby because we're trying out restaurants in our neighborhood. Originally wanted the Dine About Town menu but decided against it because I tend to order too much food. Hubs had the lobster napolean, flank steak, and almond cake. I had the Seafood Basquaise (pronounced: bas-guess).

Service was good & quick. Place is pretty small, not well ventilated, and kind of stuffy. Food came out fast though. Came without reservation on a Friday night and they sat us pretty much right away.

Lobster Napolean: like a yummy tuna tartare but w/ lobster. It was a little watery near the bottom because of the white sauce. However, it was still refreshing and I polished it off. 

Flank Steak: good flavoring but was a bit salty to me. Cooked to my hubby's desire.

Seafood basquaise: first thought was "this dish is small!". However by the time I finished I was nearly comatose. It was a good seafood dish with mussels, salmon, tuna, and shrimp (all cooked in red bell peppers and tomato sauce).  The flavoring was good but it didn't wow me.

Almond mousse cake: Fabulous! I ate 3/4 of it. The almond flakes on top was crunchy, the cake was spongy, and the chocolate syrup was delicious.

After all that I still rate this place only 3 stars because it was really expensive (hubby & I spent almost $100 here for two. They charge every time you want a coke refill!) and I don't think I will be back. The food just didn't blow me away.
author: Terry D.

description: I wish I could give this place a higher rating, because I loved the ambiance and the intimate romantic setting. However, the food itself was sadly underwhelming for the price. For the entrees I tried the duck confit and the garlic mussels. The duck confit was good, with soft tender meat that fell easily off the bone. As for the mussels, I liked the strong garlicky flavor, and it comes in a huge bowl that can feed at least 4 people. However, half of my mussels were not fully cooked, evidenced by the closed  shells and tough chewy meat. When I told the waiter, he was surprisingly not at all apologetic and seemed almost doubtful, though eventually he did end up giving me a creme brulee on the house. When M went to the bathroom he also saw a chef leaving without washing his hands, which put another damper on our meal. The best part of our meal were the desserts. The creme brulee was thick, almost like custard, and had a delicious caramelized top. The hazelnut roasted almond mousse cake was even better than the creme brulee. It was light, fluffy, and just the right amount of sweetness. However, as harsh as a two star rating is, I can't help but think that the price of the entrees was not worth the half cooked mussels and lack of hygiene =/
author: Joyce H.

description:
If you want a lick your plate clean sort of meal, Fringale is the place to go. I've been here a couple of times now. The food is always fantastic and the flavors incredible. I don't think I've ever ordered anything (or been with anyone who ordered anything) that wasn't superb. The waiters are kind and attentive (even though they're French ;-) and always make you feel like welcome guests. 

All the foods good but the Shrimp Pastis is WONDERFUL. I could eat it every day. Really. Also - they use a fancy French butter but makes the constantly flowing rolls amazing.

I've tried a couple of French places in the city now but every time I go back to Fringale it reasserts itself as "the one".
author: Jeff S.

description:
Very good french food. 
Very formal atmosphere.
The staff is more prim and proper.
Not a place for casual eating or loud groups.
A good place to impress your date
author: S.K. Y.

description: We got excellent food and attentive service. The restaurant looks unassuming from the outside, but is cozy and friendly inside.
author: Markus F.

description:
Had to wait a bit though we had a reservation. Luckily it wasn't raining outside. The waiting area was packed with a large party also waiting for their table.

-Light and fresh tasting Dungeness Crab Napoleon.
-Rib-eye steak and pommes frites tasted good, though the fries were not as hot as I would have liked.
-Brussels sprouts with bacon could have been bacon-ier (get this at Cafe Rouge in Berkeley instead)
-Dessert of warm chocolate torte plus ice cream was small but tasty.

Location is easy to get to.
author: Priscilla K.

description:
Let's play everyone's favorite game of, 'Guess That Adjective!'
1.  The overall impression of our three course meal,
2.  Our server's performance and attitude,
3.  The feeling of my stomach post-Fringale,
The studio audience cheers!
That's right!  You guessed it!
Horrible.
author: Dario B.

description:
Given the reviews, I was thrilled to have dinner at Fringale. My experience was that the dishes were very hit or miss.

The good
The pork appetizer with mint and pomegranate was truly amazing! I could have eaten two for my meal and have been in heaven.
We liked the brussels sprouts and polenta fries, but would have been better off with the pork appetizer.
The pork shoulder braised in cola was HUGE! Big enough for two people, it was incredibly tender, well seasoned, and delicious.

The bad:
The Beef Wellington: I love Beef Wellington, but this one was served on a plate of greasy pastry dough crumbs in oil, had small meat, that was flavorless and tough. It was served with Yorkshire Pudding popovers, both of which were burned (BLACK!) This dish is also the most expensive on the menu, so I think it's best to avoid.

The service and wine were fine, and the prices were fair. I really want to give this place 5 stars but the Beef Wellington with burnt popovers made this place a 3, I'm giving an average of 4.
author: J B.

description:
