I decided to try this restaurant during "Dine about town" week.  The desert pictures really pulled me in and seeing as it was kind of last minute I chose this place.  Hoping that the 4 stars would do my date and I justice it didn't.  We ordered the 3-course dinner.  
First off 
Service: 5 stars
Presentation: 5 stars

Appetizer: 

Crab Napolean:  the salad around the crab had much more flavor than the actual crab meat.  
Calamari: it was way too salty and really chewy for our taste.

Main course:
Lamb shank: The meat fell off the bone which made it really easy to eat.  the flavoring on this was a little wierd for me but then again I've never tried french food.  It was good the first couple bites but I got tired of it real quick. It came with mash potatoes but it didn't taste anything like the typical mashed potatoes ive eaten ever.  It tasted like little grains of i dont know who to describe it.

Duck Confit: my date said the duck was cooked a little too much and that it was too dry. I tried a piece and did not like it.  Once again the flavor was a little wierd for us.

Dessert:
Chocolate Gourmand: the cake itself did not taste good at all.  It didn't taste like chocolate to me.  The vanilla bean ice cream on top of it however was delicious! 

My date ordered the coffee dessert in a cup.  There was also a hint of what could be kahlua.  It was a little overkill on the coffee taste so we both did not enjoy it really.

Over all our meal was not really enjoyable that night.  But then again it could be that French food is an acquired taste.  So I guess you can try it out and see for yourself.
author: Oreo b.

description:
The employees steal credit card numbers!!!!

This month my husband and I had dinner here separately within a week of each other, and both of us had our credit card numbers stolen.  How do we know it happened at Fringale?  The charges began on both card the next morning, including at the Walgreens that's only 2 blocks from the restaurant.

Beware, and pay only in cash if you go
author: S S.

description:
Solid French fare in a comfortable, unassuming setting.

The pate was good, the grilled calamari was great!  Having tasted every one of my party's entrees, I thought the halibut was very tasty, the salmon was ordinary and I thought the sauce was a little too mayonnaisey.  The ribeye was fairly tasty, and my bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin was good, but I've had better.  Flourless chocolate cake was fantastic. 

The service was friendly, but I couldn't quite put my nose on a certain smell until near the end of my meal - it was B.O., not too pleasing.   In summary, I thought Fringale was like a lot of my SOMA experiences - some good dishes, some not so good.  Worth a try (maybe a return for the grilled calamari) but there are so many restaurants out there, nothing too compelling to come back to.
author: Jim W.

description:
YUM...

I had ordered the Poached Alaskan halibut, potato puree, piperade, artichokes, capers & olive tapenade...cooked to perfection and delicious!  

Looking forward to my next visit, I'll either order the Basque tuna burger or Salade Niçoise.  I've heard these are a must try...now to decide when to come back!
author: Grace J.

description:
Went to Fringale during the January Dine-About-Town.  The menu selected for this event was somewhat limited, so I went with the regular menu.

I had the rib eye steak, served with pomme frites.  It was yummy!!  The meat was really tender and flavorful.  I had the flourless chocolate cake for dessert - this is also good.  

Funny waiter.  Good service.
author: Ivy L.

description: Incredible food !!!!!!!!!!!!  Everything on the menu is wonderful- from starters to fini! I would write more, but it only makes me hungry !
author: Margaret A.

description: Excellent food and atmosphere and service. They are actually kind!  One of the few places where you can hear yourself think. The pork is excellent and the sides great.
author: m j l.

description: Delightful. The special coq au vin was amazing, I couldn't stop eating it. The Mme Angeles dessert almond cake with custard was heaven. Charming service and atmosphere.
author: Jessica G.

description:
Such a disappointment.  I came here with some friends the other night.  Other than our nice waiter, service was rude and snooty.  Our food was really crappy -- dry fish, super fatty steak, overcooked chicken breast, the list goes on.  It wasn't just average -- it was not good.  The wine list was boring and their glasses tiny.  These people are cutting corners all over the place and it shows. 

And the price tag?  Ridiculously high.  

I had been to Fringale before the ownership changed, and it was much better then.  This place no longer lives up to its reputation.

All in all, I felt like an American tourist getting ripped off in a Parisian restaurant.  

Several hours later, I puked my brains out, and sadly I still can't decide if it tasted better on the way down or on the way back up.
author: marie m.

description:
It's really too bad about Fringale, but not unexpected in a city where a Michelin star might separate a truly great restaurant from the merely tasty. Where abundant fresh ingredients and world-class spirits encourage the entertain-at-home Martha Stewards among us to do just that, it takes more than understated elegance, consistently good food, and a top shelf bar to draw them out for more.

It takes great service, devoid of pretense, and drawn from a true love for entertaining people, no? Too many times have I been enlisted in the defense of the French when it comes to service, who (like the Chinese), more often than not, expect more from their American customers than they would ever demand of themselves. Too quick are they to exit, stage right, when faced with a request off the menu.

Thirsty for a refreshing Pinot Grigio (not French enough for inclusion?), and eschewing the so yesteryear selection of whites, we who were celebrating my sister's 50th anniversaire decided to challenge the bartender to create a special cocktail in her honor. To our dismay, our waitress informed us that there was no grapefruit juice. Il n'y a pas de jus de pamplemousse!

What do the French have against grapefruit?

It was a lie, of course, but to what end? Wouldn't the Petty Bourgeoisie be happier with a Chardonnay, she seemed to ask, with arched brow? We quickly moved past her to address the man behind the black stools, who quickly produced tiny, familiar cans of Del Monte.

Ah ha! we exclaimed, and though disappointed with the lack of pink, we ordered two with Mandarin, Rose's, a squeeze of lime, and soda, shaken long and vigorously, and served straight up. Birthday girl, also a bartender of suspicious nature, ordered Petrone Silver with a soda back. Smart. What came back for us was on the rocks. We sent them back. What finally arrived looked like the same drinks on stems, no froth, definitely not shaken. Incroyables!

Have the French abandoned pride for prejudice? Or perhaps, being the first table for lunch, these two just weren't ready to entertain. Regardless, the chef appeared ready to please. The beet salad was as succulent as ever, the crusted Sea Bass tender and almost too buttered, the calamari divine. And please, before the Petty Bourgeois Americans ban fois gras from the politically correct banquet, you must indulge in the little points at Fringale.

But beware the Carpaccio. For some reason the chef has overlooked the marvels of capers and lemon juice, for too much mustard.
 
How American.
author: John Z.

description:
This little place was a great find for us.  We had a big group going to see Cirque and we searched the area using open table and this is the only place that had space.

I really wasn't sure what to expect but the food was excellent.  I had one of the more mundane dishes in the group, but it was still pulled off nicely.  The crispy skin chicken was just as advertised - crispy!  It is also worth your while not to skip dessert. 

Prices are also pretty good if you want something nice in this area but don't want to break the bank, most entrees are under $20.

The service left a little to be desired given the price of things on the menu, but I'm willing to write that off to the whole big group situation.
author: Raven B.

description:
Take a little journey with me if you will... a friend of mine told me about a great dining out "experience" that SF does in January. I immediately went online and made reservations to 3 different restaurants, Fringale being one of them. We've always wanted to go to a nice French dive and based on the reviews from Zagat and Yelp, we chose Fringale.
On a side note, the "experience" is basically a 3 course meal for a set price, no questions asked. Some places already have their 3 course meal planned in advance, no substitutions.

So, we got there, sat down, got our water and then told the waiter that we were there for the 3 course special dinner. He steps away and two minutes later, comes back to tell us that they don't start this "experience" for 2 more days. That was it... nothing else but a long awkward pause... So we said okay, and thanks and got up to leave. I was hoping they would accommodate us somehow but nothing... All we got was a sorry, come again! Right... no thanks. 

Think about it, even if they did accommodate us and let us enjoy a 3 course meal for the set price we were going to pay, they would have made more money than the big fat $0 they got from us walking out the door. Not to mention, the waiter made no tip and from the looks of it he wasn't going to be getting much anyway (there were only 6 other people in the whole place).

So America, here's YOUR tip: This place gets 1 star for lack of customer service.

I'm sure the food's great, but we'll never know.
author: Rebecca J.

description: My quest for decent French food goes on.  I am again amazed at how generous San Franciscans are with bad restaurants.  Fringale is one star.  There is not anything they did well. The décor had a little charm, but I found it to be bland.  The service was rude, inattentive and at times incompetent.  For each course, the waiter switched our courses.  Since one of us ordered a prix fixe menu, you would think he could figure it out, but he didn't.  Every dish fell far short of acceptable.  The corn soup was bland and runny.  The scallop salad was too sour and overpowered the mild taste of the scallop.  My seafood stew (kind of like a bouliabase) was fishy.  The fish was overcooked, not fresh and under-seasoned.  My friend's duck confit was under-flavored and dry.  In addition, they served it with lentil stew, so the dish was a brown blob that was a one note in terms of flavor and texture.  How do you screw up duck cooked in duck fat?  Well go to Fringale and find out.  Nothing came out hot (like warm at best).   If I could give this place zero stars I would, but I have to settle with one star.  Looks like I have to travel to Napa or better yet New York to find good French food in the US.
author: Scott C.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend for the dine around town last weekend. We had a really good experience. 

So, my boyfriend got the dungeness crab napoleon and I ordered the calamari. My boyfriend LOVES his dish, and my dish was SO BIG for an appetizer which is always a plus! The calamari was also VERY tasty!

I got the lamb for entree, and my boyfriend ordered the hanger steak. The steak was also very tasty and I actually enjoyed his dish more than mine. 

Very cozy restaurant, and service was great!
author: Willa L.

description: it was good dining experience. Got TWO complimentary desserts at the end! They were awesome although I am not fond of creme brulee. Good service. Went there for DAT last year.
author: Cliff T.

description:
Ive been here about 3-4 of times (lunch, regular dinner, dine about town) and each time was very pleasant. the restaurant itself isn't fancy shmancy but good food doesnt require that. 
i love french food and it's great to see a restaurant not being overly posh but keeping it simple and succulent. 
their wine selection is really great too!
author: Mary O.

description:
Would not go again!  Better places in the neighborhood.

I've been there twice now on different nights and both times it was just ok.  The food is ok depending on what your order. The duck is good, but the rest of the meat selections are mediocre.  

The service was atrocious! If you're spending over $250 for a dinner you would think you wouldn't have to clear your own glasses, find yourself some silverware and have the waiter throw down your dessert and say "you figure it out!"  I've heard the french are rude, but come on!!

I'd prefer going to COCO500 right next door any day. Much much better service and much better food!
author: Tomisha D.

description:
We went for dinner for my daughter's birthday. The maitre d' put us in a corner although the restaurant was almost empty. When we asked for a better table he said that it will get crowded later ??? The table we had requested was never used between 6:30pm and 9:00pm while we were there. The appetizers were good but the main courses were just OK. Nothing exciting, including the presentation. The veal was more like a home cooked meal. The mussels had too much vinegar in the sauce, the vinegar taste was overpowering everything else. I had the duck confit which came with a spoon of cooked lentils. I expected to also see more seasonal dishes but they offered just butternut squash soup.

We were quite disappointed service and meal wise.
author: Simona N.

description: This place is not crackin'. It is overpriced for the caliber of food it offers. (Don't get me started on the portion sizes. I know French restaurants give you close to nothing, but come on, I'm a growing man!) I had the pork tenderloin, which was OK. There was nothing about it that was special. You can get way better food at way better prices at Home or Osha Thai. Just don't go here; we're in a recession, save your money and go somewhere cheap. Your wallet and taste buds will thank you for it.
author: Kevin D.

description:
5 stars on the service
4 stars on food quality
3 stars on food quantity 

We went with a group of folks for a friend's birthday party. The service was top notch with bread replenished and dishes taken away immediately when you're done. 

I ordered the roasted rack of lamb and although the portion was tiny, the lamb was very good and tender. I really don't like the eggplant caviar side though because 1) I'm not a big fan of eggplant and 2) upon trying it, I hated it. (Reminds me of p-k-) but the potato gratin was wonderfully creamy. 

Now had we split the bill accordingly to what we ordered, the night would've been great but it was split evenly... Darn, we should've opt for the steak and some appetizers.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Fringale is excellent. I've been there for dinner four times over the last year or so, and I've been impressed each time.  Here are some of the highlights:

- Beet salad special: Excellent mix of flavors. Not too heavy. Perfect start to meal with a glass of white wine.

- Crab napoleon:  I would come in just to eat this appetizer. Very light and refreshing way to start dinner. You can easily split it -- it's not huge, but you will get several bites each.  The last time I visited, my companion and I split this and the beet salad for starters.

- Lamb: Delicious. Very moist, tender, and flavorful. The potato gratin that comes with the lamb is very good, too.

- Ribeye:  Also very moist, tender, and flavorful. Not too fatty. The red wine butter is addictive and the fries are perfectly crisp.

- Bread pudding: Delicious. Interesting blend of flavors, including banana and coconut. Order with a coffee. 

Why not five stars?  It can be a bit cramped and the chairs are not the most comfortable. But don't let that keep you away. This is a true neighborhood gem -- superb food at reasonable prices given the quality and ambience.
author: Lynn F.

description:
This is my long overdue review for Fringale...

I like that this place is casual and elegant at the same time.  There is also a particular waiter that could be cast in a James Bond movie.  Il est un bel homme, sensuel.  You know you're fine.  So let's get to the food.  I always like it when they refill your water, cold water, thank you.  

I ordered the chicken mousse terrine which I spread all over the bread.  This was one of my favorite dishes.  By the way, I think they get the bread from Tartine.  On to the main dish, roasted chicken with squash and brussel sprouts.  This dish could have been parfait, if there was a little more squash.  Better yet make it entirely a squash dish.  The chicken could of had more flavor and juice.  And for dessert, my favorite part of any meal, was the warm chocolate gourmand accompanied by a scoop of vanilla ice cream with raspberry sauce and candied orange peels.  The chocolate wasn't very sweet, but bittersweet which worked great with the contrast to the sweet vanilla ice cream. 

I'll be back to try more.  And see more.
author: Glu C.

description:
I saw the San Francisco D.A. eating here when I went in for lunch.  Kudos for attracting the rich & famous electable types, Fringale!

Otherwise, this is a great space, with great light, and great service, and a great list of wines by the glass -- which is all great.  The food is solid, but a tad light/local/organic/small plates-y/farmer's market-y for my mood that day.  I was all steak-and-potatoes-minded, and they were all herbs-and-organic-arugula-minded.  I will go again, though.
author: Ann M.
Jiajia C.

description:
"Fringale" means "the urge to eat" and definitely lived up to his name.  Service was exceptional even by American standards -- I went in expecting French snobbiness and instead got a maitre 'd and waiter with yummy French accents bringing the most delightful food.  

This place is great for cozy romantic dining; it made me feel like I was eating in a friend's dining room with a personal 5-star chef instead of being in SoMa.  It isn't too hard on the wallet either:  we went for Dine About Town and just ended up ordering from the regular menu b/c there was so much else I wanted to try!
author: Erica Y.

description:
The food was pretty good.  Some people in our group ordered the DAT menu, others ordered off the regular menu.

Here are the courses we had:

prawns in pastis with sun dried tomatoes   
Spicy calamari & chorizo    
frisee salad   
crab salad
ribeye steak
pork tenderloin
filet of sole
some other fish dish that was cooked w/ tomatoes? (i believe it was halibut)
pomme frittes
flourless chocolate cake

The people who ordered off DAT were satisfied.  I liked my ribeye and crab salad.  My bf did not like his calamari nor did he like his halibut.  People also enjoyed their desserts.  Service was very friendly and efficient.  Nothing blew my mind but all the food was cooked well.

I would definitely go again minus the bf since he refuses to accompany me back.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
Came here yesterday for lunch with 2 of my girlfriends for an indulgent mid week lunch because I could not resist the $21.95 pre-frix lunch price in the dine about town menu. So glad I did because it was delicious. 

We all had the sautéed prawns in Pastis with sun dried tomatoes, there were plenty of perfectly cooked prawns and the sauce was rich and flavorful. My friends had the sole with risotto and I had the lamb. My lamb was wonderful and really made the lunch feel decadent. My friends enjoyed their sole, I thought it was a little to heavy for my liking for a fish dish, but they seemed to enjoy so it was a win win. One of my friend's and I finished with the hazelnut and roasted almond mousse cake which was absolutely divine. The texture of the mousse was heavenly, the thin sponge cake was just right to hold it all together and then the chocolate sauce was amazing. My other friend had the sorbet which was good, but tasted like sorbet usually does.

I would love to come back, but although I paid $21.95, normally my meal would have run $44 and right now that is not something I can stomach for lunch. Maybe when the economy isn't in the shit hole I will treat myself again.
author: Sophia D.

description:
A friend booked this place for dine about town. A decent prix-fixe menu, a small cosy restaurant, and good service.

To start: A generous slice of pate with sides of baby greens, mini pickles (?), and toasted bread with a side of dijon mustard. A thoughtful and well balance assortment, very tasty. The pate was not terribly salty and had good flavor. The dijon was a nice touch. The mini-pickles help to cleanse the palate in between the little open-faced pate sandwiches you can construct. Eat the baby greens, they're good too. It's all good.

Entree: Hanger steak in a red wine sauce, served with pommes frites. A staple at many French restaurants, and executed very well here. The steak came partially pre-sliced and was a bit smaller than I expected. If I hadn't eaten more than half a pizza at Cheeseboard earlier, I would have been hungry afterwards. My med-rare steak was delicious, tender, and full of flavor. Even better, the outside had been seared to a slightly crispy perfection with hints of rubbed-in spices. The red wine sauce was fabulous, not over-powering, but a nice complement to the natural flavors of the steak. The fries were also really good, crispy, and not too oily. You must utilize the fries to soak up every last drop of the red wine sauce mixed with the steak juices. Think of your poor friends sitting at home eating Lean Cuisine.

Dessert: You must order the chocolate gourmand. Read the other reviews on Yelp, its legend grows daily. Let me tempt you, just a little bit. A flour-less, warm, chocolate brownie, topped with a scoop of ice cream and drizzled with a raspberry sauce. It's unbelievably soft, moist , and decadent, but not so sweet you need to chase with water. A good size dessert, even if you think you're full, with proper motivation and determination you can will yourself to victory. It will fill in the cracks, believe me.

I was close to giving Fringale five stars, but it wasn't orgasmically good. The prix-fixe menu for dine about town made it good value though. Perhaps I'll come back and try something different from their regular menu.
author: Kenny J.

description:
Apparently Fringale is in the middle of changing chefs, which would explain the inconsistency of the food.  Stick with the coq-au-vin and you will be fine.

I found the service to be a little over the top French rude as well, which kind of rubbed me the wrong way on top of the food.  Add that to the fact that the bartender thought Talisker was a Vodka, and you get 3 stars.
author: Steve S.

description:
I think it is very hard to rate restaurants independent of the actual company and experience.  My company was fantastic. Five Stars or better. The service was fantastic, but food just wasn't enough to push to four stars... If our conversation had been derailed by how good the food was,  that would have been four to five stars. 

Things I did like:

I loved that we were not rushed. We arrived early from work and stayed quite late. Our waiter Xavier was awesome, did a great job with his wine selection, and who can argue with bright blue eyes and a cute French accent.  The atmosphere was really great. 

Fois Gras was awesome, and my favorite thing of the evening. I had the duck, which was nice. Artichoke salad, not all that exciting. 

And the cutest thing, was when my date suggested that we take all of the leftovers, so we could give them to a homeless person. How thoughtful.
author: Danielle V.

description:
I came here a while ago with my family, and we all enjoyed ourselves. Fringale is a small place, and there was certainly a wait, but it was worth it. The floor staff was very friendly and helpful--our waitress clearly explained the meaning behind the restaurant's name, and the food was just great.

I forget what kind of salads we shared since this was a while ago, but one of our salads had what I believe was Asian Pear in it, and that was just fantastic. I'm usually not a big fan of fruity salads that somehow make you hungrier than before, but this one was on point.

The Halibut over peas. Try it. Really, just fantastic. The sauce just worked perfectly with the dish and I wouldn't hesitate to order it again.

Cool place.
author: Edmund C.

description:
Really enjoyed this quaint bistro style place. Everything we ordered was lovely; I only wish I could have tried more dishes.

Foie gras: the pineapple chutney and micro green salad added the perfect sweet and bitter complement. A fantastic dish.

Bouillabaisse: saffron infused deliciousness with fresh seafood.

Duck confit: Brilliant. The lentils were well seasoned and the texture was perfect. Rich and earthy.

Lamb: Perfectly cooked, and the au gratin potatoes were yum (not too rich). Haricot vert was a hit as a side.

I'm bummed we didn't try the desserts but we were perfectly stuffed. Overall, I was quite impressed. And I have to hand it to our server, who, despite stereotypes about the French, was unbelievably patient with our party and very charming. A solid 4 stars.
author: Leah Y.

description:
My favorite restaurant, hands down, in SF. Been here 10-12 times since I moved back from the NYC. Great for out-of-towners from big cities who are getting tired of the same 'ol same 'ol trendy scene, and simply want an extremely enjoyable, elegant, classy and well-prepared meal.

Steak & frites are a must. Foie gras is a must. Calamari app is a must. Mussels are a must. Sea bass is a must. Chocolate gourmand is a must. Ravioli is a must. Etc, etc.

Says a lot that Fringale was around long before the gentrification of the neighborhood. It was a top-rated restaurant back then, and continues to be today.
author: Veronica S.

description:
The menu online looked tasty so I was really looking forward to dining here.  I made reservations on OpenTable.com for 8pm but we showed up early and they seated us promptly.  The restaurant isn't huge but the space was cozy without feeling crowded and claustrophobic.  Nice ambiance and everyone seemed to be enjoying themselves.

We ordered the spicy calamari as a shared starter.  It was REALLY tasty, super tender calamari with great flavors...could've been spicier though, but that's generally how I feel about most foods.  Then for the main course, I chose the chicken breast w/frisee salad and chantarelle mushrooms.  My friend ordered the halibut with peas & bacon.  Both looked lovely.  The chicken was great.  Crispy skin, great flavor, and a huge piece of juicy chicken breast.  The frisee salad and mushrooms were great, very tasty.  The mushrooms were a little too salty at times though.  The halibut looked tasty also.  However, only the outside really was good, great flavor or crunch, the inside was too soft so the texture really broke down.  We also ordered a side of sauteed spinach.  Good & basic, couldn't go wrong here.

The service was not bad, but could've been a little more attentive.  I finished my coke and no one came by to ask if I needed a refill.  But everyone was generally nice.  It's possible they were unstaffed that night?

All in all, the food was good and I would come back to try other things on the menu.  It's in a not too crowded neighborhood, so parking wasn't a pain.
author: Winnie L.

description:
I've been a couple times for lunch (never for dinner). I was expecting more. The service is excellent, but the quality vs. price of the food doesn't line up for me. 

I'd go back anytime...as long as someone else is picking up the bill.
author: Amanda S.

description:
I went last night, a Wednesday, and it was packed. The very french waitress said it was due to Dine About Town. I have to say, the crowd was young and good looking - prob another result from D.A.T. 

Our service was scattered due to, I think, 2 larger parties that potentially sucked away our waitress into neverneverland for great amounts of time (no fault of theirs of course). Once we did order, and we all ended up ordering off of the a-la-carte, the service picked up.

I had the prawns in pastis - amazing though rich. We lapped up the sauce with bread and cleaned the plate. Others enjoyed the calamari (little dry for my taste), beet and goat salad (yummy), and the crab and celery root salad (quite light and refreshing). For mains, I had the lamb which was very well prepared at a medium rare and extremely rich but flavorful potatoes gratin. Others had the steak et frites (I should have ordered this) - the meat was cooked perfectly, the frites were a little too Americanized (too large), they were not steak frites enough. Someone else had chicken, not sure how it was really.

I should mention the wine list began with two dissapointments. Our first wine selected was not available (a Gigondas) and the second was a different year than originally stated. We tried it nonetheless at the urging of the manager or front of house person in charge, it was not great, a disappointment perhaps. OUr second bottle, the waitress recommended and it was quite delicious. Of course, since i didnt actually see it on the menu, i dont recall any details about the wine except that it went well with the lamb and steak.

dessert was just ok. the tarte tartin should have been better and the chocolate cake was just ok. i am sure there are more tasty sweets but we didnt order them. My friend did order a nice digestif, something framboise, and it was tasty.

overall, except odd wine and timing of service, i had a very nice food and dining experience. perhaps if you go, see if there are two parties of 10 that night before booking...
author: Hilary H.

description:
I had seriously high expectations for Fringale, as everyone I know who has dined here has absolutely loved it. A coworker's wife still talks about their dinner here, 3 years later.

So what went wrong? Maybe because it was a late-ish reservation (9:30)? Maybe because they had at this point seen a full month's worth of Dine About Towners? I don't know. But 3 of the 4 dishes ordered were absolutely pointless. 

I started with a fois gras terrine, that when delivered, must have made me look like you had just read Dostoevsky to the dog--I just didn't get it. Someone had taken a can of the stuff out of the fridge, cut a slab off, put it on my plate, and brought it out to me. There was nothing about it that took any care or thought. I love fois gras. This is the first time in my life I've ever been bored by it.

It was the same deal with my companion's venison pate. Bland, tasteless.

Ok, second course. I know what Bourdain said about mussels in Kitchen Confidential, but I've been craving mussels, and they're in season, so I thought... well, look, I thought wrong. These were the most pathetic little retard mussels that must have literally been at the bottom of the barrel, or net, or however the damned things are caught. AND they were cooked badly! I went to Plouf a few days later just to confirm I hadn't gone crazy. They served me mussels the size of my fist, in a very nice sherry garlic sauce.

My companion's pork tenderloins was the highlight of the meal. Spot on. Wish we got four courses of that instead.

Dessert was unremarkable. Oh, I remember what we had. I only wish I could reclaim the space in my brain where that bit of information lives.

Service was disappointing. Our waiter recommended every other bottle of wine on the list, brought out my companion's dessert before I was even offered a menu (she ordered from the DAT menu; I did not), and tried to compensate by pouring ONE glass of dessert wine, for her.

And yet... I will likely go back. Not soon. But I will. I feel like this was a fluke, because Everyone Loves Fringale. We'll see.
author: Daniel K.

description:
OMG yelp just crapped out on me and erased my review when I tried to submit the thing!!! Ugh! Take 2...

I was there for Dine About town and ordered from the DAT menu.  Mussels, flat iron steak, and apple tarte tartin is what I had and my sister ordered the pate, salmon, and chocolate gourmand which all i had a chance to taste.  Nothing hit the spot, which was a disappointment because we were both starving.  It was almost as if they didn't try too hard with the menu.  Maybe you might have a better experience if ordering from the regular menu.  

To be fair, we were seated right away without a reservation at 6:30pm on a Thursday, which was really nice, and their goose and tonics were excellent. :)
author: Yve T.

description:
I went to Fringale  for lunch on a late Thursday afternoon with a party of 8. Being that it was around 2, the restaurant was not too busy so we were served very attentively.

I had the crab napoleon appetizer - guacamole, crab, and tomatoes which was very rich with large, chunky crab - highly recommended.

For the entree I had the duck confit. It was served over a bed of lentils in some mixture of duck fat and some herby, gravy like sauce. The duck was great. The leg and thigh had very crispy skin with very moist duck meat.

Sadly for my diet, I did not know that the lentil sauce was essentially melted duck fat and I naively dipped about a quarter of a loaf of bread into it. What can I say, fat tastes delicious.

It is rather pricy, though.
author: Hendson L.

description:
I went with my girlfriends a few days ago. It's a small cozy place. The owner wasn't very warm, to us anyway, but our waiter was very kind and attentive and even entertained our girly energy, which yes, can get very annoying.

We had
Appetizer: 
-Prawns in sun dried tomatoes. You get about 6 medium sized prawns in a savory sauce. I loved dipping my bread ( which you have to ask for if you want it) into it.
Entrees, we shared
-Duck Confit over lentils, Halibut with peas, prosciutto, and cabbage, grilled rib eye with pomme frittes. All very good and flavorful. My favorite was the halibut, though the sauce was a tad rich for me. But since we shared entrees, it wasn't too much.
Dessert:
Banana Chocolate Bread Pudding, soooo delicious and the Hazelnut torte. That was just ok.

Overall, a good experience.
author: Kat T.

description:
I have frequented this restaurant on numerous occasion in the past 3 years. It is still really good even after the previous French chef left. Only one downer, the host who seats you, is not friendly to us. Even though we are French and frequent this place, he pretends to no recognize us. Other than him, the staff is nice.

This place serves flavorful and yet sophisticated to simple French dishes. The ingredients are fresh and high quality. I usually order the calamari, salad frisee, and seafood Basquaise or Steamed Mussels (Moule). Delicious! I consider this place gastronomic even though it is set up like a bistro. The deserts are great too. Did I mention that the service is impeccable and attentive! The wait staff run to attend to me whenever I make eye contact with them. The ambience is candle lit and romantic. The price is very reasonable. The decoration is contemporary and charming.
author: N G.

description:
Last night's dinner at Fringale was fantastic! I went with some friends of discriminating taste for Dine About Town. Here's the rundown:

The restaurant itself is cozy (read: very small) and classy, and the service was somehow both extremely polite AND extremely French (I kid; but I also have never heard anyone say 'bon apetit' without sounding cheesy before). Fringale is not exactly vegetarian-friendly. I would not recommend coming here with vegetarians because they would not be able to eat any of the entrees (I'm not detracting a star because it's the vegetarians' own fault if they come here!). However, my appetizer and dessert were scrumptious and completely friendly to various dietary restrictions. Tip: they do not accept any substitutions to menu items. The bill for 6 people, including tax, tip, various surcharges for SF health and big groups, came out to $47 per person. I went home pleasantly full and happy, with slightly less than the expected damage to my bank account. Not bad at all! 

What I ordered:
- Uber-fancy ravioli appetizer (other choices were calamari and scallops; I tried both but was glad I hadn't ordered either one as I'm not a seafood person). Flavorful and delicious, and 3 big pieces were actually just the right amount of food!
- The BEST steak I've ever had (the other choices were duck and fish). This lovely filet mignon came with fries and green beans, which were very simple but very good. I didn't ask for ketchup because that would have been crass, so I commandeered the red wine marinade floating around the plate to do the job. The beans were precisely the way green beans are supposed to be cooked (crunchy and bright green).
- Stupendous creme brulee for dessert (other desserts were almond mousse cake or Chocolate Gourmand, which is fancy talk for brownie+ice cream - my choice was clearly the best). It was a good-sized, perfectly-caramelized portion.
- I also ordered a plain latte, which was very tasty and gourmet and all that, but not the best I've ever had. No harm done; Fringale isn't a cafe so I don't care. 

All in all, a fantastic meal at a lovely restaurant. I would definitely go again!
author: Namita D.

description: Love, love, love it.  Fantastic food in an utterly charming setting.  Great for an intimate date.  Duck confit was just excellent.
author: Patrick S.

description:
When we arrived at Fringale, and stepped out of the cab it felt like i was being transported to a Parisian neighborhood. Entering the quaint dining room you greeted with the aromas of herbs, roasted meats and savory seafood. I was salivating before even being sat.  

We wanted to try several items so we opted to center our attention on the seductive selection of appetizers. First we started with the calamari, "al la plancha" with chorizo and jalapeno. The texture and mix of spicy flavors were amazing. 

Next, we were on to the foie gras terrine with a nectarine comptoe and toasted brioche. The dungeness crab was a beautiful paring avocado, tomato and creme fraiche. 

For my main dish I chose the duck confit, which in my opinion is some of the best I have had, and I lived in Paris. The skin is crispy and cooked to perfections the lentils add a superb contrast and compliment the savory flavor of the duck.

The mussels are plump, full and steamed with the aroma of white wine, shallots, and garlic. Great for dipping the crusty bread. All was delicious, and was washed down with a lovely sancerre that is available by the glass.

Dessert = Flourless chocolate cake!
author: Tammy P.

description: Fixed menu was a good choice.  Crab lasagna was alright.  It was the beef bourgignon and chocolate gourmand dessert that made the trip to this tiny restaurant really worth it.
author: Kevin C.

description: We've been in the neighborhood for 5 years and only discovered this gem tonight.  We judge a French restaurant by the duck confit and the creme brulee.  Both were excellent.  The appetizer (shrimp in a pastis sauce) was light and delicious.  We also had pork wrapped in bacon.  Does in get any better?  The food was great, prices were reasonable.  Service was great.  The waiters were very knowledgable and recommended good wine pairings with the food (actually cheaper than the initial bottle that we were considering).  Digestifs were great as well.  Very nice cognac.  Definitely going back
author: Jordan W.

description:
This has become another favorite neighborhood dining spot. It's steps away and the food has been fantastic each time I've gone. I've only had the Calamari a la plancha which was very unusual and absolutely worth it. I've had the pork tenderloin, the rib eye, and the fish basquaise. I think the pork tenderloin wrapped in bacon has been my favorite. I recently had my family visit and I treated them to dinner there. I've never seen my mom finish up anything so quickly. My sister is very picky, especially with steak and I never thought a french restaurant would be the place for a good ribeye...but it was very tender and the flavors in the marinade were fantastic. Our favorite was definitely the chocolate gourmond. It's so decadent you feel like you just cheated on your partner and just had the best sex in your life...that's how good the chocolate induced endorphin rush is. Honestly, I'd go for the gourmond alone.

I'm giving Fringale 4 stars instead of 5 because of 2 issues...first is their pres fixe menu. It was advertised on their window but it wasn't clear that you had to order by 6:30 pm for dinner. My second issue occured when I had a friend visiting. I had talked up Fringale and knew they closed at 10...we arrived their shortly before 9 and were told the kitchen closed early because it was a slow night. I had not bothered to make reservations because the place is not usually too crowded on weeknights. This was very disappointing. If you say you're open until a certain time you should commit to it.
author: Rene A.

description:
Came here as part of the Appetite Stimulus Plan - 3 course prix fix for $35. From the menu, selected the Crab Ravioli appetizer (very rich sauce, 3 raviolis), Veal Osso Bucco entree (rich saucy, super tender, yum!), and Creme Brulee dessert (nicely done, crisp brulee top). 

I would have also chosen the prix fixe as well but I could not ignore the call of the Duck Confit. Served with lentils "Du Puy" in a red wine sauce  ($19), the duck was prepared perfectly, crisp skin, tender meat that forked off. A little much on the lentils, wouldn't have minded a little leafy greenery to break up the brown coloring.

Should also mention my starter of the Soup du Jour - which was Chestnut soup that day. It was delicieux. Mmmm. Perfect in the cold SF evening, flavored with mushrooms, the soup had a nostalgic warmth. 

I would definitely want to go back to try the other menu items.
author: Cindy W.

description:
This was my first French dining experience in the city. I wanted to try a restaurant from the Dine About Town list and my bf wanted to try a french restaurant. I choose this place because the online menu looked good.

We arrived to find ourselves seated by the window, eating in a quaint restaurant. Tables are roomed very close together, so close that my seat kept getting bumped by the person behind me. Food was pretty good (good in the sense that I already knew that I wanted to come back) and service okay.
author: Janel Y.

description:
Was very excited to try the dine about menu. The place is very cute, small and quiet. Definitely not a place you want to unload all your secrets or have a lively group. It was a bit uncomfortable when catching up with a friend, maybe a great place for a date where all you do is make googly eyes at one another. :-)  

The staff was not super friendly. We were oddly standing there waiting to be seated in a half filled room when we came in with a reservation. Our waiter made our dining experience uncomfortable as well. When we were ordering wine, we had asked for a taste and then wanted to order our wine before our food but he was not quick enough. His response was, "sorry I have other patrons". We understood but it took him over ten minutes to come back so by the time we had our wine, our food came out at the same time...and I hate that....

Our food was tasty but the crab napolean too buttery instead of refreshing and the lamb shank lacked some flavors although very tender. It was not as imagined. The desserts were delicious. I remember when asking for a dessert wine, we asked for something similar to a moscato and the waiter said " I wouldn't know, its not french". The rudeness was not necessary.

I've spoken with other friends who have had this same waiter and noted the same problems with this restaurant. Not what I want in a dining experience.
author: Kalifornia S.

description:
Fringale is Basque style french food and highly enjoyable.

They lose a star with me because of the location, the room and the waiter not being terribly helpful. I had the duck confit and it was done really well - cooked appropriately, presented nicely and paired well with other foods. One of the folks I was there with had the Scotish Salmon - she thought it was great. It looked great.

Fringale reminds me of a little place that I used to love on Rue Lauriston in Paris called Le Etoille.

So I said that it lost a star because of a few factors: the room is small and was shockingly loud last night, which kills the environment. It  looks quiet and serene and just wasn't.  After dinner, we stood in the street for 15 minutes, shuffling our feet and making small talk before we finally got a cab out of this corner of SOMA....even though the folks at Fringale had called a cab for us.

I would definitely go back and am thinking of doing just that, while I'm still on the Left Coast on this trip.
author: Brad B.

description:
I dined her last Thursday night with a group of coworkers for the Dine About Town special.  I love French food and was excited to try out Fringale. Let me just say that the food was DELISH. Definitely four stars. I ordered the pate, coq au vin and hazelnut/almond mousse - it was a party in mouth, seriously. So overall, no complaints about the food. 

Unfortunately I can't say the same about the service. 
1) Our waiter poked me in the back with a steak knife while leaning over me to hand someone in front of me a knife.  Seriously, stabbed in the back. (Clearly an exaggeration, but still...) I yelled "ouch" pretty loudly and he did not notice so I brought it to his attention because I was so horrified and he gave me a very insincere apology. Like no big deal. Brushed it off her shoulders. Um, EXCUSE ME? If this is supposed to be a fine dining experience, their wait staff should not be so careless with sharp objects.

2) We were seated by the entrance to their kitchen and every time the waiters walked by, they would knock my purse off my chair. Which isn't the issue here. The issue is that at the end of my exquisite meal, I leaned back into my chair and got blind sided on back of my head with a platter from a waiter walking by. How he didn't notice is a shock to me. He just walked on by. No sorries. NOTHING. Atrocious. Absolutely atrocious. 

I would come back because I thought the food was delightful but i hope that the owners read this and ask their wait staff to be more attentive of where they're swinging their limbs.  I would've said something to the manager at the time I dined there but I didn't want to embarrass the rest of my group.
author: Felicia H.

description:
Great place to get lunch or savour a delicious and intimate dinner. It's so simple looking from outside that you could almost miss it.

PROS:
- This is authentic French food. Simple, small portions, flavorful and tasy to the last chomp!
- The wine list is simple and the selection is good
- The atmosphere is very provencial and you feel like you've entered a different world when you come through the door
- Friendly and efficient wait-staff

CONS:
- Seating can be a bit tight with chairs bumping other patron's chairs but its an experience in itself

I like it. It is a bit pricey so its a place I might frequent once in a while when I want to treat myself to really good food and the key to Fringale is one word - Simplicity!
author: Amit S.

description:
Overall 3: decent food and service, but definitely not good enough to come back.
Food: 3
Service: 3.5
Ambiance: 2

Food: 3
Pate Campagne (appetizer): chunky in texture - not what I expected, not flavorful, served with mustard and pickles - just weird. I'm a bit pate/foie gras fan, but this was big disappointment.
Calamari (appetizer): lightly stir fried with bell peppers. Very bland and flavors didn't work. Not worth ordering at all.
Duck Confit w Lentils in Red Wine Sauce (entrée): duck was moist, lentils were good, overall flavor was good but not excellent.
Pork Tenderloin wrapped in bacon w cabbage: amazingly super dry - worth sending it back (but we're too nice to do that).
Hazelnut Mousse Cake w Almond Flakes: for hazelnut lovers you should order it. Loved the contrasting texture with the crunchy almond flakes and flavors were rounded out with a wonderful chocolate sauce. However, it's 3/4 mousse and 1/4 cake. I would've preferred a higher cake ratio.

Service: 3.5
Decently friendly. Took our coats as we were shoulder to shoulder. Weren't too happy that two people were 30 minutes late in a party of 18 which is reasonable.

Ambiance/Décor: 2
Kind of sad and old looking on the inside because interior was dim and painted a light salmon color.
author: Lily V.

description:
Small, busy yet fairly intimate restaurant that appears to crowd up around the bar pretty often.  Very French service - knowlegeable, efficient, but definately not chatty.  Direct & to the point, reserved even.
Food was great - the lamb pot au feu was marvelous, possibly the best broth I've ever had.  Just fantastically rich.  Great selection of reasonably priced French wine as well.  I recommend the Cahors - fantastic with food and a steal at $30!
author: Don H.

description:
This tiny restaurant, the closest to where we live, pleasantly surprised us.

We got a beet salad, and calamari appetizer. The chorizo in the calamari was awesome. Then we had a chicken entree and a lamb. Both were great. Service was good. Cocktails were good.
author: Sachin A.

description:
I came here on January 15th for Dine About Town. When the waiter took our order he mistook me for a girl, but I guess with my long hair he wasn't sure. He apologized profusely so I will not take off stars from the review.

The two people that joined me had the butter lettuce salad and mussels. My appetizer was the mussels which was just alright. They were not as good as Chapeau's (especially since they complement them with rouille and bread with pesto on it), so I'll leave it at that. I'm not sure what my friend thought about her butter lettuce salad, though she didn't finish it.

Our entrees were the hanger steak with pommes frites, salmon with mashed potatoes and the coq au vin. I ordered the coq au vin which was incredibly succulent; the meat fell off the bones. Unfortunately, I feel the dish was lacking; it mainly tasted of wine and something was left to be desired; that "something" wasn't there to complement the dish. Our friend also didn't finish her hanger steak nor pomme frites. The salmon was incredible, according to the girl; as it looked so. I had a little and I agreed it was probably the best thing on the menu; that is, until our chocolate gourmands came out. We all agreed it was great.

I think I need to come back another time to try things off the DAT menu,  but then again I know almost everything I get at Chapeau will be good.
author: Anthony K.

description:
Ate here a few days ago, after DAT ended.  I think that made the difference... Service was great, the food delicious, and the wines by the glass reasonable with a decent selection.  I liked the smaller feel of the restaurant and loved the French-accented servers.

The food was great.  I really enjoyed the Asian pear salad and the pate de campagne as appetizers.  The salmon was perhaps a little more cooked than I'd like, but very very good.  Their special of veal cheeks fell apart on the fork.  The almond torte was delicious, with a dense texture and a fantastic almond flavour.

We lingered a long time and no one rushed us.  I'll put it on my list of places worth revisiting.
author: Suzanne T.

description: This review is for the Dine About Town menu, which I've later learned that a lot of DAT menus really do not represent what a restaurant has to offer. Such is probably true for Fringale, because I know a lot of people love this place, yet what I had here was nowhere near satisfactory. The food was very under seasoned, flat iron steak was tough and the lamb stew meat was also tough. It's a mystery how a stew dish requires knife to cut the meat...
author: CS L.

description: I chose Fringale as my last choice for the "DAT" SF 2011 end of Jan series...It was the best one I picked this time around for DAT. Its a cute,french restaurant in the SOMA district. Right when I walked in the service was exceptional,friendly waiters and hosts that have French accents..My first course was the Dungeness Crab Napoleon. The presentation of this dish was a round and layered food item..there was a middle part of guacamole and crab meat was sandwiched on the top and bottom of the guacamole, and a bed of greens layed around it...my 2nd course was the lamb shank which was cooked perfectly that it would literally fall off the bone when I cut into it. For dessert, I had the Chocolat Gourmand. The cake was warm and there was vanilla bean ice-cream served on the top of it. The creme brulee is a good choice as well. Everything was perfect and the service was awesome!
author: Apple S.

description: Terrible service and over-priced, below average food. Have no idea why people are giving this place a high rating... avoid.
author: Mark L.

description:
Just went here for lunch with a couple of girlfriends for the S. Pellegrino dine-out. What a bargain! $20 for an appetizer, entre, and dessert. We tried the prawn ravioli in lobster bisque, the kabocha squash soup, the mussels, the salmon, and the petrale sole. For dessert we tried the creme carmel and the warm chocolate cake. Everything was delicious, the service was good, and we could actually hear ourselves talk. I would totally recommend this place... 

My only complaint: The meters out front get you only 5 minutes for each quarter and when we asked them to make change for us, they claimed they could only give us a dollar's worth. Lame. You'd think they'd have a big azz bag back there just for their customers.
author: L. M.

description:
I came here with high expectations but was utterly disappointed. Ordered the roasted chicken breast, it was well over cooked, rendering it chewy and tasteless. 

The only pleasing thing about this place was our French waiter. :) 

Good atmosphere but incredibly disappointing food. They should add some flavor, and they might be halfway to having something worth the money. Not inexpensive.
author: Seema H.

description:
If you've ever had this conversation with yourself, Fringale is for you: 

'OK, I'm a techie, I'm going on a date with another techie, and I need them to know I'm hip, with it, and pretty loaded. Unless they're a Googler and have tasted the pleasures of the free Japanese-Peruvian food on campus, this place will have me made in the shade.'
author: Carla C.

description:
Came here for the first time as our first stop in the Dine About Town tour this year.  Food and service were both excellent!!  Our waitress was so cute with her French accent.  We had five people so we got to try pretty much the whole DAT menu.  

The shrimp and tomatoes appitizers was very yummy.  It was a little small, but I don't think that is their normal size.  The sauce was so good that I ate like four peices of bread just to dip in in there.  

My bf got the ribeye and I had the lamb.  I was soooo jealous of his steak though, but he was sweet and shared with me. :) The lamb was just okay, very tender but not too much flavor, and I usually love lamb.  The steak however was perfect.  Very flavorful and tender, and huge!  It also came with a huge pile of fries, nice and crunchy.  We came back again for our anniversary dinner and both got the steak again.  So good!!  

Dessert -  they were out of the creme brulee, so they let us choose anything we wanted off their dessert menu.  Yay! Everything was very good. We each had a favorite.  Try their sorbet which they make themselves.  Perfect ending to a perfect meal. 

By the way, their prices are very decent for the quality of their food.  I think the average entree is about $20.  Also, there is usually plenty of street parking so you can spend that extra ten bucks on dessert!
author: Jenny C.

description:
I returned to Fringale and was absolutely wowed. We sat for a three hour dinner and enjoyed every last nibble. They make some absolutely amazing foie gras, which is delicate and creamy. My seafood dish was so robustly flavorful, and my husband's osso bucco was sublime enough to make me forget I was eating baby cow (sorry, baby cow!). 

The wine that our server suggested was absolutely perfect, too. I can't go on enough. We had such a wonderful evening at Fringale!
author: Sahra H.

description:
Came here for Dine About Town.  I ordered off the DAT menu and bf ordered off the regular menu.

We were super late for our reservation (bf's fault...I am nearly always punctual).  We had called to say we were going to be late, but the place is tiny so they had already given away our table.  They offered us two seats at the bar...we reluctantly look them.  The bartender was super nice.  All the reviews are saying the waiters are kinda rude, but this guy was overly nice.  The owner of the place did seem a little mean though.

Anyways, I got the mussels for my appetizer, HUGE portion...it could have been my entire meal!  I got chicken for my main course.  It was lacking flavor and the chicken was dry, but again portion was huge.  Dessert was warm chocolate gourmand...it was pretty good....great texture and flavor.

My bf's shrimp appetizer was also delish.  His pork entree....not so much.

So...I wouldn't go back to this place, but appetizers and desserts were good....so 3 stars for that!
author: Neety P.

description: We love to go to Fringale, because we know we will get a delicious French dinner, just as if we were in France. The duck confit is tender and moist, the foie gras is homemade, the calamar a la plancha is tasty and flavorfull. The wine list is great and the service attentive. What more could you ask for?
author: NATHALIE S.

description:
Darn.  The bf and I had been looking forward to this dinner, and we expected much better food & service.  

I had to say we started off on the wrong foot, as we got the last table in the back corner, next to the waiter's station where they were banging plates & silverware like 3yo's.  Man, what did those plates do to you?!  

We thought the food was hit-or-miss.  We started off with the pate (ok) & salad (meh).  Main courses were duck (dry/overcooked) and lamb (nothing to write home about).  The hazelnut mousse was to die for... if I come back, I'm showing up for dessert only... probably just to hang out at their cute bar!  

The service seemed pretty harried.  In their defense, the restaurant was almost full when we went in (at 8p), but it was half-empty by the time we left (9:15p).  Our waiter didn't know what the soup of the day was.  Whoa. C'mon now.

Was it because we were there during Restaurant Week?  Off day?  Dunno.  We went to Cafe Claude a few days before and the food/ambience/service was a lot better, which was unexpected.

Sincerely yours,
Bummed
author: Doreen S.

description:
me and my friends all did the dine about town thing. we get a 3 course meal for 34.99. the food was ok at best but the service was excellent. they somehow knew about two of our friends birthdays and surprised us at the end with the dessert.

not written by me.
but best thing here was the appetizer and great service.

some lady fainted so the ambulance came when we were about to leave. staff stayed calm. thats a definite plus.
author: kim w.

description:
Located in SOMA, Fringale is tucked away on the corner of 4th and Freelon St... This French restaurant is so quaint and cozy, with none of the pretentiousness that you might associate with French cuisine. The restaurant was filled with a diverse group of people which made for a very interesting dining experience! Since the dining room is a bit small, you will most likely be closer to other diners than what you're comfortable with. Fortunately, I was seated next to a very nice older couple that completely fascinated me. The night continued with a wonderful 3 course prix fixe. I started off with the crab ravioli, followed by the beef bourguinon as an entree, and finished with the classic creme brulee. All of the dishes that I had were excellent. The flavors were classically French but very subtle so that it does not overwhelm your palate. All in all, it was a steal considering the prix fixe was $30! 

Love it: Crab ravioli
Leave it: Sorbet
author: Nancy H.

description:
Mileu:
very small place.  the tables were so close together, i was not just eating with my friend, but 10 other people too.  Was I in Chinatown?(yes, i'm chinese, so don't call me racist)  I don't think so.  

Service:
great bartender.  we ordered our drinks when we came in and they even brought it to our table.  Nice people.

Food:
I'm not a huge lamb fan, or actually never been one, but to be honest.. i had the best lamb ever.  This place has made me like lamb now.  I've tried it so many times, but finally i have made peace with it.  hehehe  Appetizers and dessert was spectacular too.  I enjoyed it very much.  Get the prawns...yummmy

A definite recommendation for me.
author: M L.

description:
When I used to live in San Francisco, this was one of my most favorite places.  I always knew to *never* get the male French server in his 50s -- he was so French, right down to his rudeness.

That aside, the service was always magnifique and the food consistently fabulous, dahling.

Chic, well heeled clientele could be found here.  It's definitely for the discerning diner.
author: Carina M.

description:
I would've given this 5, except:

1) pommes frites were awful - wth?
2) service was rushed
3) puny, lame wine glasses - unless you order a tres expensive bottle.  I just don't like this - a beautiful pinot poured into a little glass when folks at the next table have legitimate, full glasses for their wine.  Not cool...

Granted, it was Dine About Town, but I expect better from Fringale.
author: Christine K.

description:
This place was very good :). Try the $28 half bottle of wine. The last one on the list, it was very good. 
I had the Angus steak, which was a pretty decent size and the Carpaccio. The carpaccio was pretty skimp and not as flavorful. Don't try that.

The next day I woke up with a sore throat. My body was telling me that this is place might be a little bit too salty and oily.
author: Dao C.

description:
My palate is easily bored, and Fringale never disappoints. From the entrees, to the plats, to the cheese course, to the dessert, it's always top-notch. It's quasi-Basque (French) cuisine, and absolutely delicious.

I have to knock down a star because, although we make reservations, we are ALWAYS kept waiting, which is predictable and quite annoying.
author: Akasha A.

description:
Being one of the 250 review-ees on here I will get straight to the point. 

First time to Fringale- Last Thursday on Valentine's day. 

The place is small but adorably quaint. The people are ridiculously French with their thick accents and je ne saix quoi about them. 

The food: Prefixed V-day Menu consisted of: 

Course 1: choice of some pear salad, some crab something and Quail! (Sorry to all you Monte Sereno people I am about to offend) The Quail was amazing. If I could, I would eat that bird for every meal! 
I almost ate all the bones it was that good. 

Course deux: blue cheese/brie with bread and fruit. Very French- but not a fan of blue cheese. My date ate his plate and mine. 

Course 3: Choice of halibut, chicken, and le beuf. Fillet came perfectly prepared with potatoes. By this part in the meal I was already drunk off our Bordeaux wine and which prevented my ability to politely eat the cow. I bagged it up and pan fried it the next day... even better than what I could remember the night before.

Course 4: my favorite: DESSERT. Due to my inebriated state my memory does not remember dessert as I had hoped. I do recall ordering the cream stuffed pears in a butterscotch sauce. The sauce alone could be a dessert- I believe I had drowned my fingers in it just so none was wasted. 

The entire restaurant was covered with pink, white and red heart balloons. Every table had a red rose- and at the end of the night I was able to take 3 for the road. 

Frigale deserves 5 stars not only because their food was to die for, but despite the Valentine's Day rush- the service was superb.
author: Nathalie D.

description:
This was a great little find on Yelp. Everything everyone else said was pretty much on the mark. Very French restaurant, and the waiters all had a very heavy french accent! It was a very quaint place.

I made a reservation through open table, and unfortunately, we were 45 mins late. The place was packed and there were about 6 people waiting outside, I thought  "oh boy, we probably lost our table". The host was gracious and acted like he was waiting for us when we showed up.  Our table was ready, and it was just as I requested....NOT in the middle of the restaurant. The food was great, we shared a wonderful warm salad with a poached egg and bacon. I really really enjoyed this. I had the steak, it was done perfectly, and my girlfriend had an appetizer of shrimp and sun dried tomatoes in this wonderful sauce as an entree. We passed on desert, but the menu had lots of chocolate on it, which I LOVE. Will  have to try it next time. 

Overall the restaurant was a good experience, the food was delicious, and the atmosphere was very plesant. Mid way between casual and dressy. I will go back to try different things, and share with my friends!
author: Kelly A.

description:
Tres tres bien!! 

I took my bf here for his birthday celebration and it was just perfect =)  The little table next to the window looking out to the street in a quaint restaurant is quite romantic eh?  And it was exactly that.

At first we were a bit "scared" because we were the youngest one there, but I was captured the moment the waiter spoke to us with the French accent hehe 

Food was great (carrot soup!! yummmy!  pate .. yummy!!!  lamb shank, red fish ...!! wow .. creme brullee was ok .. sorbets were delish!), service was excellent as I was exclaiming to my bf the whole time about how our waiter was professional but yet "homey" at the same time, and the whole experience was memorable!

The bill came out to about 126 tax/tip incl. for all those food plus a glass of pinot noir and lemon drop cocktail!  Overall, OUR TUMMIES WERE VERY HAPPY =)  wonderful night ...
author: Chau L.

description:
When: Sat, Jun 14, 2008
Time: 7:15 pm
Occassion: Anni (Dine About Town)

We looked at the Dine About Town menu, and realized that the saving basically getting a free dessert. I went back and forth a few times between the DAT menu and the regular menu, and really had a hard time deciding...nothing looked appealing. Finally I settled with the DAT menu (31.95): 
- Pate de campagne served with mache, cornichons & toasts
- Flat iron steak served with haricot verts, pommes frites in a red wine sauce 
- Warm chocolate Gourmand
SO settled with regular menu:
- Spicy Monterey calamari " la plancha" with jalapenos & chorizo  11
- Bacon wrapped Pork tenderloin, braised savoy cabbage, caramelized onion sauce 19

After ordering, I crossed my fingers and hoped that even though I wasn't crazy about the things I ordered that I may be surprised. NOT! I packed the flat iron steak to go, and just shared my SO's pork tenderloin. BTW, we were wondering if they forgot to piggy blanket the pork tenderloin.
author: Aldo H.

description:
Fringale doesn't have mind-blowing French food in my mind, but it's perfect in every other aspect.  It has a cozy ambiance, great French staff, and reasonable prices.

Saturday night was incredibly busy, so the 5 of us waited for a bit, which wasn't unpleasant as they do have a nice bar in the not-so-large restaurant.

We ordered 3 appetizers: sweetbread, foie gras and crab Napoleon.  All very well done.  My only thing was that the crab was slightly overpowered by the amount of avocado in the Napoleon.  But it was still delicious. 

For entrees, we had duck confit, steak, pasta with chicken, and seafood basquaise.   My friends loved their duck confit and commented on how tender the steak was.  My basquaise was flavorful and came in a large quantity, but not extremely exciting. 

Most importantly, I have to give props to the wait staff who had to endure our TMI conversations.  We were raunchier than Samantha Jones, and yet the waiters filled our water over and over again with a straight face as if we were just discussing the weather.  Now that is a professional!
author: Candice B.

description:
I had my surprise birthday dinner at this lovely restaurant. It was quite delicious! The crab napoleon was fresh and tasty and my entree (the special of the night) braised short ribs were delightful. It was a mouth watering dish with polenta and sauteed spinach that just melted in my mouth.

The restaurant was on the small side, quite cozy. Maybe a little too cozy as the woman next to us, almost hit my friend in the head. Service was good and we found out you can BYOB.  That's a plus.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Mom and I came here on Friday night. Very nice space, ambiance very cool in its own quiet way. The place filled up and by 8:30 the place was good and crowded.

Had the calamari appetizer -- nice plate presentation, but not an astonishingly good dish. That said I'm not a huge calamari fan in the first place.

The short ribs were nice, but again, not special.

The dessert was fantastic -- had the bread pudding and it impressed. Great conclusion to the meal.

Very reasonably priced. All in all, seems like it would be a very reliable, safe place to bring a date if you're risk averse and not a total food snob.
author: Nick B.

description:
Calamari with jalapenos and chorizo : very fresh and I love it.
Seafood basquise is really good quality.
I am a Creme Brulee hater but I can't believe I finish their Creme Brulee.
author: Zoe C.

description:
What brought me here was that Fringale is part of a number of restaurants on the Celebrated Chefs program that are donating 5% of revenue to charities for customers that sign up.   Well done to them for that.  For signing up, we also walked out with a great recipe book where they list some of their recipes along with recipes from other great restaurants in the area. It's a great book.

Anyway, the food here was excellent. The mixed seafood, foie gras and bread pudding were great.  The suggested dessert wine pairings with the foie gras could've been better and I think there's more reasonably priced French cuisine in SF but it's still a great restaurant.

In terms of experience though, it's always fun for me to banter with the French with my awful grasp of the French language.  I've accidentally asked waiters in France if I could go to their house and use the bathroom so that will tell you how good I am at speaking French - it makes me laugh at least.  My gf says the only word I understand in French is "buffet" so the Fringale staff get some points for being good sports.
author: Dave F.

description:
We've been coming to this restaurant for 17 years.... We just don't come often enough.
We've considered this a "special occasion" restaurant in the past, but the last three visits over the past two months, we seem to think otherwise.  The prices are on par for restaurants in San Francisco, most all entree's are under $20.  We need to get in here more
often...
The restaurant is small, so reservations are really suggested.  I guess you could describe this place as casual chic'.  The restuarant is "cozy" which is a code word for small but not cramped.  

The owner and staff very unpretentious and just really down to earth.  Andre' ,our usual waiter is fantastic, and very helpful with paring the wines with our dinners.

We've had most everything on the menu, but we keep coming back for the Frisée salad with warm bacon dressing, poached egg & toast points.  Salads just don't get better than this....all of the entree's are excellent, but you can't go wrong with the Steamed PEI mussels in white wine, garlic & shallots sauce, or the Bacon wrapped Pork tenderloin, with braised cabbage and a caramelized onion sauce.  Get an order of fries with the either of these dishes... damn these are the best fries in SF, and the order is large enough for at least three people to split.
Finish off your meal with any of their desserts, but if you've not been to a Basque restaurant, you have to get their Gateau Basque.  This is a dense almond cake with a layer of custard cream filling.  If cake isn't your thing, get the crème brûlée. 
This is one of the best deals in SF for the price
author: Jim R.

description: Moved from SOMA a while ago, but went back to Fringale last week after a thing at a gallery...mmmmmm!  Music was totally fine, atmosphere was good, and I ate everything placed in front of me--so delicious.  Happy to change my rating--I'm a fan again!
author: Jennifer K.

description:
Overall my experience at fringale was great. The service was attentive and very professional. We asked the waiter for suggestions and he recommended the pork tenderloin - my friends who ordered it were glad they did. I started with the asian pear and apple salad and really enjoyed the blend of flavors and textures. The duck confit was very good, but not amazing. We each ordered a different dessert and shared a bite or two - they all went over well. 

The atmosphere is warm, but the space is very tight. I may have not been in an ideal position, but I sometimes felt like my chair was in the way. On my way to the restroom I had to do some maneuvering to not run into waiters. This detracted just a bit from the experience. We were a party of four, which was fine, but I wouldn't try it with a larger group.
author: T _.

description:
Cozy French Restaurant - I like it. Service was superb & it also helps when waiters are French - just love their accent. Note to self - need to practice my French once again. ^_^

Mr & I along w/ his friends checked out Fringale last Fri. Great Experience, don't mind coming back again. It's not pretentious, relaxing atmosphere. We were eating and chatting for almost 3 hours.

We had Chateau Jonqueyres, Bordeaux '01 for wine, like it. Not too light & not too strong either.

I forgot what we had for appetizers however for main course. We ordered

* Spicy Monterey Calamari w/ jalapenos & chorizo (It was good but I wish it was more Spicy)
* Steamed mussels w/ fried garlic, herbs & sherry vinegar was yummy.
* I ordered the confit of duck leg w/ green lentils & du poy - it was tasty.
* Mr ordered Black Angus rib eye steak w/ red wine butter & pommes frites - it was also yummy. 

For dessert: Friends ordered Baba au Rhum with Beaujolais and berries compote
(Sponge cake in a rum syrup, berries cooked in Beaujolais and vanilla, and whipped cream) according to them is not that great yet they finished it, go figure.

While Mr & I had Crme brle 
( Creamy custard with a caramelized sugar crust) it was so yummy

It's in 4th St so parking kinda sucks especially if there's a game. Bring a credit card coz it can get pricey but it's worth it.
author: jubi l.

description:
Today was moms b-day. This is her favorite spot . I took a party of her friends here. 

I hate to say but bad service. I made it clear that It was moms b-day when they confirmed the reservation, the hostess with the nice french accent said we will put a candle on her dessert. I said fine. We ordered 5 desserts and no candle. I had to ask for a candle.

Cold Creme Brule..the first one I have ever had. Everyone else was satisfied with the food. But bad service, I will not return.
author: Dee D.

description:
One of the few places in town where the staff and the food have remained excellent over the years.

Don't go w/o reservations though b/c the secret is out.  Was just there last night, and it feels like a Sat night!  Good thing we were there just for desserts.  Oh, and the first time to have those killer fries!  No wonder so many go here before the game!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
This was a great place.  After 100 reviews theres not much to add to them, save a personal experience story no one reads.  

It would have been five stars but there was a large group ahead of us that seemed to take a long time to finish and the restaurant couldn't handle it so the line to be seated was really backed up until they finally left.
author: Joshua G.

description:
Great French Restaurant!

My family took me here for my birthday recently. The place itself is pretty small, but cozy. The staff was is very friendly and made for a great dining experience. I ordered the foie gras to start and the seafood basquaise as my entree. Everything was delicious!

For dessert, my family and I split four desserts. My favorite was the gateau basque. 

Will definitely come here again.
author: Andrea G.

description:
Had the prix fixe:

Starter - mussels were eh....rather flavorless.

Main - Salmon - cooked perfectly tender and pink but the flavor could have been better.
Dinner Guest had Hanger Steak - again, cooked perfectly but the flavor was a little limp

Dessert - Apple Tart - boring
Dinner Guest had Hazelnut Mousse - too sweet
author: Lev E.

description:
The meal was good.  Solid, decent.  
Lamb chops perfectly done.
Shrimp ravioli was tasty.
The Chocolate Gourmand dessert a must.
Pricing is fair for quality of ingredients, service, and execution.
author: K W.

description:
Just went here for the first time despite working around the corner for a few years.  Go figure, I never knew it existed.  Went with a crew of coworkers and colleagues and a had delicious, YET DELIGHTFULLY UNPRETENTIOUS, French/Basque dinner.  I found the menu slightly limiting because they put pork in nearly everything and I don't eat the piggies.  However, what I did eat was extremely tasty.  

I had/tried:
Salad with Basque crutons
Lamb stew (special)
A tiny bite of creme brule, the almond cake, and the custartd tart thingie (yes, I believe that's its technical name)

I wasn't paying the bill so I have no idea how spendy this place is.   I tend to be sparing with the stars but this place earned all five.  Not at all snobby but with the skillz to back it up if they chose to be.  Would give them an extra star for that if I could.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
Had a lovely anniversary dinner here on Saturday. Parking was easy, booking through OpenTable was easy, even traffic from the 'burbs was easy! 

I had the awesome crab appetizer, and DH had tomato soup and a salad. The crab was so good that our waiter noticed I'd scraped up all the drippings and bits from the plate and he made joke about it! The mister had duck as his main, which was served on a bed of really rich, really yummy lentils. (Seriously! Yummy lentils!) The waiter brought me a steak knife for my pork tenderloin and assured DH he wouldn't need a knife for his duck. He could have saved my knife, too, because the pork didn't need it either. Mmm, very tender. We shared the pan perdu for dessert, and it was a great ending to the meal: sweet, flavorful, and light.

Hope we'll get a chance to come back soon!
author: Kendra A.

description:
Outstanding food and service!
After reading the mixed reviews on YELP about the service, we went in with low expectations in that department.  
We dined early (6pm) with another couple before the symphony so it was not crowded and perhaps that is the reason for the attentive service.  Regardless, we found our server to be very good.  
The food and wine were also great!  I wish I could comment on specific dishes but it has been a couple weeks since we went.
author: Patrick Z.

description:
