I went there last night.  

Food was great!  
Shared the "Dungeness crab Napoleon, avocado, tomato confit, crème fraiche" to which my boyfriend ate the majority (much to my dismay).  You know it's good when you are fighting for the last bite!
We each had the "Sweet gem lettuce salad, herb vinaigrette, croutons with Basque cheese".  Good side salad, that filled me up!
I had the Bacon wrapped Pork tenderloin, braised savoy cabbage, caramelized onion sauce",  which was amazing.
He had the special, sea bass.  It was good, but not amazing.
We shared the "Warm sponge cake bread pudding with chocolate and bananas".  I made sure to get the last bite of this...it was superb!

Service was ok, but seemed to slow down greatly after we were finished our entrees.  It took longer than I would have liked to order dessert, receive the dessert, get the check, and get the check payment.  Almost perfect!

The venue is small.  I could hear the conversations of the tables next to us very clearly.  Warm atmosphere and romantic, despite the eaves dropping.
author: Valerie D.

description:
Food 4 stars, service negative stars, atmosphere 4 stars.

Have been here several times and always impressed by the food... duck confit and pork tenderloin - amazing!

service historically has been indifferent at best but on Tuesday night service was so dour and rude it really ruined our meal.  Sigh - I wanted to love this place enough to make it a regular stomping ground but they need to do a lot to improve the service...
author: Stacy N.

description: I don't understand the reviews that describe this staff as rude.  We have been going to Fringale for years and find the staff to be welcoming and talented.  We also enjoy the owner.  This is a great neighborhood restaurant with very good food.  It is small enough to enjoy dinner conversations.  I would not, however, bring a large group here.  The size and shape of the restaurant does not accommodate groups larger than 8 comfortably.
author: Grace F.

description:
I can only speak for the dine about menu- but we had a great experience! 
The french server was very attentive and everything came in a a timely matter. 
The calamari appetizer was my favorite out of the three dishes I had-it was sauteed so not fried and had a great spicy flavor to it! 
Everyone at my table thoroughly enjoyed their food and I am pretty sure we all finished off every bite! 
Also creme brulee-great (it is one of my fav desserts and it was done well!) 
A cute little cozy restaurant in a slightly shady area! 
The only thing I was surprised with was that there were no white wines by the glass...strange...luckily I am a red drinker :)
author: Janae L.

description:
how i love thee. this place turned out to be utterly stupendous. our french server was fun and friendly. the ambiance was charming. great corner location to get the 'city feel' while eating. very slightly loud. this is probably one of my top three favorite restaurants in the city now. 
to start of my bf's birthday dinner, us ladies had a glass of sparkling. the men had manhattans. 
first course: mr. p- heirloom tomato carpaccio with goat cheese and arugula(!). mrs. p and i had the frisee salad, bacon dressing, perfectly poached egg, & toasted levain. the flavors and seasoning were delicious. creamy egg yolks with the crisp bacon bites piled onto the toast topped with the frisee was a perfect beginning(!!). birthday boy tried out the beef carpaccio, and yes, that too was thinly sliced and savory.
entrees: mr. p- halibut. steaming hot, he loved it (although i didn't get to try this one), mrs. p- salmon dish. the sauce on here was incredible. i kept stealing pieces and drowning it in this tart savory berenaise sauce that i couldn't get enough of. my bf had the steak frites. the red wine shallot butter was perfect to this mouth melting piece of meat. i went for the lamb. cooked exactly to a  med rare, paired with a red wine reduction, creamy and crispy potato gratin and veg (which at this very moment i can't remember because the rest of the dish stole the show). we are all cooks, and savored every last morsel of food on our plates. it's ridiculous how delicious and flawless everything came out. 
us two meat eaters had a glass of pinot, while the fish friendly sipped on a glass of viognier. 
and for dessert- the chocolate bread pudding and Mme. Angele's Gateau Basque- this almond torte and probably paired with a creme anglaise was the ultimate ending. 
so at the end, the server overheard us talking about his birthday, and brought out a plate with four chocolate truffles and a candle. how sweet :)
author: Abigail W.

description:
This French Basque inspired restaurant is situated in South of Market on 4th Street and Brannon. Non-formidable from the outside and very chic and simple decor on the inside, I wasn't sure what to expect of the food as I walked in for a ladies night trying to stand straight in my high heels and tight skirt as an oh so ever "pang of hunger"  hit me (or Fringale as the french call it!). 

What the restaurant lacks in it's formality of space and small room, it makes up for in every delictable item on the menu. As an appetizer, I ordered the frisee salad with poached egg and bacon. It came with a light dressing and two small slices of  baguette on the side. I ate every bite.  For entree, the steak with pommes frites and green beans was a great choice. The Steak was mouth melting delicious and seasoned well. I also tried the duck confit with lentils, which was equally good in flavor. For dessert, our table ordered the creme brulee, lemon tarte, and angele's gateau basque. The angele's flaky and fresh almond cake was by far my favorite, but the lemon tart was a second favorite at our table. 

Another plus was that when we walked into the restaurant, the staff greeted us immediately. I felt almost if I had entered a private party or someone's home. We dined early (6p.m.), which could have accounted for the extra attention. But as the restaurant filled up, the staff seemed equally attentive. One note is that the clientele is on the older side and not necessarily suitable for very loud parties. The restaurant tends to be more on the mellow side.  

However, we found we didn't have to lower our voices, but expected to get a few smirks from our waiter  and nearby guests as we made quite a few dirty jokes. It was a b-day party after all!  Thus, the restaurant is very intimate in nature, so to speak. 

Speaking of wine, the wines by the glass are not highly impressive and unfortunatley our table did not opt for a bottle. But, some wines of noteworthy mention were the syrah and medoc they serve by the glass. Both were light weight and floral and paired well with the flavorful dishes. 

My french was a little rusty throughout the evening, but I still managed to find the bathroom comfortably, which is always a plus! I guess "bathroom" translates in every language. 

......So me and my tight skirt and uncomfortable heels are sure to return to this little gem of a restaurant in the future. I hope you will try it out too.
author: Laura L.

description: Love this place-my favorite french restaurant in the city!
author: Cheryl M.

description: I don't know why anyone would read a long review, so will be short. The place is wonderful! The best French place in SF: affordable price, excellent food, great service, beautiful environment and chairs are not too close to each other (those who say they are have not tried Chapeau restaurant to which I will never go again). If a guy wants to get a girl's respect, he should take her to Fringale.
author: FairMe R.

description: Came for DAT on Friday the third. The appetizer were good and original. Spinach ravioli was tasty with nice cheese flavor. The plancha was good. I thought the size was more toward entree than appetizer. We continued with duck and salmon. Both were dry, probably too long under the warming lamp. Desserts were good and flavorful. The wine was great but a little too warm at service time. The ambiance is nice and the place is not as loud as I expected. Will probably try other French restaurants before coming back to Fringale.
author: Annie O.

description:
I finally tried Fringale, enticed by the San Pellegrino prix fixe menu.  Why did I wait so long?  This place is yummy!

For starters, I got the shrimp ravioli in lobster sauce and I think I ate the entire basket of bread on our table, using the baguettes to sponge up all the sauce.  Next was the hangar steak - cooked perfectly and deliciously.  Finally, I had the flourless chocolate cake which was the highlight of my meal, even though I had my heart set on the bread pudding which was MIA.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Great place for a nice dinner.  The seating area is not so large, and the front door was hard to find for some reason.  We almost walked by it the 1st time.  It's a little tight, but if you get a window seat, you will enjoy your dinner.  Prices are quite good for the food+service combo.  

I don't remember any of the dish's names, but the 2 appetizers we ordered were excellent.  They were challenging when we looked at the description, but quite tasty when we dug in.   

I ordered the hangar steak, but apparently, the chef dropped it, so I had to wait quite a while for it to arrive.  lucky for us, they made sure to keep the other dish (salmon) warm so they come out at the same time at perfect temperature.  My steak was a bit "tough", something I normally do not prefer in steaks.  But I thought the taste was up to par atleast.  

We also ordered some dessert, and they fell in the standard taste category for me.  It was not exceptional like Fleur De Cocoa, but more on par with a smaller hole in the wall european pastry store.  

I think 3 stars is too low, and 4 is too high, but Yelp doesn't let you do 3.5 stars, so I gave it a 4 because of my long wait for the dish.  Do I recommend it?  Of course.  Will I go back?  definately.

I did feel a little uncomfortable due to the fact that we sat next to the window facing the street, and watched 2 possibly, homeless people arguing right in front of us for about 10 minutes.  But I'm sure that's beyond the restaurant's control.
author: Terrance S.

description:
Fringale was talked up by a friend at work and I was very let down. 

Let's start with the Prawn Ravioli and Lobster Bisque: it was lukewarm. 

This turned out to be the pattern of the evening. It tasted great but was just a bit off.

I got a fish course for my main and my girlfriend got a steak. Hers was fine. Mine looked great but it was warm-ish. It just didn't work for me. 

Each of my courses tasted as it had been sitting out for a while. It was just... almost warm. 

Everything looked great but the temperature controls in the kitchen seemed to be off for my starter, main, and dessert. 

The wine list was solid. But, ironically, the food came out too quickly to have wine pairings sent out with our courses. We had mentioned to our waiter, as we ordered,  that we wanted to have a different wine with each course. But, he acted like he just wanted to serve us and free up a table. 

I'm not going back. There are plenty of other places in the city worth going to.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
My hubby and I went to Fringale because we were craving some French cuisine.  

The restaurant is relatively small, but perfect for small groups.  The decor is simple, but pleasant.  It's reasonably priced, and the atmosphere is warm.  The wait staff are friendly and attentive.  

To start, we had the pate to share which was delightful.  It wasn't a big appetizer, but it was rich and peppery.  

We ordered the special of the day, which was a homestyle poultry dish served with beans in a ceramic dish.  It was an enormous dish which we couldn't finish.   The meal was good, but it wasn't incredible.  However, it was nice to get a taste of the more traditional French home style meal served in France.

I would go back again. 

By the way, the dinner rolls are fresh and addictive.
author: Natalie T.

description:
I went to Fringale the other day with a friend for my second time.  Both times were pretty comparable.  The food is very good for the price (we did the dine about town menu) and the atmosphere is nice and cozy. However, it is a little cramped in space and you can definitely overhear the conversation next to you (we had to ask the table next to us to move their table just so we could physically get out).  

The one area where this restaurant lacked was service.  Both times I went we had to wait at least 15 minutes after our reservation time to be seated.  They didn't even ask to take our coats at the front (yes I'm being picky) and the wait staff was very slow.  I found a fruit fly in my wine and when I told them about it I received a new glass, but no apology.  I was impressed when the waiter brought us out an additional desert on the house while we waited for the other two deserts (which were taking a bit longer).
author: Justin S.

description:
Came here with the fiancee for DAT on Friday night. We arrived a few minutes late for our 8pm reservation and the place was packed. We ended up waiting next to the door trying not to get squashed as people arrived. While we waited we had a couple of drinks from the bar (Kir Royale's because we're classy like that). In all we waited about 15 minutes, but during that time we were eyeballed by, I swear, Cruella Deville's exact opposite. Where Cruella was tall, thin, and had black hair with a white streak, her opposite was dumpy and sported white hair with a black streak. Tres bizarre (as they say in France).

I had the beet salad with goat cheese (very nice) and warm chocolate Gourmand (excellent, but I'm a sucker for all things chocolate), while my fiancee ordered the sauteed prawns appetizer (she loved them) and Hazelnut mousse cake (great, maybe a little too buttery for our tastes). For the main course I ordered the pork tenderloin, but swapped with my fiancee who had ordered the Lamb Osso Bucco, but didn't like it (it wasn't what she was expecting).

Overall we thought it was good, but not great. I'm sure we will come back again, but maybe only for DAT.
author: Chris K.

description:
After a drink at district, we realized we were hungry earlier than expected. We headed over to Fringale to see if we could be squeezed in a bit earlier. As we walked and explained that we were early for what we thought was our 8 PM reservation, we were enthralled by what seemed to be a hot party over at the retirement center. This tiny venue was flooded with a crowd obviously weeelll over retirement. (Not to say I don't love my grandparents, love you grandma!!). As we were passed by couples, we were informed our reservation was for 9:15... and it was spelled out for us- (in a snooty French accent) "nine-one-five". Merci beacoup Monsieur! Mais je crois que je comprends l'anglais!

---This must have been an online opentable error on our part, but nonetheless, no need for the attitude. So we kindly said we will eat elsewhere and left. The next day, message from opentable that we were a no show! 

I'll give you two stars for the benefit of the doubt.
author: Rada I.

description:
Love this place and eat here almost every week. Great food at  a reasonable price. If you want a great country French meal and don't want to pay 300.00 for it, stop in here. I have never had a bad meal and the service is always good as well.   

Make sure to get a reservation before you go.
author: Brian K.

description:
Very good.

Pate yummy.  Little bit too cold for my taste but it was a cold night.  Management needs to make sure that door stays shut.  There was a heater right under my seat which was quite nice.

Hangar steak with haricot vert and frites.  Excellent steak.  Extra points for a place that actually has my steak come out rare instead of medium rare.  Frites ok.  Not terrible, just not great.

Fantastic chocolate gourmand.  Looked like an undercooked rectangle of chocolate cake, tasted like a souffle.   Accompanied by some sort of berry coulis and vanilla ice cream.

Tarte tatin needs work.  An entire apple on top of a not so tasty disc of hard flat pastry.  Caramel sauce was yummy but doesn't make up for the almost impossible to eat apple.
author: Poppy C.

description:
A lot of the negative reviews about this place mention horrible service, and the positive reviews mention amazing food.  I didn't find either of those things at Fringale. 

I went there a couple weeks ago on a date, and both of us were underwhelmed by the food. We had the crab napolean, mussels, pommes frites and one of the specials of the night, a veal dish (how do you make veal tough?). Nothing to write home about. But, they did have my fave Riesling on wine list...yay!

The service, on the other hand, was great! From making the reservation to walking out the door, everyone was friendly and accommodating. The lady that took the reservation was a sweetheart, the waiter was great about checking on us without bothering us too much, and one of the other waitstaff  agreed to take pictures of us over and over when we weren't satisfied with our pics ;) No attitudes...just charm.

All in all, it's worth trying once. Maybe the chef had a one-off bad night.
author: Baby Bear G.

description:
I'm so glad that one of the closest fine dining restaurants to my home is this place! The interior is adorable and inviting although the restaurant is tiny, so the side tables are crammed together. Service is impeccable, and the waiters were very polite but still joked around with us in their cute French accents. Food came out very quickly but it might have been because we were having an early dinner.

Appetizers: Spicy calamari was good, not what I would call spicy but well-flavored and not too chewy. Wasn't a fan of the foie gras, I prefer mine seared so the huge block of it was too much, we actually left about 1/4 of it unfinished. I liked the toasted brioche that came with it more than anything else.
Entrees: My friend's mussels were really good and garlicky but there was so much of it. I'd recommend the mussels only if you're going to be sharing your food family-style. My duck confit was great, the skin was crispy and the meat just fell off the bone, I didn't even need to use the knife that they provided.
Dessert: Hazelnut roasted almond mousse cake = heaven. I do not like sweets, but the texture was light and the almonds balanced out the sweetness of the mousse and chocolate.

With a full bottle of wine and 2 glasses of dessert wine, our meal came out to be a little over $90/person.
author: S L.

description:
I went for dinner only.  It was OK.  
The wait person was kind, but not Service was Ok.  
Food was delicious, but not extraordinary. Comparing to other French restaurants, it was average.
author: Leo P.

description: This is a great spot for a date! The service is fantastic and the setting is intimate. Prices are very reasonable for the quality and I was very impressed with the wine selection. It's a good list that won't break the bank.
author: Kandace K.

description: I haven't been there in a few years, but it was my favorite intimate restaurant in the area. Excellent food and service, a relaxing ambiance. Wonderful for an intimate meal.
author: Joe B.

description:
Appetizer - sauteed prawns was ok.
Main course - Best cod I've ever had.  They really know how to cook fish.  
Service was very good and attentive.
author: Grace L.

description:
I was defintely impressed with Fringale.  Went here last night with a friend.

Very cozy. Staff was more than attentive.

We did the Dine About Town. Amazing.
author: Michael D.

description: My husband and some friends had dinner here and we enjoyed our food so much!! We're foodies so we really appreciate the quality of food served here. My husband had the  foie gras as appetizer (it was a large portion) and it  was delicious!!! This restaurant is nice for a small group of people. The restaurant is small and intimate. I gave it a 4 star because the waiter didn't pour the wine for us, but overall it's a great place to take your partner or guest.
author: Etude R.

description:
Went here for dinner and the service was good, but the food was ok.


Spicy Monterey Calamari ala Plancha - This appetizer was very good. Just the right amount of spice to bring out the flavor.

Duck Confit - This was a bit overcooked but still good. The duck was a bit crispy and a little dry. However, the beans with the duck confit were a good compliment. 

The best DUCK CONFIT I've had in the city is at Cafe Bastille. The meat fell off the bone and was very tender.  

Creme Brulee - Very good. Topped off with blackberry and raspberry.  Standard fare with a small layer of toasted sugar. Creme was not too rich or creamy. This was probably the best part of the meal.

Overall, I give Fringale - 3 stars. The service and food was good, but nothing over the top. This is a good date place as it is not very noisy inside (you can hear the other person talk) and the ambience is great.
author: blahblah h.

description: had a late lunch here before attending cirque de soleil. both my wife's crab salad and my pasta were quite good and very satisfying. nice reasonably priced wine list. very good service. will definitely come here again and would not hesitate to recommend.
author: Joseph B.

description: Excellent service and delicious food is what you will find at Fringale (Frihn- gal).  For starters we had the Spicy Monterey Calamari "a la plancha" and Black Angus Beef Carpacio with Capers, Etork Chees & Olive Oil.  Our entrees were Steam PEi Mussels with fresh herbs & sherry vinegar and the Creekstone Farm Black Angus Ribeye with red wine butter & pomme frites.  For dessert, we had the Creme Brulee and Mme Angeles Gateau Basque. My steak came out a perfect medium rare (so tender & juicy) and the mussels were so tasty that it livens up your taste buds. Everything was delicous and the ambiance was nicely set, Definitely a great place to dine at, especially after listening to The SF Symphony. It added the finishing touches to a lovely evening.
author: gordon g.

description: I cant say enough....it was so good.Duck Confit,spinach Ravioli,and 1 amazing desert which was a Mousse of Coffee and Armangec(sp?) couple this with attentive service from waiter extraudonaire Andre who has been there since the beginning,it was just excellent.It may be the best French restuarant in town for the price....killer
author: james m.

description: The place is a gem and so very consistent. I took one of my staff for lunch, he had the seafood medly in tomato coulis and loved it.  I took a risk and got the duck confit; it was dynamite. The duck skin was gorgeously crisp, no fat, and the meat was melt in your mouth.  They continue to serve excellent bread and quality butter and service is very attentive without being overbearing. A great value.
author: Jack K.

description:
What an adorable find!  My uncle (whom I haven't seenin 7 years!) was in town for a conferenceand so I wanted to find a place that would be nice, but not too stuffy...  I also wanted a place a bit off the beaten path - not somewhere that everyone has been to ro would have an obnoxious wait time, even with reservations (I hate that!)...  
Anyway, Fringale was perfect.  Delish food, incredibly friendly staff, and such a cozy place!  Without even realizing it, we stayed long enough to close the restaurant and then proceeded to be cahtted up by our waiter outside while he waited with us for our cab... Now, if that's not the epitome of European eating, please tell me what is.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Last night I Dined About Town at Fringale.  I was excited to try this place, as it is Michelin Guide recommended and getting the reservation was a challenge.  Thinking back on the night, I would give the service a 10/10 and the food a 7/10.  You might think this would lead me to offer up more than three stars.  But, in a town full of fancy French options, I think a restaurant of this ilk would have to be superb to garner more.

The details of the evening are as follows:

Butter Lettuce Salad: I would not order this again.  It was salad in the blandest sense of the word.

Coq Au Vin: Worth it!  This dish was excellent.  My serving was perfect, though my companion's noodles were overcooked.

Apple Tart & Hazelnut Almond Cake: The tart was the star of the evening.  The cake was good, but there was something just a little less than fabulous about it.

The wine was good.  The waiters were there when they should have been and gone when they were not wanted.

All and all, Fringale is worth a try, but go for wine, a small, shared main course, and dessert.  Save your big French splurge for someplace else.
author: Margo C.

description:
Every time I come here, I always ask myself why I don't come more often. The food is always very good. Last night I had foie gras, and their fish stew (I am sure it has a fancier name, but that is what it is). 
They were both excellent. I took one star off because you are so crammed in together, and I was practically elbowing the diner behind me. But it is a great place. A little out of the way for me, but well worth the trip.
author: Dave O.

description:
Great Food, Great service, great ambiance.  Love it.  Cozy, authentic and worth the visit!  The prices are a good value for the meal.  

Crab Napoleon, Almond Cake and Mussels; all delicious!
author: Liz L.

description:
I picked Fringale for a friend's birthday, because I heard some good things about it.  Overall, the food is good.  I especially liked the prawns in pastis which I had as an appetizer.  The sauce was so very tasty that I ended up eating way too much bread which I used to wipe my plate.  The halibut was quite good as well.  

The setting is a bit cramped and somewhat old school.  For some reason, it didn't feel 'cozy' to me like some other small restaurants.  Maybe it's the layout - I don't know.  The service was fine, not great not bad...a bit of attitude.

I would probably go back, though I don't think it would be my top choice for French given all the options in this city.
author: Eric C.

description:
I came here for my second visit several months ago with a few of my friends for a nice dinner. We were a little late, but they were accomodating enough, though they told us that we could only have the table for an hour, which was good enough.

The decor is really cozy and tasteful, and it was definitely a restaurant with the right kind of ambience. Service was pleasant and efficient (though that might have also been a part of how we only had the table for an hour).

Food was absolutely scrumptious! The first time I came here, I had the roasted rack of lamb, which was very good, but this time I ordered the ribeye steak. I would venture to say that it was even better! (although of course, that's my own personal preference). We all had the soup du jour, and for dessert I ordered the special, a peach melba, which was delicious as well (and I really want to try some of the other desserts!)!

Overall, I am definitely hoping to come back soon!
author: Maggi L.

description: This is my new favorite place. It is very close to where I live, so it is my numero uno choice to take my friends out for dinner. My favorite is their duck confit!  Their coffee and desserts are to die for. The best part is they don't rush to throw you out if your table is the last one to leave. I would highly recommend this place to have great food and wine without breaking the bank.
author: Anbu A.

description:
We met up with some friends here last Thursday to sample the restaurant for Dine About Town.

My boyfriend and I started out with drinks, which are nice and strong (how I like them), but at $10 for a simple rum & coke.. they'd better be strong. I started out with the calamari appetizer, which was good. Not great, but good. However, it was nowhere near what I'd consider "spicy," as the menu advertised it. My boyfriend had the crab ravioli and he didn't like it at all. I tried a piece of it (he didn't warn me beforehand) and it was COLD. Not even room temperature, COLD. I'm amazed he didn't send it back. Two of our friends had the ravioli as well and were definitely not impressed.

For main course, all five of us had the filet. The filet itself came exactly as ordered (medium rare) and tasted good, but the cabernet sauce was on it was nothing spectacular. My boyfriend remarked that he could make better filet. It came with fries, which is somewhat of an odd choice to go with a filet. While the fries had good crispiness, there was practically no salt or other seasoning on them. Because of this, they fell really flat. The meal also came with a "salad" that was basically a bit of spring mix with an ever so tiny bit of dressing. It was just a touch above inedible. 

My boyfriend and I both had the hazelnut almond cake for dessert and it was just ok. We had a bite of our friend's chocolate cake and while not great either, it was better than ours. Upon receiving a bill for $115, my boyfriend remarked that he felt legimately ripped off for the food we received.. and I definitely agree with him. If this place is capable of serving great food, it was certainly NOT on display tonight. Isn't the point of Dine About Town to impress customers so that they come back to you?

We would definitely never come back here to give them another shot.
author: Michael M.

description:
I recently moved near Fringale and would come here all the time if not for the moderately expensive menu. With good service, a romantic ambiance, and wonderfully classic French fare, I definitely recommend it.
Both times my boyfriend and I came on Friday nights without reservation; despite a crowded restaurant, we spent 15 min at the bar with some wine and were seated promptly after.
For appetizers, we've tried the calamari (fresh from Monterey) with jalapenos and chorizo, which is extremely flavorful. The pineapple chutney also goes nicely with the foie gras appetizer.
The duck leg confit in the red wine sauce with lentils falls apart perfectly and is delicious traditional fare. The bacon wrapped pork tenderloin with caramelized onions is also wonderful.
The ambiance is romantic and the service good.  My boyfriend is French and likes that the ambiance and food feels like a simple and delicious restaurant back home - they don't try to be over-the-top cheesy French with pictures of the Eiffel Tower on the walls.
I definitely recommend this for a nice night out, and even though we didn't make reservations, I would recommend that you do.
author: Britt M.

description: Came here for dinner and was very satisfied.   Maybe as good as it gets for Basque country French dining in SF.  Great service, better food, fair prices.  I had the rack of lamb and even though the rack was only two bones, it was quite filling with the haricot verts and potato gratin. The creme brulee was to die for. The restaraunt is small, so probably not best for large groupings or loud children.
author: C R.

description: C'est Magnifique! My bf and I went to Fringale for the first time and very much so enjoyed ourselves, the food, and the charming staff. We also received a free cookbook with recipes from other great restaurant in SF. We are looking forward to our next visit! Definitely worth a try.
author: Miss B.

description:
Where are 27 Stars When We Need Them?

I took a friend here two weeks ago on a freezing Saturday night promising her some of the best French bistro cuisine in the City. As she was driving her expensive sedan, I could tell she was less than happy about heading southward of Mission. Luckily we found a spot right in front and two seconds later were embraced by this marvelous restaurant.

First let me tell you about the waiters and other staff: so attentive without being intrusive, so warm and friendly without sitting on your lap and expecting to be waited on themselves. Pitch perfect!

And then I have to tell you about the other diners. I have been struck each time I have gone there by how respectful the folks who choose this restaurant are of the small, cozy environment it offers. We were seated next to a table set for 12 and with great trepidation I watched the group approach us. That was the last time I noticed them. The restaurant's acoustics and the civility of the guests allow everyone to have a beautiful evening and nobody felt the need to raise their voices.

Now...the food. The food is so special, so perfectly prepared, so delicately seasoned and so plentiful that you will want to sit there and wait for your next mealtime to arrive. It was days before I could stop thinking about the lamb reduction sauce that came with my rack of lamb or the total perfection of that lamb. We shared a cookie platter for dessert and were thrilled to discover it not only had at least a half dozen delicious homemade cookies, but also little truffles that melted in our mouths.

I have never had anything less than superior, perfectly prepared and perfectly served food at Fringale's. I hope you won't either, because it is a treat not to be missed.

PS: But please don't go there if you are the type who likes to balance wine bottles on your nose and scream across the room "Garcon!" There are other places you will like much better.

PPS: Dear Fringale: Please bring back the heavy velvet curtain you used to have over the front door. It was perfect at keeping out the cold wind and drafts.
author: Annie A.

description: I'm so glad we have this restaurant in our neighborhood. I made a reservation here and didn't realized until we arrived that we had eaten here maybe 5 years earlier. The service is great, it's authentic, waiters seem to be from France, but unlike many French waiters, ours was very friendly. I had a great bean salad they had for a special that night to start and my husband had a tomato salad. He had a steak and I had to get the duck confit of course. Like in France, the portions aren't massive, but were the right amount to be filling. I really enjoyed the duck confit and find that it's hard to find once close to what you'll get in France. We of course had the chocolate souffle cake and that was amazing. My husband almost ordered a second one. We'll definitely be back here, it's got a great neighborhood vibe, good service and good French food that's not overpriced.
author: Lauren M.

description: For SOMA, this place is great. I enjoyed the small quiet ambiance the most. The servers are French too to give you that provencale feel. I had the poached cod and the calamari appetizer. Both dishes exceeded my expectations (This is coming from someone who adores any Thomas Keller restaurant).
author: Elaine L.

description:
I would highly recommend this place if you are a woman and need a cheap thrill.

First time in my life I have not left a tip. When the waiter served my entree, his arm touched my breast. I thought it was an accident and blocked with my arm. The pressure continued. I looked around and saw that he had plenty of space to serve me and did not understand why this 'accident' happened. I then watched him serve my friend. His arm touched her breast as well. There was plenty of space around her as well, no reason to be crowded into accidental cheap feels. She jumped and said, "Oh!".  I said loudly, "He just did the same thing to me. No tip for you buddy." It was no accident. The waiter maintained his distance from them on. 

The food- good. If the evening had gone without the boob assault, I would have given this 3 stars.
author: Sharon K.

description: We just moved to the area and are so excited that we found this little gem of a French restaurant just a few short blocks from our new apartment. We have gone here twice and have had excellent meals both times. We have had the pork wrapped in pancetta, the duck and the chicken. The best entrée by far was the pork. It was juicy, tender and delicious! For appetizers we have tried the tomato soup and the scallops. I probably wouldn't order the soup again as it tasted a little like spruced up marinara sauce and was nine dollars! The scallops were good. We also enjoyed the fresh French bread they serve and a side of the pommes frites with aioli.  We had two nice quiet evenings here and I hope to be back soon!
author: Anne D.

description: I seriously cannot comprehend why this restaurant has 4 stars--the food was incredibly bland.  It literally had no taste!  We had such high expectations based on other yelp reviews and the fact that my partner and I both love French food.  The night that we were there the food tasted like the chef forgot to bring salt, pepper, butter, cream, and spices.   It's a "French" restaurant for goodness sake, I expected rich flavor full dishes.  We spent $130 for two (with tip and no drinks) and I really hated having a 1 star dinner experience at that price.  It's too bad the great service by the staff unfortunately couldn't make up for the bland food. It was a real disappointment - probably the worst dining experience in the last 3-4 years.
author: Daisy D.

description:
Classic
* french - basque
* quaint, intimate space in a cheery yellow
* love the mussels & frites, quail w/apple risotto and frise salad
* full bar/wine list
author: susan f.

description:
One can never say enough about the wonderful awesomeness that is COMPOUND BUTTER.

The rack of lamb and gratin were absolutely divine.  

The gateau Basque was an almond-y delight.

Only sore spot was the bitter nature of the deep fried horse radish strands toping my beef carpacio, though i'm afraid thats more personal taste than anything else.

I only wish I'd been here sooner...this place as an asset to an otherwise bland SOMA food scene.
author: Sean M.

description:
Shoot, an old standard just didn't come through! It had been years since I had been here and loved it. My husband took me here for my birthday dinner last night and I was excited to go back. The dungeness crab appetizer was perfection -- literally the best thing that has melted in my mouth in recent memory. A symphony of lightly scented, perfectly matched ingredients. 

As for the main course, it was half-hearted. Partially my fault for ordering the pasta, which truthfully, just didn't look exciting, but I wasn't in the mood for heavy, dressed-up meats. I think I was picturing the perfection of the house-made fettucine from the Slow Club, which is always toothsome and scrumptuous. The pasta in this dish was not fresh and was overcooked, the mushroom sauce dull and uninspired.  The waiter didn't even bother asking us how things were once we had our mains.

My husband had the salmon for the main served with yummy shredded brussels sprouts and mashed potaters. The salmon was really too rare... by just a hair, but pushing it.

We didn't stay for dessert, as fabulous bday cake was provided by a loving friend at another locale. Sorry Fringale, I don't know if I will go back!
author: Liza T.

description:
2nd time there tonight with my love.  I like that the tables are not too tightly packed together.  Easy parking.  Great Calimare!  Ordered 'beef cheecks' which was tasty as well. 
Desert and wine made it a complete package.
Service is always very good with nice recommendations.  Some complain about the French waiters, but I find them charming and very professional.
Also the crowd was nicely dressed, which matters to my wife who likes to dress up nicely for a quality dinner.
Highly Recommended!
author: Robert C.

description:
My friends and I had a great dinner here at Fingale. At first I had some doubts about the restaurant because we had to wait 15mins or so to be seated when we did make reservations, far in advance. But once we were seated the servers were very patient and were very excited to tell us their special dishes of the day and the servers were also very detailed with explaining about the different dishes. My friends and I don't have French cuisine often, so that was very helpful.  The people there are very professional and definitely are knowledgeable. 

I loved every dish I had at Fringale. I had everything, from the bread to appetizer, to the main entree, to dessert. i also tried my friends dishes too. I liked them all!!! I would highly recommend this restaurant to anyone. 

My friends and I drove all the way from Santa Clara to try it!! So why not try it yourself?
author: Linh D.

description:
me and the girlie are just abusing dine about town completely.  i will say it's kinda interesting to see how different places are approaching this whole dine about town thing.  for example, what was Le Charm to do for dine about town when they already offer a $30 fixed price 3-course dinner?  well, they took one of their premier entrees that is normally excluded from the 3-course dinner and added it and called it their dine about town.  and what did the Big 4 restaurant do?  they just completely cheaped out!  instead of manning up and offering one of their decent $40 entrees plus appetizer and dessert for $35, they cheaped out completely and offered the 3 least appetizing entree options on the menu.  anyway, back to fringale.  they did a pretty decent job, offering some of their tastier, heartier entrees.  

they didn't however, jump for joy when we brought our own bottle of Roederer champagne.  :)  but i guess they weren't negative about it either just kind of bummed that these 2 cheapo's not only went for the dine about town menu but also brought their own liquor!  ha.  but they were civil.  and in fact the appetizer, the hearty entrees, the atmosphere, the dessert.  it was all quite top notch.  the fish and the pork tenderloin were awesome. the creme brulee wasn't bad at all and the lobster ravioli was definitely a treat.  and, of course, the champagne was outstanding.  worth noting here is that they actually have Roederer champagne on their wine list and, as already mentioned, it's great.
author: dan h.

description: Gracious service, excellent adult beverage selection (pre-and-post dinner), expertly prepared food. And quite reasonable for the quality of the food and wine. Given the small size of the restaurant and the location, don't think you're going to get a quiet, romantic evening. We visited on a Friday night (with reservations) and had a wonderful experience.
author: Richard G.

description: Solid 4 stars for a great, unpretentious French restaurant!  My friends and I came here for the Dine About Town deal, and we all thoroughly enjoyed our meals.  Started with some charcuterie and yummy pate.  For entree, I had the filet mignon that was honestly perfectly medium rare.  To top off the meal, I had the hazelnut and almond cake that was just sweet enough but not overbearing.  The service was fantastic as well.  It did not get 5 stars because I really felt like the patrons were packed in the restaurant like sardines.  I'll definitely be back to try other foods here, though.  The table next to us had mussels that looked really good.  Must try in SoMa!
author: Linh L.

description: The place is very small and have very cute atmosphere.  I tried the prawns in pastis sauce...hands down, the best pastis you will ever taste.  I had the seafood basquaise, it was so-so...I've had better.  The service was great.  Overall, it was great, I'm planning to come back to try out their other dishes
author: elle n.

description:
Very mediocre.  I went to this place a few days ago for the Dine Around Town set meal.    The ambience is pretty poor. Lighting was bad.  The interior was cheap.

Anyway, the place got crowded very quickly.  I am not sure if that had anything to do with it but the food was absolutely nothing special.  Seriously, I could have cooked better meals at home.  Worst, the calimari appetizer that came with the set meal made me sick.  Both my gf and I got sick.  I am surprised this place has such good reviews.  Perhaps Fringale just made big vats of food for Dine Around Town.  It's too bad.  I was really hoping to discover restaurants to patronize in the future, and this place is within walking distance from my place.  I won't be coming back.
author: Loc N.

description:
Great date place....Hubby and I went out for a nice dinner. Hadn't had French cuisine in a while...were impressed with soup of the day, fresh tomato basil (non-dairy), fois gras terrine was fantastic served with a recommended dessert wine by our native French server.  My hubby had the Ribeye Pomme Frite while I enjoyed the Rack of Lamb.

Highly recommended for a date with your spouse or special loved one.
author: P C.

description: I've been looking for a good french bistro in SF for ages. This is exactly what we were after. Great simple french bistro dishes, reasonably priced and in a classic setting. I've been back many times since. Love it
author: Richi E.

description: Sorry Fringale - food was ok - nothing amazing out of this world....service SUCKED!  We had reservations - sat down 10 minutes later got our food 90 minutes after we sat down.  Thank God that we were talking about wedding planning - that always is a huge conversational piece that takes up lots of time.  No sense in apology - I've heard about the slow food movement in SF but not the Slow service movement.  Steak was good but I dont know if I was famished, or drunk.....you need more cake and ice cream when you give desserts to a table who is not happy.  Maybe next time.....
author: Shel D.

description: This is my local 'upscale lunch' choice at work. Real French cooking, with real French staff. Always solid, always delicious. The steak and pomme frites is my favorite.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Everything about this place is OUTSTANDING!  
Just check out their website and you'll see

www.fringalesf.com
author: Shasha P.

description: i love this place. i have been here a couple of times with the boy and it has been a magical experience each time. the apps and entrees are phenom, but the reason for the 5 stars is because of the gateau basque. Probably one of the most phenomenal desserts ever ;). This place is adorable and a great place to take a date. It has become our go-to restaurant for pre and post giants games now! hehe
author: Sheeva G.

description:
The food was awesome and the service was great. We ordered the Calamari which was delicious. The main course I had the steamed Halibut and my husband ate the pork which were both really good.
Chocolate dessert was SOOOO GOOD!
author: nit p.

description: This is a great spot. I've been here a couple times and both times had a great experience. Service is very friendly. The food i must say is top notch. Personal favorites for starters are the Spicy Monterrey Calamari with jalapenos & chorizo and the Frisee salad with warm bacon dressing and for entrees the duck con fit and the Black Angus rib eye. I rarely have room left for dessert so i can't tell you how it is. Cozy spot not too loud inside so you can hear whoever your dining with. This is a great place for a first date or a follow up date or a small group of 4-6 friends. Plenty of free parking nearby which is great.
author: mitchell l.

description: Amazing service from our Parisian waiter and the food was excellent. Will definitely  go back.
author: Mat J.

description: Very classy restaurant, I think I was underdressed, haha. The service was decent, I wish it was better
author: Eric A.

description:
quaint and charming means teeny tiny. 
but some good things come in small packages. 

since they were michelin rated, i have seen busloads of people coming in and the dat event was not helping. though it was packed like a clown car at times, the service was never frazzled and the host was a happy and courteous frenchman. 

avoid: the seats at the bar near the door unless you want someone to breathe down your back. 

avoid: the outside seat of the tables near kitchen/bathroom. my poor friend got knocked a few times from diners and servers. 

dine about town menu: 

i ordered the beef carpaccio which was excellent. super thin slices that just melted in your mouth. the veal osso buco was equally flavorful but the meat was a touch tough and not as tender as i would like it. it's an excellent source of vitamins and nutrients - especially helpful when you have a tendency for anemia like myself. 

my friend had the endive salad and the sole which were ok but not as good as the dishes i selected. 

for dessert...the creme brulee was a good dish. the sugar coating was a touch too thick. i like mine a wafer thin crisp but the custard was lovely and creamy. 
i preferred the apple tart which had a flaky buttery crust with a tart apple filling served a la mode.

overall solid homestyle basque dishes and good service in an intimate setting.
author: Anh V.

description:
Came here after a long business trip looking for something nice eat. Decor is very nice and Provencal french - cozy place for a nice evening out with the lady. All the servers have the foreign accent (even though I think it's faked for a few because I heard at least one suddenly lose his accent) - regardless, adds to the ambiance. 

Got the soup de jour, which was a potato chestnut, the mussels, and the creme brulee for dessert. Soup was very flavorful yet light, mussels better than the ones I recently had in Brussels (good combination of garlic and lemon, which really helped bring out the taste).  Could have done without the sourdough bread - while it's a good nod to local tradition, it really did not fit the rest of the meal.

Creme brulee was not bad - at least the creme part. They made a classic novice mistake on the brulee, which was to put too much sugar and attempt to burn it. Made for a really hard glassy shell that I really had to poke my spoon at to break through.  

Food, perhaps a 3 to 3.5 but I'm giving them 4 stars because of the service. Very friendly and generally on the spot, even though I was flying solo (alot of upscale places in SF tend to treat solo diners as second class citizens). Waiters helped out each other and generally added that familiarity feeling that I get when I go to restaurants in Paris or elsewhere in Europe. Without the obligatory snobbishness towards Americans.
author: Dave L.

description:
first off, this place is small (some might say "intimate"--certainly our four-top was intimate :\) and the patrons, at least tonight (12/30, for dinner), were on average at least 45ish years old and seemed to be the marin type. not that that's a bad thing, but just not what i was expecting!

the staff is very nice and pleasant; i'm hoping that's the norm and that i didn't catch them on a "good" day. the service, however, is a bit on the slow side, but i think that's more the kitchen's fault than the servers'.

i tried the duck confit on the recommendation of the other reviews, and frankly, i wasn't wowed by it. the duck wasn't DRY, but i wouldn't call it succulent, either. three stars. others in the party had the chicken, the pork, and the salmon, and they were pleased with their dishes.

dessert, however, is what most definitely pushes the overall review up to 4 stars. i had the gateau basque. such almond-y goodness! the creme brulee was also good, although the crust was a bit too thick/hard for my taste. i had a bite of the pain perdu as well--a winner!
author: Jonathan K.

description:
The food is s good mix of traditional french recipes with a note of modernism. Service was a bit slow. 
This restaurant is very discreet and located in a place you don't expect it to be, it is tiny but cozy. Their wine list is pretty interesting.
There was a big table celebrating a birthday not far and they really seem to enjoy their time there.
Desserts are very nice as well.
author: florence m.

description: Fringale remains one of the most pleasant old-world Basque restaurants in the city, with an imaginative menu in which each dish is beautifully prepared. The service is attentive and caring, and the ambiance is warm and convivial. The prices are reasonable, especially given the caliber of the cuisine.
author: Steve A.

description: Fringales is our favorite San Fran restaurant and is on the top of the list every time we visit the Bay Area. Tables are close together but does not impede conversation, but rather  gives a true French feeling to the ambience.  The waiters are lively and serve food with that passion for food that thrives in the French culture. The food is consistently good, the service fun and amicable, the wine list not extensive, but well selected. You never feel rushed.  Make reservations as space is limited.  A great place to meet up with friends for a relaxing evening French bistro style.
author: nancy a.

description:
It is very difficult to explain how bad this place is.  I left feeling disgusted, offended, and ripped off.   I HAVE NEVER EATEN AT A WORSE RESTAURANT IN MY LIFE.   Terrible food, terrible service, terrible pricing.  They basically charged my wife and I 72.81 (not including tip) to insult us and serve us disgusting food.

In response to the owner's comment, I want to note:  (1) the restaurant was sold a couple years ago which if you read the reviews appears to correspond to a SUBSTANTIAL decline in quality.  (2) In keeping with the terrible nature of this place,  the new owner outright lies and asserts their healthcode scores are "consistently 97-100."  Not true, says the San Francisco Department of Public Health.  most recent rating:  92.  One of the violations noted is, in fact, one of the exact things I listed in my original review of this terrible restaurant (unclean walls).  Check for yourself:  http://www.sfdph.org/dph/EH/Food/Score/default.asp .

Please note:  after writing a bad review for this place the manager contacted me apparently trying to pressure me into changing my review...
author: cody k.

description:
We've been to Fringale twice now, and I have to say: this place is damn good.

I'm not all about highfalutin' Frenchified food, but this is good French food at a fair price.  The fois gras appetizer was SO French, and SO good.  In fact, everything we've ever had here was really good.  

I know, I'm going to hell for that... whatever.  Fringale is a small place, and you will absolutely need reservations for dinner on most nights.  This last time we made ours for a relatively early 6:30pm (one of the only ones left that day) on a Friday through Opentable.  By the time we were leaving, the place was *packed*.
author: Dave N.

description:
it's okay.  i wouldn't come back.  i could think of 4-5 other places i'd rather go... not particularly cute inside and not very good dishes.

but i suppose, don't know till you try.
author: Erika C.

description: The restaurant is small and a little crowded, but the food is quite good.  the calamari appetizer wasn't the usual deep fried appetizer that you'd expect and was quite tasty.  I had a seafood stew type dish (whose name evades me) and it was very good.  the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin and quail also looked delicious.  For dessert I had the Creme Brulee which was done very well.  Our waiter was a little rude... in a teasing manner, but by the end of the meal, it had gotten a little old.  I get it... Americans think French people are rude... you don't have to play the part.  Definitely worth going back.
author: Nedra D.

description: The place was romantic; the wait staff were wonderful; the food was out of this world; fantastic wine list.  A little pricey.
author: Stuart L.

description: I took my coworkers back here and the service was a lot faster this time. However, two of them ordered the duck and it came out really dry =(
author: Anna T.

description:
If there is one thing I hate when it comes to service is arrogance and lack of respect.  The atmosphere was nice.  It's nice enough for a quiet dinner for two.  Not so great for any parties bigger than four.  The food, I've had better.  The serving sizes are your typical large plates with little content.  The only thing that seemed worth the cost was the steak.  Everything else... not so great.  

The waiters.  I've definitely had better service.  I've probably had better  service going to McDonald's.  You ask them for something and what do they do... argue with you.  You ask for a fork, what do they do... say "okay" and never come back with it.  Okay, so this happens everywhere.  But what gets to me was the fact that our waiter argued.  Even after you repeatedly said, "it's fine, it's fine".  Here's the kicker, he came back and argued some more.  I mean, come on!!

The only thing positive was the fact they kept refilling our water glasses without us asking for it.  

Would I recommend this place?  I don't think so.  I'm harsh when it comes to service.  You give me crappy service, I never come back.  The food wasn't impressive enough to override their "hospitality".
author: D G.

description:
Who should eat here:  First time back to Fringale in two years.  Great, authentic French food.  Prices are reasonable, probably not worth a huge trek, but if you are in the mood for French and are in downtown/SOMA area, not much better out there for the price.
 
1 Star - Lacking/Turn Off
2 Stars - Needs Work, But fixable
3 Stars - Adequate
4 Stars - Near perfect, rough edge here or there
5 Stars - Can't get much Better
 
Ambiance/Atmosphere: 3.5 Stars.  Small, quaint, but well put together.  Fringale is tiny, and it fells that way too, but you will not feel crammed in cage or anything.  It helps create a good intimacy.  The place is borderline romantic if you are looking for a date place, and the acoustic level is acceptable so you can hear the person across from you speak.  Its a bit of an older crowd, and if you are looking for a trend setting place and want to be seen, this isn't the place.  Just the setting for a nice quality night out.
 
Service: 4 stars.  Our waiter was fantastic.  I am giving him an extra star for two reasons.  His recommendations were fantastic, and made the meal for a lot of us, and he dealt flawlessly with a table of 8.  WELL DONE!  Bread came on time, our wait for food was perfectly adequate.  All and all it was a job well done.  Given our table size it was hard for special attention, but I have no room to complain about that given the size of our party.  It seemed to that the staff had a great deal of comprehension over not only the menu, but the wine list.  Granted both are not overly complex, but it shows to me they want to take their job and your experience above the average.
 
Food: 4.5 stars.  I think in general this is a four star for food.  Given them a nudge because both my app and entree were recommendations of the waiter and they were fantastic.  Also I tasted two other apps and three other entrees, all were very solid.  So lets begin.  I started off with the grilled calamari.  The waiter promised me it was the best in the city.  Well, he was right.  Are you kidding me this dish was out of hand, I was tempted to go back the next night and order this at the bar.  The squid was grilled perfectly in a very light sauce with jalapenos and some bell peppers and onions.  I also tried the beef carpaccio, which was very tasty, but really no need to order any other starter than the calamari.  Next I had the duck confit over green lentils.  This was very good, but not something that is going to blow you away (it was hard to follow up such a showing after the calamari).  It was about as good as duck confit could be, but I thought the lentil accompaniment was a bit bland.  I like the pork and the truffle risotto just a tad better than my duck.   We passed on desert, so no comment here.
 
Wine: 3 stars.  The wine list at Fringale is great, so don't be scared off by my three stars.  It is very small, very reasonable, and actually matches the food (thank you, this has become a big annoyance for me recently).  The staff has a great knowledge of the wine too.  I ordered a Sancerre and a Gigondas.  Both our waiter confirmed as being fantastic.  I would say they were very, very good, a bit shy of fantastic though (some call me a bit of a wine snob though).  But get this, the total for the two bottles: $74.  Not bad.   I think this could be four stars if they had just a couple more selections, and provide just slightly better glassware.  Overall, well done!!!!!
 
Overall: 4 stars.  A great place for high quality French food, good French wine, and a fun atmosphere in Downtown/SOMA.  And best of all it will not put a huge dent in your pocket book.  In fact, this might be one of the better values in the area.  Check it out, you will not be disappointed.
author: Scott P.

description: Real good.  Some of the best steak frites I've had a in while.  The shrimp appetizer with sundried tomatoes and this lemony sauce was tasty as tasty can be.  Service was very friendly and the ambiance was just right.
author: Mamoon H.

description:
A friend of mine had mentioned they were having the "Dine about Town" in SF and showed me some places where there might be some good menu's to try out. I wanted something different besides sushi (because that's pretty much all I love to eat) so we went ahead and chose Fringale. I 'm not a city person at all, despite living in NYC for 2 years, so I pretty much dread heading up where there is no parking, crowds everywhere and only one bathroom per restaurant where 60 people are eating (did I mention I don't like the city - Haha) but for this, I said why not?
Our reservations were for 8 and we were promptly seated next to the window. Their pre-fix menu had a lot of choices so I was happy with that. I choose the Mussels, Coq Au Vin (I know its spelled wrong), and a Chocolate cake for dessert. 
We end up ordering a bottle of nice Cab Sav, which was really nice and later a half bottle of a Pinot Noir which rocked me out. Their wine selection is really nice and nothing unrepeatable - Very impressed.
The mussels were a bit overcooked  and had little broth but it still had a nice flavor. My friend ordered the Butter lettuce salad and that was just kind of boring. 
My entree was very nice. The meat was extremely tender and felt right off the bone. It wasn't in it's traditional pot but that was fine - I figure they were just trying to bang out dishes as fast as they could to keep up. My date had the Hanger steak with fries and that was very nicely prepared.
My dessert came out next and her's was an Almond Mousse. We actually ended up switching desserts but they were equally wonderful.
Overall, the service was impeccable. Our waiter (can't remember his name but a 30's something man from France) was extremely pleasant and very accommodating. 
I felt very relaxed here, which is surprising since like stated above, I dread SF. I would definitely recommend coming here for their calm, relaxing atmosphere, great service, and nice dishes.
author: Kelly T.

description: We dined there for the first time last weekend and we had an excellent meal. My partner and I shared the shellfish and seafood "basquaise" with steamed spinach (a wonderful spicy seafood stew) and the confit of duck leg with green lentils du Puy (crispy duck over smokey bacon-flavored lentils). Both are highly recommended. Also, the waitstaff was very helpful in making good wine pairings with our meal.
author: Joel A.

description: Came here for dinner and the place is small and crowded. I think the customer service was average, but the food was excellent I had the veal which was nice and fatty. I recommend the petite sirah wine if you are having meat.  The lobster bisque was delicious.  My BF had the Ribeye which is one of my fav.  the dessert was mouthwatering. I would come back again.
author: H. A.

description: Did DAT there.  Yep, affordable French.  First off, I ordered me up a glass of the Cotes du Rhone (tasted like 2 buck chuck). 1st course, sauteed prawns with sundried tomatoes.  My dining pal, Lawrence T., had the chicken pate (think chicken spam).  I know there's something in their prawn sauce cuz before I knew it I had wolfed down all the bread on the table to sop it all up (i completely blanked out - is this what they call food euphoria/high?!?).  Stuffed before the 2nd course came. Then, my lamb shankies on a bed of veggies arrived . . . I took one bite and realized my body wasn't going to be takin' it.   The lamb was good, but too hearty after I had just gorged on all that prawn sauce. Lawrence T. got the soft & tender pork tenderloin served with jolly apples and cabbage - a much lighter dish.  Happily, an exchange was made.  For dessert, got the chocolate cake (can i ask why not bigger?) - deeelicious!  The other dessert was the hazelnut mousse thing - moussey part better than the cakey part. Overall 3.5, pretty good & anything served with a French accent is enhanced!
author: Peg S.

description: omg! yum, yum, & YUM! I was very impressed with the food here as I didn't know what to expect. We ordered a bunch of appetizers and my favorites were the foie gras, Dungeness crab Napoleon, halibut ceviche, gosh, they were all good. I continued on with the Bacon wrapped Pork tenderloin while most others got the rack of lamb and rib eye steak. I loved the pork tenderloin but there are so many other dishes I'd like to try. We were too full for dessert so there's gotta be a next time! :) I hope you enjoy the food at Fringale as much as I did.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Excellent French food.  Don't miss the fries or the spicy calamari.
Food quality has declined slightly over the past year.  The flavor, especially on the calamari or the seafood basquaise has been weakened.  I hope this trend does not continue.

Ambience: French bistro
Service: efficient and friendly
author: Eric T.

description:
After walking past Fringale for the past two years, I finally stopped in for dinner on a recent Thursday evening.  I should have visited a long time ago, as Fringale offers some of the best food I have eaten in Soma.  Fringale was the first restaurant in the neighborhood I ate at and felt like the food and experience were absolutely worth what I paid.  

On the night I went, my family was out of town so I ate at the bar.  Fringale is a small place with tables situated close together and a small, four stool bar.  It looks like it would be a nice place for a romantic dinner/special occasion, or just for a regular night out.  It wasn't too crowded, but you will want to make reservations just to be safe, especially on the weekends.  

I had the the charcuterie plate to start, which featured an excellent country pate and a very good duck rillette.  I ordered the roasted chicken breast for my main course and it was excellent.  The chicken was juicy and the skin was crunchy.  The mashed potatoes and Swiss chard also complimented the chicken well.  I finished the meal with the creme brulee, which was pretty good, although did not stand out from creme brulees offered at other nice restaurants.  The wine list was limited, but I was happy with the Sauvignon Blanc Fringale offered by the glass.  You can probably expect to pay about $100 for two people with two salads/starters, two main courses, dessert and wine.  Based on my experience, it is absolutely worth it.    

An added bonus to sitting at the bar was the opportunity to chat with the bartender/host, whose name I believe is Andre.  He is very friendly and works hard to accommodate guest requests (including running outside to hail a cab for a departing guest).  Several patrons came in and sat at the bar for dinner/drinks while I was there and Andre seemed to know them all by name.    

I will definitely go back to Fringale.  My wife and I hadn't gone previously because my wife is vegetarian and the non-meat offerings are limited at Fringale (as with most French restaurants).  The menu does offer a vegetarian pasta dish.  Andre also said that the chef prepares a vegetarian dish featuring roasted vegetables on request, and occasionally Fringale offers risottos and other vegetarian dishes as specials.

Overall, Fringale has great food and is a great value for the quality of the food you get and the neighborhood it is in.  I gave it four stars, but it should really be 4.5.  If the wine list had been more substantial, I would have given it the full 5 stars.
author: Daniel C.

description:
i love the charm and ambiance of this place. but what i love even more about this place is their rib eye and fries.

Hands down one of the best pieces of red meat I've had and I don't even eat red meat anymore. Oh plus the fries rock.

Service is ok. 

I'm hoping to come back here since I haven't been here for over 3 years (thus the short review), but I promise you that the rib eye here is good. So good, I still remember it after 3 years.
author: Ceana K.

description: This is the perfect Sunday night dinner.  Steak frites and mushroom risotto.
author: Jen C.

description: Had dinner here with my roommate and was not impressed at all.  Was the food good, absolutely.  Was the service attentive, without a doubt.  But, nothing was impressive and I've definitely experienced better.  My favorite dish was the mussel appetizer and the sole entree was filling but a little too buttery.  Also, the bread was mediocre at best, come on, it's the first and least expensive thing you serve! I was very disappointed in the dessert: creme brulee which was served cold and tasted like it was made way ahead of time.  I won't recommend this place to a friend or go back with much inclination.
author: Lillian B.

description: I wasn't expecting much when I came here but was blown away. The service is very french, and the waitstaff was very knowledgeable and attentive. One nice thing about hte restaurant is that it is pretty quiet in comparison to many similar restaurants. The food was outstanding. Lobster ravioli melted in the mouth and the sauce was perfect. The shrimp appetizer was also out of this world. I took a gamble on a dish I would not normally try the seafood basquaise and found it amazing. The mussels, pan-fried chicken, and ling cod also looked outstanding at other tables. Desserts were good but not great and I didn't think the accompanying vanilla ice cream was strong - I tried the apple tart and the chocolate cake.
author: Keith R.

description: The only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is that we had to sit at the bar and my feet were dangling...But the food and wine were amazing!!!!! Delish terrine for apps, yummy stew and friendly staff.
author: Julie D.

description: Came here a few years ago for dine about town. Don't remember what I had, but had a very good meal. I will come back.
author: Helen L.

description: This has been a long-time favorite of ours.  They have the best frisee salad and a yummy lobster bisque.  It's a very small, intimate place with a decent wine selection and great service.  A party of four would have a great time without feeling crowded.  Make sure you have a reservation if you don't want to stand around the front door or outside in the cold.
author: Nina L.

description:
Very cute, quiet place with a sultry soundtrack playing in the background...an added bonus for myself. For an appetizer my date and I shared dungeness crab Napoleon with avocado and mango. The crab was noticeably fresh and the avocado was more like a 'gucamole' between the two layers of crab. Small pieces of mango were placed on top which created a very interesting flavor. (Highly recommended!) For our entree we had the roasted chicken breast, brussel sprouts ,black trumpet mushrooms & thyme sauce along with black angus ribeye steak, pommes frites with red wine butter sauce. Both were excellent and had an amazing flavor. 
Dessert was also amazing, but how can you go wrong with chocolate, bananas and coconut ice cream!? 
The service was great and very polite and helpful. Try not to fill up on all the delicious bread before the meal!
author: Whitney K.

description: semi-okay. My steak was okay, nothing incredible about the place.
author: Michael S.

description:
After eating at Chou Chou's, I was thinking that all French restaurants could be the same... Boy, was I in for a surprise!!! Most importantly, if there is anything that being Asian-PacIslander has taught me, it is the following: if the sauce makes your rice taste better, then the dish is damn good. Fringale's sauces are so flavorful that it resonates in your mouth for at least a full minute and keeps you yearning for more. The thought just makes me close my eyes and say "MMMMM!!" and a lick of my pursed lips.

Since I am the first to arrive, I decided to go check-in as well as do my mandatory skim of the restaurant. The bar is quite trendy. The restaurant is VERY small in size compared to the amount of tables and patrons. Space is very tight and people are practically sitting back-to-back. The lighting is very dim so I wasn't sure if I recognized anybody. The maitre'd said he'll seat me when the rest of my party arrive.   

We are mostly present (party of 7) and so we scoot, slide, shimmy, our way in between chairs and tables to get ours. The escorts are wonderful as they pull our chairs out for us (so chivalrous) and help us remove our coats. Since there is still one person missing form our party, we can't go over the menu. It seems that there is a huge lag time and we are quite hungry. The waiter brings us our waters and although it took forever, we ordered a bottle of wine. The waiter was very helpful in choosing our wine. As the men at the table said, "He is Inspector Cloiseau." BTW, he is very french (no joke) and extremely friendly!. 

Once we order SOMETHING, we also have our assortment of breads served to us pipping hot with REAL butter. And I mean REAL!!! It is creamy as heck and it retains it's shape. I'll say it now, it is THE BEST BUTTER that I have ever had. Our other friend finally arrives and so we can finally order. Though my friends are disappointed that they removed the Rib-Eye Steak from the DAT menu, they do find things that tantalize their tastebuds. We soon are served our wine which is light and slightly sweet (Muscadet Clos Les Montys).

Once our food orders were entered, service was very rapid. Since DAT is 3 courses for $31.00 p/p, our first course arrived. Most of us opted for the special appetizer of the night: The Lobster Bisque. Oh my goodness, we were all in heaven when we tasted this. It is a tomato-based soup with a dollop of cream (swirled in the middle of the little cup). The waiter puts some fresh ground pepper on top. The soup was accompanied with some toasted mini-baguette slices with what looked like a velveeta cheese spread. It was all YUMMY!!! Someone also ordered the sauteed prawns pastis with sundried tomatoes. Oh yes, the sauce on this baby was so buttery, garlicky and what ever else. Thank God for refills on the bread b/c we were dipping into each other's soups, sauces, etc. all night. Another person had the beef carpaccio which they enjoyed very much. At the end of the appetizer, ALL OF US were literally taking the breads and soaking whatever liquid we had left on the plates. Even better, one of the chefs or owners would walk around and smiled whenever he came by our table and I was screaming "MMMMM!!!" at every bite of anything. 

For the main course, I choose the special for the night which was a white bean stew with proscuitto, ham, pork confit, and homemade sausage. Oh my!!!! I was floating on clouds at this point once I had that first scoop in my mouth. It was again a tomato-based stew and smoky pork-flavored. It seemed that everything was simmered to perfection. Every bite of pork melted in my mouth. The stew didn't seem fatty. Again, we were all dipping the bread into each other's dishes. The sauce on the Petrale Sole was again buttery and garlicky and whatever else. the sauce on the Lamb Osso Buco was also very good but a bit on the gamey side (I am not a lamb fan thought). The sauce on the Pork Tenderlon was also very good. I would order this next time I come or try the mussels. All of the portions were perfect size as we didn't have leftovers but were not left hungry. Again the chef or owner was quite pleased with my ""MMMS" and "AAAHHHs".

Finally, our desserts. I ordered the Pear tart. This was delicious, but what made it even more delicious was when you combine everything (the pears, the ice cream, the crust, the kiwi, and the strawberry) in my mouth. The mixture of flavors and textures made my eyes roll back in utter shock as to how good this was. I honestly do not know what they did to the kiwis and strawberries, but those by itself was savory enough. The Creme Brulee was good. The Hazelnut and Roasted Almond Mousse was also soft and silky, but rather sugary for my tastes. The coffee kicks a$$. Loved it so much I had 3 cups. 

We loved our meal so much we were bopping to the beat of the French music as we left the restaurant. We had managed to stay for 3 hours. The staff was still friendly at the end of the night as well. Smiles!!!
author: Lorna D.

description: Je crois que j'ai bien compris le sens du mot "fringale"...Si je suis a la fin d'un marathon, et mes jambes ne travaille plus - je n'ai pas la puissance de passer l'ancienne femme devant moi, j'exprimerais "Je n'ai pas de fringale!"  J'ai bien bouffe la bas, mais je crois qu'il y avait au moins une tasse de sel dans le poulet...Heureusement j'aime le sel.
author: ellyk E.

description: I'm not sure what happened Thursday night that made many tables get seated at the same time... but waiting 20 minutes for your check is a bit much. That said, my Coq Au Vin (a special that night) was just right: fall of the bone tender chicken in a earthy mushrooms & wine sauce over mashed potatoes. Unfortunately I wasn't hungry enough to have an appetizer so I'll have to come back to try the mussels.  Is this destination dining? No.  But if you're in the neighborhood and looking for a "scene-free" restaurant to have a good french meal at, stop into Fringale.
author: Natasha R.

description: Was there for Dine About Town but I ended up ordering from the regular menu.  Food was just ok.  Wasn't blown away.  Started with the Dungeness Crab Napoleon, which was good and something I'd order again.  For the entree I ordered the Seafood Basquaise which was ok--a very rustic and warm dish, but just not my thing.  As for the service, I was pleasantly surprised.  I was expecting snooty, horrible service based on some of the other reviews.  Although not the greatest service ever, I've definitely had a lot worse and the waiter didn't seem really stuck up.  The place is charming but tiny.  It gets pretty warm in there so I'd probably save the trip for a cooler evening when I want to be tucked away somewhere cozier.  I'll probably give this place one more try before putting it on my pass list.
author: Tara C.

description: I had the best sea bass ever last Saturday night.  It was in a piperade sauce and so full of flavour.  I also had the fava bean, carrot, asparagus, etc...salad that was delicious!   It's a small place but felt very welcomed and well taken care of.  Will definitely go back.
author: Bea A.

description: " Like Ceasar and the Terminator used to say:"Vini, Vidi, I'll be back" Come, bring up a new level of a fine dinning, enjoy yourself the "french way". Simple meal, nice presentation, you can take it seating at the bar where you'll see the ballet of the staff satisfying every bit of your experience, relax, have a nice chat with that smiling bartender or take a table for a romantic dinner. While there, ask for the chef and see the face behind this ephemere artwork. Beware to the side effects : addiction, chronic goose bumps and endless water-mouthing dreams. Only one remedy :  Must go back.
author: jean-michel b.
