description: I researched for hours to find the perfect restaurant to bring my friend to on his 29th birthday. I wanted fantastic food, impeccable service, and authentic tastes- all in one. I got average service with the waiter taking our food away before we had finished it, and subpar food, with the soup having too little salt and really too little flavor in general. I wouldn't shun this restaurant but I don't think I will ever willingly go back. Not awful, just definitely not worth 5 stars.
author: Nicole S.

description:
Came here for Dine About Town (DAT) and some of us ordered off the special menu and some of us didn't. We all ended up tasting/sharing and most of the food was pretty good. The steak was great and the coq au vin was by far the best I've ever had. I was extremely disappointed in the overcooked, tasteless pork tenderloin and my friend was really unhappy with the tiny piece of yucky duck. My butter lettuce salad was good enough for me to make yummy noises (unusual for a salad!) and the mussel appetizer my boyfriend got was an extremely generous portion. I thought the desserts were just okay, not great.

The service was fine, but because the food ranged from "fantabulous" to "meh" I can only give this place three stars. I want consistently fabulous food. Fab-food, if you will. 

If you go, get the coq au vin and be sure to have a reservation--the place is tiny.
author: Tracie L.

description:
I'm not sure how to rate this place.  Some of the dishes were spectacular, but others felt very below par for the cost of the food.

It was a Tuesday night for a large party (surprise party for that matter).  For a party of 13, we got our plates rather quickly, from appetizers to entrees to dessert.  For the size of the restaurant, they were nice enough to accommodate our large party.

As for the food...  The carpacio was alright, nothing spectacular about it.  The soup was rather cold, that was a surprise.  The Dungeness crab Napoleon was a must have, this was a very well prepared dish, very tasty.  I still think Foie Gras is best served seared IMHO.  The salmon I had for my entree was prepared very well.  Nicely seared on the outside to a crisp.  It was just right on the inside slightly moist and not dry at all.  Along with the lobster sauce it was spectacular.  Although I didn't have a chance to try the other entrees, I didn't hear many yays or boos at all from any of my fellow coworkers.  As for the dessert, the only thing memorable on the menu was the Hazelnut & roasted almond mousse cake.  The creme brulee had was on the cold side, meaning it had been sitting out for a while.  The same with another friend that had the creme brulee (which I ended up finishing also (OMGTHATSLIKE3000CALORIESPLUS3000CALORIES!?!?!GOTTAHITTHATGYMNOW).

Overall I expected a lot, and was only partially satisfied.  For a slightly more expensive price, I would say Chapeau! is by far a better choice.
author: Clifford C.

description: Great little french restaurant just around the corner from our place.  Apparently this place has been around a while and the emphasis is definitely on substance rather than SOMA flash.  Fringale is by far my wife's and I favorite place in the neighborhood.  The steak pom-frits is solid as is the coco vaughn.  The menu is limited, but everything is excellent.
author: David B.

description: Fringale is one of those snotty places by the CalTrain station--you walk home and wonder who the hell are those yuppies having such a lavish dinner on a freakin' Tuesday? No matter...Fringale's food is delish. I've been there twice, once with a regular and once anonymously. The service was excellent both times and the second time, the actually French waiter did not make me feel too stupid about ordering wine. And! For a nice romantic dinner and a nice bottle of wine, the damage wasn't really that bad! I'm not sure I'd go out of my way to dine here, but if you're in the neighborhood and you want fancy, or you're just rich anyways, it's solid.
author: SheRat R.

description: I hate to share my secret with the rest of San Francisco-Fringale is the best place for a first date. Every time I have gone there, its been on a first date- and its always able to subdue any awkwardness with its pretty scenery and yummy food. There are lots of lovely things on the menu, but I personally love the organic chicken breast with fingerling potatoes and roasted corn. I would make a reservation, and even then there might be a wait. Sit at the bar and munch on some Acme bread. Its hidden away along fourth street, and always warm inside-especially if the date goes well :)
author: Michelle K.

description: Excellent food - always. I've been dining here several times a week for lunch/dinner since it opened and I've never had a bad meal.  The wine list always has unique choices that complement the food.  All this with professional waiters (yes, real professionals - ask for Andre') and very reasonable prices.  Want a restaurant that consistently performs?  It's Fringale.
author: Sabrina B.

description:
I met up with a few friends for dine about town at Fringale last night.  Good wine, great company, cute environment, good service, bland food... that about sums up my experience at Fringale last night.  

Nestled away on 4th Street close to the ball park is Fringale, a cute and cozy French restaurant.  On a weeknight, street parking was easy - I parked only steps away from the restaurant.  The five of us were seated at a round table soon after our arrival.  The table looked small but it was surprisingly comfortable and perfect for conversations.

Our waiter was efficient in taking our order and suggested a delightful, light red wine for us - Patricia Green Pinot Noir.  I ordered the Black Angus beef carpaccio served with capers, Etorki cheese & olive oil for appetizer, fettucine pasta with chanterelles, baby carrots, artichokes & parmesan cheese for entrée, and crème brûlée for dessert.  The carpaccio was practically tasteless, despite the other ingredients in the dish.  I ordered the pasta mainly for the chanterelles, a flavorful mushroom.  But I was disappointed; that, too, was bland.  It basically tasted a little creamy/oily (read:rich) and that's pretty much it.  I had a bite of my friend's Veal Osso Bucco; that has a little more flavor to it - meat flavor - but pretty bland otherwise.  It was as if the chef ran out of salt in the kitchen and washed all the ingredients under the water 10x to rid them of flavor before cooking them.  The only decent part of my meal was the crème brûlée - creamy, just the right size and right amount of sweetness.  

Overall, I still had a great night hanging out with my friends at an intimate, charming restaurant.  Just wish the food was a little more up to par.
author: Christine C.

description:
So I'd actually been here once...then was trying to find new restaurants to try for mother's day...saw Fringale on yelp with 4 stars and 275 reviews, didn't remember that I'd been before, and came back. 

This place is a cute little place that has a very homey feel to it. For mother's day dinner, it was squuuuished with tables where waiters barely had room to move around us. I was rubbing elbows with the nice lady at the table behind me. 

The four of us (myself, the mother, the father, and the sister) started with three appetizers: 1) the calamari which is sauteed with slivers of chorizo and olives in a kind of oily sauce, 2) a crab salad beautifully presented in a tower, with tomatoes and avocado, and 3) pate-ish foie gras with orange marmalade, some greens, and toast. All of these were very very tasty. I think the first time I came, I also had the calamari and actually don't think I liked it much. Maybe because there was only two of us and only one appetizer so it was really heavy/salty.

As for entrees, the wait in between appetizer to entree was PAINFUL. It was probably like 20 minutes? We ordered something similar to a seafood bouillabaisse, but it was called something else, seafood basquaise? This was ok. I think I had this the first time I'd been here and seeing that I don't really remember...must've been not that memorable of a dish. I had the veal osso ruso. This is a big chunk of veal with bone still attached. Super tender, I found it a little salty and heavy, but wasn't too bad because I was sharing my family's entrees. They were sweet and substituted asparagus instead of fava beans for me, yay! It also came with some other veggies like broccolini and some rice pilaf (very little) kind of mixed into the sauce and veggies. The last entree was the mussels, which were very yummy! It had a pesto sauce with some garlic and onions. There were a lot, but it really was more of an appetizer than entree. It only came with a couple slices of crostini. We got some of their pomme frites to go with it. These fries were pretty good, but it kind of seemed like we got the bottom of the barrel for these...most of them were pretty brown and pretty short fries, rather than the nice long, golden fries I saw at other tables. On request, they gave us some aioli to eat with it, which was good.

My favorite part was the dessert. I was super excited to find out that they had profiteroles as their special dessert! Profiteroles are like cream puffs with ice cream instead of cream. It's a little pastry puff cut in half and ice cream put in the middle! They drizzled some chocolate on top and Christine is one happy little camper. I'd never seen this before, but even the puff pastry was chocolate flavored. They put plain vanilla ice cream in the middle, which went very well with the chocolate. YUM. It comes in three and I think I ate 2 and 1/2...the other half was for my mom, dad, and sister. We also got this warm chocolate cake with some berry compote, pretty good. Lastly, we got homemade truffles...mm dark chocolate goodness. It also came with some cookie/biscuit-y things to complement the truffles.

Overall, it was a very enjoyable meal. I think the appetizers, the mussels, and the profiteroles really stood out to me. The waiter switched our bill with the table next to us (150 vs 250, ours being the cheaper!) and I luckily checked the bill!! Anyway, our table was ready when we arrived on time to our reservation. Service was fairly attentive, but not amazing. Got cozy with the neighboring table, but maybe because it was Mother's Day? Food was enjoyable, but is it memorable without me writing it down on yelp? Maybe not because I hardly remember my first time here. 3.5 stars if I could.
author: Christine L.

description: The food was great and the service was just as good as the food. I will definitely go to Fringale again.
author: david l.

description: Small, cozy restaurant.  If you don't like to feel cramped, I'd ask for a window seat (which is what I did and it was fine).  Loved my food and we had a really friendly waiter.  Perfect place for a first date.
author: Kris L.

description: This place is like a sophisticated mom & pop diner, but French and that is why I love it. I mostly come for lunch because I love their tuna burger; you actually have to order it medium-well, else it will come out like a huge piece of sashimi on a bun. A lot of other French restaurants are overdone for the California self-proclaimed foodie crowd, so I appreciate this place most for their authenticity in dcor, service and menu.
author: Midori G.

description:
its coo, its coo. i enjoyed my experience here. i went with a group of my out-of-towner buddies and praise of satisfaction all around. we ordered the bowl of mussles, and i honestly was expecting to get five pieces at most, but to my surprise got a big o' bucket full!!! it was so tasty. service was great. our waitress had the greatest french accent. 

a bit pricey, but the food and service was well worth the cost.
author: MrBoomBastic ..

description: The salad was simple but refreshing. The sweet bread was prepared well and my bacon wrapped pork was delicious. The calamari and crab appetizers are by far my favs though. I also like the fact that its a small spot; it feels a little more intimate. My only complaint, the tables are super close and you end up getting nudged and accidentally walked into by people trying to get by. The tuna burger also looked amazing. I am def. planning on going back and trying it out.
author: shadi m.

description: Great food! Great atmosphere! Awesome waiter-he looked liked a french wolverine!!! We went for an early dinner. I took advantage of the early bird special (good before 6pm). With that I got the black angus beef carpacio, the salmon and the chocolate cake. They were all delicious for such a reasonable price. My fiancee got the foie gras, the rooster (special for the day)  and a vanilla pastry. He loved his food as well. Our bill came out to approx $86 after tax and tip. Not bad for all the quality food (plus 2 glasses of wine)we had!! The service was great and the waiter (again..who looked like wolverine) had a great knowledge of the wine selection. Highly recommended!
author: Emily C.

description:
Fringale is a steady, reliable, excellent french bistro located south of market.  On our first visit since Gerald Hirogoyen has sold his ownership stake, both Liz and I were anxious to see if the food was as good as I remembered.  We weren't disappointed, in fact, the food was better!!  No slight on Gerald, but the food coming out of the kitchen was flavorful, masterfully prepared and wait staff were friendly and helpful throughout our meal.  
After selecting our appetizers of escargot in a pesto sauce for Ron and Liz had sauteed prawns in pastis with sundried tomatoes.  Both were tasty and not too rich.
Our entrees were Rib Eye Steak for me and a nightly special for Liz fish on a rosemary skewer.  My steak was excellent, prefectly prepared and very tasty.  Liz was a bit less enamored with her dish, and felt that it was lacking in flavor and execution.  A little salt perhaps?
We had an excellent 2003 Gevry Chambertin red with our meal.
For dessert we had Hazelnut & roasted almond mousse cake.
Layers of hazelnut mousse and genoise topped with roasted almonds.  The dessert was very very good.
Fringale is a keeper, great food, excellent wait staff, just a good reliable place to go have a nice lunch or dinner.   -Ron and Liz
author: Ron T.

description: It was nice, especially the french fries and the wine list (not too expansive for a french restaurant).
author: Laurent R.

description: I have eaten here several times at lunch. it's a real gem and I am always surprised there isnt a line out the door.   everything is always worth the money.  I love the seafood stew and the professional waiters.
author: Cazsh R.

description: went here last night for dine about town- I actually went off the dine about menu and ordered from the real deal! I had the salad with bacon dressing and poached egg (OMG!) and chicken with mushrooms and noodles (not my fav) my hot friend had the muscles (OMG!) skirt steak and french fries with green beans (OMG!) For dessert we shared this delicious apple tart with ice cream and caramel sauce....unbelievable! I would have given FIVE *stars* but service was a little on the slow side between dishes and when it came to picking up the check!
author: Ricquel N.

description: I love this restaurant and I'm not really a fan of going out to eat.  The food is always excellent, the wine superb, the staff friendly, and the other patrons a joy.  oh yeah, and the prices are reasonable!  It's a great cozy place for an intimate dinner.
author: shannone e.

description: I like course meals.  So we opted for that.  In this case it was 3 course.  The 1st dish was a salad.  Pretty good.  The second was the entree.  I got the steak.  I have to say the steak was fantastic.  It was comparable to Bobo's.  (Suprising)  However we go to the French restaurants for the frites!  And they need to work on that.  (Create some Aoli to start)  But like I said the steak made this place a winner for me.  Oh, I forgot the desert.  Some of the best desert I've had too.
author: Chad C.

description:
it seems like everyone's got most of this place covered, but i just wanted to chime in to say that i, too, had a wonderful experience.

the service was impeccable from the start, with a charming and unpretentious waiter who always seemed to materialize at the right moments.

sure, the food was delicious - i started with the calamari, which was tender, fresh, and a bit spicy (the chorizo is a really nice touch). i was surprised when i saw that it wasn't fried, but it somehow worked.

i had the lamb, which was tender and flavorful, and i ended with the almond torte - yum. my date started with the beef carpaccio, which was really thin! he initially thought it was a pink sauce at the bottom of his plate.  it was still pretty tasty. 

his steak & frites also went over well - the fries were crispy and delicious, and tasted even better drenched in the red wine butter sauce. i stole a few to dip in the sauce from my lamb, which worked well. 

despite the delectable meal, i'd have to say the best part of the night was the matre d, for 3 reasons:

1. he sat us down at our table even though we were 20 minutes early; the table was obviously prepared for us in advance, because my boyfriend had sent flowers to the restaurant and they were waiting there for me when we sat down.  i think i owe this to opentable.com's 'order flowers' feature. 

2. when i excused myself to go to the restroom, he swooped in behind me and whispered in my ear "it's ahead to the left, my love" before i had even displayed any signs of looking for it. so classy.

3. when we went outside to catch a cab, it was pouring rain. he was already in the street under an umbrella, hailing a cab for another couple. he got one for us, too, without even batting an eye. 

as i got into the cab, i was positively glowing from the entire experience. the food, the ambience, the service - perfecto.
author: natalie m.

description:
We just celebrated a family birthday at Fringale.  This was our first visit to this restaurant which was recommended to us by the concierge of a local hotel.

Authentically French cuisine beautifully presented!  Attentive service.  Even French music.   It was a wonderful evening.  Could not have better unless actually located in France!
author: carol e.

description: Great food, nice atmosphere, great staff. We go here for special occations. This is one restaurant that we still think is great, even after our trip to the countryside near Toulouse France. Yes, it is authentic Basque/French food.
author: Jennifer D.

description: I just loved my meal. I ordered the lamg and it was prepared exquisitely. I went with my best friend in the whole world. She was visiting from down under. Two other friends that we share took us there. We all had wonderful dishes. We were all trying tastes of each other's dish and the deserts as well! And the waiter had a really good humor. I would go there again and recommend it. It's a small place and cozy.
author: Christine U.

description:
It's a bit old school, but hey so are you.

I've been to Fringale once before and remember having a good meal and was so happy to have that reinforced this past weekend. I was able to book within a week of the desired date for 9 people on Open table, and was happy that we could get in. They called to confirm the reservation, which is great because you never know if the restaurant gets that Open Table request sometimes, I've been left hanging in the past. Got seated right as we got there, felt bad because we were a little late, but it was no problem with them. Very laid back atmosphere, decor is sort of French, not fussy at all. The food is Basque, and you can tell in a few of the dishes, especially the Calamari, very yummy. The food is basically good quality unpretentious French food, Everyone at the table was very impressed. Service was slow, they could have made a few more bucks off of our drink orders had they remembered, but in the end it made for a affordable gourmet meal. Wine selection was good, prices very reasonable.

This place is a standard the some of the new places should try to stand by.
author: Brian Thomas M.

description:
All I can say is that Fringale is wonderful. From the impeccable service to each and every dish being absolutely delicious, this restaurant has everything going for it. I lived in Paris for a long time and am a nightmare for most French restaurants in the US since I'm both a "foodie" and have very high standards for French cuisine. Fringale lived up to and then exceeded all of my expectations... Several times I had flashbacks to Paris just from the taste of whatever I was eating. I had made the reservation for our party of 10 without ever dining at Fringale, and I was thanked by everyone in the party upon leaving... I will definitely be back!

Personal faves: calamari "a la plancha", frisee salad w/ warm bacon dressing, rack of lamb, pain perdu, apple tart
author: Patricia M.

description: Intimate, and romantic. I really had an eye opening experience here since it was my first time being at a French restaurant. The waiter was outstanding and very knowledgeable about the menu and wine selection. Their rib eye steak was killer! Will definitely be going back there!
author: Joon Y.

description: Sorry not going back there again. If you're lucky or come with big group of friends then you probably wont have any problem wit the table set up for 2 people. These tables were abreast right next to each other with little less than no room. I had to hold my pee until everyone around me was done with their food. It was that bad. The food is mediocre nothing fancy or interesting. I could have cooked it at home following Giada's recipes. Haha! Wait..Giada is italian...hm.
author: Michael K.

description: I liked this place a lot.  Came here with a group and everyone was satisfied with their choice - except for one person who found a hair in her food.  The waiter apologized and gave her a different entree.  The desert is really good too!  Prices are a tad high but it's forgivable because the food is good.
author: Nunya B.

description: Horrible service, we has to ask for someone to take our food and wine order. Food was unappealing and the restaurant is too small so you almost sitting with everyone there. Will never go back again.
author: leah p.

description: Great food at a great price, need I say more?  Fringale is an adorable gem in SOMA, close to Caltrans and the Ballpark that I love to take my friends to.  Love the mussels, duck confit, wine list, and the staff, who have helped make some great recommendations for some picky friends.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Solid food, good wine, you get what you pay for here.  this place is not cheap but in line with what you'd expect from a cute French restaurant.  I did like the fish dish and the apps a lot.  We were adventurous and got the sweet bread (for anyone who doesn't know what that is, it's not made of bread), and we got the foie gras.  Both were very good.  The dessert was also good, though nothing crazy or inventive - tasty basic is how I'd put it.  I think this place would be a very nice date place.  It's cozy, not a ton of tables, and nice ambiance.
author: Tiffany C.

description: There isn't enough Basque food in the city. Vive la basquaise! Went there intending to get one of the prix-fixe Dine About Town dinners but was happily lured away to a la care options. Great food, but the place is cramped, though the highly professional wait staff do an amazing job of working within the space.
author: David Y.

description:
This place used to be so good, back when Mr. Hirgoyen held it...it was a place you could get a to die for three course French meal for about $30 a head.

Now it's fine, but nothing special....it's hard to find affordable French food in SF..Le Charm at 5th and Folsom is pretty good.....and definitely very reasonable.
author: Darien W.

description: This French basque eatery can almost be called a hole-in-the wall since it's such a tiny place. Even though the seating area is small, the food is delicious. I had the shrimp to start off and the sauce was to-die-for and great for dipping bread. Next I had the lamb which came in a stew with vegetables, which was also just as good. I'm a risotto lover so I ordered the mushroom risotto which they made with wild rice, and I definitely wish I had more. I was with my boyf and he had the rib-eye, which was okay. This isn't a steakhouse, so I would stick to the other French food. I liked the chocolate cake more than the almond hazelnut mouse, but my boyf liked the other one more. It was either 3 or 4 stars, but I gave it 4 since I would recommend it and go back again.
author: Ivy C.

description:
Somewhat of a strange experience at this restaurant. The food was fantastic (butternut squash soup, ribeye, roasted chicken, creme brulee). The evening environment was solid ... not exactly elbow-to-elbow coziness but no tumbleweeds rolling through either. As a restaurant-goer, I'm low maintenance - I order quick, never complain about the food, pride in being polite/respectful, enjoy the food, and tip well.

But the one thing I had issue with at Fringale was the service. Again, it may be hard to put into words but our waiter (seemingly nice chap with moustache and requisite French accent) sprinkled in some off-putting remarks and slightly uncomfortable vibe throughout the evening.

For example:

When ordering our appetizer (butternut squash soup), my GF ordered first and asked for it. OK. But then, when it was my turn, I said, "The butternut sounds delicious, I'll order that too." The waiter responded, "Well, that's our ONLY soup so you can't get anything else." Huh? Where did that come from? Thinking it was the dry French "humor" I let it go ... even though it was clearly snide.

Then after completing our meal, the waiter ambled over and asked, "Are you done?" ... and my GF said, "Yes, but I'd love to see the dessert menu." Again, the waiter responded, "You may have never been to a French restaurant before but we CLEAR the table before we bring the dessert menus." Again, huh? Where did that come from? At this, I sighed and I guess he got the message ... quickly clearing the table, swiping the cloth clean, and scurrying off. The dessert and subsequent bill went smoothly (but the waiter said nothing; no "enjoy" or "thanks").

Again, the interactions were brief. But I understand humor and wit. And I understand condescension. And this waiter's attitude was clearly leaning towards the latter. He went the extra mile to make pretentious remarks ... certainly did not ruin the evening (thankfully, this wasn't a "date") or the delicious meal but made us think twice about frequenting the restaurant again. I'm trying to convince myself that I'm being overly sensitive but it's that gut feeling, you know? Look, I get it. French = French, especially when it comes to the food. I've eaten at La Grenouille and Left Bank and everything in between. But here, my "rude" radar was beeping quite loudly.

When my GF and I were walking home, she volunteered, "Was it me or did the waiter seem off?" and I agreed ... so it obviously just wasn't me.
author: Mike C.

description:
went for a graduation dinner here.  most excellent.

must gets apps:
crab napoleon
spicy calamari
frisee salad (with warm bacon)

must get entrees:
bacon wrapped pork loin
duck confit

well come to think about it, everything we ordered in our party was excellent.  i will definitely come back here.  the service is excellent.
author: Jason J.

description: Came here for dinner back in May and I still remember really enjoying the braised veal short ribs! So delicious and tender, my bf had the coq au vin and was really happy with it as well. I also had the foie gras to start which was very rich and a good start to the meal. The portion size was perfect for me and I have a pretty healthy appetite, no food left to take home but left feeling full and not overly stuffed. Nice ambiance for a small restaurant and not to loud. This would be a great place to take people from out of town or  for a small dinner party.
author: Cristina F.

description: Went with a group of friends and had a great time. Very flavorful food. Please leave room for dessert. The hazelnut mousse that I had was absolutely awesome I (pretended to) refused to share it with my friends. Service can be a bit spotty at times but not too bad overall. The noise was at a minimum that we were able to have a conversation and not have to shout to be heard. Great experience and we all agreed that we would go back again.
author: Jo D.

description: Wow, this place has gotten trashed - but I'll stick by it. I really like Fringale. It's classic, but not stuffy, they mix a good drink, and the food, while bistro style is really solid. They have a way with foie gras. It's true, I wish they changed their menu more, and that it has definitely changed for the worse once Hirigoyen left - but come on! I think the food is as good or better then Chez Papa and the service has been better at Fringale in my experience.
author: michael c.

description: I went here with an ex-girlfriend and we had a fabulous meal. The fois grois apetizer we had was wonderfully decadent. If you don't have anything against it, I would highly suggest it. The casoulet was wonderful all around. The duck and sausages were magnificent. The wine list is made up primarily of French and Spanish wines are most all of them pair well with the food. This place is romantic and the food great. Bring a date here. You'll have a very nice dining experience.
author: Steve H.

description: Had a wonderful meal here Wednesday evening.  Got the prix fixe meal and had an excellent bottle of wine suggested by the server.  I had the endive salad, fettucine w/chanterelles & baby carrots and the creme brulee.  All of them were great and well portioned.  My BF had the crab ravioli, osso bucco and the lemon tart.  The latter two were excellent.  The ravioli tasted fishy.  We also had a drink to start, which I'd skip in the future as a bottle of wine is plenty and the drinks weren't anything special.  The service was excellent and well-paced (no rush) and it was a romantic setting.  Definitely will be back.
author: Kevin M.

description: This is some seriously good French food. Amazing value and excellent service! I recommend the pate and rib eye/frites. Great Beaujolais on the menu as well. If I was really picky, I'd update the decor...
author: Matt W.

description:
Fringale came highly recommended by one of my former co-workers so I decided to round up a bunch of friends to experience the Dine About Town menu.

Here is what I ordered:
- Pate de campagne served with mache, cornichons & toasts - Not the best that I have had, but the flavor was good and the spicy mustard sauce that came on the side of the toast was a nice addition
- Flat iron steak served with haricot verts, pommmes frites in a red wine sauce - Served rare...JUST like I had asked. The red wine sauce was very good, even though I usually like my steaks plain. 
- Hazelnut & roasted almond mousse cake - Probably my favorite part of the meal. I am a sucker for hazelnut and this was very rich and had a long hazelnut aftertaste! Great with coffee.

My only complaint is that the 5 of us (some of who were very tall) were seated at a table that probably only should have seated 4 small to mid sized people. Fringale has a very "cozy" dining room and it is packed with tables from wall to wall though. All in all, what a great French restaurant that has decent portion sizes and very reasonable prices!!
author: Matt K.

description: Nice little place for a romantic dinner.  It is a small place and I guess I could see how some might call it cramped, but think intimate is a better description.  While the food isn't the best in the city it is very good and reasonably priced.  My girlfriend and I went last week and had a very nice dinner for $120, we did bring our own wine.  The service that we received was excellent.
author: Steve S.

description:
"The Urge to Eat".  Can't go wrong with a name like that!  
Nice place tucked in the corner off 4th and. Brennan  The place was bustling when I arrived with groups sloshing away their coutour red wines.

I was there for my bday dinner with my gf and we arrived promptly for our reservation.   The first thing I noticed was how stuffy the place was when I walked thru the entrance.  We were promptly seated by the window upon announcing our reservation.  This was a relief seeing that there were up to 5 people waiting for a table by the bar!

Appetizers
We scanned through the menu with a quick run-through by the waiter of the chef special.  We decided to order the calamari and the prawns.  The calamari was alright .  I definitely suggest trying the prawns!  It had a lot of colorful flavor and was so fresh.  

Entree
I had the pork tendorloin while my companion choose the Australian sea bass in lobster reduction.   The presentation was very well done for both dishes.   My pork was very very tender.  Although I have to say that the pork was a little lite on flavoring.  The Austrailian Sea Bass is definitely the dish to get!  The sauce was phenomenal.  Added to the sauce, you have greens, sliced potato beds, and mushrooms to complete the experience.  

Dessert
We decided to share the house variety sorbet.  It wasn't to my liking especially for dessert because it was so tart.  I believe the sorbet was apricot and strawberries with cherrie puree.  The sorbet was also served with two cookie swirls to complement to tart flavoring with a bit of crunchy texture.  Neither myself nor my companion really enjoyed it.  

Overall, I'd say its a 4 star and I certainly will go back.  Although the place is small, its dishes certainly speak volumes in taste.
author: Michael C.

description: a yummy soma staple. classic french cuisine that acts as comfort food.
author: Ronnie R.

description:
Evaluating the food alone, I will give a two-star.  What I like most about the Fringle is not the food but the service, which I will give 3.5 stars.  I went to Fringle for the first time about 6 years ago. Over the years, I have gone there probably once a year on average.  Every time I was impressed by the quality of the services.  The service is always proper, polite and warm.  Somehow they have a way of maneuvering in that small space efficiently and don't make it seem too busy.  And to me, more importantly is that they don't try hard to rush you out.  On a busy night they may drop a hint or two, but you won't ever feel that pressure.  That makes my dining experience relaxing and I can really enjoy the food.  

This past Saturday when I went, I noticed that the menu has changed a little. The mussel is now an entree.  I didn't order it, but I did ask the waiter about it. He told me it has only the basic ingredients - garlic, wine, a little bit of salt - the most simple and dependable recipe.  I would recommend that if you are in the mood for basic and classic French cuisine.  I had the seafood "basquaise", which is decent but not exciting.  For desert, we had the Chocolate truffle.  That impressed me. It was freshly-made chocolate!  I strongly recommend it.
author: Xiaobei F.

description:
fringale is a breath of fresh air,from it's 5 star roots.......................
the cutting edge,casualness of a real bistro current feel,
remains the joy of Jean marie and his fabulous chef Thiery,they provide our friends endless joy!!
author: dave g.

description: Cozy, laid back ambiance. The service is relaxed - the waiters didn't seem to hurry anyone along. The prices are totally reasonable - especially considering that this is a French place in San Francisco. The PEI Mussels are great, as is the chicken with fingerling potatoes.
author: Jen L.

description: This is my second-favorite French restaurant in the City (first is La Folie) because it is always quiet enough to have a conversation among 6 people around a table and the food is very good and the service attentive but not bothersome.  This week, after some renovation, the decor is pleasant, very simple.  The wine list is not as good as it used to be, but OK and reasonably priced.  The Confit de canard and Coq au vin main dishes were really excellent, as good as they come.  The Onion tarte and mussels appetizers were also outstanding.  More than alomsot any other restaurant, this leaves us feeling as if we were in France.
author: Michael S.

description: If you are all about eating rich, calorie dense food that will make you fat and disgusting like 60% of our American popluation,  and everyone in this city,  than I reccomend this eatery.  My sister dragged me here for my birthday because one of the waitors was so "cute" and so "french"  and he was going to "hook us up" .  I didn't like the food, and then I had to shell out 300 bucks to pay the bill.  Hooked up?  No, not at all actually.  The people that own this place should know that their sleazy waitors are lying to cute girls to get them to eat here....which in turns results in the writing of negative reviews!  growl!!!
author: Hm M.

description: I committed a sin, I ate foie gras....but I wouldn't take it back, it was soo good!  I promise I won't do it again though, poor ducks.  I committed another sin, I ate the chocolate bread pudding...that was so RICH, yum.  Overall, I had a great time dining at Fringale...it's a cozy, unpretentious place that was perfect for good conversation and good food.
author: Debbie Y.

description: My supervisor took me here for lunch on my birthday and I had no clue what to expect. The menu wasn't all that big, but they had a variety of choices. I ended up ordering the tuna burger with the pomme frites. Everything about it was delicious. The tuna itself was moist, not dry at all. The pomme frites (fries) were crispy and fresh. For dessert I had some sort of hazelnut mousse and that was topped my meal off. It was not too sweet and I finished every last bit of it. I want to come back here again soon. I mean come on, the food is yummy and the service was great. The only problem is the parking, but I give them 5 stars for being so fabulous.
author: Anne Y.

description: I'm lucky enough to work a block away from Fringale, so I visited for lunch.  Had a really lovely nicoise salad and my companion had the halibut - both were served super fast and were absolutely excellent.  I just LOVED our waitress, very sweet with a fantastic accent.  The best part though was the chocolate banana bread pudding - oh my god!  Make sure you save enough room for this!  Can't wait to go back for dinner.
author: kerry l.

description: As wonderful as it has been over the last eight years I've visited.  Very french, from the food to the staff, and very tasty.  The tightness of the space gives it a great atmosphere.  This is the place that taught me to like chicken after too many years of bland chicken breasts.  I still make their mussel recipe.  Pricing is very reasonable for the quality, and the location means you park and get in most nights without a reservation (still, do make one).
author: Trent W.

description: I found Fringale on Yelp when I was choosing a restaurant for my birthday dinner.  This place is a real find!  We had a lovely dinner and the food was really great.  I had the duck confit - meltingly tender, and the skin was crisped nicely.  Came with delicious lentils, tangy and flavorful.  My brother's organic chicken was the best I've ever had, tender and super crispy skin!  The steak and veal shank were great too.  The only bad dish in the bunch was my sister's rigatoni.  I don't expect fab pasta at a french restaurant, but we expected more since the app ravioli was really perfect.  Anyway, nice cheese plate and charcuterie for starters, although these did not go too far with 6 people.  Each would feed 3-4 as apps.  skipped dessert as birthday cake was waiting nearby.  oh and did i mention the wine??  yummy Saint Emillion.  Wine markup was pretty reasonable.  Wait staff was attentive, and the extra nice touch was bringing the bottle and doing a taste check for a white wine by the glass for my friend.  Great experience.  Would even go so far as to give it 4.5 stars.
author: Teresa S.

description:
Excellent place for dates, especially as the waiter didn't mind us snuggling next to each other on the bench seat rather than sitting opposite.

Excellent duck confit, amazing wine list, lovely staff.

A SOMA special.
author: Alex G.

description: I came here for dine about town and ordered the mussels with pomme frites and a salmon tartare. I still think their mussels are some of the best I've had in the SF. I also like the ambiance and the general setting of the restaurant. I've only been here once and it was a while back, but I plan on coming back soon!
author: ting b.

description: Excellent!! amazing food and great service. the staff was very knowledgeable and attentive. we started with the dungeness crab napoleon which can be shared by two. I had the rack of lamb which was paired by an amazing side of melt in your mouth potato gratin. My date had the duck confit which was delicious as well. pricey, but worth it. definitely an older crowd. people go here for the food. Bravo!
author: Dana M.

description: Fringale is a fantastic place to dine for French food. It has good ambience, great service, and some of the best food we've ever had. Each time we've gone we have thoroughly enjoyed ourselves
author: JC M.

description: We came here for Dine about Town. The waiter was spot-on with his wine recommendation, and we had a great meal and great service. It's a small cheerily lit place. It was an interesting mix of romantic/family/business groups. I had the crab and julienne vegetable ravioli in lobster bisque, sole with risotto for an entree, and hazelnut almond mousse cake for dessert. The ravioli was light and I ended up adding a little salt. The lobster bisque was more like gravy, and I could only taste lobster when I tried it alone. It didn't add too much to the ravioli. The crab and julienne carrots were delicious, however. The sole was lightly pan fried, and the risotto was amazing. It was in some sort of lemon scented butter sauce, and I could have eaten it all night. The almond hazelnut mousse cake was heavenly, but I am not hard to please when it comes to all things hazelnut. My date had a plate of cured meats to start, the coq au vin, and a chocolate ganache cake with vanilla bean ice cream. The wine reduction on the Coq au Vin was flavorful and rich, but the chicken was a little dry. The waiter was a little snooty, and even when my date correctly identified his accent as Quebecois, he wouldn't be our friend. I assumed that the waiter would be excited to have a French speaking customer, but that is because I am from a small town where people still get excited about foreigners and accents, but in SF it's really no big deal. He also constantly tried to steal our wine menu no matter how many times we asked him to leave it. It almost stopped us from ordering wine with dessert, but we persisted.
author: Merrilee T.

description:
I came here tonight for DAT but was a bit disappointed with their menu for it.  I didn't see anything I liked on it.  The main entree selection for DAT was between petrale sole, osso bucco, or fettuccine so I ended up just ordering from their normal menu.  I started with the foie gras and ordered the PEI mussels as my entree.  I asked the waiter if came with anything.  He suggested that I order it with...what I thought at the time he said was a side of rice...but when arrived, he actually said "a side of fries".  I guess I should have known better that a french restaurant wouldn't be serving rice.  How fobby am I?  Anyway, the foie gras was huge - like a giant slice of pate.  I almost confused it for pate when it arrived.  It came with 6 pieces of toasted brioche.  I enjoyed it.  The mussels were extremely garlicky and vinegary.  If you like that that combination, go for the mussels though heed warning that you'll probably be hungry again in a few hours. BF ordered the sauteed prawn pastis and the ribeye steak.  The prawns were excellent.  Whatever sauce they use is very good.  Ribeye was nothing spectacular.  

Overall I had a pretty good meal but was sorely disappointed by the service.  Maybe it was because we came on a Friday night or maybe it was because our waiter seemed like a novice but I felt like we were not tended to enough.  I'm not some attention whore who needs it all the time but the waiter didn't even check on us once.  We had to cue him when we wanted to order, when we needed our plates removed, and even when our beverage glasses were empty.  I understand it was a busy night but a quick "is everything all right" would have been nice.  I observed him for a while and noticed that he didn't do it with any of the other tables either.  Maybe he just lacks multi-table skills.  Anyway, it's questionable whether I'd return.
author: Jess C.

description:
I went here the other day for Dine about town and the place was super crowded which is usually a good sign right? I decided to go off the DAT menu because I wanted the lamb and an appetizer (beef carpaccio) with a diet coke. The soda they gave me was gross and the waiter said that there was something wrong with the sodas so he offered a lemonade instead. I didn't really want a lemonade but eh, why not. I was a bit surprised that he charged me for the lemonade on the check though.

The food was great. The only knock is that the lamb was really small. Wasn't really that filling but it was still great. Overall, it was a good spot but not necessarily somewhere I'd go on a regular basis.
author: Michael P.

description: We came in for a late lunch and we couldn't have been more graciously received. The service was attentive without being intrusive and the food -- AMAZING!!  The frise salad and the roast chilcken were out of this world and when I tasted my friends steak I thought it would melt in my mouth. I will definitely make this a return stop the next time I visit San Francisco!
author: Brian S.

description: I had a wonderful experience at Fringale.  I made a reservation for 2 people at 9 pm.  However, I got stuck at work so I changed the reservation online to 9:30 pm.  This place was actually closed by 9 pm on Monday but the owner was nice enough to call me and made an exception for me.  So my date and I went there around 9:20 pm and the owner came to our table to greet us and even apologized.  The customer service was top-notch.  We ordered whatever the waiter recommended and everything came out to be delicious.  Highly recommended this place for dates and special occasions!
author: Charming Prince W.

description: Good, a little old fashioned, and the decor is still mired in mid 90's bistro. The food however, is classic. It's a good place to take one's less adventurous parents.
author: Stellah D.

description:
I recently had dinner with a friend of mine here - it's so different this time since the other time was a date dinner...  Its amazing how perceptions  change- to reflect the feelings you have (be it amorous or amicable)- now the soft lighting did not make any difference and the-void windows- bothered me :-(  I dont know why but- I just love to see long drapes or curtains...I guess its the Martha in me ;-)  ANYWAY- not to be distracted...
The menu is even more splendid- echoing the basque influence in some of the dishes...among these was the Duck Confit with Lentils and Roasted Lamb shanks in broth with root vegetables.  I tasted my friend's confit- it was fried to the crispiness with the preserved flavor of the meat- I didnt care for the lentils-  but to be expected in the winter meals. I loved the lamb shanks- in its au jus nature-unadulterated and simple - this light even broth graciously  flavored the sauteed root vegetables. This meal was also complimented with their house Pinot noir... We also shared a salad and pomme frites ...
For dessert- we shared the flourless chocolate cake, warm- smooth and decadently rich. 
This is a definite crowd pleaser- so if you have the urge for french- make this one of the destination!
author: Arissa C.

description: I've read alot of good reviews from other sources about Fringale.  Unfortunately there are many mixed opionions from people yelping.  I do agree that it was nothing spectacular.  However,  the best thing about Fringale is the price.  For some decent french cuisine everything was under $20.  The restuarant is on a smaller scale so make sure you make a reservation.  The day I ended up going was Bastille day so they had a prefix menu as an option.  But I would stick to the regular menu.
author: Fatty A.

description: I've eaten here twice and enjoyed one meal more than the other.  I liked the ribeye with frites & calamari appetizer. I can't remember what I had during the lackluster meal.  The wines are decent (skip the dessert wines) and the prices aren't too bad.  Tables are quite cramped however and the service is hit or miss.
author: Derrick V.

description: I'm a big fan of Gerald Hirogoyen's and absolutely love his Piperade.  I have not made it to Bocadillo's yet but have been to Fringale, on and off, over the past 10 years.  I strongly believe that its been better.  I was there last week with some friends.  While the food is good, it does not have the same sparkle it used to.  The squid with chorizo is still excellent, but the foie torchon was served with burnt brioche (where is Thomas Keller when you need him?) and my friend's Seafood Basquaise had some sort of fish that was very tough and overcooked.  I had a panko/ almond crusted halibut filet that was tasty enough, but seemed to have been waiting a while as it was only lukewarm when it made it to our table.
author: Claudine C.

description:
People are so generous with their stars for this place!  I really think this is a 2.5, but closer to a 3 than a 2, so I'll bump them up.
I'm mostly left with a bad taste for the service.  Chez Mama's service is rude French, but in a funny, charming, none offensive way.  Fringale is the exact opposite.  I'm sick of getting bad service for looking young.  My friends and I are all nearing 30, we are not that young, but we were obviously the youngest people in the place.  They obviously cater to older clientele.  First it was ordering tap water, not bottled, or wine or a cocktail, how dare we!  Then when it came time for me to order I asked for one of the first courses and a side as my meal.  I asked, is that ok?  Hello, of course it's ok why did I even ask?  I just knew he was not going to be happy with my selection.  Well, the waiter gave me such attitude and made a phhhrummpph noise down the back of my neck.  How dare I not order both a starter and a main course!  Hello, both of them together equaled the price of many of the main courses, chill out!
The food was decent.  The calamari was non breaded in a sauce with jalapenos and chorizo.  Very tasty, minus the bodies, I only like the rings.  I also had the pomme frites.  Horrible!  They were soggy and cold.  They came with no dipping sauce, ketchup, nothing.  I never saw the waiter after, so I couldn't ask for some.  I would have rather had fries from McDonalds.  We had the almond mousse cake for dessert.  It had that greasy on the roof of your mouth consistency and tasted like cookie dough.  Not very pleasant.  Everyone else seemed to like their food fine.  The salads were good, and big portions.  Loved the huge basket of bread.  The drinks were very pricey at $10 each, yikes! but at least they were strong.
Would not waste my time or money coming back, so many other great places in the city.
I'm sure us using the Cosmo Card made him hate us even more.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Consider this a 4.5 star review.

We went to Fringale yesterday for the Dine About Town lunch, and were definitely impressed.

I got the pate appetizer, and my husband got the shrimp - both were quite good, and he was particularly impressed by the sauce.  He got the sole main and again, loved the sauce. I had the coq au vin, which needed a bit more sauce as the egg noodles really soaked up the flavor and left things a bit bland; the pickled pearl onions on top were fantastic.  The creme brulee was fine, but his hazelnut and roasted almond mousse cake was WONDERFUL.  I would go back to Fringale just to eat the hazelnut cake.

The little space is snug, but I enjoyed the feel - it's perfect for a French bistro, and getting the interesting bits of your neighbor's conversation is a plus. ;)

While the prices are a bit high for Fringale to become a regular on my list, it's definitely great food and worth it for a nice lunch/dinner out.
author: Christy C.

description: Delicious...went for Dine About Town...had the duck confit, but what really got me was the sauteed prawns in pastis with sun dried tomatoes.  I seriously was cleaning the plate with bread to capture as much as I could of that sweet sauce.  To the point that it might have been embarrassing for my companion...if he wasn't doing the same thing.
author: Michelle P.

description: Place was yummy!  Kicking myself for not trying the confit.  Atmosphere and service were top notch, menu reasonably priced, I'd definitely go back!
author: Larissa D.

description:
and 1/2.

frenchy people serving frency food. a very sweet waiter and a very packed space....the crowd is older and even though the space is small, conversation is easy. great for after a show at limn.
author: heather m.

description: Sit at the bar with a buddy while singing sorrows about a girl, and Melanie will talk you to recovery.
author: Lane K.

description: Fringale was a nice way to end my brief DAT run.  Each course was enjoyable, the ambiance was friendly and quaint  (it IS small and the tables are tight, but I thought it kind of charming), service was fine, and no problems with our reservation/seating time.  Would probably give this place 3.5 stars, but I give an extra 1/2 star for the nice waiter who said (in his French accent) - are you ready to order?  After nodding yes to him, he said "Tell me."  Okay, somehow it was cute when he said it!
author: Joyce L.

description: Been here only for lunch. It's always spectacular and the service is great. My faves are any version of the seafood, duck and chicken, all well paired with their delicious wine list. Perfect for DAT.
author: Colleen B.

description: I've heard a lot of good stuff about this place, so I was expecting a lot.  We had the crab meat stuffed in a spanish chile and that was really good.  My entree was the Hawaiian Mongchong and that was just ok.  It was not bad, but it wasn't WOW good.  The best thing about this place was the dessert!! We tried the flourless chocolate cake and the banana bread.  These deserve the WOW's from me.  They were absolutely delicious!  The ambiance is not bad.  It's really kind of romantic and all, but I think it is really over rated.
author: AhLin C.

description: I was impressed by this place. The waiter was great, the food was great, the bread and wine were quick and ample and the pace of the meal was perfect. I will be headed back to this place to sample a few more dishes and this review might change to five stars.
author: M L.

description: Great for fellow Francophiles (and there were several French patrons as well).  Further,  the service is attentive and pleasant, the food enjoyable and tasty.  The wine list is well-spectrum'd.  And, per the unanimous consensus at our table, the hostess/barmaid is hot.
author: Kimberly Q.

description: Ate here for Dine About Town and it was good, but I don't think I'd go back...simply because there are so many other places in the city to try! I started off with the pate which was disappointing - it looked more like spam (which I actually like) when I was expecting something a bit more creamy. I tried my friends' oysters and they were pretty good. I'm not a fan, but I think the sauce made that dish. Main course was steak with pommes frites. The steak was cooked well but it was a tiny portion. The fries were the highlight because they were thin and crisp - just the way I like it! Dessert was scrumptious. I had a chocolate cake that was decadent, while my friend had a hazelnut dessert which felt like it had granules of sugar in each bite. Overall a good meal, but it didn't impress me enough to return.
author: Nina R.

description: Fringale is a wonderful dining experience. I took my husband there for his birthday this year with a group of 6 total. I made the reservation on opentable and even managed to book a 1000 point dining time! Sweet! Many of us had the ribeye steak, which was soooo yummy. I had the dungeness crab as an appetizer and sipped on a mojito. Both of which were deelish! Total bill  including the 18% gratuity which was already factored in came to $75 per person. I love this place, why have I not been here before???
author: Joyce L.

description: Tried this place for Dine about Town.  I had the carpaccio, sole an the apple tart.  I also got a small taste of the calmari, oso bocco, and mousse cake.  My favorite was the sole.  It was buttery, light and flaky.  The mousse cake was very good as well.  This is a pretty small restaurant with a small wine list but the waiter gave a great recommendation on a zinfindel.
author: Ginny M.

description:
We went to Fringale's for a birthday party on Saturday night.  It was a full house. I really wanted to like this place but....   Started out with bottle of wine and appetizers.   We tried the  charcuterie, carpacio, calamari, and escargo. Nothing was really spectacular.  I would skip them.    

Then for the entree's we had  the Bacon wrapped Pork tenderloin. The waiter said it would be cooked medium ( a little pink)  it was extremely dry.  The duck confit was dry.  The rack of lamb was cooked perfect but a little tasteless.  But the seafood basquaise and the special of the day  the  Monk fish  were excellent.  

The waiter ask if we wanted desert and we said no( we were thinking this whole meal was just average and the desserts would be no better. )

To be fair the waiter did ask us why we didn't eat the pork and we mentioned it was extremely dry and he said let's us know next time.  He did take it off the bill and gave us dessert just as we were about to leave.

ambiance and service very good,  food average (I guest you need to pick the right things).
author: daniel s.

description:
I went here on a sunday evening.  The place was not packed.  We went there for our anniversary and already have a reservation.  We were seated rite away.

The food was good.  We started with the calamari.  It was cooked with jalapeno and has a nice spicy kick of it.  For the main courses, tried the duck confit and the pork tenderloin.  The skin on the duck was amazing.  It's duck skin fried with pork lard, it has a nice crispiness on it.  The pork tenderloin also was nicely done.  

During the dinner, the server was not attentive.  We asked for extra bread and none was brought to our table.  Furthermore, there are a lot of insects in the restaurant.  Flies keep buzzing near our table.  Some small insects are also around.
author: Arswendo T.

description: I've been meaning to write this up for a bit. Awesome, awesome experience here. Had a party of 9 lined up for a reservation and asked them to place us where it wouldn't be too loud. Upon arriving they were all setup and ready to go. Service and food were spot on and oh so good. The prices were extremely reasonable for the quality of food and service. Everyone left impressed and I was the hero since I set-up the reservation :)
author: Andy S.

description: I can't figure out why this place has a better reputation than Bizou down the block.  The food is pretty good, the atmosphere is nice, if a bit cramped, but they seem to think a bit more of themselves than is really warranted.
author: J P.

description: I found this place at open table and tried it because it participated in DineAboutTown and i would never decline a rib eye with an appetizer and dessert for 29.95.  Well it was amazing.  I'm so glad i went there with friends so we had different appetizers and desserts to try.  This please is really good!
author: May A.

description: I thoroughly enjoyed my dining experience here.  Calamari appetizers were uber tasty.  I recommend the lamb shanks, sea bass and apple fritters.  Again, all very tasty.  We had a bit of a long wait for our seats so the staff gave us comp appetizers.  Great service and quaint ambience.
author: jhon k.

description: We came here for lunch and it was delicious. The restaurant was a lot smaller than we anticipated. It's like a cute little French bistro. We had butter lettuce salad with sweet anchovies, butternut squash soup, salmon, lamb, the chocolate dessert, and the almond hazelnut mousse all from the DAT menu. Then we had the calamari with jalepenos and chorizo as an appetizer. My husband got the steak off of the regular menu. That steak was delicious and perfectly cooked. The almond hazelnut mousse cake was very decadent. The salmon was moist and flaky. Everything was tasty. The service could have been a bit faster since it was lunch. The meal took over an hour and 30 minutes, which is a bit long for my lunch break.
author: Diana S.

description: Super lunch place. Sunlight filled, great service. Their tuna burgers are so yummy that my colleagues get cravings for it in groups and we go en masse to Fringale. If you're feeling a little more sinful, order the fries instead of the side salad with the burger. Drink a glass of wine if you're there on a Friday lunch. MMM
author: joann p.

description: I think we might have come here a bit too early (6:30 on a Weds night) and the restaurant was almost full but the crowd was definitely "early bird".  As the night went on the crowd got more to our age (30's) though.  The food was ok, I was really excited about their menu but nothing really stood out with regards to flavor.  We had the osso buco and pork loin and the frisee salad to start, and while they were all good, it just tasted like food I could make at home.  Also our waiter was kind of gruff, not very friendly but I guess you should expect that at a french restaurant!
author: sasha y.

description: Fringale is really good! Honestly, I can't think of a single thing to complain about! We were able to walk in and get a table for two on a quiet Sunday evening. The bread was great, the butter at just the right consistency, the wine excellent. Of the food my favorite was the calamari, really tasty! i had the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin which was also very good and perfectly cooked. While I can't say it really stood out for any reason, there weren't any flaws either. Fringale is definitely a good choice for a nice dinner in SOMA.
author: Will A.

description: The few times that I've been to Fringale, it's been with clients for work and only at lunch.  I'd love to dine here in the evening but it always seems to be filled with suits at that hour.  Meh, not really my type of French bistro especially after a long day at work.  But the food is very good and the service is great.  You can't go wrong with their meats or the soups.
author: Kimmie N.

description:
From beginning to end, my husband and I were pleased with our evening out at Fringale last week. It is a tiny, but very cozy French Bistro that gives a welcoming feeling upon entering. We were warmly greeted by the owner who made us feel like we were family. 

My husband loved his steak, cooked to perfection and my roasted rack of lamb could not have been more tender. It was accompanied by a wonderful potato gratin that was so creamy and had a beautiful light brown crust which added a nice texture and flavour.  

Service was very friendly and quick and I look forward to the next time I dine at this charming little French bistro.
author: Jewel R.

description: Another cute little French place.  I wish I remember everything I had here.  That's the problem when you don't yelp your restaurants right away.  I chose the special tasting menu during the Open Table "Appetite Stimulus Plan".   I had some sort of crab appetizer that was absolutely delicious.  My main course was braised beef (if I remember correctly), which was also very good.  The meat was very tender and delicious.  I wasn't too trilled with the veggies /starch that it sat on.  My friend had the duck confit... also very good.  For dessert, we had the creme brulee.  That was probably the low light of the meal.  The caramelized sugar just tasted burnt and it was a little ticker then how I normally like it.  Overall, the food was excellent and the service was wonderful too.
author: Sam C.

description:
4.5 stars for me.  Just don't have the half star option here.  Great French food with multiple layers of flavor.  Very friendly staff.  Great service.  Great atmosphere.  Quaint and charming little place.  Had our one year anniversary there and they couldn't have treated us better.  We got the window seat at what I considered the best tabel in the place. The desert was especially memorable: Warm Chocolate Gourmand flourless chocolate cake served with a vanilla ice
cream & red fruit compote.   For dinner: the fettucine pasta with wild mushrooms, baby carrots, petit pois & parmesan cheese and Poached Alaska halibut served with piperade, artichoke, olive & pepper d'espelette.
author: A L.

description: We had our New Years Eve '08/'09 dinner here and it was perfect in every respect.  Filet Mignon with truffles that melted in your mouth, perfect desserts, perfect bread, friendly staff, yadda yadda yadda.  It's pretty straightforward, not too pretentious, and really good at what it does.  I'll come here again if I'm looking for a nice meal to take my folks to or something similar.
author: Steve G.

description: Had an excellent meal here on Wed night. I would say 4.5 stars. I had the pumpkin ravioli to start, which was fair. Then the osso bucco which was amazing and the lemon tarte for dessert- yum. Also, shared an amazing bottle of wine with my bf. Service was great, very friendly, helpful, and at the perfect pace. Great for a date or special occasion.
author: Art A.

description:
Very flavorful french/Basque inspired food at a good price point (most entrees under $20). Atmosphere is a little on the granny/grandpa side, but the food is tasty, especially the grilled calamari and the grilled prawn starters. My boyfriend had the steak and frites and loved it! The banana chocolate bread pudding is very yummy. The bread is okay, but I noticed it was outsourced Acme bread and not in-house fresh baked.

2/07 Update---
Just made my fourth return visit and my fiancee and I ate every bite of our delicious crispy skinned salmon and pork loin entrees. The sauteed prawns appetizer is worth an hour on the elliptical machine. Absolutely fabulous food establishment. Service is VERY spotty, but as expected at most French restaurants. One of my top three favorite restaurants in the City (The House and Quince are my other two favorites).
author: Mama L.

description:
I'm wanting to give Fringale a 5 star rating but...5 stars to me exemplifies ULTIMATE service and quality.  Service was definitely 4 stars and the food...well, including tonite it's been pretty consistent and I love the fact that this is a "neighborhood" french restaurant b/c it's literally 3 blocks from my place and it serves up good food consistently.  

Tonite I started w/ my staple Fringale Frisee salad w/ warm bacon dressing and bits, poached egg, and toasted levain (toast!)...a great winter salad with enough tangy/tartness from the dressing to bridge over to a spring salad starter.  For wine pairing I'd recommend a full-bodied sauvignon blanc or a medium body chardonnay w/ good acidity to carry out the flavors.  My entree was a bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin with braised savoy cabbage and carmelized onion sauce.  The pork was nice and tender and juicy. The carmelized onion sauce and savoy cabbage offset the saltiness of the bacon nicely.  The wine I'd recommend would be a burgundy or a young pinot noir with evolving fruit and a bit of acidity to complement the the sauce of the pork.  Dessert was "Pain Predu au Chocolat et Bananes" (bread pudding w/ chocolate and bananas).  Usually if the dessert menu has bread pudding or some type to puff pastry like a galette, I need not look further.  As far as my scale of bread pudding goes, this one gets a 3.5.  I like that fact that it was bitter-sweet chocolate and the pudding was moist and somewhat chewy.  However, it didn't "wow" me and I barely tasted the bananas.

As far as logistics like parking...you can park at the Wells Fargo parking lot across the street if there's available space, otherwise street parking which can be a lil challenging.  The wine list isn't very extensive but offers interesting options.  They don't have a sommelier so your recommendations will come from your server, which can be hit or miss.

Fringale definitely deserves 4.5 stars.  In order to get that half point nudge up, they need to expand their wine list, have a lil more attentive service, and offer up some "wow" entrees.
author: Rick P.

description:
This place is really adorable and very good, brownie points for all the waiters speaking French.  
Fish with brussel sprouts & mushrooms--excellent
seafood basqaise--excellent
prosciutto/apple/arugula salad--could have used more prosciutto, but still very good.  

I had a chocolate bread pudding dessert to finish, which was heavenly too--in fact writing about it is giving me the munchies.

Fyi, if you come here, expect the service to be...."traditional."  Men shall be seated on the outside, women on the inside, and the check shall be very squarely placed in front of the former.
author: Lisa C.

description: Informal and cheerful setting.  Attentive service.  Wonderful food.  Have gone for years, and it is at its best now.  My favorites include the frisee salad with poached egg, duck confit, black cod, hazelnut cake, gateau  Basque.  Nice wine list.  Easy parking in the area.  An excellent value.
author: Peter J.

description:
My family and I went here for Christmas Eve dinner - it was crowded and I could see why.  Everything I ordered was delish and everything everyone else ordered that I tasted was delish. Waiters were helpful and polite and even with the busy crowd, service was on top of things. I had the Dungeness crab Napoleon, avocado, tomato confit, crème fraiche  which was great, some places put a tiny layer of crab. They had crab on the bottom, avocado layer, more crab and tomatos..perfect amount of each. My husband had the frisse salad - the first time we've seen one with all frisse but the dressing and bacon hid the bitter taste. My entree was the Seafood basquaise in a spicy roasted red pepper & tomato sauce  which was not too tomatoey or soup. nice mix of seafood, usually places are skimpy with the shellfish and put the cheaper fish in but they didn't here!  I also had the Spinach with Roquefort which was just alittle too strong for me but it was exactly what they said it was.  My dad's duck was cooked perfectly.  Dessert was the only slight dissapointment - the Pain perdu au chocolat et bananes wasn't as good as expected but the Glace vanille sauce chocolat 
House made vanilla ice cream topped with hot chocolate sauce and whipped cream more than made up for it.  the special which was a Christmas log was good, nothing spectacular. I'd go back for the ice cream alone.  Overall - I'd go back to try everything that we didn't try this visit.
author: natalie q.

description: What a treat! Lovely ambiance in a surprising location; inviting and professional staff to help make the whole experience a pleasure; and then the food. Wow!  We had the rack-of-lamb, superb in it's simplicity with potatoes gratin and haricots verts done to perfection. Also the poached cod with olive tapenade and piperade.  Oh yes, and room for chocolate Gourmand with vanilla ice cream and an Armagnac.  Can't wait to return to The City to try more of the menu.
author: Tom M.

description: This place never lets me down! My wife and i have been going here for over ten years and although the chefs/owner has changed a few times it's always exactly what I want every time.....French comfort food! My perfect meal is a frisee salad, rib-eye with pomme frites, hazelnut mousse cake.
author: Jeremiah A.

description: Fringale is a great dining experience.  First of all, the menu is a great combination of inventive and traditional dishes.  They have a beautiful steak pomme frittes that is always on the menu, but then they're always doing INCREDIBLE things with mushrooms.  I once had a trumpet mushroom and chesnut dish that was just so unusual and delicious at the same time.  It's not too expensive either and a great place for a date.  It's nice and intimate but not uncomfortable.
author: Yvonne Y.

description: Oooo tres sexy lighting and yummy for a glass of wine, appetizers and moving on to other entertainment.
author: miriam b.

description: This is a nice, cozy little spot in SOMA.  The French waiters are lovely, and make fantastic recommendations, so listen up.  I am a sucker for Foie Gras, so naturally I ordered the Foie Gras Terrine and was not disappointed in the least.  D-lish!  The rack of lamb is juicy and wonderfully paired with a nice  potato gratin (this side was a bit drier than I like my potato gratin, but still quite good).  Bravo to the gooey chocolate cake as well.  I have had (just a rough guess) hundreds of warm little chocolate cakes and the one at Fringale does the trick.  Fantastic date place.  My qualm is having to wait for a table when you already have a reservation--to me, that is not great service.  We had to wait 10 minutes extra for a table.
author: Lily C.

description: We absolutely love this little cozy French bistro!!  We've been here about 5 times and have never been disappointed.  Definetly make reservation but if you arrive early, they have a small bar with daily wine specials to accommodate you.  The waitstaff is awesome!  My wife thinks the sauteed calamari appetizer that comes with chorizo sausage and jalapenos is fantastic.  The steak with pomme frites is reasonably priced and they have a pretty extensive wine list for a small restaurant.  We have found that substitutions to each menu item are easily accommodated.  Just beware that the place is small so the tables are all pretty close together so your conversation is inevitably going to spill over into the one next to you.  So, you might want to save the discussion about the new Jenna Jameson video for another time.  $140 for two with drinks.
author: Luke L.

description: Service was really good and the food was not bad. I went for the Dine About Town special last evening. The rib eye was just OK (maybe I've been eating at too many good steakhouses lately?), but I thought the rest of it was good. The chocolate gourmand dessert was fantastic. Looking over the menu, it looked relatively reasonable.
author: Jack C.

description: Whooops!  Why did I never Yelp! this place?  It has been awhile since I was here, but I must say it was outstanding!  The duck confit was certainly the best I have tasted, like..ever.  Friendly cozy staff, helpful in choosing wine, nice atmosphere.  This reminds me that I really must go back.
author: Jason M.

description:
best french food in town .
not only good food but great service and wine 
perfect for a date .
ask for "le labrador" for your waiter

merci fringale team
author: germain m.

description: Celebrated A's birthday here and we had a wonderful time.  Food was very good, waiters were all attentive and knowlegeable.  Couldn't ask for more.  I'd go back in a heartbeat.
author: Tess G.

description: This was place was good.  A little 'cozy' - it's not a place to bring a large group of people but the food is good.  I had the pork and it was OK but I tried my friend's lamb dish and it was yum to the 'oh'!!  melted like butter in my mouth.  I'd go again.
author: Judy T.

description: We tried out Fringale for our anniversary and had a pretty good experience.  The wait staff was good, not great, but the food was really tasty.  We had the duck and the steak and both were prepared well and very yummy.  For dessert we had the chocolate cake with banana and coconut sorbet.  Also, tasty.  I would say that everything was pretty rich as you might expect from a French place but the servings were a good size and we left satisfied and would go back again.  Our total bill including tip was just over $70 for the two entrees, dessert, and a lemonade.
author: Jason W.

description: Love this place. I got here for lunch at least once a month for work and their food is always great. The service is wonderful and the atmosphere is perfect for a small French restaurant in SF. Never been for dinner, but I'm sure they do well in that department too!
author: Ani N.

description: I had the seafood and shellfish basquaise in a red pepper sauce. You get a taste of everything from black cod, salmon, tuna, prawns, and mussels in a tasty sauce that resembles a bouillabaise. You must not skip on dessert since they do serve fine sweets. We had the pain perdu and the coffee armaranac parfait. The pain perdu is good enough to try again. The service was excellent as well. the ambience and gourmet basque food makes this quite an experience to go out and try.
author: Jennifer C.

description: This is one of the favourite places. It has been consistently good with excellent service and very reasonably prices menu. Interior is simple but classy enough for a nice romantic dinner.
author: Anna P.

description: We were a party of ten or twelve and sat in long table at the kitchen door. Lunchtime.  Were rushed to order as we were all in "reunion" mode and chatting.  Everyone liked their food. Nothing special.  I had a pasta with light olive oil sauce which was OK.  I guess I"d go back if I had to but nothing about the place says "return".
author: William G.

description:
Came here for DAT.  I really liked how they had a good selection for their DAT menu and I didn't feel like I had only one choice.  The music that was playing that evening reminded me of a video game... you know the song that plays when Mario reaches the castle to fight King Bowser.  It was quite distracting.  My server was semi-attentive and not very personable, but plates came out and were cleared at a good pace.
I ordered the mussels in wine sauce which was fine, but nothing extraordinary.  It was a good size portion and  think I would have liked it more if it didn't smell like sticky tofu.  My main course was roasted chicken breast with a frisee salad.  The chicken was moist on the inside, golden on the outside and had a nice flavor.  I really liked crispness of the frisee salad and it complemented the dish nicely.  I can't say it was too innovative because it was a chicken dish and you can only do so much.  
Overall it was a nice place, but nothing really special.  The restaurant is suppose to be French, but I really couldn't tell from the dishes my friend and I had ordered.  I think you might be able to say it was American or Californian... it really doesn't matter what genre you call it because Frigale wasn't that impressive to note.  Nice but really not that memorable
author: Kirstie R.
